#### *Comment*

<span id="page-121-4"></span><span id="page-121-3"></span><span id="page-121-2"></span>8:1 The theme of numerical abundance with the Hebrew word *rabab* is continued from the previous chapter (cf. Section Overview of 7:1–26). Observing the covenant will give Israel the opportunity to "live and multiply"—cattle and flocks, silver and gold, everything they possess (v. 13). To observe the "whole commandment" expresses the demand for complete loyalty (cf. 6:1–3). Remembering God and obedience are not separate phenomena. To fail to keep the commandment is to forget God.

<span id="page-121-0"></span>8:2–5 These verses explain the concept of God's testing his people. Humans must have bread to live but are not capable of ensuring such a necessity. Therefore, it is not possible to live on bread alone. Deprivation of food in the wilderness was an opportunity for Israel to learn that they did not live by bread alone. Such a test revealed their actual attitude of mind. Did they know that God is able to guarantee the endurance of life when all human efforts fail? Such trust is essential to life. Mortals live by that which God decrees. The wilderness experience establishes the whole premise that power and wealth are not reliable. Such knowledge is essential to those about to enter a land of riches. The wilderness was a school house; there their clothes did not wear out nor their feet swell during forty years of journeys. This provision was the verdict of God.

Manna is sometimes explained as an edible honeydew (insect residue) produced in parts of the Sinai in June and July from the secretions of scale insects on tamarisk trees that crystalize and fall to the ground. The term *man* is used in Arabic for honeydew and some insects that produce it. If this is the food referenced in the narrative, it does not diminish the miraculous nature of the provision that enabled Israel to survive.

<span id="page-122-6"></span><span id="page-122-5"></span><span id="page-122-0"></span>8:6–10 The land Israel is about to enter is described in metaphors accentuating its contrast with the wilderness. This land flows with water; springs and deep fountains feed surging streams in the hills and on the broad open valleys. The term "valleys" describes vast land areas like that of Megiddo (2 Chron. 35:22; Zech. 12:11). Such land yields food in abundance of immense variety: wheat, barley, grapes, figs, pomegranates, olive oil, and honey (possibly the nectar of fruits). This is a stock list of items; Sennacherib has a similar description of the land (2 Kings 18:32). This is a land yielding metals of iron and copper for manufacturing tools, especially in the Transjordan, the Jordan Valley south of the Dead Sea, and the rift toward the Gulf of Aqaba. Lands of such wealth readily neglect the poor, the primary concern of God in covenant loyalty. It is more difficult to trust God amid such plenty, to bless him for the goodness he has provided.

<span id="page-122-4"></span><span id="page-122-1"></span>8:11–13 The people entering this land of riches are very capable. Their herds and flocks will proliferate, and their investments will increase exponentially. How can such people not become proud? They must remember Egypt and the wilderness.

<span id="page-122-3"></span><span id="page-122-2"></span>8:14–18 Egypt and the wilderness are described with metaphorical force equivalent to the wealth of the Promised Land. Egypt was a place of slavery, while the wilderness hid serpents with a bite that burned like fire and scorpions with the sting of a lead-tipped whip (1 Kings 12:11, 14). The multitudes of Israel lacked the most vital provisions of water and food and were thus utterly helpless. But by God's decree, water emerged from the flint rock and manna gathered on the ground. Such provision for life could not be explained. There is no greater test than utter dependence; it is the ultimate hardship. All this happened for the good of the people. When they think they are providing for themselves, they must remember the lesson of the wilderness: all strength and all wealth are the gift of God. Such gifts are received completely apart from merit. The gifts of life and prosperity are given because God cannot fail to keep the oath made with their fathers. The divine

decree was responsible for their coming into existence as a people and entering a land of riches.

<span id="page-123-4"></span>8:19–20 Wealth and prosperity, which are not gained by ability or merit of the people that possess them, cannot be retained by means of their power. Moses knew very well the lure of the Canaanite gods of materialism and the deception of Baal, the god who could supposedly be manipulated for prosperity. Wealth breeds a desire for wealth and duplicity that seeks to attain more wealth. Forgetting the life-giver will result in the destruction of Israel, just as with the Canaanites before them. Israel does not live by bread alone.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-123-5"></span><span id="page-123-1"></span>This passage is well known from the Gospels' account of the temptation of Jesus (e.g., Matt. 4:1–4). After Jesus fasts for forty days, the Devil tempts him to turn stones into bread. Jesus answers with Deuteronomy 8:3 to say that man does not live by bread alone. God tested Israel to show them their dependence upon him; they cannot in their own strength supply a fundamental need of life. They must live by obedience to the will of God. Jesus answers with a correct interpretation of Moses. God tests Jesus as he did Israel to show that Jesus will live by the divine will. Satan also uses the opportunity to tempt Jesus to respond in the way Israel did in the desert. They tested God by demanding he provide water (6:16) because they did not live in trust according to the divine will.

<span id="page-123-6"></span><span id="page-123-3"></span><span id="page-123-2"></span><span id="page-123-0"></span>It is extremely difficult to live faithfully with wealth. The king must not multiply silver and gold (17:17), for God will multiply the silver and gold of Israel (8:13). The problem with God's good gifts is that Israel will attribute them to themselves because of their pride and will forget the God who brought them out of Egypt (v. 14). A king might have the power to multiply wealth, but the only reason to do so would be pride and self-sufficiency. Thus there must be a prohibition against the king's seeking wealth willfully, for the very act is a betrayal of faith. Seeking wealth for the sake of wealth is to serve mammon and not God. Wealth gained is always a gift from God to be used for him, but this is not readily perceived. "It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God" (Matt. 19:24).

1Hebrew *cast metal*

#### *Section Overview: Not in Your Own Righteousness*

The fundamental reason Canaanite culture and the prosperity of the Promised Land are a danger to Israel is the Israelites' faulty self-assessment. They assume this bounty has come to them through their own merit. A new generation falsely thinks it is advanced and progressive, that the mistakes of the past will not be repeated. There are always perceived reasons to justify this assertion. Conquest of the great city-states of Canaan could readily lead Israel into false confidence. This circumstance is not different from the deliverance from Egypt, a nation even greater than any of the cities of Canaan. Moses goes back to Mount Sinai to show how quickly such victories become occasions of divine judgment because the fear of the Lord is forgotten.

<span id="page-125-5"></span><span id="page-125-4"></span><span id="page-125-3"></span><span id="page-125-1"></span>The golden calf at Mount Sinai is the outstanding example of rebelliousness. Following a warning to a "stubborn people" (Deut. 9:6), Moses commands them to remember how they "provoked the Lord" (v. 7). Moses then relates events of Exodus 32–34, both the breaking of the covenant (Deut. 9:7–24) and the grace of God in restoration and renewal (9:25–10:11). Exodus tells of Moses' seclusion on the mountain for forty days and nights when the Ten Words were first given (Ex. 24:18), then a second forty days and nights following the breaking of the covenant and the tablets of stone (Ex. 34:28). In Exodus, the account of the golden calf at Mount Sinai separates the instructions for the building of the tabernacle from their implementation. The literary structure suggests that the apostasy of the people interfered with the erection of the tent of meeting between God and his people.

<span id="page-125-2"></span><span id="page-125-0"></span>Moses' first absence of forty days while receiving the Ten Words stimulated the making of an image, described as an idol of Yahweh. This prompted the Lord to urge Moses to hurry down the mountain because this outrage was about to lead <span id="page-126-3"></span><span id="page-126-2"></span>to their destruction (Ex. 32:7–10). Before descending, Moses petitioned for mercy on behalf of Israel. His prayer to avert judgment was based on three arguments (vv. 11–13). First, God had redeemed this people in Egypt through a miraculous deliverance. Second, the Egyptians would say it was the purpose of Yahweh to destroy his people in the wilderness. Third, God had promised the land of Canaan to the patriarchs as an eternal inheritance. This prayer is not included in the narration of the events in Deuteronomy, but it seems to be referenced in Deuteronomy 9:18, where Moses speaks of being prostrate before the Lord "as before." Reference to an earlier prayer must be an allusion to the prayer in Exodus before Moses descended from the mountain. The account in Deuteronomy assumes that the story in Exodus is sufficiently known so that hearers would know which prayer is meant.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-126-12"></span><span id="page-126-10"></span><span id="page-126-9"></span><span id="page-126-8"></span>9:1–6 The final hortatory section opens with the initial command of the Shema (Deut. 6:4–5; 9:1). This summons is found five times, all in Deuteronomy and first at 5:1, where it introduces the Decalogue. It will be repeated in the instructions for war when Israel enters the land (20:3) and in the ceremonies marking entrance into the land (27:9). The final warning of the prologue to the instruction of this law begins with an echo of the Shema. Israel must love God as the one who has created them to be his people and is giving them the land.

<span id="page-126-13"></span><span id="page-126-7"></span><span id="page-126-6"></span><span id="page-126-5"></span><span id="page-126-4"></span><span id="page-126-1"></span><span id="page-126-0"></span>The God of Israel is "a consuming fire, a jealous God" (4:24). This must be interpreted as zeal through which God is impassioned to act on behalf of his people. The mighty inhabitants of Canaan, known as the "sons of the Anakim," will not be able to stand before Israel (cf. 1:28). Victory over such forces must not lead to Israel's thinking that she is more righteous than the wicked Canaanites now under judgment (v. 4). The danger is so eminent that the warning must be repeated: it is "not because of your righteousness" (v. 5). Moses also repeats the cause: "because of the wickedness of these nations." In these references the conquest of Canaan is presented in judicial terms. The conquest of Canaan is not a question of who is right and who is wrong; the Canaanites are indeed guilty and are being punished accordingly (cf. Gen. 15:16), but this does not imply Israel is innocent. The second reference recalls fully the reason for the conquest. It is a fulfillment of the promise to Abraham: "To your offspring I give this land, from the river of Egypt to the great river, the river Euphrates" (Gen. 15:18). Entrance into the land is an execution of

<span id="page-127-6"></span>the oath God made with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. All that can be said of Israel is that they are a stiff-necked people (Deut. 9:6). A zealous God acts on behalf of Israel, but he tolerates no rivals. He is also a consuming fire against Israel.

<span id="page-127-7"></span>9:7–12 The need to fear the Lord begins with a double imperative: "Remember and do not forget." The generation in Moab had not seen the mountain burning with fire, where Moses spent forty days in fasting while receiving the words of the covenant written on tablets of stone. There is no need to recall the details of the image plated with melted gold or the way it was worshiped. The very idea that a holy God could somehow be represented by a manufactured image is an outrage. Fire frequently represents the holiness of God, his absolute separation from the common. Such a God commands trust and fear, two aspects of the same dependence. Israel did not fear God, not even in the presence of the fire on the mountain.

<span id="page-127-9"></span><span id="page-127-8"></span><span id="page-127-2"></span>9:13–15 Moses recalls the words of God while he was still on the mountain (v. 14; cf. Ex. 32:10). "Let me alone" anticipates the intervention of Moses, as is fitting for a prophet whose function is intercession for the weak. An opening is created by which appeal may be made to the mercy of God, providing an opportunity for repentance and mitigation of judgment against sin.

<span id="page-127-10"></span>9:16–17 In a very deliberate and dramatic act, Moses "took hold of the two tablets and threw them . . . and broke them." In recalling the incident, Moses stipulates clearly that the tablets of the covenant were shattered to show how the covenant was broken even as it was being revealed. Destruction of the covenant document immediately renders the covenant void.

<span id="page-127-15"></span><span id="page-127-14"></span><span id="page-127-12"></span><span id="page-127-4"></span><span id="page-127-3"></span>9:18–21 This is the second of three references to forty days and nights during which Moses prayed for the people. Deuteronomy 9:25–29 reveals the content of his prayer, and 10:10–11 reports God's favorable response to his prayers. This prayer is located between the shattering of the tablets and the destruction of the idol, but the reference to forty days is not meant to indicate that more than a month elapsed between these events. Exodus tells us of three occasions on which Moses prayed. The first was while he was on the mountain (Ex. 32:11–14), the second after the destruction of the calf and the execution of the guilty (Ex. 32:30–32), and the third when the tablets were written again (Ex. 34:9). The events described in Deuteronomy parallel those in Exodus, though Deuteronomy omits many details. Moses here prayed "as before" (Deut. 9:18), indicating that the forty days of fasting refer to the time he was on the mountain receiving the words of the covenant. The Lord heard Moses at "that time also" (v. 19), again indicating that this prayer is like that of the earlier prayer on the mountain.

<span id="page-127-13"></span><span id="page-127-11"></span><span id="page-127-5"></span><span id="page-127-1"></span><span id="page-127-0"></span>The Exodus narrative suggests that Aaron was self-deceived in the making of a calf. Although a calf was used to represent both Egyptian and Canaanite gods, Aaron did not intend it for any of those gods, since he proclaimed a festival in honor of Yahweh (Ex. 32:5–6). It seems the people wanted some representation of Yahweh's guidance since they did not know what had become of Moses (Ex. 32:1). Perhaps the

<span id="page-128-1"></span>calf was intended as the pedestal for the invisible presence of Yahweh, much as the cherubs, which were to be constructed for the Most Holy Place to represent a throne (Ex. 25:18–22). Since Moses had not yet descended from the mountain, it may be inferred that Aaron was not aware of these instructions for the representation of the invisible God in the darkness behind the veil. Nevertheless, Aaron was fully culpable for his actions but also received mercy through the intervening prayer of Moses.

The destruction of the idol through burning and grinding indicates that it was a wooden object supported and engraved with metal. The procedure for obliteration was well known in Canaanite culture. Ugaritic texts tell of the termination of a Canaanite god of death called Mot by his adversary Anat: "With a knife she split him, with a sieve she scattered him, with fire she burnt him . . . in the field she sowed him. The birds did eat his flesh, the fowl did consume his limbs."34 In Exodus 32:20 the people are made to drink the water with the dust of the idol, which might be a trial by ordeal to determine the guilty, much like the trial of a suspected adulteress in Numbers 5:12–28. Deuteronomy makes no mention of such a test. The purpose of the whole procedure is to bring about complete demolition that leaves no trace.

<span id="page-128-9"></span><span id="page-128-4"></span><span id="page-128-3"></span><span id="page-128-2"></span><span id="page-128-0"></span>9:22–24 The places of rebellion named in these verses are the first stops of the Israelites following their deliverance from Egypt. Massah was the last stop before arriving at Sinai and was where the people had no water (Ex. 17:1–7). The Taberah and Kibroth-hattaavah incidents took place immediately after leaving Mount Sinai, and they were where the people complained until fire broke out (Num. 11:1–3) and where they lusted for meat (Num. 11:4–15). No journey is indicated between these events; it may be that both happened at the same location. From Mount Sinai the people journeyed to Kadesh-barnea, where they refused to enter the Promised Land (Num. 13:32–14:4), and so that generation died in the wilderness. Rebellion for the Israelites was not incidental but characterized them on each step after they left Egypt.

#### <span id="page-128-5"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-128-10"></span><span id="page-128-8"></span><span id="page-128-6"></span>This part of the speech concludes with the summary that Israel has been "rebellious against the Lord" from the time he first knew them (Deut. 9:24). The rebellion at Mount Sinai was just one of five that are named (vv. 22–23). It was a journey of eleven days from Horeb to Kadesh-barnea by the Mount Seir route (1:2). Within the time of a journey that should have been about two weeks, Israel had rebelled these five times, extending their wanderings forty years. The prologue of the second speech, the law that Moses set before the people (4:44). concludes with the theme of dangers to faith. The generation entering the Promised Land must not be presumptuous. They are not different than their fathers.

<span id="page-128-7"></span>The concluding exhortation of this prologue is descriptive of all humanity and every society, warning against the reason for the worst of suffering and injustice in

<sup>34</sup> Johannes C. de Moor, *An Anthology of Religious Texts from Ugarit*, Nisaba 16 (Leiden: Brill, 1987), 89–90.

every civilization. Most disturbing is the record of self-deception as demonstrated by Moses. The generation oppressed in Egypt, crying for deliverance, immediately considers itself worthy of the redemption received and assumes its self-sufficiency. When God tests them to show that they do not live by bread alone, their response is to test God because of their own weakness. They seem incapable of simply trusting God for the life they themselves cannot support. Modernism has worsened this situation with the development of what is called "enlightenment." Assertions of human autonomy deny any willingness to trust anything outside of humanity itself for the life it cannot give or sustain. Postmodernism is an acknowledgment that no philosophy of history can authenticate itself, but this has done nothing to generate even a modicum of humility. Twenty-first-century North Americans think greatness is more self-esteem, more self-confidence, more self-assurance. This is a pitiful testimony of self-deception, a denial not only of human impotence in solving problems but of culpability for the consequences of hubris and greed. Modern society has proven on a grander scale than ever before the truth of the words Moses speaks here to Israel.

#### *Section Overview: Intercession and Restoration*

<span id="page-130-1"></span>The topic of this section is the restoration of the covenant relationship through the intercession of Moses. The section begins with the prayer of Moses to restore the people (Deut. 9:25–29) and concludes with the result of his petition (10:10–11). God commanded him to resume his march at the head of the people to bring them to the land he had sworn to give to their fathers.

<span id="page-130-2"></span>Various items relating to the restoration are taken up between the two reports of the prayer. The tablets with the Ten Words needed to be replaced, since they detailed the basic responsibilities of the covenant relationship and were the permanent written record. Moses fashioned these and built a receptacle for them. We also read a report on the replacement of Aaron as priest (10:6–7). Since Aaron was implicated in the great transgression, a note is included on his succession. This report is chronologically out of place, since Aaron does not die until Israel is about to enter the Promised Land about forty years later. Aaron's death is incorporated as part of a travel report adopted from another source. This is indicated by the fact that Moses' direct address is suspended and Israel is referenced in the third person. The text also includes a report on the function of the Levites (10:8–9), who had distinguished themselves as not being among the transgressors and thus were the ones to carry out the execution of the guilty (Ex. 32:26–29). Moses dedicated them to the Lord for their extraordinary assignment and declared that they would be blessed. Here it is explained that the Levites would be delegated the sacred task of transporting the covenant symbols and serving in the tabernacle rituals.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-131-8"></span><span id="page-131-7"></span><span id="page-131-2"></span>9:25–29 Forty days and nights recalls Moses' intercession before he descended the mountain, mentioned previously in Deuteronomy 9:18–19 (cf. Ex. 32:9–14). Following the destruction of the calf, Moses pleads for the people of Israel because they are God's creation, redeemed from Egypt in mighty acts. They are God's inheritance, a powerful image that draws on the analogy of land that belongs to a family perpetually. This comparison is repeated from Deuteronomy 4:20, where it was stated that God brought Israel out of the fiery furnace of Egypt to be his own. God has a personal attachment to this people; they are the object of his work. This seems to be the main argument in the prayer, as it is repeated at the end in 9:29. The second argument of the prayer is that God must remember his vow to the ancestors of Israel (v. 27); the present wickedness of the people must not prevent the fulfillment of that purpose. This argument is found also in Exodus 32:13, in the prayer while Moses was on the mountain.

<span id="page-131-10"></span><span id="page-131-9"></span><span id="page-131-4"></span><span id="page-131-3"></span><span id="page-131-0"></span>The third argument concerns God's reputation among the nations. In Exodus 32:12 this is expressed as the Egyptians' assuming that God's purposes for Israel were malevolent, that he intended to destroy them. Pharaoh had thrown out the challenge, "Who is the Lord, that I should obey his voice?" (Ex. 5:2). He could not contend with God's might, but Pharaoh could claim that Yahweh's purpose was not to save Israel and that Israel should have remained in Egypt. In this passage Moses adds the further possibility that the nations would believe Yahweh to be unable to save his people. The petition of Moses for mercy after the rebellion at Kadesh-barnea is also based on the nations' saying that God was unable to bring his people to the land (Num. 14:15–16). In the perspective of the nations, God either *could* not save Israel or *would* not. On the other hand, they could also have argued that God knew he could not save Israel but brought them out to die because he had rejected them. In either case the purpose and person of God would be maligned. This prayer is based solely on the character and reputation of God. None of the petitions suggests any virtue of the Israelites that justifies their being forgiven. It is a prayer for mercy, pure and simple.

<span id="page-131-11"></span><span id="page-131-6"></span><span id="page-131-5"></span><span id="page-131-1"></span>10:1–5 The answer to the prayer comes when Moses is commanded to shape two tablets like the ones that were shattered. God would reestablish the covenant with Israel in the words written on the covenant document just as they were originally. The first time the tablets were made by God himself (Ex. 32:16). This may be a figurative way of saying that they came into being by the divine will, like creation. The Ten Words are as much a part of the order of creation as is the regularity of nature. The container mentioned here for the tablets must have been temporary since the ark would be built by Bezalel and Oholiab, craftsmen empowered by God for the artistic designs of the articles of the tabernacle (Ex. 31:1–2, 6–11). The ark

<span id="page-132-1"></span><span id="page-132-0"></span>in the tabernacle was also accompanied by giant cherubim attached to an atonement cover (Hb. *kapporet*, "mercy seat"; Ex. 25:17) resting atop the ark. This gold covering was the place where cleansing for sin would be made (Ex. 25:10–22). This was the meeting place of the covenant.

The chest made by Moses may be understood as a container used to protect contractual documents that were a record of an agreement. Such chests were often deposited in temples, since agreements were usually sponsored by a deity. The ark in the tabernacle would follow this analogy, with the distinction that there was no image in the tabernacle. Testimony to the holiness of God was given by both the ark and the symbols of a royal throne separated from the common by a veil. The covenant that established a relationship between God and his people included a sacred element; the atonement cover above the covenant document provided for the possibility of a relationship. The ark therefore was a representation of the rule and provision of God for his people, unlike the calf made by Aaron and the people.

<span id="page-132-7"></span><span id="page-132-5"></span><span id="page-132-4"></span>10:6–7 The itinerary, which includes the place where Aaron dies, follows that of Numbers 33:30–35, with a slight variation of names and a different order of encampments. These encampments were in the area of Ezion-geber on the east shore of the Gulf of Elath. Aaron died at Moserah, which is named first in the Numbers itinerary. In that list of encampments Aaron dies at Mount Hor, six stations later than Moserah (Num. 33:38). The locations of these encampments and the relationships that may have existed between them cannot be determined. Eleazar son of Aaron is made priest in his place in a public event known to all (Num. 20:22–29). The point of relevance in Deuteronomy is that Aaron, like Moses, does not enter the Promised Land.

<span id="page-132-8"></span><span id="page-132-3"></span><span id="page-132-2"></span>10:8–9 The consecration of the Levites as the ones responsible for the ark develops their role in distinguishing themselves as loyal followers of Yahweh (Ex. 32:26–29). Priesthood is their reward for having stood in battle against illegitimate worship. They become the ministers of legitimate worship perpetually, with a distinguished role: "to stand before the Lord," that is, offer sacrifices on behalf of the people and pronounce the priestly benediction. Their special tasks require them to be dispersed throughout the land, with no territory of their own.

<span id="page-132-9"></span>10:10–11 Moses concludes with the assurance that his prayers for mercy have been answered. Not only has the covenant been restored but Israel will be allowed to enter the land in accordance with the oath made with the patriarchs.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-132-11"></span>The memory of Israel concerning these events is found in the Psalms. The fourth book of the psalter, Psalms 90–106, focuses on the exodus.35 This section of the psalter follows the plea for mercy amid the seeming delay of God's eternal covenant with David (Ps. 89:1–4). The psalter shifts focus from David to the covenant

<span id="page-132-10"></span><span id="page-132-6"></span><sup>35</sup> Cf. Response section on 3:1–29. Psalm 90 is a prayer of Moses.

<span id="page-133-7"></span>with Israel mediated through Moses. The covenant at Sinai is the basis for the rule of God over the whole earth (Psalms 93–100), as it is the establishment of the promise to Abraham through whom all the families of the earth may receive a blessing (Gen. 12:3; Ex. 6:2–8). Earth will come to realize the beauty for which it was created (Psalm 104) only through the mercy of God.

<span id="page-133-18"></span><span id="page-133-17"></span><span id="page-133-14"></span><span id="page-133-13"></span><span id="page-133-11"></span><span id="page-133-10"></span><span id="page-133-9"></span><span id="page-133-8"></span><span id="page-133-0"></span>The maintenance of this covenant is possible only through forgiveness of the covenant people. Psalm 103 is an expression of praise to God as the one who forgives sins and heals diseases (Ps. 103:3). The disease referred to is their sin (cf. Isa. 1:4–6; 6:10). Forgiveness is the most notable benefit that God provides his people (Ps. 103:2), because apart from mercy they could not be a people at all. The disease of humanity is its self-assertiveness in defiance of God, as explained by Isaiah in the introduction to his prophecy (Isa. 1:2–8). The healing of such pernicious illness is the mercy of God that is everlasting to those who fear him and keep his covenant (Ps. 103:17–18). This was made known when God showed his ways to Moses (Ps. 103:7). The specific event the psalmist has in mind is the experience of the golden calf, as is clear in the next line: "The Lord is merciful and gracious, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love" (Ps. 103:8). This line is a direct reference to the lesson of the golden calf found in Exodus 33:19 and 34:5–6. The merciful character of God is the meaning to be associated with his name. In both references the significance of the name Yahweh ("the Lord") is defined as God's being merciful in character. The name Yahweh is related to the verb for being (it translates as "he is" or "he will be"). In Exodus 3 the sense is "I am with you." In Exodus 33–34 the sense is "I am merciful." Each of these is related to the other. It is possible for God to be with Israel only if he is merciful, which is what the sin of the golden calf illustrates. It is God's mercy and his love for Israel that moves God to be present with them through the covenant even when they rebel.

<span id="page-133-16"></span><span id="page-133-15"></span><span id="page-133-12"></span><span id="page-133-6"></span><span id="page-133-5"></span><span id="page-133-4"></span><span id="page-133-3"></span><span id="page-133-2"></span><span id="page-133-1"></span>The fourth book of the psalter concludes as it began: with cries for mercy. The prayer of Moses in Psalm 90 ends with a plea for mercy: "Return, O Lord! How long? Have pity on your servants" (Ps. 90:13). Individually and collectively, mankind is in need of God's mercy. The reason for the plea is found at the end of the third book of the psalter, with the plea to remember the promise to David (Ps. 89:49–51). The covenant of Sinai assures that the promise of the kingdom will be fulfilled. The earth will be a marvelous home for humans (Psalm 104). Although Israel sinned and acted perversely (Ps. 106:6), God remembered his covenant according to the abundance of his mercy (Ps. 106:45–46). The redemption of the exodus is the assurance of mercy in the distresses and failures of later times.

### <span id="page-134-1"></span>DEUTERONOMY 10:12–22

**<sup>12</sup>** "And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God require of you, but to fear the Lord your God, to walk in all his ways, to love him, to serve the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul, **<sup>13</sup>** and to keep the commandments and statutes of the Lord, which I am commanding you today for your good? **14**Behold, to the Lord your God belong heaven and the heaven of heavens, the earth with all that is in it. **15**Yet the Lord set his heart in love on your fathers and chose their offspring after them, you above all peoples, as you are this day. **16**Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart, and be no longer stubborn. **17**For the Lord your God is God of gods and Lord of lords, the great, the mighty, and the awesome God, who is not partial and takes no bribe. **18**He executes justice for the fatherless and the widow, and loves the sojourner, giving him food and clothing. **19**Love the sojourner, therefore, for you were sojourners in the land of Egypt. **20**You shall fear the Lord your God. You shall serve him and hold fast to him, and by his name you shall swear. **21**He is your praise. He is your God, who has done for you these great and terrifying things that your eyes have seen. **22**Your fathers went down to Egypt seventy persons, and now the Lord your God has made you as numerous as the stars of heaven."

#### *Section Overview: The Supreme God*

<span id="page-134-0"></span>The prologue comes full circle to its starting point in the Shema with its demand for love. Moses is the spokesman of Yahweh, urging Israel "to fear the Lord your God, . . . to love him, to serve the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul" (Deut. 10:12). This is the only time that the imperatives to love and to fear the Lord are brought together in the same sentence. These are not sentimental desires but require concrete manifestation in conduct to "walk in all his ways" (10:12). Love is the commitment of the covenant relationship, but fear must be Israel's response to the person of Yahweh. The previous exhortation has established why Israel must fear Yahweh and why they should love him.

This passage does not use the word *holy*, but this is nevertheless the concept developed. *Holiness* is the term used to describe the person of God, who is separate from all material elements. The God of Israel brings into existence the heavens in their uttermost reaches, which in turn sustain life created on earth. Yet this God is very present in heaven and earth, represented uniquely by man (Hb. *ʾadam*) made as his image on earth (*ʾadamah*). Such representation brings a moral dimension to holiness, since the Creator determines what relationships shall exist between those who represent him. In his concluding exhortation Moses addresses both the metaphysical and the ethical dimensions of the holiness of God.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-135-2"></span>10:12–14 The uniqueness of this declaration made about Yahweh is rarely acknowledged. The God of Israel is holy. He exists entirely outside the order of the visible and known world of the common but is completely in control of the heavens and the earth, everywhere present within it. It is not possible to conceive of such a concept having evolved in any ancient period, though such facile assertions have often been made. Most such claims revolve around a revolutionary period in Late Bronze Age Egypt initiated by a pharaoh of the mid-fourteenth century named Amenhotep IV. He declared Aten, the solar disk with its life-giving illumination, to be the sole ruling deity. The king changed his name to Akhenaten as the only son of Aten (Egyptian pharaohs were deemed gods). To empower this deity above all other gods, Akhenaten moved the temple to a new capital called Akhetaten ("the horizon of the Aten"), modern day Tell el-Amarna.

Freud is one prominent figure who argued that Moses was an Egyptian priest of Aten whose followers joined a monotheistic tribe in Midian. His *Moses and Monotheism* used psychoanalytic theory to generate a hypothesis concerning historical events. Freud did acknowledge the Israelite distinction of an invisible god, but this passage in Deuteronomy makes a much more radical distinction. Yahweh is not one god above all others; he is *the* God, not to be associated in any way with material elements such as the sun. In other ancient religions the physical elements were extensions of the gods. In Mesopotamia all was subordinated to the cosmic, unalterable, and impersonal law called *kittum*. 36 The God of Moses rules over all because he is creator of all. Such a concept cannot be an evolution from the surrounding culture, as it is much too radically different.

<span id="page-135-4"></span><span id="page-135-3"></span>10:15–16 Given this description of God, the astonishing truth is that God created Israel as a people of distinction. Verse 15 begins with this surprise (Hb. *raq*, "yet"). Despite all that is true of God, he chose to love Israel and give them a peculiarity above all other peoples in making him known.

<span id="page-135-5"></span><span id="page-135-0"></span>The mention of the fathers is the background to the graphic metonymy of verse 16: the sign of the covenant is named for the covenant itself. Circumcision is the sign of God's covenant with Abraham in Genesis 17:9–11: "This is my covenant, which you shall keep, between me and you and your offspring after you: Every male among you shall be circumcised" (Gen. 17:10). In Deuteronomy this is cryptically

<span id="page-135-1"></span><sup>36</sup> For an explanation of the Mesopotamian and Egyptian views of humanity and history in relation to the gods cf. E. A. Speiser, "The Biblical Idea of History in Its Common Near Eastern Setting," in *The Jewish Expression*, ed. Judah Goldin (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 1976) 1–17.

<span id="page-136-2"></span>stated as "Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart" (Deut. 10:16). The sign performed as a public confession must correspond to the commitment of mind to observe all the commands of the covenant. The sign is nothing apart from this reality. Circumcision and stubborn rebellion are a grotesque combination that mocks the confession made in the sign.

<span id="page-136-3"></span>10:17–19 The omnipotence of an awesome God is manifested in his character, which treats all created persons equally. Bribery and favoritism are particularly offensive violations of respect toward humans. Although God has loved Israel to make them a covenant people, a kingdom of priests to represent him, Israel must expect no special favors from God. As they know, God's judgment is as harsh for them as for any others. God has also given other nations land (32:8), so Israel must be careful to treat all others with the same respect. They must not be guilty of the sins the Egyptians committed against them.

<span id="page-136-7"></span><span id="page-136-5"></span>Justice in Scripture is always defined according to covenant requirements. Care for the most vulnerable of the community is the standard measure for keeping the covenant. Isaiah's call to repentance is to learn to do good by seeking justice, especially for the orphan and the widow (Isa. 1:16–17). Widows and orphans are easily marginalized to the periphery of family support, but they are very much a part of God's family. Another that is socially on the margins is the sojourner (Hb. *ger*), who does not own land but lives among the people. Most of these would be Canaanites employed by Israelites. As a day laborer, the *ger* was vulnerable without a stable income. The *ger* is to be not only protected but given provisions. Israel—of all people!—should know of this importance, having been such laborers in Egypt. Covenant responsibility requires care for all, with special attention to those that might be readily neglected.

<span id="page-136-4"></span><span id="page-136-1"></span>10:20–22 Taking an oath in the name of God is an expression of covenant loyalty, as stated in 6:13–14. A false oath shows contempt for God because the oath taker assumes there is no punishment for violation of the word spoken. An oath is taken when affirming the covenant, as done exuberantly in the renewal of Asa (2 Chron. 15:14–15). Those who fear God will serve him, cling to him, and swear by his name without fear.

<span id="page-136-6"></span><span id="page-136-0"></span>The multiplication of Israel is the sign of God's fulfillment of the oath he took with the patriarchs (Gen. 15:5). The miraculous growth of Israel was a work of God alone; there could be no human contribution to this feat, just as God had shown in fulfilling his promise to Abraham. According to the census in Numbers, Israel numbered six hundred thousand males of military age at the time of the exodus. This declaration of God's great work transitions abruptly to a second exhortation to love God, which details further the great things he has done.

#### *Response*

The irrational assumption of atheism is that humans have the power to discern all that can be known by perception of their senses as analyzed by their mind. Only

rationalism and empiricism are acceptable; revelation is arbitrarily excluded as a possibility. Immediate suspicion of this assumption should be raised with the acknowledgment that the human mind and empirical observation cannot even contrive a theory for the emergence of life from inanimate chemicals. On earth, life seems to spring up irrepressibly when all the forces of death are arrayed against it. Origins of life are pushed back ever further in the mysteries of time, or even off to some other planet, but this does nothing to answer the problem of what Michael Behe has called "Darwin's black box."37 "Black box" is his metaphor for a process not understood that obviously takes place. Evolution must include a process whereby life arose from nonliving matter and developed entirely by impersonal means observable to human perception. The words of Klaus Dose, researching molecular chemistry in 1988, have become ever more true today:

More than 30 years of experimentation on the origin of life in the fields of chemical and molecular evolution have led to a better perception of the immensity of the problem of the origin of life on earth rather than to its solution. At present all discussions on principal theories and experiments in the field either end in stalemate or in a confession of ignorance.38

It might be argued that, one day, science will do more than discovering increasing complexity, but this still would not answer the assertion that humans have access to all possible knowledge through their own mental powers. The Hebrew concept of a holy God is one that cannot be perceived or discovered by humans independently. The Hebrew God belongs to a dimension called *holiness*. This order is outside the chemistry of the common but is responsible for creating it. Thus Moses speaks of the God of gods and Lord of lords. All other beings, some called gods, are derivative of the common order. The God of Moses can be known only through his self-revelation, which is the claim Moses makes in these verses. That revelation is rational and reasonable. Israel had seen and heard that which no one could possibly discover by human ingenuity. But this God should also be loved, the only acceptable response of everything that Israel has experienced.

Another irrational characteristic of humans is their refusal to live by what they know. Sometimes this is a matter of defiance, sometimes indifference, and sometimes simple lack of discipline. Thus Moses calls for a circumcised heart. It is one thing to admit something is rational, but quite another to live in accordance with such knowledge. Israel might believe and follow through on the covenant oath, taking the sign of circumcision, but they might not have the love demanded by God. They must live in accordance with the way of life laid out before them. Fear and love for God is nothing less than following in his ways. It must never be reduced to mere belief.

Fundamental to following in God's ways is the recognition that no human has exclusive privileges or rights limited to a certain status. Even the king must live

<sup>37</sup> Michael J. Behe, *Darwin's Black Box: The Biochemical Challenge to Evolution* (New York: Free Press, 1996).

<sup>38</sup> Klaus Dose, "The Origin of Life: More Questions Than Answers," *ISR* 13/4 (1988): 348.

according to the values of the covenant. Life is a gift, given equally to all, whatever one's fortunes within society. The privileges of life must be ensured for all the living. Israel has a special calling to represent the Creator. The most fundamental way they do so is by showing utmost respect for all life given by their Creator, knowing that he cares no less for the person of low society than for one of privilege.

11 "You shall therefore love the Lord your God and keep his charge, his statutes, his rules, and his commandments always. **2**And consider today (since I am not speaking to your children who have not known or seen it), consider the discipline*<sup>1</sup>* of the Lord your God, his greatness, his mighty hand and his outstretched arm, **3**his signs and his deeds that he did in Egypt to Pharaoh the king of Egypt and to all his land, **<sup>4</sup>** and what he did to the army of Egypt, to their horses and to their chariots, how he made the water of the Red Sea flow over them as they pursued after you, and how the Lord has destroyed them to this day, **<sup>5</sup>** and what he did to you in the wilderness, until you came to this place, **<sup>6</sup>** and what he did to Dathan and Abiram the sons of Eliab, son of Reuben, how the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them up, with their households, their tents, and every living thing that followed them, in the midst of all Israel. **7**For your eyes have seen all the great work of the Lord that he did.

The eyes of the Lord your God are always upon it, from the beginning of the year to the end of the year.

**<sup>13</sup>** "And if you will indeed obey my commandments that I command you today, to love the Lord your God, and to serve him with all your heart and with all your soul, **14**he*<sup>3</sup>* will give the rain for your land in its season, the early rain and the later rain, that you may gather in your grain and your wine and your oil. **15**And he will give grass in your fields for your livestock, and you shall eat and be full. **16**Take care lest your heart be deceived, and you turn aside and serve other gods and worship them; **<sup>17</sup>** then the anger of the Lord will be kindled against you, and he will shut up the heavens, so that there will be no rain, and the land will yield no fruit, and you will perish quickly off the good land that the Lord is giving you."

#### *Section Overview: God of Power*

<span id="page-139-6"></span><span id="page-139-4"></span>Moses reminds Israel of her experience with the power of God, which demands a response of fear and love. The children did not see this encounter with the power of God (Deut. 11:2), but the elders have seen all the deeds that God has done (vv. 3, 7). These are the lessons of forty years that are to teach Israel the fear of the Lord. Verses 2–7 are one long sentence that begins with "consider today" and continues with a series of clauses concerning "what he did." This develops the conclusion of the last chapter: "He is your praise. He is your God, who has done for you these great and terrifying things that your eyes have seen" (10:21). Israel is to consider the "discipline of the Lord" because this is her wisdom and understanding before all peoples, who will say, "Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people" (4:6). Discipline (Hb. *musar*) is the means by which God brings wisdom (Prov. 3:11–12; 4:13). To live out wisdom means to "keep his charge" (Deut. 11:1) and the "whole commandment" (v. 8), namely, everything Moses is instructing in this law.

<span id="page-139-8"></span><span id="page-139-7"></span><span id="page-139-3"></span><span id="page-139-2"></span><span id="page-139-0"></span>To keep the whole commandment is to "love the Lord your God" and to serve him in every thought with complete devotion (11:13), the words of commitment declared in the Shema. Obedience to the covenant demand comes with the promise of long life in a land unlike Egypt, a land in which God provides rain from the heavens that generates an abundance in the hills and valleys. Since the religions of Canaan were all about prosperity, Israel must remember that God is their only source of life and that such life comes with an abundance they never knew in Egypt.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-139-1"></span>11:1 The demand to love God is now reinforced by the reminder of what Israel has learned of God in its experience since leaving Egypt. This verse is a conclusion to the command to fear and love God in 10:12, which is repeated in verse 20. It is also the introduction of the theme of God's deeds for Israel, which otherwise begins abruptly.

<span id="page-139-5"></span>11:2–7 Syntactically, it is challenging to determine the object of the imperative "consider." The NJPS renders it this way: "Take thought this day that it was not your children, who neither experienced nor witnessed the lesson of the Lord your God—," with the list of deeds then simply listed as examples. The ESV makes the children parenthetic, with the object being the list of deeds. Consideration of the list of deeds done and the need to teach the next generation are equally important. It is impossible to say that one should be subordinated to the other; the ambiguity may be a way of making both equal. The list of deeds shows why it is necessary to love God, but a love for God learned through these deeds makes more urgent the imperative to teach the children, since these lessons can be learned only through the enactment of the confessions that follow. These words must be bound "as a sign" on the hands, and the people will need to take the oath of a "a blessing and a curse" (vv. 18, 26). Consideration of the children anticipates the sequel of what is necessary as Israel enters the Promised Land.

<span id="page-140-10"></span><span id="page-140-7"></span>The lessons of the sequel all deal with the consequences of rebellion against God. The lesson to be taught may appropriately be described as a "discipline" (v. 2), the primary lesson being the human propensity to rebel against the love of God as something restrictive. This is true not only for the Egyptians but equally so for Israel, as is shown in the lessons from the past. Israel witnessed the judgment of God against Pharaoh and his armies, a stupendous event that could be nothing less than the actions of the Creator. The Red Sea flowing back over the Egyptian armies defies natural explanation; this event was remembered as the sea covering the enemies of Israel in Psalm 78:53. Pharaoh had defiantly asked, "Who is the Lord, that I should obey his voice . . . ?" (Ex. 5:2). The last of the plagues had only temporarily brought him to submission. The judgment of the Red Sea ended the power of Egypt "to this day" (Deut. 11:4). No one present could deny the truth of this great deed.

<span id="page-140-11"></span><span id="page-140-8"></span><span id="page-140-3"></span><span id="page-140-2"></span><span id="page-140-0"></span>But just as Pharaoh rebelled against God, Israel defied God in refusing to enter the Promised Land and then, in her disillusionment, challenged divinely appointed leadership. Dathan and Abiram, sons of Reuben, firstborn of Jacob, challenged the leadership of Moses over the people (Num. 16:1–2). In Numbers this story is told together with that of a rebellion against Aaron of Levites who claimed his clan did not have exclusive right to the priesthood (Num. 16:3). Deuteronomy refers only to the civil rebellion against Moses, which may be analogous to the hubris of Pharaoh. A special punishment was designated for Dathan and Abiram because they refused to leave their tents at the command of Moses (Num. 16:12–15). Their punishment was unprecedented in that they literally went alive into their graves with all their families and possessions (Num. 16:25–34). No one was to go near them since they were subject to the *kherem*, a designation by which they were set apart exclusively to God and would no longer live in the common world. Just as it would be fatal for the people to come too close to Mount Sinai when God appeared there (Ex. 19:12), so touching anything that belonged to the rebels could be fatal.

<span id="page-140-9"></span><span id="page-140-6"></span><span id="page-140-5"></span><span id="page-140-4"></span><span id="page-140-1"></span>11:8–9 The lessons of Egypt and the wilderness enforce the requirement that Israel must keep the "whole commandment," all the Torah that Moses is setting before them. This verse concludes these lessons introduced by the demand to love God and "keep his charge" (Deut. 11:1). Love for God in keeping the whole commandment will ensure both possession of the land and a long life there. This leads Moses to a description of the land, which is not at all like what they experienced in Egypt.

<span id="page-141-3"></span><span id="page-141-2"></span>11:10–12 Love for God in keeping his charge will be necessary for survival in the land Israel is about to enter. Egypt was a land requiring irrigation, a task expressed ambiguously as "watered it with your feet" (11:10 ESV mg.), involving various aspects of diverting water. Agriculture in Egypt depended on the rising of the Nile in summer and fall as a result of melting snow and of rains in Ethiopia. Vegetation in Egypt to the present time is supported by the Nile and systems of irrigation canals and reservoirs, since the levels of the Nile may vary significantly from year to year. It may be debated whether a land that depends on rain is more advantageous for agriculture. The point of this passage is that a land dependent on rain is advantageous to those who observe God's commands. This land makes obvious the need for dependence on God. For the land to yield its abundance, God must continuously watch it, from the first of the year to the last. It is therefore the best of all lands for those who observe the whole command of God

<span id="page-141-0"></span>The sentiment concerning the abundance of the land expressed here is like that already given in 6:10–11; 8:7–9. These passages express how the abundance of the land in terms of houses, vineyards, grain, oil, honey, and abundant water are entirely a gift of God.

<span id="page-141-4"></span>11:13–17 This section concludes with the exhortation to love and serve God, returning to the theme of the importance of complete devotion to relationship with God. The exhortation here comes with the warning implicit in the previous verses. Ironically, the people's temptation will be to follow fertility gods, who went through cycles of power to give rain and death when the land languished. The God of Israel could be relied upon to provide rain in its time. The requirement was faithfulness, lest Israel experience the judgment of the heavens' withholding the rains.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-141-1"></span>Love must be learned, in a lesson that is never complete. Learning to love God as he demands is the process of a lifetime. It requires observance of the whole Torah, everything that God revealed to Moses concerning how life is to be lived. Learning this love is a discipline (11:2) that involves an understanding of all the ways God corrects us, as seen in his deliverance and instruction of Israel. The deliverance from Egypt is a stern reminder of the necessity of learning to fear the Lord. The Egyptians suffered the judgment of their denial of Yahweh. This fear was not learned by those of Israel who rebelled against their divinely appointed leaders and therefore suffered the same kind of judgment. Learning to fear the Lord is, at the same time, instruction to love the Lord. Knowing the Lord, who gives bread for life and whose words are therefore the bread of life, will lead to the devotion demanded in the command to love.

Entering the land of rain and abundance is a means of learning to love God, but it is also a temptation to believe that bread may be earned apart from God. An example of this truth takes place in the days of Ahab during the time of Elijah <span id="page-142-5"></span><span id="page-142-4"></span><span id="page-142-1"></span><span id="page-142-0"></span>(1 Kings 17–18). Elijah represents the power of God to determine the times of rain, as Moses declares (Deut. 11:11–12). Ironically, Ahab blames Elijah for the drought instead of repenting and acknowledging the powerlessness of Baal to provide rain (1 Kings 18:17–18). He does not understand that mortals do not live by bread alone, that God alone grants rain, grain, wine, and oil as his people learn to love him (Deut. 11:13–15). Love for God does not mean there will be no times without rain. God disciplines his children so that they may continue to learn to love him. The love demanded by God is exclusive (v. 16). It requires constant self-discipline, something not learned by Ahab nor by the people of the covenant.

#### *Section Overview: Confessions of Faith*

<span id="page-143-0"></span>The exhortation of this Torah concludes as it began, with the command to keep these words continuously in mind and to make such knowledge one's constant desire. The requirement that these words be bound on the hand and forehead is repeated from 6:6–9, signaling that this portion of the sermon has come to an end. Combatting the danger of forgetting the entire charge given by God requires vigilance, hence the requirement that they be impressed on the mind in such a way that every action may be controlled by them.

<span id="page-143-4"></span><span id="page-143-3"></span><span id="page-143-2"></span>The preamble of this Torah is summed up with a blessing and a curse, typical language of a covenant in the treaties of the Late Bronze Age. The blessings and curses are part of an oath ceremony to be carried out at Shechem, the city between Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal. Chapter 27 develops and clarifies the covenantal renewal ceremony to take place upon entrance into the land. The enactment of this ceremony is described in Joshua 8:30–35, following the defeat of Jericho and Ai, and again in Joshua 24:1–27, at the conclusion of the account of the conquest and the distribution of the land. Renewal of the covenant for the new generation is the burden of Moses in these closing speeches. It is only appropriate that formal instructions for when this should be done punctuate the key points of the giving of this Torah, first at the end of the prologue and again just before the blessings and the curses that set out the destinies of life and death.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-143-1"></span>11:18–21 The command to bind these words on the wrists, hands, and forehead is slightly different from that given at the introduction to the prologue. The imperative to instruct the next generation is given between the command to bind them on prominent parts of the body and on the house and gate. Binding the words on the body has a significance separate from that of the house and the city, as it is intensely personal. Individuals must show the signs of covenant obedience, especially in actions but perhaps also as symbols on the body. Head ornaments are known in ancient times, but no connection can be made between "frontlets" (Hb. *totaphot*) and such symbols, nor can a historical connection be established with the phylacteries of a later time. It is known, however, that tiny rolls of text were used as amulets for protection. In 1979 two tiny silver scrolls were found in a burial chamber located in Ketef Hinnom ("slope of Hinnom"), near Mount Zion and the old City of David. These scrolls come from the First Temple period;

the larger one is about 4 x 1 inch (10.2 x 2.5 cm), the smaller about 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) in height. The words on the larger scroll call upon Yahweh, who keeps the covenant to those who love him and keep his commandments. The second scroll is a prayer to be blessed by Yahweh, who rebukes evil. Both conclude with the blessing found in Numbers 6:24–26. These are the oldest actual biblical texts extant.39 The presence of such scrolls may suggest that words such as these were bound to the body.

<span id="page-144-0"></span>The Greek word *phylactery*, used for the later practice of binding the words to the body, is derived from the Greek word for "protection." This is appropriate, as security and protection can be found only in obedience to the whole charge of God. Whether the words were bound to the body metaphorically, in the sense that they were so embedded in mind that they controlled the body, or physically, as a constant mental reminder of the message they contain, the effect is the same. Safety and blessing are to be found in keeping the whole commandment.

<span id="page-144-2"></span><span id="page-144-1"></span>11:22–25 Moses here develops the conclusion given in Deuteronomy 11:8, the first section of the exhortation to listen to God the Most High. Yahweh would give Israel the land controlled by kings that even the mighty power of Egypt could not control. They would lay claim to it by walking through it in conquest. The land is described in terms of the major features that mark Canaan, that is, the extremities of its extent. These are the deserts on the south, Lebanon and Euphrates in the north, and the Mediterranean on the west. Israel is about to cross the Jordan, so implicitly that is the eastern boundary.

<span id="page-144-3"></span>11:26–27 Blessing or curse is a choice immediately present for Israel. All that has been said in the previous exhortation and the prologue is a choice between two futures. Following in the way of gods that Israel has not experienced, those that have not proven themselves in the way that Yahweh has done in bringing them to this place, will result in the curse. Israel has never had a helper outside of the God revealed to them and delivering them. Following any other god is both unbelief and betrayal.

<span id="page-144-4"></span>11:28–30 Public ceremonies are a critical part of instruction, as they dramatize the consequences of obedience and disobedience. The importance of this ceremony to the people about to enter the land may be observed by its repetition in chapter 27. The location of the ceremony is described specifically for those about to enter a land they do not know. Ebal and Gerizim are in the highlands some 30 miles (48 km) to the west of the Jordan valley. The location of Gilgal named here must be a different location than the one across the river where Israel was encamped. The only alternative is to assume that this description has been merged with that of another ceremony which also took place at Gilgal. Chapter 27 seems to indicate that there was more than one ceremony.

<span id="page-144-5"></span><sup>39</sup> A thorough study of these amulets is provided by Gabriel Barkay et al., "The Amulets from Ketef Hinnom: A New Edition and Evaluation," *BASOR* 334 (May 2004): 41–71.

<span id="page-145-0"></span>The tree at Shechem called the "oak of Moreh" is first mentioned in Abraham's journey into the land of Canaan in Genesis 12:6. This tree or grove of trees was significant in receiving oracles, or divine instruction, as indicated by its name ("Moreh" = "instruction"). Such sacred sites are widely known in many cultures. Shechem seems to have been particularly noted for its sacred locations. Jacob buried his various idolatrous artifacts there (Gen. 35:4), and Joshua set up a great stone there at the time of the making of the covenant (Josh. 24:26). These events may have all involved the same tree, as large distinguished trees can stand for many centuries. Their endurance increases their distinction.

<span id="page-145-3"></span><span id="page-145-2"></span><span id="page-145-1"></span>11:31–32 These verses are transitional, as they constitute the introduction to the next section of the address, the exposition of this Torah. They do not conclude the instructions for the ceremony, but they do summarize the preceding prologue, which instructs Israel to live in the land across the Jordan. The necessity of keeping all of the rules and regulations that Moses is teaching them turns the focus of the address to the exposition of the entire instruction.

#### *Response*

Ceremony is important for the Christian no less than for the people of Israel. Public confession creates an accountability of commitment important to maintaining fidelity. The covenant Israel was to make on entrance to the Promised Land might be compared the significance of a wedding ceremony to a marriage. The church recognizes a marriage only if there is a commitment made with vows and witnesses known to the congregation. Ideally the congregation is then involved in supporting the marriage and helping the couple. The vow of commitment in the new covenant is baptism. In the same way, the expression of this vow in baptism is a criterion of belonging to a congregation. Those making a faith commitment to redemption in Christ receive baptism to show their unity with him in his death and resurrection (Rom. 6:3–5). As Paul explains, this results in a transformed way of life, putting away former conduct with its vain way of thinking and living in the newness of the way of Christ through the power of the Holy Spirit (e.g., Rom. 8:1–17).

<span id="page-145-7"></span><span id="page-145-6"></span><span id="page-145-5"></span><span id="page-145-4"></span>Baptism as a sign of the new covenant is established by Jesus when he is baptized by John in the Jordan. In this baptism, Jesus shows his identity with those who display their repentance in accepting the baptism of repentance and expressing their desire to be faithful to the covenant. Jesus will declare himself to be the fulfillment of the new covenant at the time of his death: "This cup that is poured out for you is the new covenant in my blood" (Luke 22:20). With Jesus, baptism is given a new significance. It is no longer only a testimony of repentance but a confession of following Jesus, who has brought to us the redemption of the new covenant. For this reason, followers of Jesus make disciples from all nations, baptizing them into the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit (Matt. 28:19). As with Israel in covenant declaration, baptism is the uncompromised dedication of one's life to Jesus as Lord and Savior.

<span id="page-146-3"></span><span id="page-146-2"></span><span id="page-146-1"></span>Jesus calls his followers to the same love that Moses requires of the children of Israel. "We love because he first loved us" (1 John 4:19). Disciples of Jesus are known by the love they have for one another (John 13:35). This love for God is not without failure—the disciple who vows he will lay down his life for Jesus shortly denies him three time (John 13:37–38). Such failure is not the end of the covenant vow; it is a failure common to all humanity. Peter weeps bitterly over his failure, and his life becomes one of the most powerful examples of love for God and others, just as Moses demands of Israel. But a denial of this love in relation to God and others is a denial of discipleship, irrespective of vows that may have been taken. The expression of this love may be found in the requirements of Deuteronomy. Ceremonies and rituals have necessarily changed in the expression of the new covenant, but the requirements in relation to others and God remain the same.

#### *Section Overview: Regulations for Worship*

<span id="page-147-2"></span><span id="page-147-0"></span>The exposition of this Torah extends from 12:1 to 26:19, concluding with the blessings and curses in 28:1–68. Chapter 27 repeats the necessity of covenant <span id="page-148-2"></span>renewal in the Promised Land. The exposition falls into several large sections that sometimes digress or transition into tangential issues, so that determining the subdivisions is to some measure the choice of the reader. The first major section deals with matters of confessing the covenant in worship (12:1–16:17). Related topics include instructions for dealing with syncretism of Canaanite religion, consumption of food ritually pure and eaten in the right place, care for the poor, and observance of the annual festivals. A second major section deals with appointment of civil and religious authorities (16:18–18:22). A third section concerns judicial and military matters as the people move into the Promised Land (19:1–21:9). Family matters and civil issues take up the last section of instruction (21:10–25:19). The whole exposition concludes with a ceremony of praise and fidelity (26:1–19) and the blessings and curses (ch. 28) that are part of the covenant vow.

<span id="page-148-8"></span><span id="page-148-7"></span><span id="page-148-6"></span><span id="page-148-5"></span><span id="page-148-4"></span><span id="page-148-0"></span>The section on worship makes its primary concern the distinctiveness of the covenant God. Israel must know what it means to make the astounding confession that there is no other God (4:35, 39). To say Yahweh is holy makes a statement that he is unlike any other kind of deity worshiped in any other culture. Worship of Israel's God can have no association with those gods that emerge from the order of the common and are ultimately dependent on it. Israelite places of worship, the Israelite manner of worship, and the covenant of Israel with the Giver of life must not be compromised by any association with worship in the common culture. Of course, the language of culture, whether in words or ritual, must be used to express the concepts of Israel's God, but it must never be thought that other gods can contribute to the life of Israel.
