#### *Comment*

<span id="page-148-3"></span><span id="page-148-1"></span>12:1 The heading introducing the rules and regulations of this Torah continues the transition of the previous chapter that summarized the prologue and directed attention to the instruction Israel had been exhorted to observe. This orientation toward instructions for worship in the Promised Land is concluded in 12:29–31,

in which Israel is exhorted to be separate from the abominations of the people whose land they are about to enter.

<span id="page-149-0"></span>12:2–3 Canaanite gods emerged from the natural world and were dependent upon it; such worship was a contradiction to the Israelite concept of a holy and transcendent God. Therefore, Canaanite places of worship were to be destroyed. These were for the most part not temples but open-air sanctuaries consisting of a raised platform leveled with stones called in Hebrew a *bamah*, often translated "high place." Such places were usually associated with trees called "Asherim" and with an altar, a pillar, and associated artifacts. Gideon was told to cut down the "Ashera," destroy the altar of Baal, and break up the platform (Judg. 6:25–26). All reminders of the existence of these places in the Promised Land were to be eradicated.

<span id="page-149-3"></span><span id="page-149-2"></span>12:4–7 Israel is to distinguish its worship from the Canaanites' by seeking out, from all the tribes, the place God has claimed as exclusive to his presence by placing his name on it. A name on a place is a sign of ownership. This is not to suggest that God is confined to this place or that one place of worship would eliminate false worship. One place of worship appears to be required because using multiple places of worship has unacceptable associations with Canaanite practice: "You shall not worship the Lord your God in that way" (Deut. 12:4). Other features of Canaanite practice, such as altars, sacrifices, and agricultural festivals, are acceptable means of confessing Israelite faith, but the practice of multiple shrines is not.

<span id="page-149-1"></span>Moses envisions the distinctiveness of a single worship center to which Israelites will come from all their places of residence. In practice this will be not possible before David captures Jerusalem and makes it a capital for all the tribes. The elimination of Canaanite places of worship is not undertaken until the time of Hezekiah. Two related assumptions about these realities must be challenged. The first is that the date of Deuteronomy must be associated with the political efforts to centralize worship. The second is that the motivation for a single place of worship is to foster political control, as is the case when Jeroboam sets up altars at Bethel and Dan (1 Kings 12:26–33). Centralization does not necessarily foster unity or political loyalty; the Rabshakeh could accuse Hezekiah of betraying Yahweh because of the destruction of the altars in Judah (2 Kings 18:22). If the prophetic word to Israel found in the Former Prophets (Joshua–2 Kings) is based on the Torah of Moses, similarity in the language will naturally be found. But this does not require the Former Prophets to precede Deuteronomy, as is often claimed.

<span id="page-149-5"></span><span id="page-149-4"></span>Specific acts of worship are to be limited to the one place God will choose. These include the burnt and sacrificial offerings, tithes, contributions, vows, voluntary offerings, and the offering of the firstborn. Worship is not limited, however, to pilgrimages to the central place, for that would allow very limited times of worship. Prayer and other forms of worship are not prohibited at the places people live. However, worship in Israel is to be distinguished by limiting certain corporate worship to one central place. Further, other worship is not to have any association with

<span id="page-150-12"></span>shrines like those used by the Canaanites. Such places of false worship continue to be present in Judah after the building of the temple from the time of Rehoboam (1 Kings 14:23), though Asa and Jehoshaphat make some attempt to control them (2 Chron. 14:3, 5; 17:6). Such worship is condemned under the covenant and is cited by the prophets as the reason God exiles Israel and Judah.

<span id="page-150-13"></span><span id="page-150-11"></span><span id="page-150-6"></span><span id="page-150-4"></span>12:8–12 The place of rest is the land God promised to Abraham (Deut. 3:20). The years of wilderness wanderings have required the people to adapt their worship to their situation. Entrance into the promised inheritance will provide for the peace and security necessary to honor God in his prescribed form of worship. This rest is achieved when the conquest of Joshua is complete (Josh. 21:43–45). Once the people are settled, times of worship at the place of God's choice will become festive occasions for all people, particularly those dependent on others because they have no property. This includes Israelite servants, possibly those who must work off debt incurred against their property (Ex. 21:2–6). Deuteronomy specifically includes Levites among the disadvantaged because they receive no property. Once worship is limited to a centralized location, the Levites will lose their normal sources of livelihood (cf. Deut. 18:1–5). Deuteronomy frequently appeals for the Levites to be included and provides a special tithe for them (14:28–29). Participation in the centralized festivities will partially compensate for former shares of sacrifices and donations.

<span id="page-150-10"></span><span id="page-150-9"></span><span id="page-150-7"></span><span id="page-150-5"></span><span id="page-150-2"></span><span id="page-150-1"></span>12:13–19 These verses clarify the situation of centralized worship. Legitimate sacrifices for worship must not be offered in the wrong place, namely, people's residences. Sacrifices must be offered at the sanctuary, where the blood can be sprinkled on the altar. It is debated whether Leviticus permits domestic animals slaughtered for food to be eaten away from the sanctuary; the question depends on whether the slaughter of an animal in Leviticus 17:1–7 includes those animals used for food or is limited to sacrificial animals. Deuteronomy makes this point clear in the new situation; domestic animals can be slaughtered for food and eaten anywhere (Hb. *zebakh* = "sacrifice," Deut. 12:6, 11; but in v. 15 it clearly means "slaughter"), just as hunted wild animals are. The only stipulation is that the blood cannot be eaten since it represents life, which can be given only by God (Gen. 9:2–4). Leviticus further specifies that when animals are killed the blood must be covered with earth (Lev. 17:13–14). Uncovered blood cries out for vengeance (Job 16:18). Deuteronomy clarifies the sacred aspect of blood; it is poured on the ground like water (Deut. 12:16), that is, blood is not in *itself* sacred but is like water in that it can represent something sacred.

<span id="page-150-14"></span><span id="page-150-8"></span><span id="page-150-3"></span><span id="page-150-0"></span>Domestic animals were used primarily for their products and for labor; only the wealthy could afford them for food. Further, meat could be eaten only when there were enough people to consume all of it so that there would be no spoilage. Consumption was therefore limited to special occasions such as festivals or honored guests. Nonsacrificial meat could be eaten away from the place of worship, and it was not necessary for one to be in a state of ritual purity to consume it. All sacred food, however, such as tithes, vows, voluntary offerings, and gifts, had to be eaten at the central sanctuary, where all people could participate and celebrate.

<span id="page-151-2"></span><span id="page-151-1"></span>12:20–28 When the Israelites come into full possession of their vast territory, it will become impossible from a practical point of view to slaughter meat for food at the central sanctuary. Meat is a desirable delicacy as part of the human diet, and there are times when one may simply have a desire for this rich food. Such a desire can be legitimately fulfilled, but at the same time this must be done with due respect to the life of the animal. The warning about blood is repeated (vv. 23–26). This indicates the seriousness of violating animal life and perhaps is a warning against carelessness. "You shall not eat the life" indicates that care must be taken to ensure the blood is properly removed in the process of slaughter—a key requirement of kosher food today. Neither is the blood to be used in an alternate form of food. A warning to be observant of all the sacrificial regulations concludes this section. The ritual regulations of Deuteronomy are less stringent than those of Leviticus, particularly regarding the avoidance of eating the fat (Lev. 3:17; 7:23, 25), while Deuteronomy especially emphasizes the sincere intentions of the worshiper.

<span id="page-151-6"></span><span id="page-151-5"></span><span id="page-151-3"></span><span id="page-151-0"></span>12:29–31 The Lord is granting the land of Canaan to Israel according to his promise. The danger is that the Israelites themselves might become like the Canaanites. The burning of infants as a dedication, offering one's most valuable gift to the gods, was a Canaanite practice (cf. 2 Kings 3:27). The actions of Ahaz in passing his sons through the fire (2 Chron. 28:3) appear to have been the dedication of a child to a deity through a ceremony involving fire (cf. Deut. 18:10), a practice that was also a Canaanite abomination.

#### <span id="page-151-4"></span>*Response*

This chapter is frank about the reality that Israel will not be an isolated nation. They will be living among the Canaanites with the constant temptation to compromise the way of life in which Moses has instructed them in the giving of the covenant. The chapter also implicitly recognizes the reality of the deception of such a compromise. It will not be perceived as a rejection of the covenant, because the Israelites will forget the exclusive nature of the God they have professed. They will fail to understand the significance of his holiness once they are immersed among the ideologies of other great and powerful peoples.

<span id="page-151-7"></span>The words of Jesus in his prayer for his disciples just before his crucifixion address the same situation as the words of Moses to Israel. In John 17:14–17 Jesus prays,

I have given them your word, and the world has hated them because they are not of the world, just as I am not of the world. I do not ask that you take them out of the world, but that you keep them from the evil one. They are not of the world, just as I am not of the world. Sanctify them in the truth; your word is truth.

<span id="page-152-0"></span>The disciples of Jesus are in the world just as Israel was in Canaan. Fidelity to the covenant depends on the Word of God, and as Moses will say, this Word is not too difficult and is not far away (Deut. 30:11). The difficulty is in carrying out this Word in the midst of a culture that challenges and even hates it.

<span id="page-152-1"></span>In postexilic times the place of worship becomes a highly contested matter, evident in the prominent temple remains on Mount Gerizim to this day. This temple is the reference point of the woman Jesus meets at the well in Samaria, who asks about the proper place of worship (John 4:20). In this text John points to the transformation of the place of worship through the words of Jesus. A physical temple is not vital to worship; knowledge of the one who is worshiped is in fact the key (John 4:23–24). Temples can only represent the presence of a holy God. The temple that Jesus builds is that of his church, where worship must take place (Eph. 2:19–22; 1 Pet. 2:4–5). The gathering of the church is where the Lord places his name—it is his temple.

<span id="page-152-4"></span><span id="page-152-2"></span>The Christian must ever recognize the critical importance of worship at the place where God has placed his name. Gathering to worship the holy God in spirit and in truth is critical to maintaining a distinct presence in the world and living in faithfulness to the covenant. The Christian must never neglect the regularity of coming to worship at the place God has chosen. A second element of the challenge emphasized by Moses is to worship God by caring about the concerns of God. Moses stresses that those concerns begin with the needs of the people of the covenant. When Israel settles into their farms they must not forget the disenfranchised, some of whom are disenfranchised for a special purpose, such as the Levites. Worship of God does not take place apart from the concerns of God. In Chronicles, once David has established the Levitical choirs, it is evident that singing praises in worship is important to the community. Deuteronomy calls attention to what is also essential, namely, caring for all the needs of those who come to the place where God has placed his name.

<span id="page-152-3"></span>Food is always a part of worship, as it is vital to human existence. In Israel a large part of the food at the place of worship is used to care for the poor. Meat is always a serious consideration in food consumption, as it involves taking the life of another living animal. In Israel sacrificial animals must be carefully distinguished from animals used for food, usually wild animals in ancient times. God grants animals as a means for food, but not without the required acknowledgment that humans receive all life as a gift. Blood represents that life and therefore is to be buried in proper recognition of the taking of the life of the animal. In Acts the church determines that this requirement should continue to be observed (Acts 15:20). A strangled animal is not bled and would be particularly offensive in the synagogue context. While this is not given as a permanent moral prohibition, it is a reminder of the importance of cultural considerations in all use of food. It is a further reminder that meat should not be treated as other plant food but that in some way the life of the animal is to be acknowledged. This is probably rarely considered by most Christians in the consumption of food, but there should be an

awareness of the special status of meat. Thought should be given to all the food we consume, with due consideration to the impact our food habits have on the proper worship of God.

#### *Section Overview: Incitement to Worship Other Gods*

The history of the covenant is a long account of the insidious nature of apostasy. The problem is not that apostasy is difficult to recognize. The boundaries of adherence to covenant faith are at times ambiguous, but if a community has a clear focus on the central tenets of the covenant commitment, then the continuously shifting responses to new ideas and questions need not be threatening. Much more problematic is the seduction of affiliation. There is inherent danger in the influence of an individual who has compromised the covenant faith by turning away from complete devotion to the one and only God. Resisting compromise to the covenant may require the breakup of families or communities. Apostate families may lead to the apostasy of whole communities. This is the progression warned against in this chapter.

<span id="page-154-1"></span>The challenge in all cases is to determine "if it be true and certain that such an abomination has been done" (13:14). False charges are as insidious as apostasy itself. Sometimes this is simply a matter of uncompromising pride over matters of opinion or, even worse, simple jealousy at the success of another person. But in Israel seduction becomes normal; the materialistic temptation of Baalism is a constant lure. The Baal religion always promises a little more. It can always be rationalized that it does not violate the covenant worship of Yahweh.

#### *Section Outline*

II.C.1. Instructions for Worship (12:1–16:17) . . .

- b. Seduction to False Worship (12:32–13:18)
	- (1) Adherence to This Torah (12:32)
	- (2) Seduction through a False Prophet (13:1–5)
	- (3) Seduction through Family Affiliation (13:6–11)
	- (4) Apostasy of an Entire Village (13:12–18)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-154-0"></span>12:32 In the section divisions of the Masoretic Text this verse is included in the conclusion to the regulations for proper worship, warning against any alteration of the requirement that sacrifice be limited to the place God will choose. However, the chapter divisions in the Masoretic Text and the LXX join this verse to the following

<span id="page-155-4"></span><span id="page-155-0"></span>section. This chapter division makes verse 32 a heading for the judgment against those who might incite sedition, an important literary introduction to the consequences of covenant violation. This warning not to add or take away (cf. 4:2) finds parallels in ancient treaty formulas, where such warnings serve to guard against any person who might change the stipulations of the oath that has been taken.

The lure of a materialistic Baal culture is a constant threat against loyalty to the covenant God. In Israel many voices would claim to have the power to bring the wealth of the Baal cult.

<span id="page-155-5"></span><span id="page-155-3"></span><span id="page-155-2"></span>13:1–5 Prophets, those who interpret dreams (oneiromancers) or produce evidence of signs, as Moses did before Pharaoh, represent revelatory authority. False prophecy is always a problem in Israel, especially since such prophecy is usually given in the name of Yahweh. Israel must know that any prophecy that compromises the total claim of God is sedition, for he is the one and only God (4:35, 39). False prophets may be able to provide evidence of authority, and such claims to power are a test to determine Israel's loyalty to God. This is the kind of trial that Israel faced in the wilderness to test their loyalty to him (8:2). Such tests can become temptations to deny trust in God and to follow other gods they do not know. Israel has experienced and knows the salvation of Yahweh, who brought them out of Egypt. A prophet who undermines such hope "has taught rebellion." Such a prophet is adding to the instruction of Moses; such words are sedition or rebellion (Hb. *sarah*), inflicting violence just as the false witness does in 19:16. Such false teaching is at the same time rebellion against God, because Israel knows there is no god among the nations who has led them as Yahweh has (4:6–7). There can be no mercy for such seduction into sedition; Israel must purge such a person from its midst.

<span id="page-155-8"></span><span id="page-155-7"></span><span id="page-155-1"></span>13:6–11 The second test of loyalty is more demanding, as the source is an intimate family member, specifically "the son of your mother," that is, a blood brother, a child, a spouse, or the closest of friends. The emphasis in this description is the deep emotional commitment to the person who is secretly seducing those nearest him to follow other gods. Familiar oaths of loyalty from royal courts began with condemning utterances of disloyalty in the king's family, then the family of friends, and finally any public person, such as a prophet. The oath is concerned entirely with stability in dynasty succession, not on the nature of family relationships. Moses places a deliberate emphasis on the most cherished of relationships because these are most easily prioritized ahead of loyalty to God. The Greek text compromises the intimacy of blood brothers with an additional phrase: "If your brother, the son *of your father* or your mother . . . entices you . . . you shall not assent" (vv. 6–8 AT [7–9 LXX]). This addition is frequently followed, but it appears to be the result of later legal interpretation of the texts. The concern of this passage is loyalty to God above the dearest of relationships; it is most difficult to expose them.

<span id="page-155-6"></span>A situation of seduction within the family cannot be compromised: "You shall not . . . spare him, nor shall you conceal him." The sense of this verse is not that of covering up the sedition as a means of delaying judgment. The form of the <span id="page-156-8"></span><span id="page-156-7"></span><span id="page-156-2"></span>expression corresponds to that of Nehemiah 4:5, which states, "Do not cover their guilt, and let not their sin be blotted out." This same sense is found in Jeremiah 18:23: "Forgive not their iniquity, nor blot out their sin." The point Moses is making is that there can be no pity nor forgiveness; this is a matter of treason against God. For this reason, "You shall kill him. Your hand shall be first against him" (Deut. 13:9). Many translators follow the Greek at this point (*anangellōn anangeleis peri autou*, "You shall make a report concerning him"; 13:10 LXX), sometimes without explanation. The Greek translator is making allowance for judicial procedure, such as that found in 17:2–4. The translation may have been influenced by legal interpretations familiar at the time of the translator. However, this passage is not about judicial procedure but about the necessity of purging falsehood from Israel in the most difficult of circumstances, namely, when the source of the seduction is someone with whom there is deep emotional attachment.

<span id="page-156-4"></span><span id="page-156-3"></span><span id="page-156-0"></span>13:12–18 The final situation concerns a sedition that encompasses an entire town, the consequence of not dealing with false prophecy when it begins. In this case, careful investigation must be made to ensure that the reports concerning such a city are as claimed. If they are true, the city is to be taken militarily, "devoting it to destruction." This act must be understood theologically; this is the same situation as pertained in the conquest of Sihon (2:31–37) and the rest of the land of Canaan (7:2–6). The *kherem*, as it is known in Hebrew, is a sanctity in which something that belongs to God is removed from all use in the sphere of common life. In the case of living beings, removal from life in the common means death. Unless such total dedication to God is carried out in the case of apostasy, removal of divine judgment is impossible.

<span id="page-156-6"></span><span id="page-156-5"></span><span id="page-156-1"></span>Israel experiences this in the case of Achan (Josh. 7:16–26). The city of Jericho is claimed by God; the defeat of Jericho is entirely the result of divine warfare. Achan does not accept the dictum that everything in Jericho now belongs to the realm of the holy (devoted). As a result, Israel suffers catastrophically in confrontation with the armies of Ai. Not until the *kherem* is removed from Israel—that is, Achan and all those complicit in his rebellion—can there be reconciliation with God. The same situation pertains for an apostate city as with the family of Achan. There is no record of how this may have been carried out in practice, though Judges 19–21 may serve as an example. The rabbis held that it was never to be applied, that the dictum was in the Torah merely for educational purposes. This passage is a theological statement concerning the relationship of the covenant. For Israel to have a holy relationship with God as a treasured people living in the land of Canaan, it is necessary to purge out of the realm of the common all that comes under the irrevocable judgment of God. It would be carried out representatively in the same way it was in the land of Canaan.The purging of apostasy is essential to Israel's observing the covenant commitment. This verse is transitional and serves both to conclude the necessity of preserving holiness by the removal of unfaithfulness and also to introduce the positive confessions of Israel in daily life that they are a

<span id="page-157-1"></span>kingdom of priests (Ex. 19:5–6). Israel is set apart among the nations to represent God to all the earth.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-157-2"></span><span id="page-157-0"></span>The only means of controlling apostasy is to eliminate it, beginning with the individual, which may very well involve family members, or, if necessary, removing a whole community from the common by dedicating it irrevocably to God by means of the *kherem* (13:16). It has been observed that the language of this chapter, especially 12:29–13:11, has a striking resemblance to the Assyrian loyalty oath (*ade*), a means used to maintain fidelity and control distant territories in the Neo-Assyrian Empire. Such oaths were required across the Assyrian Empire, as is evident in tablets recovered from Tell Taʻyinat (on the Orontes River, possibly the ancient biblical Calneh).40 These tablets bear the actual text of an oath required by Esarhaddon in 672 BC to ensure succession of his son Assurbanipal. Copies of this text would have been present in Judah, and the archaeological evidence indicates that the oath (*ade*) would have been on display within the temple during the days of Manasseh.

Based on literary similarity, it is alleged that the scribes of Deuteronomy relied on this Assyrian document to compose the oath commitments of this chapter, as well as some of the curses in chapter 28. Such claims are conjectural. The linguistic similarity does demonstrate that Deuteronomy, as should be expected, shares the language of oath culture common to the ancient Near Eastern world centuries before Esarhaddon. Our knowledge of these oath forms shows how the writing of Moses would have a powerful impact in the warning against adding or taking away from this Torah, to which Israel will swear allegiance when they enter the Promised Land. The concern of Moses is quite different from that of preserving a royal dynasty. He seeks to preserve the nation of Israel through loyalty to their King, Yahweh. He uses language for purging a family or community of dissidents like that used in royal households of great empires.

<span id="page-157-4"></span><span id="page-157-3"></span>Paul also warns against the insidious nature of apostasy. In the church at Ephesus were two such apostates, Hymenaeus and Philetus, who denied the resurrection, saying it was already past (2 Tim. 2:16–19). They apparently had adopted certain Greek philosophical ideas denying the importance of the body and were seeking to integrate these into Christian theology, as in later Gnosticism. This was a fatal compromise of an essential Christian doctrine (cf. 1 Cor. 15:35–49), not just a minor difference on eschatological views. Not only are such ideas worthless, but they spread like a cancer and lead some away from the faith. It is necessary to be intolerant of this kind of deviation in the church. The church found this very difficult, with the result that Gnosticism threatened to subvert the true church in the second century. In more recent times, the so-called Enlightenment has been no less a threat to Christianity, with its rise of deism. Deists attempt to define God their own way and mute his activity in the world.

<sup>40</sup> The full text and commentary of this treaty is provided by Jacob Lauinger, "Esarhaddon's Succession Treaty at Tell Taʻyinat: Text and Commentary," *JCS* 64 (2012): 87–123. An excellent introduction, translation, and commentary of the treaties is provided in D. J. Wiseman, "The Vassal-Treaties of Esarhaddon," *Iraq* 20/1 (Spring 1958). This is the best place to begin a study of the treaties.

Great revivalists such as John Wesley attempted to address this threat to the church, but today modernist churches are testimony to the way the cancer of autonomous humanism has spread throughout what once were vibrant Christian denominations. The words of Moses in this chapter must be applied with vigor.

### <span id="page-158-0"></span>DEUTERONOMY 14:1–21

1Or *addax* 2The identity of many of these birds is uncertain

#### *Section Overview: Instructions for Holiness*

<span id="page-158-1"></span>This section begins and ends with the statement that Israel is holy (14:2, 21). Holiness is a category that designates the person and being of God. Separateness is fundamental to the sense of being holy, and as a category for God, it distinguishes <span id="page-159-8"></span>him from all creation. In biblical thought, everything in the universe is dependent on God. Fundamental to this conception is the presence of life. Life is not innate to the material elements; it is continuously infused by God into the order of creation (Ps. 104:29). Therefore, to belong to the holy is to have life; separation from the holy is death. These concepts seem to be the basis of the ritual confessions demanded in these verses.

<span id="page-159-6"></span><span id="page-159-5"></span><span id="page-159-3"></span><span id="page-159-2"></span>The assertion "You are a people holy to the Lord your God, and the Lord has chosen you to be a people for his treasured possession" (Deut. 14:2) is virtually a repetition of what Moses said in 7:6. In that context, Israel was to separate itself from the Canaanites by putting them under the *kherem*, that is, separating them irrevocably to God. In this case, Moses forbids certain foods because they are an "abomination" (14:3)—they are identified exclusively with pagan practice. In contrast, Israelites are "sons of the Lord" (v. 1), and they must distinguish themselves as belonging to the family of Yahweh. The stipulations of this chapter are a way for Israel to express its adherence to the covenant. The designated foods are made to be representative of the life and wholeness that characterize those who belong to God. There is no indication in the text that forbidden foods are inherently unclean or unhealthy. They may be perfectly acceptable for those who do not confess the covenant; Moses simply says that these foods are "unclean for you" (vv. 7, 8, 10, 19). The classifications that follow in this chapter are part of a systematic ordering of ideas that make them significant only for those following these rituals.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-159-9"></span><span id="page-159-4"></span><span id="page-159-1"></span><span id="page-159-0"></span>14:1–2 As children of God, Israel must honor God as their Father (5:16). Parents are the means for children to receive life and its provisions. God is the creator of Israel, but he also cares for them and corrects them as a father (1:31; 8:5). Participating in pagan cultic ritual is a denial of holiness. Cutting oneself was a Canaanite practice of mourning, often accompanied by shaving the head and beard, tearing the clothes, and wearing sackcloth. It was intended as sympathetic magic to appease the gods or influence them to show favor. In one Ugaritic myth, the god Latipan mourns the death of Baal by scraping his skin, shaving his beard, and plowing his chest. This is similarly a sign of the Philistines' mourning at impending judgment (Jer. 47:5). Likewise Moab's citizens cut their hands and shaved their heads as signs

<span id="page-160-11"></span>of mourning (Jer. 48:37). The prohibition in Israel is based on the sacredness of life and respect of the human body. These are a gift of the holy, for God is their Father.

<span id="page-160-7"></span><span id="page-160-6"></span><span id="page-160-5"></span>14:3–8 Clean animals include three types of domesticated bovids (Deut. 14:4) and seven types of undomesticated bovids of the deer family, or caprines (vv. 5). Four animals are examples of forbidden food, particularly the rabbit, rock badger, camel, and pig. The rabbit and rock badger are not ungulates or ruminants, but they do chew their food a long time and may appear to chew the cud. It is not possible to specifically identify all of the ancient designations with known animals.

<span id="page-160-3"></span><span id="page-160-2"></span>The list of land animals in Leviticus is expanded to include insects, rodents, and reptiles. All grasshoppers, those insects that have four legs and leap, are acceptable for food (Lev. 11:20–21). A list of forbidden rodents and reptiles is provided (Lev. 11:29–30), whose impurity is even more consequential than that of land, sea, or sky creatures. The prohibitions include everything that moves on its belly (snakes) or other insects with any number of legs (Lev. 11:41–42); these creatures are regarded as repugnant and "detestable" (Hb. *sheqets*) for food and make the person unclean.

<span id="page-160-8"></span><span id="page-160-4"></span>14:9–10 Water animals are only distinguished by a general rule in both Deuteronomy and Leviticus.

<span id="page-160-9"></span>14:11–20 No general rule is provided for distinguishing between edible and forbidden birds. Those birds that are forbidden are listed, a list exclusive to predators and scavengers. Modern classifications place the bat among mammals because its young are born alive and are nursed by their mother. Ancient classification operated according to simpler anatomical criteria: bats have wings. All "winged insects [*sherets*]" refers to all manner of swarming bugs; these are forbidden as in Leviticus.

<span id="page-160-10"></span><span id="page-160-1"></span><span id="page-160-0"></span>14:21 Hunters and farmers kill their own food. Exodus 22:31 stipulates that the remains of anything killed by an animal must be given to dogs. These might be clean animals, but the means of death has rendered them unfit for food. The reason given is that the people of Israel are to be holy, the status they received by making the covenant at Sinai (Ex. 19:6). Leviticus 17:15 stipulates that eating food prepared from an animal that has not been slaughtered renders the person unclean. There are two possibilities for such food. It may be given to sojourners, non-Israelite neighbors, because they were usually landless and poor, not part of the covenant. Or it may be sold to a foreigner, an individual present in order to conduct business. Ritual purity did not pertain in such cases because these people were not part of the covenant; they were not set apart as holy.

While animals are part of human food, there is always the recognition that animals carry the gift of life no less than humans do. Humans are not entitled to kill animals without reason. Rather, humans are permitted to use animals for food, always acknowledging that this is a gift of God in the present order. The prohibition against consuming blood is a confession of this concession and an acknowledgement that animal life itself does not belong to humans. The prohibition against certain kinds of food preparation falls in the same category. In Israel, <span id="page-161-0"></span>meat would have been eaten at festivals. In Exodus the command not to boil a kid in its mother's milk is part of the festival stipulations (Ex. 23:19; 34:26). The fall festival would be the time at which young goats born that previous spring might be eaten. Here the command is part of provisions for eating meat. Similar stipulations require the young of cattle to be left with their mother at least a week before being made a gift to God, and similar stipulations forbid the slaughtering of cattle on the same day as their young or capturing a bird with her young or her eggs (Lev. 22:27–28; Deut. 22:6–7). Meat boiled in sour milk is much tastier than when simply cooked in water. The prohibition is that this must not be the milk of its mother, recognizing that she is the bearer of this life. It is likely that a kid is mentioned because of the festival contexts of this prohibition elsewhere, but the same rule would pertain to the young of cattle or sheep.

#### <span id="page-161-1"></span>*Response*

The ordering of clean and unclean is an enigma that has generated numerous explanations. Going back to the medieval period, Jewish interpreters, some with a medical background, argued for hygienic reasons, but some of these foods, such as the pig, were commonly eaten and used in religious rituals in ancient times. These are seemingly arbitrary classifications to all those outside the system that gave them significance. The reasons that guide categories of clean and unclean can only be partially discerned, but they have to do with representing holiness, the converse of death.41 An animal that has died may be sold to a non-Israelite neighbor (Deut. 14:21) but is not suitable for Israel. Animals associated with death are prohibited, including all scavengers and carnivorous animals. Pigs and vultures are principally scavengers. High-carriage land animals are classified as clean if they share the characteristics of those raised for food. For pastoralists, these are ruminants with divided hooves. Fish, birds, and insects seem to be further classified by appearance of wholeness or completeness, another way of representing well-ordered life.

<span id="page-161-2"></span>Food for the person outside the purity system of the tabernacle or temple is regulated only by health concerns, as it was in the time of Israel for the sojourner and the foreigner. Jesus declares unequivocally that a person is made unclean or common not by anything that enters the mouth but by that which comes out of the mouth, that is, words (Matt. 15:10–11). Consideration should be given to the sensitivities of others, as decided at the Council of Jerusalem (Acts 15:20), but these are concessions for the sake of peace.

<span id="page-161-4"></span><span id="page-161-3"></span>Modern food stipulations based on environmental or economic activism are of an entirely different order, with no relevance to holiness, the concern of this chapter. These are considered by some to be ethical issues, but in virtually all cases are ridden with subjectivity. Even medical concerns not only change but even reverse over time, as may be frequently observed.

#### *Section Overview: Provisions for the Poor*

<span id="page-163-0"></span>The fourth section on worship in the exposition of this Torah is concerned with regular life cycles that are the means of honoring God. The weekly Sabbath is not developed beyond what is given in the Ten Words (Deut. 5:12–15), where it is a sign (confession) of the rest of redemption. The weekly Sabbath is a significant part of economic and social life, though the details of how it should be practiced, such as how work is defined, are never given. The requirement of worship at one central place also bears a substantial impact on annual life activities. The principal requirements of life order are now given by Moses.

<span id="page-163-1"></span>Food requirements occupy much of all human activity and thus are a very important part of the way in which God must be honored. Food has already been a significant topic in instructions for the life of individual Israelites. Moses now turns to the more general topic of agricultural produce, instructing Israel on the provisions of the agricultural cycle and on incorporating pilgrimages to the central shrine into crop production. For the individual living under the covenant, every activity is in some sense an act of worship through which honor is given to God. Israelites could not make a distinction between things a modern society might call secular and those it calls religious. In Israelite life, social matters (such as care for the poor, giving of the tithe, and pilgrimage to the central shrine) are all part of one integrated system. The giving of the tithe and the firstborn to God are both a matter of learning to "fear the Lord your God always" (14:23). Sowing crops, raising livestock, keeping the Sabbath, and going on pilgrimage festivals are all equally a part of giving honor to God.

<span id="page-164-4"></span>Possession of land is fundamental to life provision in an agrarian society. Deuteronomy is especially alert to the fact that not everyone possesses land. Orphans and widows either do not have access to land or are not able to farm it sufficiently to make a living. Such people constitute the "poor" (Hb. *ʾebyon*; 15:4), a word indicating dependent economic status. This is understood primarily in terms of honor. The poor are the humble (*ʿoni* ) because without their own land they are always in need of help. To care for the poor is to honor them, but more importantly this honors God and becomes the means of blessing. Another situation is loss of use of land through misadventure or simply an inability to farm successfully. These Israelites become indentured, creating a condition in which "your brother . . . is sold to you" (15:12), meaning that this family comes to be in the employ of its benefactors until the obligations are paid. Such dependency can become an endless cycle of debt, contrary to the principle that each person should have freedom to work his own land. Provision for this contingency is made a part of the cycles of the annual calendar according to the Sabbath principle of seven. This cycle operates in days, weeks, months, and years as explained in these provisions for daily life.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-164-2"></span><span id="page-164-1"></span><span id="page-164-0"></span>14:22–27 Only Deuteronomy mandates a tithe of all produce be set aside and taken to the central sanctuary. Other texts give instructions for tithing, but they have more the appearance of an offering than an obligation (Num. 18:21–32; Lev. 27:30–32). In Deuteronomy this is one of the obligations of worship. It may also be a part of the special concern in Deuteronomy for those dependent on the tithe. The tithe here is specified only for three types of produce. This tithe would amount to over a month's supply of these foods. The details of how it is to be dispensed at the temple are not specified, other than that it is eaten as a festival celebration. It may be that the tithe is to be brought at the time of the fall festival pilgrimage, when the harvest is complete, since that is the only time it can be calculated. Since there are three festivals, each a week in length, it may be that food is to be stored there until the next harvest.

<span id="page-164-3"></span>It is not intended for the entire tithe to be consumed by the person bringing the offering. Rather this is the means by which all the Levites (which would include the priests) could join together in the celebration, as specified in Deut. 14:27. Such festivals are not merely a means of celebrating redemption and the divine

blessing; they are also a means of supporting the whole temple system and all the dependents of the people. The logistics would change over time, as evident from the support system of the temple outlined in the last chapter of Leviticus. The tithe there also includes animals (Lev. 27:32–33), which could not be redeemed but belonged to the temple.

<span id="page-165-4"></span><span id="page-165-2"></span>It would not be practical to bring the tithe to the central sanctuary from a distance because of the great quantity of food "when the Lord your God blesses you" (Deut. 14:24). The food would be sold for silver (minted coins did not exist at this time in Israel) and then exchanged for any kind of food desirable for the festival. The tithes and provision of the firstborn animals legislated in Deuteronomy would be a generous contribution for the Levites and all other needy people, as well as providing for a celebration for the farmer of the blessing of harvest.

<span id="page-165-5"></span>14:28–29 The tithe of the third and sixth years are taken not to the central sanctuary but to the gate of the local city. These tithes are to be distributed there to the landless, namely, the Levites, non-Israelite neighbors, orphans, and widows. This provision would extend for two years and would be an important way of honoring the Lord with daily work. This kind of generosity is the means of blessing. Societies that provide for their poor will always receive much more benefit in return.

<span id="page-165-3"></span>This tithe for the Levites is not reconciled with the tithe for the Levites specified in Numbers 18:21–32. There the entire tithe is given to the Levites; the Levites in turn give a tithe of this amount to the priests. Since Deuteronomy envisages a much later time in the history of Israel, with a king, central sanctuary, and pilgrimages, it may be that the legislation of Numbers provides for the earlier centuries, when Israel is a tribal federation.

<span id="page-165-1"></span>No tithe is specified for the seventh year, since in that year the land is not to be cropped. One aspect of the Sabbath confession is a seventh year in addition to the seventh day (Ex. 23:10–12). In that year it is made clear that all of the land belongs to the Lord, as the yield of the land is made freely available for everyone.

<span id="page-165-9"></span><span id="page-165-6"></span><span id="page-165-0"></span>15:1–6 These verses speak of a seven-year cycle, much like the requirement for the land to lie fallow in the seventh year for the sake of the poor (Ex. 23:10–11). These verses seem to presume that practice but add to it the requirement for debts to be released as well. This was the practice in the time of Nehemiah, at least (Neh. 10:31). Debts would normally come due at harvest time, the occasion of new revenue. If debts cannot be paid in years in which there is crop revenue, they must be waived in the seventh year, which includes no harvest for the landowner. The person owing the money is "his neighbor, his brother" (Deut. 15:2), most likely an actual relative but certainly a fellow Hebrew. This remission does not pertain to business debts that might be made with other non-Israelites. The main objective is to provide relief from indebtedness that can result in the inability to recover the use of one's own land.

<span id="page-165-8"></span><span id="page-165-7"></span>Remission of debt establishes stability within the community. This is fundamental to covenant relationship, as emphasized in the exhortation of verses 4–6. Israel is not to have within her bounds any poor who are not in some way provided for by the care of the community.

<span id="page-166-8"></span><span id="page-166-7"></span>15:7–11 Since the seventh year can be calculated, it might be tempting to deny help in the fifth or sixth year, knowing there might be no repayment at all. But the spirit of the covenant is not to do as little as possible in order to meet the demands of the covenant. The goal is always to provide as much help as needed; when the poor are provided for, everyone fares better. This is the way that "God will bless you" (v. 10). That "there will never cease to be poor" (v. 11) might seem to be a contradiction to the assertion that "there will be no poor" (v. 4), but each of these statements speaks to the same reality. There will always be people who come into poverty; illness and death are not respecters of persons. On the other hand, a society that always cares for those in difficult circumstances will always benefit.

<span id="page-166-10"></span><span id="page-166-9"></span><span id="page-166-6"></span><span id="page-166-2"></span><span id="page-166-1"></span>15:12–18 Provision for forgiveness of debt is to be made in accordance with the seven-year sabbatical cycle. A more severe form of debt would be a case in which someone can no longer borrow money but is required to give up land as collateral and enter the service of his creditor. The time of such servitude is limited to seven years. The seven-year period of labor is not related to the sabbatical cycle but begins when the person starts the term of service. The provisions for a maximum of six years of service are related to those found in Exodus 21:1–2. Deuteronomy augments those provisions in several respects. Freedom is inclusive of female as well as male servants (Deut. 15:12). In Exodus a woman in debt servitude is under the control of her master (Ex. 21:4, 7–10); if the master has given the servant as a wife, she remains with the master. If a man gives his daughter for debt, the master must let her be redeemed or treat her as a wife. As in the case of the tenth word, concerning coveting (Ex. 20:17; Deut. 5:21), the woman is given an independent status in Deuteronomy, demonstrating a consistent concern for the rights of the woman. A further benefit in Deuteronomy is that all debt servants must be given abundant provision in order to enable them to regain independent status (15:13–15). The regulations for indebted servants make provision for someone to permanently work for another person if he decides that is preferable.

<span id="page-166-11"></span><span id="page-166-5"></span><span id="page-166-4"></span><span id="page-166-3"></span><span id="page-166-0"></span>The jubilee regulations for release of debt servants and restoration of property make provisions for the clan, aggregates of families that are a subset of the tribe. Those regulations prevent loss of property to the tribe. Under those regulations, release from debt and the restoration of property happens on the fiftieth year (Lev. 25:10, 13, 28). If a family becomes indentured to a benefactor, it works only until the fiftieth year, at which time it returns to its clan (Lev. 25:39–41). A fifty-year span would encompass most of the life of an individual. Freedom in the fiftieth year is thus not as relevant to the individual as it is to the group, which is to be reintegrated with its tribal family. In this way one tribe does not lose property to another. This is in keeping with the principle that women who inherit land must marry within their own tribe (Num. 36:5–9). In addressing situations of debt relating to the clan, Leviticus makes no mention of the seven-year release provided for in Deuteronomy.

It is likely that the jubilee law of Leviticus addresses the situation of the person who chooses to become a permanent debt servant. The commitment of servitude would not extend perpetually for the family, which would receive its freedom in the fiftieth year. In this way property would always revert to the original clan and families would be able to live in self-sufficiency. There were to be no permanent debt-servant clans.

<span id="page-167-0"></span>Israel is reminded repeatedly of the redemption that they received when slaves in Egypt. They are children of God (Deut. 14:1), and thus they are expected to conduct their lives according to the mercy they have received from their father. Laws of debt relief are to be regarded not as a burden but as a testimony to their own beliefs about how God redeemed them from slavery.

#### *Response*

Modern thinking attempts to separate secular life from religious faith, as if these had no relation to each other. This is manifest in presumed rights and freedoms that promise freedom of faith apart from any state interference. In Christianity, such a distinction is impossible. Christian faith demands an integration of all areas of life, as assumed by the instruction of Moses concerning worship. Economic affairs, property, and care for the poor are as integral to the practice of faith and covenant as is any other ritual. Further, the values defined as secular function as the equivalent to those of faith; in practice, such "secular" values are a religious or faith system. The inability to separate these spheres makes living the Christian life a challenge, as demands imposed by the state may well contradict those held by the Christian. These can include matters of taxation or other benefits. In Canada, for example, job funding universally available to help the poor is withheld from anyone who does not support the state provision of abortion without restriction, even at the point of childbirth. Such job funding is supposed to help the poor, but it is available only to those adhering to what is in effect a state religious policy.

<span id="page-167-3"></span><span id="page-167-2"></span>The apostle Paul explains the continuum of faith and life in his teaching that the Christian has a new mind created in righteousness and true holiness (Eph. 4:23–24). This new way of thinking affects the most fundamental aspects of life, especially work and words (vv. 25–30). Paul's exhortation is that work should be performed for the purpose of being able to give to those in need. Words must be spoken only when they are edifying to those who hear them. These are the very kind of values Moses is eliciting in this chapter. The purpose of work is to support fellow property owners and the community. This is not the spirit of the adversarial relationship between unions and employers that affects many Christians in western society. Living the teaching of Moses in the contemporary situation is a real challenge if one seeks earnestly to maintain the values of faith for life.

<span id="page-167-1"></span>In the Sermon on the Mount Jesus uses this passage from Deuteronomy in his own instruction concerning work and well-being (Matt. 6:19–24). There he employs three metaphors: laying up of treasures, clarity of vision, and attempting to serve two masters. The second of these metaphors has to do with focus of <span id="page-168-2"></span><span id="page-168-0"></span>vision. Disciples have their focus on the kingdom of God, a clear vision. If their "eye is bad" (Matt. 6:23), they are disadvantaged as a blind man. The evil eye is drawn from Deuteronomy 15:9, an expression of resentment over the obligation to help a poor brother just before the year of remittance of debt. This is the attitude of stinginess rather than the desire to help another in need. Disciples of Jesus will seek to follow the teaching of Moses in working their best to help those in need in every way they can.

You shall do no work with the firstborn of your herd, nor shear the firstborn of your flock. **20**You shall eat it, you and your household, before the Lord your God year by year at the place that the Lord will choose. **21**But if it has any blemish, if it is lame or blind or has any serious blemish whatever, you shall not sacrifice it to the Lord your God. **22**You shall eat it within your towns. The unclean and the clean alike may eat it, as though it were a gazelle or a deer. **23**Only you shall not eat its blood; you shall pour it out on the ground like water.

you. **11**And you shall rejoice before the Lord your God, you and your son and your daughter, your male servant and your female servant, the Levite who is within your towns, the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow who are among you, at the place that the Lord your God will choose, to make his name dwell there. **12**You shall remember that you were a slave in Egypt; and you shall be careful to observe these statutes.

<span id="page-169-2"></span>**<sup>13</sup>** "You shall keep the Feast of Booths seven days, when you have gathered in the produce from your threshing floor and your winepress. **14**You shall rejoice in your feast, you and your son and your daughter, your male servant and your female servant, the Levite, the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow who are within your towns. **15**For seven days you shall keep the feast to the Lord your God at the place that the Lord will choose, because the Lord your God will bless you in all your produce and in all the work of your hands, so that you will be altogether joyful.

**<sup>16</sup>** "Three times a year all your males shall appear before the Lord your God at the place that he will choose: at the Feast of Unleavened Bread, at the Feast of Weeks, and at the Feast of Booths. They shall not appear before the Lord empty-handed. **17**Every man shall give as he is able, according to the blessing of the Lord your God that he has given you."

#### *Section Overview: Ceremonies at the Central Sanctuary*

Deuteronomy emphasizes the social aspect of temple, sacrifices, and offerings. Sacral offerings are consumed by the person coming to the sanctuary, where they are shared with the poor, the widow, the orphan, and the Levite. This continuous emphasis leaves the impression that the primary purpose of sacrifice is nutrition for the needy. Deuteronomy teaches an aspect of sacrifice not found in the covenant instructions given at Sinai. The rituals declared at Sinai, so essential to the understanding of Yahweh, are assumed in Deuteronomy. The practical manifestation of faith, keeping the covenant by caring for the community, is the constant emphasis of Deuteronomy. A complete understanding of the covenant requires both theology and its implementation. After the utter failures of the rebellious generation of the wilderness, the renewal of the covenant quite appropriately emphasizes the responsibilities of the individual to the community in the Promised Land.

<span id="page-169-1"></span><span id="page-169-0"></span>The ceremonies at the central sanctuary consist of offerings of firstborn animals and three pilgrimage festivals. All three festivals bear a relationship to the agricultural cycle, which is integrated with the confession of Israel's redemption and covenant with God. No time is specified for the offering of the firstborn, whereas the annual pilgrimage festivals begin with the first harvest of the agricultural year (16:1–2). The pilgrimage festivals operate on the basis of the number seven. Seven weeks are counted from the first of the grain harvest to the harvest festival celebration, and in the seventh month of the year a final celebration is held after the entire crop has been gathered (v. 13). Passover celebrates redemption from Egypt, while the harvest festival implicitly celebrates the giving of the law that took place in the third month after Israel left Egypt (Ex. 19:1; cf. Deut. 16:12). The great festival of harvest celebrates God's redemptive provision in the wilderness.

The restriction of limiting the offering of the firstborn and the observance of the festivals to the central location will result in significant changes in social structure and the function of the priesthood. Deuteronomy anticipates these changes, so the practice of the rituals is accommodated accordingly, whether it be the dedication of the firstborn or the celebration of the Passover. The ritual confession is not a matter of unalterable regulations; it is always a confession of the covenant. The practice of the rituals therefore is modified to accommodate changed circumstances. This is an alteration not of the covenant but of specific practices to provide for the ideals of covenant observance. The effort of the rabbis in harmonizing the ritual into a single legislative system misunderstood its purpose. Ritual is not a system of regulation but a means of spiritual formation as well as a confession of beliefs.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-170-3"></span><span id="page-170-0"></span>15:19–23 The firstborn of an animal belongs to the Lord, just as the firstfruits of the crop do. This is one way of making the confession that God is the source and owner of all life. This confession is first found in the creation narrative, with the offerings of Cain and Abel (Gen. 4:2–4). Both the farmer and the herdsman brought offerings appropriate to the divine blessing. The teaching of Deuteronomy is already implicit in the Genesis account. The offering of the first of the harvest and of animals must be done as a confession of love and fear of Yahweh. Abel offered the choicest of the firstborn; Cain merely brought an offering. Ritual apart from the faith commitment of the participant has no merit.

<span id="page-170-2"></span><span id="page-170-1"></span>In Deuteronomy, the offering of the firstborn is done at the central sanctuary and is eaten by the herdsman making the offering. This appears to be an advancement of the earlier requirements. In the original covenant, the offering of the firstborn of clean animals belongs to the Lord as a confession of the slaying of the firstborn in Egypt and the sparing of Israel at the time of the exodus (Ex. 13:11– 15). Unclean animals and the firstborn of humans are redeemed. Deuteronomy is also a development of the law of the firstborn as given in the wilderness. There the firstborn belongs to the *kherem*, that is, the irrevocable dedication that cannot be redeemed (Num. 18:14). In Numbers, humans and unclean animals can be redeemed; unclean animals may be bought back by the owner for use on his farm. All other firstfruits and the firstborn of animals are proscribed. In this case, they must be eaten by the families of the priests. Leviticus conforms to the regulation of

<span id="page-171-8"></span><span id="page-171-7"></span><span id="page-171-3"></span>Numbers in declaring that the firstborn is *kherem* (Lev. 27:26–29). Leviticus includes humans in the items that may be so proscribed, such as someone guilty of a capital crime (Ex. 22:20). In Deuteronomy, Moses makes the individual making the offering responsible to "dedicate" it to the Lord (*qadash*; Deut. 15:19), which does not make its use exclusive to the sanctuary or the priests. It is, however, a sacred meal, probably reflecting the circumstances of a later time in which worship was limited to the single place the Lord would choose. There was no longer a need to support clergy at the more local sanctuaries.

<span id="page-171-9"></span><span id="page-171-5"></span><span id="page-171-4"></span>16:1–8 Passover celebrates the exodus from Egypt. It consists of two festivals: the sacrifice of the Passover animal and the seven-day festival of *mazzot*, the Feast of Unleavened Bread (cf. Lev. 23:6). Since the Passover meal also involves unleavened bread, the two are described as one (Lev. 23:4). The time of the feast is calculated according to the moon of the month of "Abib" (= "new ears of grain"). In later Babylonian nomenclature, this is the month of Nisan. Since the lunar cycle was also the basis of the agricultural calendar, the months had to be kept concurrent with the seasons. Twelve lunar cycles constitute only 354 days, requiring the periodic addition of a lunar equivalent. At some point the Babylonians determined that 235 lunar cycles equaled 19 solar cycles, so they could be very precise in integrating 7 lunar months during a 19-year period. Modern-day Passover is celebrated on a modification of that cycle.

<span id="page-171-10"></span><span id="page-171-6"></span><span id="page-171-2"></span><span id="page-171-1"></span><span id="page-171-0"></span>"Passover" is a translation of the Hebrew *pesakh.* The origin of this term cannot be determined, but it has the sense of "protective sacrifice." The English term *Passover* comes from the Latin translation; the LXX uses the verb *skepazō* for the Lord's covering or protecting the Israelites (Ex. 12:13; cf. Isa. 31:5). Making the Passover sacrifice into a pilgrimage festival brings about modifications. The meal is no longer celebrated as a family, with the blood of the sacrificial lamb smeared on the doorposts and lintel. It becomes a communal event in which a larger animal can be chosen from the sheep or goats (Ex. 12:5). Deuteronomy 16:2 includes bovines, which later Jewish exegesis takes to be additional offerings (cf. 2 Chron. 35:7–13). It is no longer specified that the animal be roasted (Ex. 12:8), only that it must be cooked (Hb. *bashal* often means "to boil"). The Passover is to be eaten with unleavened bread, signifying the hasty circumstance of the flight from Egypt. The urgency of harvest requires the pilgrim to return home following the Passover sacrifice, but he is to continue eating unleavened bread for six more days (Deut. 16:7–8). Leaven is to be removed from the entire territory (v. 4), not just from the central sanctuary. On the seventh day after the sacrifice, counting the day as beginning at sunset, a festal gathering is to be held. This would take place in the various towns and cities to which the pilgrims return—only the sacrificial food is to be consumed at the central place. Deuteronomy only mentions the assembled festival for the Passover, but the other festivals had one as well (Lev. 23:21, 35–36). The conclusion of unleavened bread takes place at home during the height of harvest, when greater temptation to neglect the duties of the festival might be present.

<span id="page-172-5"></span><span id="page-172-0"></span>16:9–12 The Feast of Weeks derives its name from the method used to calculate its date. The feast is unique in that a precise date for the celebration of the feast is not given. The counting begins with an offering of the first sheaf of the harvest on the day after the Sabbath (Lev. 23:10–11). The time of harvest varies from year to year and place to place, depending on the weather. It is possible the time of the feast would vary from region to region. Debate has centered on whether the Sabbath specified is a Sunday or the day after the Sabbath of a festival, such as the first day of Unleavened Bread. A later halachic ruling used the latter interpretation to state that the first sheaf must be brought on the second day of the feast, namely, the sixteenth of Nisan, so the Feast of Weeks always falls on the seventh of Sivan in the Babylonian calendar (May/June). The Torah simply specifies that it be the first day after the Sabbath.

<span id="page-172-1"></span>Harvest is a festive time. The offerings of harvest are voluntary according to the blessing of the harvest. A time of plenty may be expected to be a time of greater generosity. According to Leviticus, the Feast of Weeks is also a solemn assembly in which no work is done (Lev. 23:16–21). It consists of offerings of loaves made of new grain as firstfruits of the harvest. The various offerings by fire make it a complete festal occasion.

<span id="page-172-8"></span><span id="page-172-4"></span>At least by the time of the second temple, the Feast of Weeks became the occasion to dramatize the revelatory event at Sinai, known in Hebrew as the *zeman mattan Toratenu* ("time when our Torah was given"), and to make a renewed oath of the giving of the law. This may be the festival setting of Psalms 50 and 81. These festal psalms are a proclamation of the theophany and celebration of the commandments in another era. The day of the assembly, as expressed in Deuteronomy 9:10; 10:4, was when Israel received the Word of God through an apparently dramatized ritual and then took upon themselves the Ten Words by covenant and oath. This was the counterpart to the dramatization of the exodus at Passover and of the wilderness by the erection of booths. In 2 Chronicles 15:8–15 we read of a great assembly under King Asa in the third month, in which participants come from Ephraim, Manasseh, Benjamin, Judah, and Simeon. They offer sacrifices, enter a covenant to seek the Lord with all their heart and soul, and take oaths to the accompaniment of blasts from the trumpets and shofar (cf. Ps. 81:3). All this is done with great joy, which may speak to the occasion of a festival in which the rite of a covenant renewal is observed.

<span id="page-172-9"></span><span id="page-172-7"></span>The celebration of Weeks is much better known from later Jewish writings and the NT. As is typical in Deuteronomy, there is no attention to accompanying festal celebrations, such as those mentioned in Leviticus. The emphasis is entirely on being proportionately generous to the blessing of the harvest.

<span id="page-172-6"></span><span id="page-172-3"></span><span id="page-172-2"></span>16:13–15 Booths is a full, eight-day festival, with sacred assemblies on the first and last days (cf. Lev. 23:33–36). The festival takes place after all the harvest has been gathered. Booths is characterized by ceremonies of festal processions adorned with fruits and decorative palms (Lev. 23:40). As the last of the harvest, this is the most joyous of festivals. It is also the time of year when the labor of the field is

<span id="page-173-4"></span>not pressing. According to Deuteronomy 31:10–13, this is the occasion of the teaching of the Torah every seventh year. In later Jewish tradition this is also the time of prayers for rain.

<span id="page-173-5"></span><span id="page-173-1"></span>The Festival of Booths is explicitly connected in Leviticus 23:42–43 to the time of wilderness wanderings. The connection of Booths to the time of the wilderness is not self-evident, for at that time Israel lived in tents. Booths are connected to harvest, when the fruit is ripening and being gathered. Booths are set up in the fields for shelter from sun and rain (e.g., Isa. 1:8). An apt symbol for the completion of the harvest and the celebration of bounty is a booth of the type used in the fields at harvest. This also becomes a way of remembering God's bountiful provision during the years of wilderness wandering.

<span id="page-173-3"></span>16:16–17 God is the sovereign King, who reigns from the temple. His subjects are required to appear before him in acknowledgement of his rule. Only adult males of the family are obligated to make their appearance three times a year at the central sanctuary. The celebrations themselves are inclusive, as is repeatedly emphasized. There may be a practical side to this requirement's being limited to males, as nursing mothers and young children could not easily make a journey of several days.

<span id="page-173-2"></span><span id="page-173-0"></span>The Passover sacrifice is here referred to as the Feast of Unleavened Bread. The obligation at the sanctuary is limited to the night of the Passover (Deut. 16:7), and the workers then return home but eat unleavened bread for seven days. According to the instructions of the Passover, the Feast of Unleavened Bread begins on the fourteenth day of the month, in the evening (Ex. 12:6). The summary appropriately concludes with the emphasis of social responsibility present in the entire section: each family must be represented, bearing gifts in proportion to the way that God has blessed them. The goal of prosperity is the ability to give more.

#### *Response*

Deuteronomy does not repeat or alter the function of the priesthood found in Leviticus. The ritual in Leviticus focuses on the work of the priests in the daily ritual of the temple. That ritual is intended to declare the holiness of God as the source of all life. The confession of Yahweh made in temple ritual positions the priest as a mediator between those in the realm of mortality and the Giver of life, symbolized in the Most Holy Place. The temple and priesthood declare perpetually that God is the continuous source of life to ward off the power of death, which threatens in many ways. This aspect of declaring the divine presence in the world of the common is not explicit in Deuteronomy. The covenant that Moses renews with Israel does not negate this ritual but brings to it a different emphasis: the personal role and responsibility of the individual Israelite in providing for life. Expiation is accomplished by the confessions of the person making an offering, not by the illocutionary declarations of a priest. This ritual is a very important confession, but it has no merit as an independent activity. The faith of the persons making the offerings is essential for it to be efficacious, which is the constant emphasis of Deuteronomy.

<span id="page-174-1"></span>Relationship with God is not found in either observance of ritual or the performance of good deeds. As expressed in Psalm 40, a relationship with God is established and maintained by faith, which expresses itself in the desire to do the will of God:

 In sacrifice and offering you have not delighted, but you have given me an open ear. Burnt offering and sin offering you have not required. Then I said, "Behold I have come; in the scroll of the book it is written of me: I delight to do your will, O my God; your law is within my heart." (Ps. 40:6–8)

<span id="page-174-2"></span>The will of God written in the scroll does include the bringing of offerings to express the need of cleansing and forgiveness, but these must be the expression of a submissive and repentant heart. The will of God requires care for the poor and dependent, which in Israel is a part of the temple ritual. Care for the poor in Israel is so rooted in temple pilgrimage that the two cannot be separated. Pilgrimage requires the bringing of gifts, but neither of these should be done out of obligation. These practices arise from faith in God, which inspires a desire to do his will.

## <span id="page-174-0"></span>DEUTERONOMY 16:18–17:20

**<sup>18</sup>** "You shall appoint judges and officers in all your towns that the Lord your God is giving you, according to your tribes, and they shall judge the people with righteous judgment. **19**You shall not pervert justice. You shall not show partiality, and you shall not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds the eyes of the wise and subverts the cause of the righteous. **<sup>20</sup>** Justice, and only justice, you shall follow, that you may live and inherit the land that the Lord your God is giving you.

#### *Section Overview: Governance Regulations*

Centralization brings administrative changes, especially the necessity of a centralized judicial system and governance, the provision of a king along with officials of his administration. It will be centuries before the tribes of Israel occupy the territory of the Promised Land and can establish a centralized government. Moses anticipates the time of Israel as an organized kingdom in the land. He makes provisions for state institutions, but not in the specific sense of a constitution. His provision is not a systematic definition of offices and duties but rather the general principles of governance. In contrast to the surrounding governments, the authority of officials is limited and accountable. The concept is a sense of equality and brotherhood under a single covenant. These regulations are to ameliorate the dangers of status and power by a ruling elite.

<span id="page-176-3"></span>Such centralized structure of governance is original to Deuteronomy; there are no parallel regulations elsewhere in the Torah. Knowledge of these regulations provides empowerment to the members of the covenant. It is a means by which the people can resist and protest abuses of authority. It is the reason why prophets can challenge kings; Nathan can be expected to call David to account when he abuses his power in executing an army general in order to make that officer's wife a part of his harem (2 Sam. 12:1–12). Greedy kings such as Ahab suffer the ultimate judgment of death and dynastic failure for violating the property rights of a private citizen (1 Kings 22:34–38; 2 Kings 9:21–26). The reigns of the kings of Israel and Judah are consistently evaluated according to the legislation of Deuteronomy. In the renewal of the covenant, Moses makes provision for Israel to become a kingdom. The caveat is that the kings of Israel are not to be like the other nations'. The political reality is that power is inevitably driven beyond the limits set for it.
