#### *Comment*

<span id="page-176-2"></span><span id="page-176-1"></span><span id="page-176-0"></span>16:18–20 Every local center is to appoint "judges and officers." Officers have a record-keeping function (cf. comment on 1:14–18). These officials are usually listed first with the judges, but they appear to have a subordinate function. The officers and judges are appointed by the people, much like the judges in the wilderness (1:9–17). The participation of the community is a critical component in the selection of its officers. Qualifications for the execution of justice are the same as when judges were first chosen: recognized leaders must have demonstrated their wisdom and shown an understanding of how to assess situations. The judicial system of the <span id="page-177-0"></span>wilderness was a temporary provision. Once the nation was organized as a state, a centrally structured judicial system was necessary. Nothing is said of the relationship between elders and judges. It is likely that judges were chosen from among the elders. When Moses was unable to carry the burden of the people, God instructed him to select leaders from among the elders (Num. 11:16–17). The same officers (Hb. *shoterim*) are named there. The priests also had a role in exercising justice (cf. Deut. 17:9), but nothing suggests they were among the appointed judges. In later times judges were appointed by national figures, but royally appointed judges are limited to Jerusalem.

<span id="page-177-7"></span><span id="page-177-6"></span><span id="page-177-5"></span>The requirements for impartial justice are addressed to the people, not merely to the judges (v. 19). These three stipulations are reiterated frequently in the Bible. Bribes are literally a "gift" (*shohad*), which corrupt officials claim as a payment for services (Isa. 1:23). The metonymy is natural; gifts often imply some sense of reciprocation, since receiving gifts can leave a person indentured to the giver. For a judge, even a gift accepted as a fee is unacceptable because it will tend to influence decisions. The explanation at the end of the verse suggests that this is not simply a bribe. The closing appeal of this section emphasizes that the objective pursuit of justice is always to the benefit of everyone.

<span id="page-177-4"></span><span id="page-177-3"></span><span id="page-177-2"></span>16:21–17:1 The sequences in the exposition of the laws are frequently tangential; laws are related, but they are not given in an orderly or topical fashion. Josephus said that Moses left the laws in disarray, written as he had learned them from God (*Antiquities* 4.197). Ancient Near Eastern laws are often concatenated by means of assonance or key terms. In this case, it may be that the form of the verb for not perverting justice in 16:19 (Hb. *tatteh*) links to not planting (*tittaʿ*; v. 21) an "Asherah." The three prohibitions that follow are representative of cult worship and are natural examples of issues judges would need to adjudicate in a covenant context.42 It is explicitly said that an Asherah is a tree that is planted (v. 21). Such a place of worship was constituted by a leveled stone platform beside a tree or a grove of trees. The term *Asherah* is regularly used as synecdoche for the whole platform and its altar.43 Such platforms were characterized by an "altar" (*mizbeach*) and a "pillar" (*matsebah*), all technical terms for ritual artifacts. The pillar was an erect stone representing a Canaanite god. With the centralization envisaged by Deuteronomy, all such platforms for worship are forbidden for Israelites. Israel must have its own specified place of worship that does not include these cultic items.

Sacrifices are to be brought to the central location. Such sacrifices are not regular food. These are a confession of divine provision, as Moses explains. As representative food, such animals are dedicated—they are holy and therefore cannot be defective in any way. Judges might be called upon to make decisions as to whether an animal is qualified to be representative in this fashion.

<span id="page-177-1"></span><sup>42</sup> For an explanation of Asherahas a place of worship and a description of the platform cf. comment on 7:1–6. 43 Synecdoche is a figure of speech in which part of an object is used for the whole, such as "fifty sails," meaning fifty ships by the naming of the means by which they are powered. Similarly, one might say "those are awesome wheels," referring to an impressive car.

<span id="page-178-11"></span><span id="page-178-7"></span>17:2–7 Moses describes the procedure that is to be followed in the locations at which judges have been selected. Deuteronomy here again is inclusive, with its reference to both men and women; women have their own status and carry their own responsibility. This is the only instance in Deuteronomy of the phrase translated "transgressing his covenant" (Hb. *laʿabor berito*). This verb is used regularly to speak of crossing over a territory. It may be used again deliberately in 29:12, where God leads Israel to "enter into the sworn covenant." Those who have crossed into the covenant by means of an oath are liable if they then deny that oath in leaving the covenant by crossing over any of its stipulations. Denial of the covenant oath could take any form of subservience to the creation rather than the Creator. The heavenly bodies are typically represented as gods in other religions (e.g., the sun god Shemesh, or Baal as rider of the clouds). Allegations that this has taken place must be investigated very thoroughly; this is the most serious of offenses, with an ultimate penalty of death, since the words of the oath are taken in the name of Yahweh. However, it is all too easy for disgruntled individuals to lay dubious charges. Such cases would not easily be proven, for it would take the agreement of two or three independent witnesses. The integrity of the witnesses is tested, in that they must be the ones taking the initiative in an execution. Any false representation in this instance could not be atoned.

<span id="page-178-8"></span><span id="page-178-3"></span><span id="page-178-1"></span><span id="page-178-0"></span>17:8–13 The central court is not a court of appeal but a court of referral for those cases that cannot be determined. The cases given as examples at Mount Sinai are good examples of subjective situations (Ex. 21–23). Homicide might be unintended or might be a case of willful planned attack (Ex. 21:12–14); situations of missing property could be complicated by circumstances (Ex. 22:6–14). Assault could involve the loss of an unborn child or various kinds of permanent bodily injury, for which appropriate monetary compensation would need to be determined (Ex. 21:22–25). Revenge is never permitted under the covenant; justice is always measured in terms of appropriate compensation. This is one of the ways Israelite law is unlike that of all other known law codes.

<span id="page-178-10"></span><span id="page-178-9"></span><span id="page-178-6"></span><span id="page-178-5"></span><span id="page-178-4"></span><span id="page-178-2"></span>The composition of the central court is not specified. The role of the priest in the judicial system is mentioned only in Deuteronomy (19:17). Priests are otherwise involved in those cases that cannot be solved and must be referred to God through oaths, the Urim and Thummim (Ex. 28:29–30; Num. 27:21; 1 Sam. 28:6; Ezra 2:63), or ritual ordeals (Num. 5:11–31). It may be that Deuteronomy provides a role for priests in the judicial system apart from sacred rites because of their knowledge of the law and their role in teaching the regulations of the covenant (Lev. 10:11). Priests are also responsible for retaining copies of the Torah (Deut. 17:18; 31:9, 24–26). Priests may well have been regarded as the experienced interpreters of covenant responsibilities. Ancient law did not operate in casuistic fashion, as does modern law. Laws were given as examples, rather than precedents, to provide guidance in types of cases, but even so correct interpretation of the intended outcome was very important.

The decisions of the central court may not be disregarded, either by another judge or by the individual. Dismissing a court decision is a capital crime even if the punishment for the crime committed is not a capital offense. The involvement of the priest in such cases indicates that God is involved in the decision, which makes its disregard a capital case.

<span id="page-179-4"></span><span id="page-179-2"></span><span id="page-179-1"></span><span id="page-179-0"></span>17:14–20 The king of Israel described in Deuteronomy is not like other nations'. The Greek translator understood this and paraphrased the word "king" (Hb. *melek*) as "ruler" (Gk. *archōn*). The only other occurrence of *melek* translated as *archōn* in the LXX is in the blessing of Balaam (Num. 23:21), where it refers to God. The king does not grant a covenant and law to the people, as in all the other nations, but must live under the covenant renewed under Moses; he must be one among his brothers (Deut. 17:15). When Israel asks for a king, it is for him to fulfill a role in the central court and exercise judgment (1 Sam. 8:5)—a function of all kings and to provide for national defense (1 Sam. 8:20). The problem is not having a king in each of these capacities, which is provided for in the regulations of Moses. The problem with Israel's asking for a king is their rejection of Yahweh as King (1 Sam. 8:7; cf. Judg. 8:23). It is quite impossible for Israel to have a king under the covenant when the covenant itself has been rejected by the people. Israel in this situation is like all the other nations.

<span id="page-179-7"></span><span id="page-179-6"></span><span id="page-179-5"></span><span id="page-179-3"></span>It is possible, however, for God to appoint a king over Israel as part of the fulfillment of his covenant with Israel, as when God anoints his own king in Zion. God declares his loyalty to the king he has anointed (2 Sam. 7:11–17), and the king in turn declares that this people belongs to the God who has redeemed them (2 Sam. 7:18–24). The declaration that there is no other god as this who has redeemed a people for himself through great and awesome deeds is particularly Deuteronomic. In establishing his king, God at the same time secures a covenant people for himself. Psalm 2, a celebration of the anointing of David, affirms the rule of the divinely chosen king over all nations. In this psalm the rule of Israel's king and the rule of God are fully unified. Kingship is essential to covenant, but this is not the kind of king or covenant found in other nations.

<span id="page-179-8"></span>The covenant faith of Deuteronomy contrasts above all with the ideologies of Mesopotamia and Egypt, the nations with the greatest influence over Israel. In Mesopotamia, kingship was created by the gods for the well-being of human society; the king in turn created and granted laws that he gave to the people. The king was above the law. In Egypt the king was a god and therefore embodied the law.

The instructions of Moses stress proscriptions against the usual excesses of kings rather than the responsibilities of the king. The responsibility of the king, stated simply, is to lead the people in obedience to the covenant. For this reason the king is responsible to have a copy of this Torah and to read it so that he may learn to fear God, the fundamental covenant requirement. This surrender of the king to the covenant is the antithesis of human hubris typical of kings. Such hubris manifests itself chiefly in three vices characteristic of kings: military power, wealth, and a larger harem (to secure alliances with other nations and numerous offspring to act as heirs and officials). Such royal aspirations are a threat to Israel's hope for longevity in the land.

<span id="page-180-3"></span><span id="page-180-2"></span><span id="page-180-1"></span><span id="page-180-0"></span>By the measure of Deuteronomy, kingship in Israel is a failure. The first requirement is for the king to be one of God's choosing (Deut. 17:15). The first king of Israel meets that qualification but immediately is also the king God rejects (1 Sam. 13:13). The Lord then seeks a prince for his people "after his own heart" (1 Sam. 13:14). The phrase "after his own heart" refers to the divine choice—God sets his mind (heart) on this man. God commissions Samuel to anoint David as the king of his choice (1 Sam. 16:1–13). In the narrative of Israel it is only this first criterion, the divine choice, that makes possible the continuation of the covenant and the kingdom. The consequences of David's failures will haunt him continuously. Not empire-building capabilities but submission in repentance enables David to become the king of promise.

#### *Response*

The maintenance of what is now called civil order is one of the greatest contrasts between the old covenant and the new covenant of the Christian. There is no civil order under the covenant of Moses because the order of the nation is subsumed under the covenant relationship with God. This distinction is evident already in Israelite times, with no distinction between the sacred and ordinary life. In other nations the king held a position as a god or a direct ordination of the gods, which gave him and the ruling class a status independent from all ordinary people. In the epilogue of the Law Code of Hammurabi, the king declares himself preeminent and without equal. The statutes he has given are never to be rescinded, and his justice will prevail by order of Shamash.44

While Israel is radically distinct in its own context, the NT church has no direct engagement in the government of its time. The charge against Jesus at the crucifixion is sedition in claiming to be King of the Jews. When Pilate asks Jesus specifically about this claim, Jesus tells him that his kingdom is not of this world (John 18:33–36). Proof of this is that his disciples do not resist his arrest. The mission of the Jesus is to make disciples of all nations. The charge to the church is not to establish a Christian nation.

<span id="page-180-4"></span>In the days of the Roman Empire, Christians everywhere found themselves subordinated to one nation. Once Christians were clearly distinguished from other Jews, they suffered more mercilessly for their insistence on belonging to another kingdom. A letter from the church at Smyrna describes the mob at the martyrdom of Polycarp: "All the crowd, astonished at the noble conduct of the of the Godbeloved and God-fearing race of Christians, cried out, 'Away with the atheists.'"45 Christians in that world had no possible engagement with the powers of state.

<sup>44</sup> *ANET*, 178.

<sup>45</sup> Henry Bettenson and Chris Maunder, eds., *Documents of the Christian Church*, 4th ed. (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011), 9. *Documents of the Christian Church* is a convenient volume for consulting such fundamental documents.

It was in many ways a sad day for the church when it became an attempted means of bringing unity to the Roman Empire and subsequently began to have not only privilege but also power. When such power began to accrue to the church, it was anything but a model of the kind of civil service described by Moses. Since the time of the Reformation the influence of the church in political matters has continuously eroded to the point that the church is marginalized in many societies and not tolerated in others. Christians are again the most persecuted group in the world, especially in the Middle East, India, and China. The continuous calling of Christians in all eras is to follow the example of Jesus by enduring suffering for doing good (1 Pet. 2:20–25). The example of Jesus before Pilate at his trial is the calling of Christians.

<span id="page-181-2"></span><span id="page-181-1"></span>This is not to minimize the importance of good social order of the kind described by Moses nor the value of Christians' becoming engaged in the process of such order as they are able. However, this is an individual calling within the church, not a collective mission of the church. The church is mandated not to create a good society but to be salt and light in whatever society it may be found (Matt. 5:13–16). Finding ways to be such salt and light in increasingly pluralistic societies takes a great deal of wisdom and should never be done in reaction to the many outrages society engenders.

#### *Section Overview: Priests and Prophets*

Priests and prophets are important leaders alongside their political and judicial counterparts. Every society must deal with two issues. One is the relationship of the individual to society; the second is the alignment of society with the natural world. The first issue is settled by law and government; the second is resolved by belief. The two issues are intimately related. Laws and government of a society are wholly dependent on what moderns call a "metanarrative," namely, those beliefs used to interpret all other phenomena. Every society has a collective belief that serves as the basis for its collective values. In Israel, the basis of law and government was determined by divine revelation. Moses now turns to the means by which divine revelation is to function in Israel.

One aspect of revelation is to make regular confession of Yahweh as the sovereign and ever-present Lord of the covenant. The confession of their incomparable God is made through the tabernacle and involves every aspect of daily life. The tribe of Levi is devoted to serving the confessions of Israel through the tent of meeting. Moses therefore turns his attention to provisions for the Levitical priests. Their God is known through his words and deeds as mediated by Moses. Provision must also be made for the prophetic function of Moses to continue. While Deuteronomy limits the authority of kings, the authority of the prophet is strengthened.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-183-7"></span><span id="page-183-4"></span><span id="page-183-3"></span><span id="page-183-2"></span><span id="page-183-1"></span><span id="page-183-0"></span>18:1–8 Establishing one central place of worship has the greatest of implications for the function of the Levites. The assignments of the Levites in the wilderness were very specific. A census was taken of the three sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari (Num. 3:17). In that context, their duties were specifically assigned. The tribes of Gershon and Merari had primary responsibility for guarding the tabernacle and providing security for all the rituals associated with it (Num. 3:7, 25, 36). The sons of Kohath were responsible for the porterage of the tabernacle (Num. 4:47). These duties were kept separate from the function of the priests responsible for the daily ritual of the tabernacle, which were limited to the sons of Aaron (Num. 3:3–4). This segmentation of duties would continue when Israel entered the Promised Land. The movements of the tabernacle are known only incidentally, but it is present at Shiloh and Gibeon before being placed permanently inside the temple (Josh. 18:1; 19:51; 1 Chron. 16:39–40). The fundraising of Joash includes provision for the tent of the testimony (2 Chron. 24:6). Whatever the fortunes of the tabernacle, the role of the Levites would change after settlement in the Promised Land. Their duties may be assumed to have been transferred to the various local places of worship Israel establishes before the centralization prescribed in Deuteronomy. Limiting worship to one center necessarily changes the duties of the Levites as well as their compensation. Some of these changes may be observed in the instructions Moses gives in Deuteronomy.

<span id="page-183-10"></span><span id="page-183-9"></span><span id="page-183-8"></span><span id="page-183-6"></span><span id="page-183-5"></span>According to Deuteronomy, the entire tribe of Levi is qualified to serve as priests; they are referred to as Levitical priests, a designation not found elsewhere in the Pentateuch. The tribe of Levi does not have an allotted territory. At the time of entry into the Promised Land, a total of forty-eight cities and surrounding territory are assigned to the Levites (Num. 35:1–8; Josh. 21:1–42). There is no mention of these cities in Deuteronomy. The function of Levitical cities changes with the coming of centralized worship, since the duties of the Levites in the countryside would be significantly reduced. The allotments for the Levites and their duties in Deuteronomy conform to their description as Levitical priests. In Deuteronomy, all the Levites are to receive the Lord's offerings by fire as their portion ("the Lord's food offerings"). These take the place of the Levites' inheritance. In the wilderness, these offerings by fire were assigned to Aaron and his descendants (Num. 18:8–10) and designated as most holy. Deuteronomy makes the distinction between those Levites serving as priests and those with the right to do so (18:6–8). It may be that Deuteronomy assumes the priestly distinctions found in the wilderness instructions, but the explanations of Deuteronomy at minimum imply changes of practice in a different time and place.

<span id="page-184-0"></span>The allotments of the priests fall into three categories (vv. 3–4): food and drink, oil, and material for clothing (the first shearing). Oil is used in eating, cooking, lighting, and healing. Since some of the endowments of food come from sacrificial animals, these could be given to the Levites only when they are serving as priests. The portion of the animal given is specified as the right foreleg (the shoulder to the knee), the jowls (including the tongue), and the maw (the fourth stomach). The priests also receive the first products of the grain, wine, oil, and wool. Giving these to the priests is a part of the confession that all these provisions are a gift from God. They are necessary as an act of faith. The service of the Lord would entail ministry at the temple in the offering of sacrifices and the pronouncing of blessings (v. 5). Moses does not here specify differing assignments from those made in the wilderness.

<span id="page-184-2"></span><span id="page-184-1"></span>Any Levite could come to Jerusalem to serve at the temple (vv. 6–8). If a Levite makes such a move, "he may have equal portions to eat." The translation of the ESV is to be followed, contrary to that of many other English versions. The right to minister at the established central place is assumed. The apodosis of the conditional sentence, according to Hebrew sentence structure, deals with their endowments, not the right to serve. They are entitled to equal shares irrespective of other income they may receive. The vocabulary concerning the sale of ancestral property is ambiguous; it may be income from Levitical properties or an inheritance.

<span id="page-184-3"></span>18:9–14 The importance of divination in the ancient world is evident in the vast number of omen collections and related cuneiform texts that have been preserved. Akkadian divination was considered a major intellectual achievement. These texts were translated into various languages, such as Elamite, Hittite, and Hurrian, and offer an abundance of material concerning the various techniques of divination. These all represent a means of communication with forces that shape the individual as well as the group. Such information was a means of averting evil or harm. Two techniques are known in Mesopotamia: operational and magical. Communication could take place through a binary answer (yes or no) or through a code accepted by both the deity and the diviner. In operational divination, answers could come through the spreading of oil poured into water or through the shape of smoke emitted from a censer. Magical techniques are effects of natural phenomena: wind, thunder, movements of stars, or effects on the external or internal features of animals. Records were kept of unusual acts of animals or happenings in the sky and were developed into a science for understanding their significance for humans. The gods could be entreated to write their message within the entrails of an animal. The internal organs of the selected animals would then be examined for any unusual features (a process known as extispicy), all of which could be determined through the maintenance of detailed records. Many signs are referred

to as "liver omens," since the liver was considered the seat of the emotions. These constitute the largest number of omen texts by far. Dream interpretations are quite rare among Akkadian tablets, and shamanism (communication with spirits) is unknown. Mesopotamia is famed for the royal art of astrology, which goes back to the Old Babylonian period and is very prominent in the library of Assurbanipal. Horoscopes, which deal with one's date of birth, are only known much later, from the fifth to the third centuries BC.

<span id="page-185-0"></span>Deuteronomy considers all forms of divination to be an abomination. Moses does not describe specific methods of receiving messages from other powers; all are condemned under the general prohibition of "divination" (v. 10). The specific practices of the various terms are never given and are not self-evident. The term "tells fortunes" usually refers to clouds (Hb. *ʿnn*); some sign is used as an omen. "Interprets omens" derives from a root that ordinarily means snake (*nahash*) and refers to some means of seeking signs. "Sorcerer" (*keshef*) in Akkadian refers to one who practices witchcraft, someone who uses spells, charms, or incantations to manipulate people. "Charmer" translates the word *heber* ("bind"); a similar Akkadian word means to bind magically as a type of sorcery. Necromancy is the practice of making inquiry through the spirits of deceased persons. This was done through a "medium" know in Hebrew as an *ʾob*. Consultations with the dead were also made through a *yiddeʿoni* ("necromancer"), someone familiar with spirits. These terms are sometimes translated interchangeably.

Distinct from all these practices is one who "burns his son or his daughter as an offering." The Hebrew expression means to "pass through the fire" (cf. ESV mg.).46 It may be that child sacrifice was practiced in Israel, as it certainly was among the Moabites. But human sacrifice is not specifically connoted by this expression. The archaeological and linguistic evidence indicates that this was a ritual cremation that took place at a *tophet*, a place outside the city wall sometimes used for special status burials. Those buried at these places were primarily premature, stillborn, or very young infants. The ritual cremation of a deceased child was a kind of human sacrifice that at least in some cases marked dedication to a deity (Jer. 32:35; 2 Kings 16:3; 17:17; 21:6; 23:10). The practice is related to dedication to Molech or the exercise of divination.

<span id="page-185-3"></span><span id="page-185-2"></span><span id="page-185-1"></span>18:15–22 Guidance for life in Israel comes through the God of the covenant. He does not speak through any of the means used by the nations. God reveals himself to Israel through the Torah mediated through Moses. Israel will have need for revelation once Moses is no longer with them. Thus he makes provision for his office to continue through prophets like himself.

Prophecy is the only means of mediating the divine word. Moses recalls the experience of Mount Sinai, where the people were terrified at the divine appearance. God approved of their request for a mediator. Those who succeed Moses in

<sup>46</sup> Analysis of the significance of the biblical expression "pass through the fire" may be found in Ziony Zevit, *The Religions of Ancient Israel: A Synthesis of Parallactic Approaches* (London: Continuum, 2001), 549–552.

this office will not be inferior in authority, though Moses holds a unique status as the prophet of Israel. Any Israelite who disregards prophetic authority will be held accountable. In addition, anyone who speaks presumptively as a prophet but leads people away from the revelation of Moses must be put to death. A prophet might speak falsely in two different ways (Deut. 18:20): (1) a word might be spoken that God has not given, or (2) a prophecy might be given in the name of other gods.

<span id="page-186-2"></span>Any prophets who contradicts the revelation received at Sinai must immediately be identified as false. Those who prophesy on other matters and do not use any of the usual methods of divination could not be identified immediately. The test of a true prophet is that his words must also stand the test of time. Later prophets such as Isaiah serve more as reformers seeking to bring the people back to the covenant. Isaiah's prophecy of total exile did not come true in his lifetime, but even in his lifetime he could be recognized as one who truly spoke the word of God. Other prophecies did come true in his lifetime, such as the ending of the Assyrian siege in the days of Hezekiah.

<span id="page-186-1"></span><span id="page-186-0"></span>The practice of divination in Israel is dangerous because it is a means of exercising supernatural power. The Egyptian magicians were able to duplicate the signs Moses gave (Ex. 7:8–11). Israel is not to rely upon such powers. Their loyalty is to be with Yahweh exclusively (Deut. 18:13). Consulting with the spirits of the dead is also a denial of trust in God by seeking guidance from some other authority.

#### *Response*

Postmodern questions begin with authentication of what is believed to be true. What validates the choice of belief held by an individual or society? In practice, controlling belief systems are determined simply by power. The epistemological assertion of Western societies demands the irrational proposition that no knowledge is possible outside of what is perceptible by the independent human mind and the senses. If this is denied in theory, it is nevertheless invariably held in practice. Evidence of realities outside of phenomena that can be perceived by the senses is undeniable. Postmodernist denial stems from the hubris of humans' adamantly asserting the nonexistence of anything greater than themselves. The ancients might have elevated themselves to the status of deity, but they were never so irrational as to think that no knowledge or being could exist outside of what they could perceive. The only question was how to access such knowledge, since it would be vital to human well-being. In Israel, the only legitimate means of receiving the knowledge necessary for human decision and conduct was revelation through a prophet in the tradition of Moses. This was authenticated by the revelatory encounter at Mount Sinai, where the Holy One chose in mercy to reveal himself in a sensory manner through darkness, lightning, the sound of a voice, and a written document.

The holy was communicated and taught through the practice of ritual, which is appropriately modified according to circumstance. Transformation enables the goal of the confession and way of life to be achieved in changing situations. Centralization was the right step for the temple confessions of Israel. It brought cohesion to the disparate parts of the country and unified the tribes in one single assembly. This had not been possible from the time of the wilderness until the coming of the kingdom. Moses anticipates this necessity; his instructions in covenant renewal reflect differing emphases than those of earlier times, with changes in practice. This is not denial of the preceding but rather empowering continuation. Christian rituals of baptism and communion are themselves modifications of previous rituals, through Christ's command, that inform the new practices so that their significance can be fully understood. It is unfortunate that much of Christian preaching makes no reference to the antecedents from which these practices emerged and the ways in which they continue the confessions of the past.

<span id="page-187-3"></span><span id="page-187-2"></span><span id="page-187-1"></span>The revelation received by Moses at Sinai was unique. There was no other prophet like him, due to this circumstance (Deut. 34:10). Moses was more than a prophet; he was a man uniquely called by God. Sinai was the great revelatory moment in the history of Israel. The belief continued, however, that there would be a prophet like Moses. In his sermon at the healing of a lame man, Peter calls for repentance for cleansing of sin, saying that this would make possible the times of renewal signified by this miracle (Acts 3:19–23). This renewal would come through Jesus, the one who had suffered for them and the fulfillment of the prophet like Moses, who would arise from the people. Failure to trust him would constitute removal from the congregation. For Peter, Mount Sinai and the Mount of Transfiguration (Luke 9:28–32) are the two great moments authenticating divine revelation, the first established by Moses and the second by a prophet like Moses (2 Pet. 1:16–18). All other revelation of any time is subordinated to these two great revelatory periods. All other revelation is more circumstantial, it does not add to the truth of what has been received. Jesus does not repeat the truth of Moses; it remains forever necessary, but Jesus does fulfill it in the new covenant, which establishes forever the relationship of God with his people.

#### *Section Overview: Protection of Life, Land, and Truth*

<span id="page-188-0"></span>The Ten Words given at Mount Sinai stipulated the life values that were to be upheld if the requirement of the covenant to love and fear God were to be observed. These began with a confession of Yahweh as holy, separate from the created order of the common but ever present within it to impart and sustain life. This is the significance of the confession that there is no other God (Deut. 4:35, 39); all other supposed gods or powers are fully subordinate to the Creator, who belongs to another order. The exposition of this Torah begins with the practices and rituals through which confession of such a God will be observed; it goes on to make provision for officials to enable this confession to be expressed communally.

<span id="page-189-4"></span>The section of exposition that begins at chapter 19 moves on to the practice of the stipulated values in daily life. The values for living in covenant are given in four statements concerning life, family, property, and relationships. These are expressed in succinct lucidity: you shall not kill, you shall not commit adultery, you shall not steal, and you shall not bear false witness (5:20). This chapter takes up the closely related questions of protecting life, family, property, and truth in the exercise of covenant as it is to be practiced by individuals and clans. An important question in the protection of life concerns accidental homicide. Cities of asylum are necessary to protect those charged with murder. Land is the most fundamental of properties to be protected, as is established in this chapter. Finally, in the case of disputes, a procedure is needed for determining the truth of one person's claims when contradicted by another's. As the exposition proceeds to the values of the Ten Words governing community relations, it begins with provisions to protect these basic values essential to integrity and peace within family and clan life.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-189-5"></span>19:1–7 State law enforcement was not part of civil provisions in ancient societies. Such a force is the luxury of more affluent societies, in which provision for life essentials can be accomplished by a much smaller number of people. Protection at the community level came through family association, by which the kinship group was the primary defender for violations of life. It was the responsibility of a near relative to restore relations within the tribe. This person is referred to as a *goʾel*, a Hebrew word that carries the sense of restoration or redemption, such as the purchase of property by a relative when it has been sold for debt (Lev. 25:25–34). In the case of a death, the restoration of relations is carried out by a near relative referred to as a *goʾel haddam*, generally translated "avenger of blood" (Deut. 19:6).

<span id="page-189-7"></span><span id="page-189-6"></span><span id="page-189-3"></span><span id="page-189-2"></span><span id="page-189-1"></span><span id="page-189-0"></span>Murder was dealt with by terminating the life of the murderer (Gen. 9:6; Ex. 21:12). In the absence of prisons, this is the only way to avoid repeat offences. The avenging of murder should not be interpreted as simple revenge, for vengeance belongs to God alone, not to the individual Israelite (Lev. 19:18). Nevertheless, among family members, feelings for revenge could be present (Deut. 19:6), creating a vengeful situation. The avenger need not be an immediate family member. In the case of a brother killing a brother, other members of the clan would seek to avenge the matter (2 Sam. 14:7, 11). The avenging of murder was a responsibility quite apart from personal feelings one might have on the matter. In the case of accidental homicide, provision was to be made for refuge to protect the innocent person and prevent a situation of continued retaliation.

<span id="page-190-7"></span>Moses introduced cities of refugee in the first address to the people after the initial conquest of the Transjordan (Deut. 4:41–43). Three cities are named, distributed geographically from south to north as a place of asylum. In the exposition of this Torah, Moses provides the details of the designation of these cities and their function. The locations are determined by a survey of the land, dividing it into three areas; distance is the criterion for selection, not tribal affiliation. The purpose of these cities is to protect the innocent person, as explained by the example of a neighbor's accidental death while cutting trees (19:5). The reason for situating the cities geographically is to provide for accessibility so the innocent person could escape and receive a proper trial.

<span id="page-190-9"></span><span id="page-190-8"></span>19:8–10 These verses are a reminder that the promises of God are yet to be fulfilled, for with the expansion of the land would be the need for additional cities of asylum. The promises to the patriarchs could be fulfilled only on the condition that the Israelites love God according to the terms of the covenant. To this end, it is important for revenge and killing of the innocent to be prevented. Three additional places of refuge are to be added once the land is fully occupied in order to protect the innocent and prevent the guilt of murder.

<span id="page-190-5"></span><span id="page-190-4"></span><span id="page-190-2"></span>Numbers 35 further explains that these places of refuge are Levitical cities given the technical designation *miqlat*. The Hebrew root *qalat* means "to take up, harbor."47 Accused individuals will find safety in those cities until they appear before a general assembly (*ʿedah*, "congregation") to face trial (Num. 35:12). If innocent, they will be returned to the city of refuge (Num. 35:25). They will remain there until the death of the high priest. This regulation is explained by the rule of biblical law that there can be no ransom or commutation for homicide. All human life is to be protected with equal sanctity, since all belong to God. The life of a slave is as sacred as any other's; if a slave dies at the hands of a master, the death must be avenged (Ex. 21:20). If death occurs in a struggle, life must be given for life (Ex. 21:23). No ransom can be received for the accidental death of another person (Num. 35:32–34). In the case of accidental death, the manslayer must live in the city of asylum until the chance death of the high priest, signifying a penalty equal to the crime.48 This may have been a time of a general amnesty; none of this is specified in Deuteronomy. Practices regarding the function of asylum cities may have changed over time, or they may have varied depending on the circumstances of each situation.

<span id="page-190-10"></span><span id="page-190-6"></span><span id="page-190-1"></span><span id="page-190-0"></span>19:11–13 Moses makes clear that the possibility of asylum for the accidental death of another human does not exist for intentional killing. The blood of the slain is

For a full discussion cf. R. Schmid, "*miqlat*," *TDOT*, 8:552–556. 48 Cf. Milgrom, "Excursus 76." Milgrom provides a full commentary on the laws of homicide.

<span id="page-191-0"></span>rejected by the earth and attaches to the killer. The elders, representative leaders of the tribe, act on behalf of the victim's family to bring the guilty person from the city of refuge for judgment. No mercy is possible in such cases. The sanctity of individuals made as God's image (Gen. 9:6) and the necessary protection of the community from further violations of life allow for no exceptions. Execution of the murderer falls to the clan, as it is its responsibility to protect its own family members. Failure to execute such judgment brings the blood of the victim upon the community and becomes a violation of the covenant made with God.

<span id="page-191-4"></span><span id="page-191-2"></span>19:14 As Moses taught in the words of the covenant at Sinai, property is closely related to life, since life depends on material sustenance. Land is the most fundamental of properties, for all acquisition in some manner depends on land. The boundaries of the tribes were set by Moses on the entrance to the land as determined by God in the casting of lots (Num. 26:53–56). The allotment given to each family unit was called its "inheritance" (Hb. *nahalah*). This ancestral inheritance is to be inviolable to each family. Wisdom writings warn against this violation in the context of plundering the poor or making land the security for risky or bad loans (Prov. 22:22–28).49 Theft by moving a boundary marker was regarded as an insidious sin in all ancient societies.

<span id="page-191-7"></span><span id="page-191-5"></span>19:15–21 False accusations are a violation of life as destructive as the stealing of property. The ninth word of Moses at the mountain warns against falsifying testimony against another person. In this context a false testimony could result in execution, which would be the equivalent of taking a life. At minimum, two or three witnesses are required in the case of a dispute, since accountability for deliberate deception and safeguards against faulty perception are both needed.

<span id="page-191-3"></span>Parties to the dispute are to appear before the Lord, an expression that often means going to the sanctuary. This is hardly the meaning intended in this instance, in that not all cases would be brought to the one central location envisioned by Deuteronomy. As indicated in the discussion on the festivals (e.g., Deut. 6:8), assemblies not involving sacrificial food took place apart from the temple. Whatever the location, the judges are God's representatives, so that appearing before them is to be in the Lord's presence.

A false witness is to be punished with the penalty that would have been laid on the accused. Penalties are to be carried out in a just fashion, the punishment being appropriate to the crime. The regulation "eye for an eye," commonly called "lex talionis" (the law of retaliation), is to be executed by means of monetary payment except in the case of murder. This may be seen in the example of damage done to a fetus in Exodus 21:22–25, where a fine is specified. A literal application of the law would be impossible in that case, since a fetus could not be demanded from the assailant. Many situations would be similar, such as blasphemy (Lev.

<span id="page-191-6"></span><span id="page-191-1"></span><sup>49</sup> This portion of Proverbs is part of the thirty sayings of the wise (22:17–24:34), which bear a close relationship to the thirty sayings of the Egyptian "Instruction of Amenemope," a work in which this prohibition is found in saying 6.

<span id="page-192-0"></span>24:10–16). The classic expression of the lex talionis is given as a general principle; it is not a prescription for particular cases or a rule naming all applicable cases. It is probably adopted from standard legal formulations as a principle of justice for the court. The standard of justice is reparation for damage done. In the case of a false witness, the reparation would follow this rule. The court would be required to administer the penalty to a false witness. In the case of murder, the offense is against the court, so it is only logical that the penalty the court would administer to the guilty would be applied to a false witness.

#### *Response*

Violence is a problem in every society. We tend to divide society into good and bad individuals according to the legal criteria held by a society, but matters are never that simple. The division between good and bad is not found between individuals but lies somewhere within each individual. A south Boston mobster nicknamed Whitey Bulger was beaten to death in prison in a revenge killing. The *Economist*'s November 8, 2018, obituary under the headline "The Business of Crime," stated that words like *good* and *bad* plagued him. He was bad because he was a racketeer, an extortionist (though "rent collector" was the term he preferred), an arms trafficker, and a mobster. His first spree of robberies in 1955 was bad in the classic style, bursting into banks with a pistol in each hand and fleeing with his girlfriend in a getaway car. His brother, William, held an eighteen-year tenure as president of the Massachusetts senate, the longest in the history of that institution. According to the *New York Times*, William Bulger lost his job at a university for refusing to testify against his brother.50 He was intensely loyal to his older brother and lived next door to a house owned by one of his brother's partnersin-crime, where the gang hatched plots, stored an arsenal of weapons, and committed murders. How do the words *good* and *bad* apply to the two brothers? They have left very different legacies. According to law one was good, responsible for crafting many good laws, while the other lived a life in perpetual violation of the law. But the younger brother implicitly was a false witness in the sense that he refused to divulge information vital to the prevention of crime. Both brothers without question thought of themselves as good; they just happened to have a very different kind of vocation.

Society will never rid itself of such problems of violence, because it cannot deal with the conundrum of the human personality. Humans are not shaped and controlled; though they may be influenced in a whole variety of ways, there is no predicting the result various influences may have. The two Bulger brothers grew up in the same family and community, with similar opportunities, but had somewhat contrasting careers. What was the difference between them? According to each of them, it would appear they did not necessarily think there was much of one. It could be argued that they were right in such an assessment. The differences

<sup>50</sup> Katharine Q. Seelye, "Sticking by a Murderous Brother, and Paying for It Dearly," *New York Times*, November 25, 2013.

between individual people are generally much less than perceived by the individuals concerned.

<span id="page-193-1"></span><span id="page-193-0"></span>The reality is that the Bible realistically makes provision for control of violence. Violence leads to the reversal of creation in the coming of the flood in Genesis 6–8. The difference after the flood is a provision for violence in Genesis 9:5–6 that has the potential to prevent society from self-destructing. That provision is what we call human government. Human government cannot solve human problems, but it does have a role in protecting victims, even a victim guilty of manslaughter through an accident such as a flying iron (Deut. 19:5). This role of government should be taken with utmost seriousness. However, the notion that governments have the capacity to remove violence from societies should always be treated with appropriate skepticism.

<span id="page-193-2"></span>Control of violence is not the same thing as justice in biblical terms. Here we see a complete confusion of terminology in contemporary society. The legal systems of most societies mete out penalties that are called justice, but penalties do not constitute justice. Penalties are punishment for damage done as part of the task of minimizing violence. Justice restores losses to an individual who has suffered as a result of violence. In the case of property or even bodily injury, the so-called lex talionis of this chapter is a useful guide in providing justice. But in the case of loss of life it is not relevant. Murder as a result of a planned scheme must not be allowed to repeat; the penalty is to forfeit the life of the murderer. Lesser penalties apply in other cases, such as accidental manslaughter, but in these cases the law recognizes that the person committing homicide is also partly the victim.

the battle and another man take her.' **8**And the officers shall speak further to the people, and say, 'Is there any man who is fearful and fainthearted? Let him go back to his house, lest he make the heart of his fellows melt like his own.' **9**And when the officers have finished speaking to the people, then commanders shall be appointed at the head of the people.

**<sup>10</sup>** "When you draw near to a city to fight against it, offer terms of peace to it. **11**And if it responds to you peaceably and it opens to you, then all the people who are found in it shall do forced labor for you and shall serve you. **12**But if it makes no peace with you, but makes war against you, then you shall besiege it. **13**And when the Lord your God gives it into your hand, you shall put all its males to the sword, **14**but the women and the little ones, the livestock, and everything else in the city, all its spoil, you shall take as plunder for yourselves. And you shall enjoy the spoil of your enemies, which the Lord your God has given you. **15**Thus you shall do to all the cities that are very far from you, which are not cities of the nations here. **16**But in the cities of these peoples that the Lord your God is giving you for an inheritance, you shall save alive nothing that breathes, **<sup>17</sup>**but you shall devote them to complete destruction,*<sup>1</sup>* the Hittites and the Amorites, the Canaanites and the Perizzites, the Hivites and the Jebusites, as the Lord your God has commanded, **<sup>18</sup>** that they may not teach you to do according to all their abominable practices that they have done for their gods, and so you sin against the Lord your God.

**<sup>19</sup>** "When you besiege a city for a long time, making war against it in order to take it, you shall not destroy its trees by wielding an axe against them. You may eat from them, but you shall not cut them down. Are the trees in the field human, that they should be besieged by you? **<sup>20</sup>** Only the trees that you know are not trees for food you may destroy and cut down, that you may build siegeworks against the city that makes war with you, until it falls."

1That is, set apart (devote) as an offering to the Lord (for destruction)

#### *Section Overview: Regulations in Warfare*

<span id="page-194-0"></span>Deuteronomy anticipates the time in which Israel will be a state with a king and with control over its territory. The wars of entrance to the Promised Land are depicted as a judgment against the Canaanites whose sins were beyond mercy (Gen. 15:16; Lev. 18:24–25; 20:23–24). Israel cannot cohabit with the nations God has judged. Their mandate is to displace these nations and place them under the judgment of God's domain (Deut. 20:16–17). But not all wars fall into this category. War is part of the human situation. As the Preacher observes in Ecclesiastes 3:8, war is one of the times that occur in the course human life.

<span id="page-194-3"></span><span id="page-194-2"></span>War is responsible for the worst of evils in human society. War not only leads to the death of combatants and innocent civilians and the destruction of civilian and national property, but also frequently results in famine and other evils.51 The regulations of Deuteronomy 20 are to minimize the destruction of life and property of conquered people and territory. The provisions of this chapter fall

<span id="page-194-1"></span><sup>51</sup> Cf. Amartya Sen, *Poverty and Famines* (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1981), Sen's classic study shows this to be true. Often the problem is administrative mismanagement and theft.

<span id="page-195-6"></span><span id="page-195-5"></span><span id="page-195-3"></span>into three categories: regulations for conscripting an army (vv. 1–9), provisions for dealing with conquered peoples (vv. 10–18), and preservation of the trees around besieged cities (vv. 19–20). In dealing with matters of justice and maintaining order, Moses prescribes conduct in military matters. Other specific examples of dealing with situations arising in warfare are taken up in association with other moral issues and values.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-195-2"></span><span id="page-195-1"></span>20:1–4 Instructions for warfare begin with an exhortation concerning the role of the military: success is always dependent on God, who fights for his people. Israel does not conduct wars on God's behalf; rather, God cares and provides for his people when they come under the attack of other nations God has judged. This is the proper definition of "holy war," as it is sometimes called. The concept is that God provides victory, not that a nation fights for God. It is important to have a well-prepared military, but military success is always dependent on God as the warrior who fights for his people. The model given is that of God's bringing Israel out of Egypt (v. 1) when Israel did not have an organized military force. God took up the military attack against Pharaoh, finally sinking his armies in the Reed Sea (Ex. 15:1–18). If this is the example of divine warfare, an army should not be necessary at all. But just as the gift of the land did not come about without combat, as Moses reminded Israel in his first sermon, life in the land will also involve war. Most often the enemy will be overwhelming, as was the case with entrance into the Promised Land. But Israel must never fear, because military success is never dependent on the superiority of military forces. And warfare should never be engaged apart from a divine mandate for protection of the covenant people. If warfare is under God's command, no opposing army should be a cause of terror.

<span id="page-195-7"></span><span id="page-195-4"></span><span id="page-195-0"></span>The priests are part of the military operations, as they represent God to the army. Their task is to provide the assurance that God is with them in battle. This is stated first as the central requirement for engagement in warfare. In actual practice, the priest would speak to the army once it had been recruited and was about to engage in battle, as explained in verse 2. Other armies would depend on the power of chariots and horses (v. 1), but Israel would call on the name of the Lord (Ps. 20:7–9). Dependence on military weapons would result in failure; only the Lord could protect his king and the nation. In one outstanding example, Jehoshaphat is overwhelmed by a coalition of kings against him (2 Chron.

<span id="page-196-6"></span><span id="page-196-5"></span>20:1–22). He seeks the Lord and assembles his army. His prayer is answered with a prophetic declaration through a Levite (2 Chron. 20:14–17). The Levite explains the route of the attack but exhorts the army not to engage in battle and instead to wait for the salvation of the Lord. In response, Jehoshaphat assembles a Levitical choir at the head of his army to engage the superior forces. Before the opposing army arrives at the scene of battle, its whole coalition collapses into fighting each other. Israel arrives to gather up the spoils. This would not be the procedure of every battle, but it exemplifies the practice Moses explains here. Once the army is assembled, the priests address them with the declaration that, unless the Lord fights for them, their cause is lost. But, conversely, if God is on their side, they cannot lose.

<span id="page-196-1"></span>20:5–9 The regulations for mobilizing a voluntary army are motivated by humanitarian concerns. The purpose is to ensure minimal disruption of civilian life. Civilian officials rather than military generals are responsible for the recruitment of the army. Deferments allow for the provision of establishing a home, farm, or family. These are fundamental to community function and the basic entitlement of every person. The opportunity to participate in these basic rights must not be jeopardized. In the case of establishing a family, a marriage has not been consummated, but the bridal price has been paid. In ancient practice this payment was for the benefit of the wife and was the equivalent of her inheritance. Once payment was made, the marriage was initiated, known as "inchoate marriage."52 This was not an engagement but the beginning of a marriage; any violations to the relationship were treated as violations of a marriage (Deut. 22:23–24). A final reason for deferment was for the benefit of the army; any individual not prepared to engage in warfare should not join, as doing so would demoralize the other troops.

<span id="page-196-3"></span>Once membership of the army had been determined by civilian officials, the military officers would take charge. The army generals would be appointed, indicating that the army would be marshaled for specific threats. These are not regulations for a standing force. It is not specified who appoints the army leaders, but it would be officials of higher authority. The procedure may follow the description of the appointment of judges (1:15), in which heads of tribes are appointed based on their wisdom and reputation, and then those heads appoint leaders referred to as chiefs of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens. Those chiefs are civilians, while these are to be temporary military leaders.

<span id="page-196-2"></span><span id="page-196-0"></span>20:10–14 The general rule in warfare is to seek terms of peace without engaging in battle. If a city accepts terms of surrender, its citizens are not harmed but become part of a state labor force. Solomon uses such a conscripted labor force from the native Canaanite peoples who live as subordinates after the conquest (1 Kings 9:20–21). These laborers are distinguished from the temporary conscriptions

<span id="page-196-4"></span><sup>52</sup> For a full discussion of ancient Near Eastern marriage practice that contains more detail than the Bible cf. Raymond Westbrook, "The Prohibition on Restoration of Marriage in Deuteronomy 24:1–4," in *Studies in Bible*, ed. Sara Japhet, ScrHier 31 (Jerusalem: Magnes Press, 1986), 387–405.

<span id="page-197-4"></span>Solomon lays on the Israelites to construct buildings (1 Kings 5:13–14). Israelites will never be subject to continuous servitude but will temporarily serve the state, as in the military service described here or in temporary service for building projects. If a city does not accept terms of peace, it will be dealt with more harshly. Its soldiers, who have the potential to lead in a future rebellion, are to be dispatched. The women and children become Israelite servants, though in some cases they might be taken as wives. All the property of the city is taken by the Israelites.

<span id="page-197-2"></span><span id="page-197-1"></span>20:15–18 The inhabitants of Canaan fall under the judgment of the *kherem*, which means that they are removed entirely from the common. The people are put to death because they stand under final divine judgment. Their time of accountability has come; their continuing presence would be a danger to the covenant Israel has with God. Their practices in relation to their gods are an abomination to Israel (18:9–13). This is not an ethnic matter. Israelite cities that adopt abominable Canaanite practices are treated the same way (13:12–16). This regulation is given as a theological reality. Canaanites must be purged so that the covenant of Israel is not compromised with their practices. It is only in select cities such as Jericho that extermination of people and property is carried out in actual practice.

<span id="page-197-3"></span><span id="page-197-0"></span>20:19–20 It is common practice in warfare to destroy the infrastructure of invaded territory in order to reduce the resources for resistance. Ancient warfare often involved a long duration of time. Cities were fortified and generally wellsupplied in preparation for war. Siege works (Hb. *matsor*) generally included a wall or fortification built around the city by an attacking army to blockade it from receiving food, military supplies, or soldiers and to protect the attacking army from resistance within the city. This practice was used in Nebuchadnezzar's attack against Jerusalem, which led to its eventual fall. He built a siege wall around the city, technically called *dayeq* (a loan word from the Akkadian *dajjiqu*), and attacked the city for three years (from the ninth to twelfth years of King Zedekiah). By the end of the third year, the city was breached because of famine (2 Kings 25:1–3). A besieging army might use a long siege to threaten a city by destroying its fruit trees and food supply. These regulations prevent such tactics, though they do allow for cutting down non-fruit-bearing trees for building the siege wall. The rationale is the well-being of the tree. Its role in military action cannot be equated with the soldiers'. The statement that trees are not human is both creational and humanitarian. Humans depend on creation; it is to be respected, as it belongs to God, who permits its use by humans.

#### <span id="page-197-5"></span>*Response*

Humans decry the evils of war, but humans alone are the cause of war. Humans are completely incapable of preventing war. There are always those willing to die or, more likely, willing to send others to their deaths in order to preserve power or overthrow it. War is an intractable problem of human society. Human history in every human society is a story of war.

<span id="page-198-0"></span>War not only causes the deaths of soldiers, making them and their families its immediate victims, but also has other consequences that bring about death. In ancient warfare this was famine, as illustrated in the narrative of the Aramean siege against Samaria (2 Kings 6:24–31). The king of Israel, presumably Ahab, is confronted by a woman whose complaint is that she has given her son for food, but now her neighbor has hidden the child she agreed to give up for food. This is not only an ancient problem. One of the most egregious famines in human history followed the Great War (1914–1918), the "war to end all wars." Over four million Ukrainian peasants were deliberately starved to death by Stalin in 1932–1933 in his paranoia over an anticipated attack of capitalist powers.53 The one hundredth anniversary of the First World War, which left eleven million combatants dead, has produced two forensic studies of the causes of this war. Margaret MacMillan, an Oxford scholar, in *The War That Ended Peace* (2013) holds Germany primarily responsible for the war. Christopher Clark, a Cambridge scholar, in *The Sleepwalkers* (2012) charges the Balkans with igniting the war. Each work is a tour de force; Clark's book has sold three hundred thousand copies in seventeen languages.54

There were no reasons for this war. The war had one outcome of dubious significance: the General Treaty for the Renunciation of War as an Instrument of Policy (a.k.a. the Kellogg-Briand Pact, named, respectively, after the foreign ministers of the United States and France). This agreement was signed by more than fifty countries, including all the great powers, in Paris in 1928. The goal of this treaty—to punish all wars of aggression, generally with economic sanctions—was at best of limited effect.55 Enforcement, as might be expected, proved impossible. The League of Nations could not stem the tide of militarism that followed, including its apotheosis in the Second World War. It is not that the pact was without effect. The organization of peace that followed the second war returned most of the land conquered, excepting the Soviet Union. The Nuremberg Trials established the principle that waging aggressive war was a criminal act, resulting in punishment for some of Hitler's henchmen.

It remains to be seen whether this policy will be effective in preventing future international wars, but it has had the effect of spawning countless intranational wars. Fractious countries do not need to fear international intervention, which would result in the loss of their power. Death and violence of war have been rampant in the seventy years since. The authors of *The Internationalists* still argue that the Kellogg-Briand Pact is better than the alternatives and laud the architects who brought it into being. Whatever the merits of the pact, it has enabled innumerable

<sup>53</sup> This history has been reviewed again by Anne Applebaum, *Red Famine: Stalin's War on Ukraine* (New York: Doubleday, 2017). For a critical review from a Communist perspective cf. Sheila Fitzpatrick, "Red Famine by Anne Applebaum Review—Did Stalin Deliberately Let Ukraine Starve?," *The Guardian*, August 25, 2017, Book of the Day. Soviet leaders had worked themselves into a frenzy over presumed imminent attack from capitalist powers and suspected *kulaks* (small farmers in Ukraine), class enemies who would welcome such an invasion. 54 For a review of these two studies cf. "Still in the Grip of the Great War," *The Economist*, March 26, 2014. 55 Cf. Oona A. Hathaway and Scott J. Shapiro, *The Internationalists*: *How a Radical Plan to Outlaw War Remade the World* (New York: Simon & Schuster, 2017).

wars, and the principles themselves are under siege, as exemplified in the Russian takeover of Crimea (2014).

As with violence within societies, wars will continue to be fought between societies. The best that is possible is to attempt to ameliorate the effects of war, as regulated in this chapter. War raises other questions for Christians. Since the highest commitment of a Christian is to a kingdom not of this world, the question becomes the level of commitment that should be made to the country of which one is a citizen. Christians in countries such Sudan, South Sudan, Syria, or Iraq suffer mercilessly through war irrespective of their resolve to live as peacefully as possible. They are targeted by various warring factions within their countries. The one responsibility all Christians have is to pray for peace—not simply the cessation of war but that families destroyed by war may find the peace of God that passes understanding. War is a continuous reminder to pray for the appearance of the rider on the great white horse (Rev. 19:11–16), who smites the nations with the (s)word of his mouth, whose sash reads "King of kings and Lord of lords."

### <span id="page-199-2"></span><span id="page-199-1"></span>DEUTERONOMY 21:1–9

21 "If in the land that the Lord your God is giving you to possess someone is found slain, lying in the open country, and it is not known who killed him, **<sup>2</sup>** then your elders and your judges shall come out, and they shall measure the distance to the surrounding cities. **3**And the elders of the city that is nearest to the slain man shall take a heifer that has never been worked and that has not pulled in a yoke. **4**And the elders of that city shall bring the heifer down to a valley with running water, which is neither plowed nor sown, and shall break the heifer's neck there in the valley. **5**Then the priests, the sons of Levi, shall come forward, for the Lord your God has chosen them to minister to him and to bless in the name of the Lord, and by their word every dispute and every assault shall be settled. **6**And all the elders of that city nearest to the slain man shall wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley, **<sup>7</sup>** and they shall testify, 'Our hands did not shed this blood, nor did our eyes see it shed. **8**Accept atonement, O Lord, for your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, and do not set the guilt of innocent blood in the midst of your people Israel, so that their blood guilt be atoned for.' **<sup>9</sup>** So you shall purge the guilt of innocent blood from your midst, when you do what is right in the sight of the Lord."

#### *Section Overview: Community Expiation for a Homicide*

<span id="page-199-0"></span>The regulation regarding homicide is based on the premise that the ground will not receive the blood of an innocent person. His blood cries out from the ground (Gen. 4:10). The blood of the innocent person can be atoned for only by the blood <span id="page-200-2"></span><span id="page-200-1"></span>of the person who shed it (Num. 35:33). No ransom can be paid for the life of the innocent. If the blood of the innocent is not atoned for, the land is profaned and its inhabitants endangered. In the case of accidental death, the innocent life to be protected is that of the person committing accidental homicide (Deut. 19:1–7). A further problem is an unsolved murder. Such a case becomes the responsibility of the community (city) nearest to where the body is found. The significance of the rites involved in this regulation is not explained. The object of the whole procedure is clearly expressed in the prayer of the elders: "Accept atonement, O Lord, for your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, and do not set the guilt of innocent blood in the midst of your people Israel, so that their blood guilt be atoned for" (Deut. 21:8). The primary focus of judicial and military matters has been the sanctity of human life. The section ends appropriately with provision for acknowledging a death that might otherwise be ignored. It makes emphatic the point that under no circumstance does the ground receive the blood of an innocent victim.

#### <span id="page-200-4"></span>*Section Outline*

- II.C. Exposition of This Torah (12:1–25:19) . . .
	- 3. Judicial and Military Regulations (19:1–21:9) . . .
		- c. Atonement for Unobserved Homicide (21:1–9)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-200-3"></span>21:1–2 These verses describe the typical circumstance of an unsolved murder. Murder within a city or near to it would typically be heard and observed, but it is not likely that an unsolved murder within a city is to be excluded from this expiation ritual. Planned murder would be executed in a remote place, much as Cain drew his brother, Abel, out into a field for the purpose of killing him (Gen. 4:8). Cain's problem was that he could not hide from God, but this would be true for any murder.

<span id="page-200-0"></span>Deuteronomy further anticipates the time when Israel is living in the land. It does not make provision for a time in which Israel might be scattered and living outside the land. This is not to suggest that there should be no responsibility for an unsolved murder that takes place outside the land. Historically, Israel very quickly began to be scattered, forming communities outside the land. This regulation does not begin to stipulate procedures for all of the contingencies that might come into play, including the influence of foreign governments. The principle to be observed is that no loss of human life can be disregarded.

The case under consideration is one in which the identity of the murderer has not come to be known. The perfect tense of the Hebrew verb (*nodaʿ*) implies that, upon the discovery of a body, an investigation is undertaken to determine whether the identity of the murderer can be ascertained. Once such an investigation is completed, the responsibility for atoning for the homicide falls to the city nearest to where the body has been discovered. The city would be designated by "your elders and your judges," a process that would ensure impartiality, since these officials would be from the entire region, not the individual city.

<span id="page-201-0"></span>21:3–4 Most laws in the ancient Near East required monetary payment to the victim's family in the case of murder, which would become the responsibility of the nearest city. In Israel, however, it was impossible to redeem a human life with money or any other sacrifice. Atonement or cleansing was made through ritual actions of the elders of the city. They were to take a heifer that had never worked a field and kill it by breaking its neck in a remote area that contained water but had never been worked for a crop. The significance of these stipulations is not explained, but some points are clear. This is not a sacrifice, since priests are not involved with the killing and since the blood plays no role in the death of the animal. Furthermore, it is not like the scapegoat on the Day of Atonement, which bears away guilt. Possibilities, which need not be mutually exclusive, are that it represents the execution of the murderer, the penalty borne by the elders of the city, or the act of the murder itself. The last possibility is supported by the fact that the heifer is to be killed in a remote area resembling the sort of place premeditated homicide would take place. The reason for its being near access to water is seen in the handwashing ceremony, which seems to be a declaration that the elders are free of any culpability for the death that has taken place.

<span id="page-201-1"></span>21:5–9 The priests are involved because of their role in the judicial system in dealing with cases of lawsuit and assault. No explicit role is given to them in this procedure, but their presence may have to do with the declaration of innocence that follows. This is not given in the form of an oath, but it may have been the equivalent of one. In any case the priests, as the officials responsible for maintaining the confessions of holiness and adherence to the covenant, are present to testify to the actions of the elders. The elders' washing their hands over the carcass of the animal cannot be transference of guilt to the animal, which would take place when the animal was alive. If the killing of the animal represents the act of the murderer, then the washing of the hands over the body of the animal would signify the innocence of the elders in relation to the murder. The psalmist could say, "All in vain have I kept my heart clean and washed my hands in innocence" (Ps. 73:13).

<span id="page-201-2"></span>The washing of hands is followed by a declaration of innocence and a prayer for absolution of guilt. As with all ritual, it is the prayer of faith that is effectual in removing bloodguilt from the land. The instructions conclude with a statement of absolution. The confession and prayer for absolution will purge the guilt of the murder. This provides for the safety of the entire nation, since keeping the covenant is both an individual and a collective responsibility. Nothing suggests that this ritual absolves the guilty party of the deed; if circumstances should change and the murder can be identified, the regulations of chapter 19 would still apply.

#### *Response*

The reality that God has given life means there must be accountability for every death. This is true even for animal life, for the hunter is required to pour the blood <span id="page-202-1"></span><span id="page-202-0"></span>on the ground to signify that he has taken a life he does not own (Lev. 17:13–14). The earth's covering the blood is an acknowledgment that the life belongs to God, who has provided the animal as food. Human life is of a different order, for humans are created as God's image, to represent him (Gen. 9:5–6). Earth cannot cover the blood of a human; thus God seeks accountability from the murderer. There is a time at which accountability will be demanded for every life taken, when the blood of the slain, which was intended to be hidden by the covering of earth, will be exposed. Isaiah speaks of this as a resurrection from the dead, when God goes forth to judge all the wickedness of the earth (Isa. 26:19–21).

<span id="page-202-6"></span><span id="page-202-4"></span><span id="page-202-3"></span>The blood of the innocent dead is the primary example of the way in which God will address all wrongs that have been done. This will be the day when God destroys Leviathan, the ancient representative of death and destruction (Isa. 27:1). John describes the day of a new heavens and a new earth, when there will be no more sea, the chaotic forces of death and destruction (Rev. 21:1–2). This will be true once the sea has given up all the dead it concealed and all the dead, small and great, will stand before the throne (Rev. 20:11–15). Death and Hades will be cast into the lake of fire; this is the second death.

<span id="page-202-5"></span>Contemporary societies have a police force that is made responsible for every death that occurs. In every society, even the most advanced, many deaths are unresolved, remaining in a file among the records of the force. There are unfortunately too many innocent deaths created by the state because of wrongly decided convictions—sometimes in actual taking of the victim's life, but more often in stealing that life through incarceration. In some ways the system of Israel was superior. The requirement of a minimum of two witnesses made the possibility of false conviction as remote as possible. All unresolved cases required a public and community acknowledgment of liability and accountability. That would bring a consciousness of the sacredness of human life to everyone for every death that occurred in a region. Such deaths are never removed from consciousness like a dead file in legal folders is, forgotten by all but the few intimate persons left to grieve.

After that you may go in to her and be her husband, and she shall be your wife. **14**But if you no longer delight in her, you shall let her go where she wants. But you shall not sell her for money, nor shall you treat her as a slave, since you have humiliated her.

So you shall purge the evil from your midst, and all Israel shall hear, and fear.

You shall not defile your land that the Lord your God is giving you for an inheritance."
