#### *Section Overview: Social Welfare in the Community*

<span id="page-231-1"></span><span id="page-231-0"></span>Although exhortation is characteristic of Deuteronomy, in this chapter it becomes a refrain that joins otherwise disparate laws. Israel must be careful to observe all the provisions of the covenant (24:8–9, 18, 22). The first law on divorce ends with the reminder that they must not commit sin against the land the Lord has given them (v. 4). The motivation for this exhortation is a common theme in Deuteronomy: they have been redeemed from Egypt, where they were slaves. The common requirement is care for the weak and vulnerable, remembering that this was their lot in Egypt. The regulations of this chapter range around a variety of usual situations, but all of them have in common a concern for the material protection of the defenseless.

The first regulation is material protection and security for a divorced wife. It requires a husband who divorces his wife to provide her with a divorce certificate. It guarantees the right of the woman to remarry and protects her property from any further claim by the divorcing husband. This remarkable provision for women does not derive from any other culture, though in other ways Israel shares similar practices of marriage and divorce as those of its neighbors.64 A related law is that of the newlywed husband, who is exempted from any obligation to military duty. This is particularly critical to the woman, because she does not yet have a secure or financially established home. The absence of her husband puts great stress on her—it makes her responsible for the care of the fields. Should her husband be injured or die in battle, she is left without children or many resources.

<span id="page-231-2"></span>The laws pertaining to collateral for loans and the protection of the life of the vulnerable share the same humanitarian concern. They are related in that property or financial interest must not take priority over the value of a human life. The chapter concludes with a stipulation that some of the harvest be left as food for the needy (vv. 19–21). The mandate for the poor is introduced and concluded with the exhortation to remember that the Israelites were slaves in the land of Egypt. Care for the poor is their spiritual responsibility as a redeemed people.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-232-2"></span><span id="page-232-1"></span><span id="page-232-0"></span>24:1–4 Although divorce is rarely encountered in the OT, it probably was as common in Israel as it was among other nations. Few regulations are given concerning the procedures of divorce, with this passage being the most specific. The only OT mentions of grounds for divorce are the failure of a husband to provide food, clothing, or conjugal relations (Ex. 21:10–11) and the "some indecency" mentioned in Deuteronomy 24:1. Differences between Scripture and the laws of other ancient nations include the rights of a woman to remain married and to remarry. The one absolute distinction of Israel was the woman's right to a divorce certificate, which affirmed she was free to remarry. The question of interpretation in the stipulation stated here concerns the conditions of the divorce that lead to the documentation given to the wife and that prevent the husband from ever marrying her again and therefore having access to her property.

The divorce law is formulated as a conditional sentence, a common form in legal material of ancient Near Eastern cultures. These have been called casuistic or case law because they first state a condition or circumstance in which the law applies. When the offense has been stated, along with associated matters (the protasis, or "if" clause), the response clause enunciates the legal pronouncement (the apodosis, or "then" clause). The lengthy protasis of this case constitutes seven distinct criteria that must be present: marriage of the woman, charge of indecency of the wife, divorce by the man, woman's remarriage, second husband's rejection, second husband's divorce (or death), and first husband's attempt to marry her again. In such a circumstance the remarriage is forbidden. The more usual cases of divorce involve simply a husband's hating his wife and divorcing her. In such a case the husband is required to repay the dowry to his wife and possibly provide other compensation, as stated everywhere in ancient Near Eastern law. But if a husband has a case for divorce, repayment of the dowry is not required. It is also possible that the husband could seek to marry the woman again, potentially for the financial benefit. In the case given by Moses in this example, the first husband is apparently seeking to divorce his wife with a minimum of financial penalty, using this charge against her to reduce his responsibilities.

In the course of time, it could be discovered that the claims made by the first husband were not valid, or they might be discounted, given the new circumstances of his former wife. She now would have considerably more wealth because of the intervening marriage, and he would want to marry her again if the opportunity arose. This is forbidden, because the husband would benefit twice. If he was able to divorce while paying the minimum penalty, a remarriage would further benefit him because she would come with her dowry and inheritance from her second husband. Denying the grounds of the original divorce for financial benefit is an abomination.

<span id="page-233-3"></span><span id="page-233-2"></span><span id="page-233-1"></span>Two lexical questions must be addressed in clarifying the prohibition of the remarriage of the divorced woman to her first husband. The first is the charge of "some indecency (v. 1)," and the second is the consequence of her being "defiled" (v. 4). The first is the rare Hebrew word *'erwat*, the same word used in relation to bodily exposures involving any kind of secretion that might defile the army camp (23:14). The second is *huttamma'ah*, found only here in the passive form. It carries the sense that she has been required to declare herself unclean, probably with reference to the charge of her first husband. The sense of *'erwat* must have something to do with sexuality; if the previous usage is a guide, it would also have to do with bodily secretions. It is probable that it has to do with menstruation, possibly a situation in which the woman has a continuous flow of blood, as in the case of the woman seeking help from Jesus (Mark 5:25–34).65 A problem of this nature would make her continuously unclean and therefore forbid her from intercourse. It might also prevent her from ever having children. The husband might have learned of this only after he married her and, instead of having compassion, divorce her in his own interests.

<span id="page-233-5"></span>Other similar interpretations have been proposed for this passage and fall within the semantic meaning of the stipulations of this law. As with other casuistic laws, this case is meant to be exemplary and may be intentionally ambiguous so as to include a variety of similar circumstances. By requiring a certificate of divorce and forbidding remarriage to the person who gave it, the law guarantees a woman's protection on two counts. She is assured of the right to remarry without fear of further interference from her first husband or any claims from him. She achieves financial independence and is perpetually free to remarry anyone else. Remarriage to her first husband would be a denial of the original reason for the divorce and a compromise of the freedoms she had received. Denial of the protection given in the divorce certificate is abhorrent to the Lord and brings wrong on the land the Lord is giving them.

The argument that the remarriage constitutes the woman as unclean is a fundamental contradiction to the purpose of the certificate. If the remarriage made her unclean, it would amount to adultery and would be forbidden outright. The protasis asserts the opposite: the certificate of divorce guarantees her right to remarry without penalty.

<span id="page-233-4"></span><span id="page-233-0"></span>24:5 Armies were summoned from the citizenry in time of need. These are wars for the citizenry: the people go out to war (Deut. 20:1). Small standing armies

<sup>65</sup> The linguistic case for this meaning has been made by John Walton, "The Place of the *hutqaṭṭēl* within the D-Stem Group and Its Implications in Deuteronomy 24:4," *HS* 32 (1991): 14–15.

supported Saul and David, while organized military warfare grew under Solomon. In general, however, men were summoned to battle as the need arose. Those newly establishing a home were exempt for the sake of their home and to meet the expectations of their new bride. This is another law with the well-being of women in mind, since the causative form of the verb does not merely mean "to be happy with his wife." Rather, the husband is to bring joy to his wife. The woman's expectations in marriage include much more than sexual satisfaction. Though the text is not explicit, the usual circumstance would be a first marriage for both the man and the woman.

<span id="page-234-4"></span><span id="page-234-3"></span>24:6–7 Loans could not be given at interest (23:19), but the creditor could have a type of lien on the debtor's property to ensure repayment. It is not specified that this is determined in advance. It might become a decision of the creditor when a loan is defaulted. But a creditor is limited in his claims for collateral until the loan is paid. He cannot claim an essential item such as a mill or a portion of it, which is present in every household for the purpose of making daily bread.

<span id="page-234-6"></span><span id="page-234-0"></span>The regulation on kidnapping is found with the same stipulations in Exodus 21:16, though Deuteronomy specifies the victim as an Israelite. It is likely that the same penalty would apply for a non-Israelite, as stated in Exodus. It may be that Moses is emphasizing the more egregious case of an Israelite who might take a human life as pledge for a loan. One of the crimes of the rich was to take the children of the poor in pledge for a loan (Job 24:9). This was not the same as a man's volunteering his services to work off a debt. Kidnapping, though no doubt rationalized legally, falls in the category of property and human life, which is an appropriate sequel to the laws on marriage and loans. However, the action of stealing a person for slavery reduces human life to property, the most egregious manner of violating life in the interests of material gain. It is particularly opprobrious and therefore subject to the same penalty as actually killing another person.

<span id="page-234-5"></span><span id="page-234-1"></span>24:8–9 The laws concerning leprosy are assumed to be well known. The command to observe them carefully is linked with the requirement to follow the teaching of the Levites in observance of the covenant that the Lord gave Israel when bringing them out of Egypt. The example of Miriam in Numbers 12:9–13 serves as a warning of the importance of observing all the commandments. Aaron compares the situation of Miriam to the curse of death (Num. 12:12), which may be why this law is singled out as an example of the necessity of observing the entire covenant. In this sense it is analogous to the kidnapped slave or the poor person left without a means to provide for his own food.

<span id="page-234-2"></span>A "leprous disease" is a good way of indicating that the Hebrew term refers to a wide variety of conditions that do not fall under the modern category of Hansen's disease. It affected many aspects of daily life in Israel and so was an appropriate example to use for the exhortation to faithfulness, which both concludes the previous section and introduces the following commands, which deal with the importance of not taking advantage of the poor.

<span id="page-235-2"></span>24:10–13 Money is always a contentious subject. Unpaid debts have always been a major problem for anyone engaging in commerce, even if it is simple peasant-level farming. Various kinds of pressure are used to collect on defaulted loans, including the confiscation of property. The stipulations of these verses set two limits on actions that can be taken to collect a loan. The first is that confiscation of property against a loan must be voluntary on the part of the debtor. The second is that the item confiscated must not endanger health or well-being. If a garment is used as a blanket at night, it must be returned each evening.

<span id="page-235-1"></span><span id="page-235-0"></span>Two different terms are used for the giving of an item in pledge as security for a loan. In Deuteronomy 24:6, 17 the Hebrew term is *habal*; in verses 10, 12 the term is *'abat.* The first term has the sense of seizing something as a pledge; the second refers to obtaining a deposit as collateral or making a loan against a deposit. The difference in the first case is that the pledge is taken after failure to pay the loan, while in the second the loan is made using a pledge as security. These are to be distinguished from *'arab*, which means to act as a guarantor of a loan for someone else. This is warned against in Proverbs repeatedly (e.g., Prov. 6:1; 11:15), as it carries the risk of total loss. One may be obligated to cover for a bad debt with no hope of any kind of recompense. The difference is comparable to the distinction between cosigning for the purchase of a property and acting as guarantor for a loan. In the case of cosigning, both parties hold title until the debt is fully paid. This provides a measure of collateral in case of default of payments.

<span id="page-235-5"></span><span id="page-235-3"></span>24:14–15 Laborers are dependent each day for payment, as they are landless and have no other resources. Delay of pay is a threat to their well-being and to their families. This is unacceptable conduct irrespective of whether the worker is a fellow Israelite. The admonition concludes with the warning that such conduct will bring judgment. The case of kindness in relation to pledges gives promise of blessing for the consideration given. All laborers deserve consideration and respect. They have a powerful recourse in being able to call out to a God of compassion.

<span id="page-235-4"></span>24:16 This law is an example of general requirements of justice in protecting human life. In biblical covenant code, human life always takes precedence. Justice is repayment of loss incurred and is never revenge. Such considerations were not the case with other codes. In contrast to the stipulation of this verse, the Code of Hammurabi addresses cases in which a builder is responsible for the collapse of a house, causing death or injury. In one such clause we read, "If it has caused the death of a son of the owner of the house, they shall put the son of that builder to death."66 The translation "Each one shall be put to death for his own sin" is not to be read as a theological statement referring to offenses against God. In the context of law, the word translated "sin" (Hb. *heteh*) refers to a legal offense or crime. It refers to missing the mark as stated in legal requirement.

<span id="page-236-11"></span><span id="page-236-3"></span>24:17–18 The admonitions to be careful not to exploit the weak and defenseless conclude with a general statement found frequently in the prophets. Isaiah singles out exactly this topic in his condemnation of the leaders of Israel for breaking the covenant (e.g., Isa. 1:16–17). Confiscating (Hb. *habal*, "take") an essential garment to collect on a debt recalls and concludes the previous examples. The whole section ends with a reminder of the mercy Israel has received.

<span id="page-236-4"></span><span id="page-236-1"></span>24:19–22 The whole chapter concludes with a final provision for the welfare of widows, aliens, and orphans. Farmers are not to be stingy in gathering up every last sheaf, olive, or grape in their harvest. The landless should also share in the harvest. The practice is illustrated in the book of Ruth, in which a widowed Moabite harvests in the fields of Boaz, a man who specifically orders consideration be given to her. This complements the tithe of every third year (Deut. 14:28–29), by which a tenth of the crop is given to the Levite and the poor of the land. The practice is mandatory, but in doing this the Israelites acknowledge that the land is a gift of God graciously given to them.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-236-5"></span><span id="page-236-2"></span>Chapter 24 provides specific examples that answer the question of the liturgies celebrated in Psalms 15 and 24. Psalm 24 begins with a confession concerning the Creator:

 The earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof, the world and those who dwell therein, for he has founded it upon the seas and established it upon the rivers. (24:1–2)

<span id="page-236-10"></span><span id="page-236-9"></span><span id="page-236-8"></span><span id="page-236-6"></span><span id="page-236-0"></span>Following this confession, which is a poetic declaration of the account of Genesis 1:1–2, those coming to worship are faced with the question "Who shall ascend the hill of the Lord? And who shall stand in his holy place?" (Ps. 24:3) The answer is those who keep their oath of the covenant, who have not taken the name of the Lord in vain, who have not sworn deceitfully (Ps. 24:4). This question is also the introduction of Psalm 15, and Psalm 15:2 provides essentially the same answer: those who live with integrity and do what is right. Moses is leading Israel in a renewal of the covenant when they enter the Promised Land. As he comes to conclude this Torah, Moses brings together the very practical, ordinary considerations of qualifying for worship at the place the Lord will choose.

<span id="page-236-7"></span>In Israel, worship at the temple was never separate from questions of faith and life. Psalm 15 provides a detailed answer to the question of integrity in the life of the covenant. It begins with speech. The words of worshipers are trustworthy: they do not speak ill of their neighbor; they never bring disgrace upon those around them. There is an acknowledged division within the people of Israel. On one side are those that are rejected (Ps. 15:4a) because they do not keep covenant. These are held in low regard, but those who fear the Lord are honored. Another issue of the psalm is money. The righteous do not loan money for gain nor accept a bribe against the innocent. Words and money are the two aspects of common life that are part of the activity of every day. Integrity with words and money is the qualification for worship because it is a manifestation of faithfulness.

Every visitor to Zion is asked to give a declaration of loyalty. Is the life of the covenant as taught by Moses in this chapter characteristic of your conduct? These simple sample activities are the measure of a righteous person. The gift of salvation in OT faith is not a magic center of power dispensed in impersonal fullness at temple festivals. Salvation is for those who come to the temple living the way of the covenant. They stand on the Rock that cannot be shaken. That Rock is the God of the temple built upon Mount Zion.

<span id="page-237-5"></span><span id="page-237-4"></span><span id="page-237-3"></span>These truths have an eschatological aspect for the Christian. Christ has become our wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption (1 Cor. 1:30). Christ is the fullness of everything the covenant demands of the righteous person. Membership in the new covenant is to belong to Christ. Those in Christ have come to Mount Zion, the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, the festive assembly of myriads of angels, to the Judge who is God of all, to the spirits of the righteous who are perfected, and to Jesus, the mediator of a new covenant whose blood speaks of better things than that of Abel (Heb. 12:22–24). The "spirits of the righteous made perfect" (Heb. 12:23) can be none other than those of faith who followed in the teaching of Moses. The blood of Abel cried out from the ground for justice, but the blood of Christ brings cleansing and redemption. Those of the church of the firstborn, which must refer to all those in the new covenant, are called to manifest their faith in their works (James 2:14–17). What does it profit if the person of faith says be warmed and filled to the person who is naked and has no food? The practice of faith for those coming to Mount Zion is also that of those who have come to the heavenly Jerusalem.

<span id="page-237-6"></span><span id="page-237-2"></span><span id="page-237-1"></span><span id="page-237-0"></span>Chapter 24 begins with the problem of marriage breakdown, referred to frequently because it is quoted by Jesus in response to a question concerning a right to divorce (Matt. 19:1–10). Jesus responds by saying divorce is not a right and that the only reference to divorce proceedings should not turn on questions of grounds establishing such a right. Moses avoids giving any grounds for divorce via the ambiguity of the first statement of the premise. The provision of Moses is about protecting a family in the covenant of Israel when marriage breaks down. Jesus does not extend the interpretation of this passage with grounds for remarriage. There are no grounds for remarriage, which is not to say it should never happen (cf. the Response section on 22:13–30 for a discussion on marriage). Divorce is a failure requiring forgiveness and restoration as far as it is possible. Such penitent persons do qualify for worship in the holy temple of the church.

### <span id="page-238-0"></span>DEUTERONOMY 25:1–19

25"If there is a dispute between men and they come into court and the judges decide between them, acquitting the innocent and condemning the guilty, **<sup>2</sup>** then if the guilty man deserves to be beaten, the judge shall cause him to lie down and be beaten in his presence with a number of stripes in proportion to his offense. **3**Forty stripes may be given him, but not more, lest, if one should go on to beat him with more stripes than these, your brother be degraded in your sight.

**<sup>4</sup>** "You shall not muzzle an ox when it is treading out the grain.

**<sup>5</sup>** "If brothers dwell together, and one of them dies and has no son, the wife of the dead man shall not be married outside the family to a stranger. Her husband's brother shall go in to her and take her as his wife and perform the duty of a husband's brother to her. **6**And the first son whom she bears shall succeed to the name of his dead brother, that his name may not be blotted out of Israel. **7**And if the man does not wish to take his brother's wife, then his brother's wife shall go up to the gate to the elders and say, 'My husband's brother refuses to perpetuate his brother's name in Israel; he will not perform the duty of a husband's brother to me.' **8**Then the elders of his city shall call him and speak to him, and if he persists, saying, 'I do not wish to take her,' **<sup>9</sup>** then his brother's wife shall go up to him in the presence of the elders and pull his sandal off his foot and spit in his face. And she shall answer and say, 'So shall it be done to the man who does not build up his brother's house.' **10**And the name of his house*<sup>1</sup>* shall be called in Israel, 'The house of him who had his sandal pulled off.'

**<sup>11</sup>** "When men fight with one another and the wife of the one draws near to rescue her husband from the hand of him who is beating him and puts out her hand and seizes him by the private parts, **<sup>12</sup>** then you shall cut off her hand. Your eye shall have no pity.

**<sup>13</sup>** "You shall not have in your bag two kinds of weights, a large and a small. **14**You shall not have in your house two kinds of measures, a large and a small. **15**A full and fair*<sup>2</sup>* weight you shall have, a full and fair measure you shall have, that your days may be long in the land that the Lord your God is giving you. **16**For all who do such things, all who act dishonestly, are an abomination to the Lord your God.

**<sup>17</sup>** "Remember what Amalek did to you on the way as you came out of Egypt, **18**how he attacked you on the way when you were faint and weary, and cut off your tail, those who were lagging behind you, and he did not fear God. **19**Therefore when the Lord your God has given you rest from all your enemies around you, in the land that the Lord your God is giving you for an inheritance to possess, you shall blot out the memory of Amalek from under heaven; you shall not forget."

#### *Section Overview: Order in the Community*

<span id="page-239-0"></span>As Moses brings his exposition of the Torah to a conclusion, he returns to regulations that pertain to the whole community. This is fitting, since the fourth topic of the exposition deals with domestic and civil regulations. The covenant community was defined by regulatory confessions that distinguished it as holy, belonging to God. These included items as disparate as the requirement to wear tassels (Deut. 22:12) and to exclude Moabites and Ammonites from the assembly (23:3–6). The concluding reference to Amalek at the very end of the fourth topic of civil regulations returns to the theme of the distinction of the Israelite community as belonging to God (25:17–19). Defining Israel as a holy community is not an assumption of moral superiority or any innate virtue. It declares the commitment of Israel to live according to the covenant under the sovereignty of the Suzerain who had redeemed them.

<span id="page-239-5"></span><span id="page-239-4"></span><span id="page-239-3"></span><span id="page-239-2"></span><span id="page-239-1"></span>Within such a community there would still be need of officials to settle the damages of private quarrels (25:1–3). In a physical conflict there might be serious injury from third-party intervention, requiring civil investigation and punishment (vv. 11–12). Death would raise problems in providing for the succession of the ownership of family property, requiring effective legislation for such a circumstance (vv. 5–10). There was always danger of economic violation in ordinary commerce through use of variable weights or measures (vv. 13–16). These disparate community regulations for order are arranged by certain catchwords not represented in translation, as will be noted in the exposition. This seems to be a common technique of scribes in the transmission of ancient texts, a vestige of techniques used in memorization and oral instruction. Until the invention of the printing press, most of community life functioned on oral transmission and mnemonic retention of detail. What appears to be arbitrary in a literary document might be quite logical in a life situation—what literary form critics labelled *Sitz im Leben*, a German phrase meaning "setting in life."

#### *Comment*

25:1–3 The section begins with a regulation concerning judicial procedure in determining sentences, one that sets limits on the punishment that can be administered. It is similar in form to the law forbidding the transference of penalty within <span id="page-240-3"></span>families in 24:16. Individuals involved in a fight might go to court so that what began as a private dispute then becomes a public case. A plurality of judges hears the case and determines punishment. If the offense is so egregious as to require physical punishment, the judges determine the actual number of strokes to be administered. The procedure is supervised by one of the judges, who counts the strokes as they are given. The maximum number is forty. The reason for this limit is that offenders are still citizens, part of the family; whatever their misdemeanor, they are not to be humiliated. Correction and deterrence are not effective if they are humiliating.

<span id="page-240-2"></span><span id="page-240-1"></span>Flogging is likely the punishment for the man who maligns his bride (22:18), the only actual case given in Scripture. In that case a fine is administered in addition to the flogging. The application in a civil context is an extension of punishment carried out in a domestic context, as expressed in the case of parents' bringing a son to civil attention (21:18–21). Its purpose is to be instructive and preventative, as is indicated by the nuance of the verb in 21:18. The Hebrew verb *yasar* always carries the sense of instruction. Punishment is never to be an exacting of revenge.

<span id="page-240-7"></span><span id="page-240-5"></span><span id="page-240-0"></span>25:4 If mnemonic devices are in part responsible for the way Deuteronomy has been transcribed, the position of the law concerning oxen is determined by the reference to beating. "Treading out the grain" renders the Hebrew root *dwsh*, which describes a method of beating the kernels from the head of the stalk. This might be done with a stick; Gideon was "beating" (*hobet*) the stalks of grain in a wine vat so as not to be seen by the Midianites (Judg. 6:11). Harvesting of olives was done by beating the branches to knock the fruit to the ground (Deut. 24:20). A labor-saving means of threshing (*dwsh*) wheat was to spread the grain on a rock and, with an ox, pull a weighted board fixed with iron or stones over the stalks (cf. the threshing sledge of Amos 1:3).

<span id="page-240-9"></span><span id="page-240-4"></span>Animals doing draught work normally eat as they pull. The farmer might object because it distracts the animal from working, and in this case the ox would be consuming valuable crop. The ox will not be much interested in dried straw; it will be aiming to lick up the kernels. This is another of the Deuteronomic laws that demands the respect of animals as living creatures in the world of the common. As expressed in Proverbs 12:10, a righteous man understands the desires of an animal.

<span id="page-240-8"></span><span id="page-240-6"></span>25:5–10 Levirate marriage accommodates the integrity of family and the order of community in the case of the death of a son who does not yet have children to become heirs. It provides for the marriage of his widow within the family. In that way, it is related to the general topic of the chapter. In terms of mnemonic devices, there may be an association here with references to parts of the body: punishment takes place before the face of a judge, the mouth of the oxen must not be muzzled, the widow refused marriage shames the man by drawing the sandal from his foot, and the injury in the intervention of the following section involves grasping the genitals.

The requirement has been given the name "levirate marriage" from the Latin *levir* ("husband's brother"). When a woman marries, she leaves her parental home and her right to the family property. The compensation for her inheritance is the dowry she takes with her. The assumption is that she is now entitled to live on the property of her husband's family. The law begins with the condition that two brothers live together. This is a statement to the effect that the brothers are interdependent. The implication is that they have married but have not yet attained independence in their share of the family inheritance. They are still living under the protection and provision of their parents. If one of the husbands dies, his wife is the responsibility of the family. She must not be left without property or the legacy of her husband. This law requires a man to manage the property of his brother and to provide eventual heirs for that property.

<span id="page-241-0"></span>This requirement was not advantageous to the surviving brother. It involved significant investment in a property that would eventually become part of another family independent of his own. The significance of this cost caused Onan, son of Judah, to prevent the pregnancy of his brother's wife, Tamar (Gen. 38:8–10). The consequence of avoiding this obligation were grave: Onan died as a judgment from God. Judah kept Tamar as part of his household but out of fear did not fulfill the further obligation of giving her in marriage to his second son. Another example of this law is in the story of the widow Ruth. Ruth was the daughter-in-law of Naomi, who held property at Bethlehem. The nearest of kin declined to take on the obligation of caring for an additional family (Ruth 4:6)—it would endanger his own properties. Boaz then purchased the property as a redeemer, which is not the same as marrying the brother of the deceased. Each of these stories is a variation on the law given in Deuteronomy, probably indicative of variation of practice over time. Laws like this were common in the ancient Near East, though they may have functioned in variant ways.

<span id="page-241-6"></span><span id="page-241-5"></span><span id="page-241-1"></span>The reason for the law is to prevent a man's name from being blotted out (Deut. 25:6), that is, to prevent a person from losing his inheritance. The import of continuing the name is expressed by Jacob in adopting Ephraim and Manasseh in Genesis 48:4–6. Jacob adopts the sons of Joseph as his own, and they receive their inheritance in Canaan. Jacob justifies this authority based on the recognition that the divine promise of the land of Canaan is an inheritance to his sons. Later sons of Joseph would receive an inheritance in the name of their older brothers. In the same way the sons of a levirate marriage would take the name of their deceased "father." Preserving the name for the sake of inheritance was important. If a man only had daughters, they would receive the inheritance and become the means of perpetuating his name (Num. 27:1–11). The children may have retained the name of their mother's father.

<span id="page-241-4"></span><span id="page-241-3"></span><span id="page-241-2"></span>This is an exceptional circumstance of marriage that stands in contradiction to the general prohibition of sexual relations with a brother's wife (Lev. 18:16; 20:21). The importance of this responsibility is indicated by the consequences of refusing to accept it. It involves a public ceremony of removing a sandal from the <span id="page-242-1"></span>foot of the brother and spitting in his face. The reputation of the family remains tarnished forever via a pejorative epithet. In the book of Ruth, the relative who transfers to Boaz the right of purchasing the property of Elimelek takes off his sandal and hands it over to Boaz. In Deuteronomy 25:9 the widow removes the sandal without handing it over, which may mean that she has now seceded from the family, which has no further claim on her. This would mean the deceased brother would simply disappear from the family. Whether she spit directly in the face of the brother or on the ground in front of him, this would be a defiant and hostile gesture, expressing the humiliation felt by the widow and the emotion of her being excluded from her husband's family.

<span id="page-242-2"></span>25:11–12 The law prescribing a penalty of mutilation for injury caused to genitals may be related to the previous regulation regarding marriage, in light of the gravity in both cases of endangering the prospect of posterity. This law is remarkable in singling out a woman for inflicting this specific injury. The motives for the woman's intervention are laudable, which makes the penalty particularly harsh. But the seriousness of the woman's action must not be minimized. Genital injury is not only extremely painful but can be fatal.67 It is surprising that the punishment is mutilation, since this is nowhere else a penalty in biblical law. It caused great discussion among the rabbis; it may be that some of their inferences are correct. The usual punishment for bodily injury is a fine; the amount of which is stated in terms of the nature of the injury inflicted, as expressed in Exodus 21:22–25. The rabbis inferred that a fine is also meant in this instance (*Sifre Deuteronomy*  §292). Since this injury cannot be inflicted on a woman, the fine is expressed in terms of the hand that caused the injury. The Hebrew term for hand (*yad*) is used also to refer to male genitals, so it is sometimes suggested that this is the female equivalent in expressing the penalty to be imposed.

<span id="page-242-3"></span><span id="page-242-0"></span>25:13–16 Integrity in weights and measures pertains to every individual, not only merchants. This is the last legal requirement in the exposition of the law, and it is applicable to all Israelites. Its climactic position indicates that honesty in all transactions is critical in the maintenance of social order. Before the time of currency, money was measured by weight via a balance scale. A stone was the common means of determining the amount of silver paid (the most common metal of currency). A temptation would be the use of a lighter stone when buying and a heavier one when selling. The same would hold for measures of volume; the measure given is an ephah, a common amount that would be traded for grain equal to a tenth of a homer, a term derived from the weight a donkey could carry (c. 200 pounds [90 kg], four bushels of barley in modern weight). In volume an ephah was about three-fifths of a bushel. The standard measure of an ephah varied over time, so the temptation would be to use the standard advantageous in a transaction. The prophet Amos condemns the merchants of Israel who sell with a small ephah

<sup>67</sup> This commentator's great-grandfather died because of just such an injury inflicted by his father-in-law. The consequences were severe, resulting in a complication of marriages and eventual emigration from Poland.

<span id="page-243-6"></span>and a heavy shekel (Amos 8:5). When standard measures were not very precise, it was easier to be fraudulent. Amos specifies this practice (Amos 8:5) as one of the injustices that brings an end to the kingdom of Israel after Jeroboam II.

<span id="page-243-2"></span><span id="page-243-1"></span><span id="page-243-0"></span>25:17–19 The attack of the Amalekites is described in Exodus 17:8–16. Amalek is the thirteenth descendant of Esau in Genesis 36. He was born to Timna, a Horite, a people indigenous to Mount Seir. The Edomites largely displaced them, making them nomads in the Sinai Peninsula. The sudden appearance of the Israelites in the Sinai was a threat to Amalekite control of oases and trade routes. They attacked Israel at a most vulnerable time. According to Psalm 83:4–9 they were among other nations who plotted to destroy Israel. They rank with the Canaanites as perpetual enemies of Israel.

<span id="page-243-4"></span>The command to remember is characteristic of Deuteronomy and an appropriate close to this section on the life of the community of Israel. The name of Amalek is to be blotted out so that the Amalekites lose all rights to their territory. This command concludes a key topic of the chapter, the entitlement of property expressed by not blotting out someone's name. The first attempt to eliminate the Amalekites was assigned to Saul (1 Samuel 15), but their removal from the territory was accomplished by David.

#### <span id="page-243-3"></span>*Response*

Conflict within families and societies is a problem that sometimes requires coercive intervention, as recognized by the stipulations of this chapter. The provisions of Moses are practical and effective in providing security and stability. They are a means by which communities could control crime within their midst in a way that is the least disruptive and as positively corrective as possible. Executions are limited to extreme cases. The goal is to enable citizens to live free and independent lives as much as possible, which requires being responsible for those who come into difficult situations.

<span id="page-243-5"></span>The modern convention of prison as a means of controlling offenders was impossible in ancient times. Confinement was limited and temporary. People were restrained as captives in war or as political enemies. Samson was a prisoner-of-war bound by the Philistines and made a slave. Sometimes prisoners were kept in custody rather than killed, as in the case of Jeremiah (Jer. 37:15–16). Other confined persons might be debtors working off obligations. For ancient societies, confinement as punishment was inconceivable for controlling violence and corruption. Not only were prisons too expensive to maintain but families relied on detained persons to provide for them. This is not true in most parts of the world today, where families must provide not only for themselves but for the person confined.

Control of violence in modern Western societies is less stark than the public executions and torture practiced in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Public resistance to these extremes led to the growth of a modern prison system that could be defended as a deterrent and a correction. Prisons were established

as an opportunity for instruction and moral reform, but their development has been in the opposite direction. People of like mind are grouped together and learn from each other how to carry out their nefarious work more effectively. In time many prisoners find prison to be the best home for them—a place where they are secure and can function.

Modern prison systems are part of a legal system that claims to deliver justice. Legislation is enacted by governments as codes. These codes are enforced by courts that administer punishment, which has two essential forms: a monetary fine or prison. Justice is conceived as the right of the state to inflict penalty for violation of the state legal code. A problem with this conception of justice is that the victim of an offense is left out of the equation. A further problem is that punishment for the most part generates anger, as punishment alone does not correct. Often the connection between offense and punishment is remote and arbitrary, such as in confining nonviolent people for economic crimes. The penal system called justice is in many cases not only unjust but also ineffective and expensive.

<span id="page-244-1"></span><span id="page-244-0"></span>The biblical system of justice operates on a different principle. Justice is always a matter of paying for damages done to the victim. It is a matter of caring for the poor and the needy (e.g., Isa. 1:16–17). The responsibility of the community was to protect the victim and provide for its dependent members. This did not preclude the possibility of corrective measures, as may be seen in the first regulation of Deuteronomy 25. Administration of physical beating was intended for correction, with a stipulation that limited the punishment so that it did not turn into humiliation. Cases of imprisonment had nothing to do with justice or correction of moral conduct. In the biblical system punishment and correction are distinct concepts. Punishment is administered for threats against the state, as in the outbreak of war or political revolution.

<span id="page-244-2"></span>Some matters of justice remain unchanged, such as honesty in using weights and measures. The means of theft and fraud change with technology, but the need to control such schemes is the same. One of the biggest problems in Scripture is state complicity in economic corruption, as in the days of Ahaz (e.g., Mic. 6:9–12). The whole court system was controlled by corruption supported by the political power of Judah. A few became wealthy at the expense of the poor and dependent. The world has not changed in this respect. Christians must seek to live in their own situation with as much as justice and integrity as is possible. This begins with understanding clearly the distinct concepts of justice and punishment, a difference nonexistent in modern penal systems.

1Hebrew *with great terror*

#### *Section Overview: Offerings of Firstfruits and Tithes*

<span id="page-246-7"></span><span id="page-246-5"></span><span id="page-246-4"></span>This chapter brings the exposition of this Torah back to its opening theme of making confession at the place the Lord will choose (Deut. 12:1–31). The Torah required every representative to appear at the place of divine choosing three times a year (16:16–17). Two additional ceremonies are prescribed as Moses concludes the regulations of the covenant. The first is the presentation of a symbolic gift of the first of the harvest, given to the priest at the place God will choose (26:1–11). The second is the completion of the tithe of the third year in each city (26:12–15). The time of each is determined by the harvest. The first takes place as soon as the harvest has begun; the second when all the harvest is complete, enabling the amount of the tithe to be calculated. These ceremonies emphasize not the ritual detail but rather the confession that accompanies them. The first is testimony to divine redemption. The second is an assertion that the responsibility to care for the poor and vulnerable has been fully and properly carried out.

<span id="page-246-8"></span><span id="page-246-3"></span>All of the ceremonies prescribed by Moses are a part of worship that is intimately connected to the agricultural cycle. This is not an accident. The dictum of Deuteronomy is that mortals do not live by bread alone (8:3). The gift of food is no less a daily miracle than the gift of life. All mortals must know that the life-giving Word of God is the means of life. It is fatal self-deception to believe that in some way those who are made by God as his image can live independently from him. Israel was an agrarian society that lived directly off the land, providing a regular reminder that the source of life is the one who has given them the covenant.

<span id="page-246-6"></span><span id="page-246-1"></span><span id="page-246-0"></span>The chapter concludes with the mandate of the great Shema as given in 6:4–5. Israel's devotion to serving God must be with all their heart and all their soul (26:16). The closing verses of chapter 26 form an inclusio with the entire second speech of Moses, which began with the exhortation to learn to fear the Lord God (6:2). Moses reminds Israel again that God has led them to make the great confession that they are a treasured people distinct from all nations because of God's love for them (26:18–19). Their distinction as a holy people (v. 19) recalls what Moses said at 7:6 and 14:2. Israel was not just another nation among the common. Their function was to represent God in the world, and they had a sacred duty to declare the majestic name of God continually, as expressed in Psalm 8.

#### <span id="page-246-11"></span><span id="page-246-9"></span><span id="page-246-2"></span>*Section Outline*

- II.D. Confessions of a Treasured People (26:1–19)
	- 1. Confession in the Offering of Firstfruits (26:1–11)
- 2. Confession at the Completion of the Tithe (26:12–15)
- 3. Divine Mandate to Be a Holy People (26:16–19)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-247-7"></span><span id="page-247-6"></span>26:1–4 The ceremony of the firstfruits is to take place when Israel has settled in the land, when families have received their allotted land and are able to harvest crops. Although the description requires the ceremony upon first entering the land, the intent of the instruction is for it to be observed every year. The formulation of the instruction makes clear that it must obeyed at the very first harvest. The firstfruits must be brought from each crop (v. 2). Since crops mature at different times, those at a distance from the temple would probably make a single journey with all the different firstfruits alongside others from their community. They might make the pilgrimage in connection with one of the three regular festivals (Passover, Weeks, and Tabernacles), since each of these was also set around harvest times for various crops. The amount offered was not critical, as it was representative of the whole crop.

The procedure is stated cryptically, so the sequence of the ceremony is ambiguous. The implied order is that the farmer hands his basket to the priest at the entrance of the court, declaring that this is the evidence that God has fulfilled his promise to bring the people to the land. The priest takes the basket to the altar in the court and sets it down. The farmer then makes confession of God's redemption to the priest and picks up the basket beside the altar (v. 10), declaring that he has fulfilled the obligation of the firstfruits. Both the priest and the farmer are involved in these actions.

<span id="page-247-3"></span><span id="page-247-2"></span><span id="page-247-1"></span><span id="page-247-0"></span>26:5–11 The confession at the giving of the firstfruits recounts the story of Israel, beginning with Jacob, who went to Egypt near the end of his life, at the age of 130. He described all his years as few and full of trouble (Gen. 47:9). All this is summarized by saying that Jacob was a "wandering [or "perishing"; *'obed*] Aramean" (Deut. 26:5). The ambiguity of the word *'obed* appropriately describes the life of Jacob. His life was one of wandering, as he was driven to his uncle Laban in the land of Paddan-aram to escape the fury of his brother. He lived much of his life in light of the deception of his sons, who led him to believe the child of his beloved Rachel was dead. Only as he was dying did his family come to be reunited, and even then in a foreign land. His wanderings extended from Paddan-aram to Egypt, most of them in sorrow and the shadow of death. But the farmer now makes triumphant declaration of how the mercy of God has prevailed. Jacob has become a great nation, and the slavery of Egypt has turned into the opportunity of a land oozing with milk and honey. This is therefore a time of joy and celebration for everyone, including those who do not have actual property in the land but can enjoy all its benefits.

<span id="page-247-5"></span><span id="page-247-4"></span>26:12–15 The tithe of the third year is holy (v. 13). This is no longer like the food that was eaten every day, just as the bread and wine on the communion table

are not just bread and wine any longer. As long as the bread and wine are on the communion table, they are not to be eaten as ordinary food. Every third year in each settlement, one tenth of the entire crop took on the same sacred character. The farmer made a vow that he had purged his storehouses entirely of that tenth, which belonged to God. It would of course be eaten, but not as the food that is eaten every day. It was another of means by which God provided for the Levite and the settler that did not have land, as well as those who had suffered the loss of a provider for the family.

The tithe was further declared holy in that it was kept pure from any ceremonial contamination, which would be offensive to the confession that God is holy and the giver of all that sustains life. "Unclean" is in some way representative of death. Partaking of the tithe while in mourning or after touching a dead body would be a direct contradiction of the purpose of the tithe. Giving of the tithe to the dead is likely a reference to some other worship. All idols are regarded as dead since they have no substance. The celebration of the life God gives through the food he provides must not be compromised.

<span id="page-248-3"></span><span id="page-248-2"></span><span id="page-248-1"></span><span id="page-248-0"></span>26:16–19 These verses hold a double function: they conclude the two major sections of the second speech of Moses, namely, the prologue and the stipulations, and they transition to the blessings and curses that conclude the instruction of Moses. The emphasis is on "this day" (v. 16), the time Moses is speaking to the Israelites on the plains of Moab. This thought is continued in 28:1, where Moses begins with the need to remember "today" that the Lord has set the Israelites apart from the nations. The transition to the blessings and curses concludes with the declaration that they are a holy people (26:19). The divine declaration is not just illocutionary, as suggested by the translation "the Lord has declared today that you are a people for his treasured possession." The verb is causative in Hebrew, meaning that God has brought the people to the place where they are able to declare the words of the oath. They have been empowered by the mercy of God to make the statement that they are a treasured people, set apart to God as holy.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-248-4"></span>The responsibility to make a confession of thanksgiving and to fulfill the tithe in caring for the poor is one of the ways Israel distinguishes itself as a holy people. These activities are an integral part of what it means to be spiritual. The apostle Paul says as much in describing the apostate condition of mankind in Romans 1:18–21. The wrath of God is revealed from heaven upon all those who hold the truth in unrighteousness. The invisible nature of God is clearly known from creation through the things made, even his power and divine nature. Knowing God, rebellious humans did not glorify him as God, neither were they thankful. This is understandable: those who deny God believe in some sense that they are autonomous and self-sufficient, on par with god, and therefore that there is no reason to give thanks. This tends to be characteristic of our world, which has many demands of entitlements but feels no need to give thanks for anything. What is not understandable is the attitude of those who believe life and its provisions are a gift from God but are not thankful, or at least never declare their thanks in a public way.

The importance of thanksgiving must not be minimized. Those who believe that humans do not live by bread alone should be particularly thoughtful about giving thanks for food. The logical time to do so is when participating in a meal. A particularly significant time to do so is when participating in a meal in a public setting. This is the most powerful way to give testimony to faith. In Israel this was to be done immediately at the beginning of harvest. Apart from the ceremony of this chapter, which is specifically a declaration of thanksgiving, declaring the provision of God was a part of the beginning of the harvest at Passover, the end of the grain harvest at the Feast of Weeks, and the completion of all harvesting at Tabernacles. In the same way Christians need to make thanksgiving a regular part of worship.

<span id="page-249-3"></span>An important concept is that tithes that belong to God are holy, which means they function in the world of the common to represent the creator of the world, who provides all things. Malachi has it right when he declares the people to be under a curse because they have robbed God in tithes and offerings (Mal. 3:8–9). Malachi is referring to a specific obligation pertaining to his time. His readers would be expected to know what amount was required in their circumstance and would be readily able to calculate their shortfall. Their failure brought them under judgment.

<span id="page-249-2"></span><span id="page-249-0"></span>The OT contains various instructions concerning the practice of the tithe. The different instructions for the tithe appear to pertain to changing circumstances. Differences include both the collection of the tithe and its distribution. In Leviticus and Numbers the tithe is specified for the Levites and priests in support of their work of the place of meeting (Num. 18:20–32; cf. Lev. 27:30–33). Deuteronomy 26:12–15 refers to one specific tithe, that of the poor calculated in the third year. The amount is the gross income of the crop when harvested. Tithing under the covenant of Moses pertains both to the support of temple personnel and to support for the poor. Deuteronomy says the tithe is to be taken to the central place, where it is eaten by both the poor and the Levites (12:5–19). Deuteronomy 14:22–29 further states that the tithe can be converted to money when food could be purchased at the proper place. The tithe of the third year is in a different category altogether. These regulations are not harmonized with those found in Leviticus and Numbers.

<span id="page-249-5"></span><span id="page-249-1"></span>Christians live in a different situation, in which they have a primary obligation to the church and its work, which includes help for the poor. Paul says Christians should work to be able to give more (Eph. 4:28). The goal of life is to be as generous as possible in all circumstances.68 Governments of advanced economies levy many kinds of taxes, which may amount to about half of personal earnings.69 Money

<span id="page-249-4"></span><sup>68</sup> For understanding grace in Christian giving (2 Cor. 8:7) an excellent resource is Iain Duguid, *Should Christians Tithe? Excelling in the Grace of Giving*, (Glenside: PA: St. Colme's, 2018), e-book.

<sup>69</sup> According the Fraser Institute, Tax Freedom Day in Canada in 2019, the time in the year by which the average worker had worked long enough to pay that year's tax burden, was June 14.

<span id="page-250-0"></span>that is taxed is owed to the government; it falls outside of discretionary income from which donations may be made. Governments may allow some of its taxes to be deducted by virtue of a donation receipt, which is a way to channel some extra giving. Christians must be able to say, "I have removed the sacred portion out of my house, and moreover, I have given it to the Levite, the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow, according to all your commandment that you have commanded me" (Deut. 26:13). Great joy is found in exercising such spirituality, and great blessing is promised to those engaging in this holy act.

#### *Section Overview: Covenant Ceremony at Shechem*

<span id="page-251-4"></span><span id="page-251-3"></span><span id="page-251-2"></span>Chapter 26 concludes by declaring, "He will set you in praise and in fame and in honor high above all nations that he has made" (v. 19). Chapter 28 resumes the sermon with the words "The Lord your God will set you high above all the nations of the earth" (28:1). The covenant words of the second sermon conclude with the blessings and curses in chapter 28, as is typical of covenant form. Chapter 27 interrupts the covenant words with instructions for the enactment of the ceremony in Shechem. When scribes inserted relevant material into a narrative text, the beginning and the end of the insertion are marked by what has been termed a resumptive repetition. The scribes used this technique to set apart intervening material. Another obvious example of this is the insertion of the genealogy of Moses and Aaron in the exodus account (Ex. 6:14–26). No conclusions can be drawn about when these instructions were included within the covenant. These instructions may have come from Moses, just as the genealogy in Exodus might have been from Moses, or they may have come from another source. The goal was to include them in the teaching of Moses in Moab. This was the logical place to insert them within the words of the covenant, as the insertion pertains to how the act of affirming the blessings and curses will be carried out.

<span id="page-251-6"></span><span id="page-251-5"></span><span id="page-251-0"></span>Chapter 27 is an abrupt shift in form to instructions for the ceremony that will eventually be enacted for enforcing the covenant given in Deuteronomy. The form reverts to the third person, describing what Moses commanded the people, the same form found in the epilogue beginning in chapter 29. This ceremony was carried out by Joshua, as narrated in Joshua 8:30–35 and repeated in Joshua 24. The instruction of Moses for the ceremony at Moab shifts to the blessings and

<span id="page-252-2"></span><span id="page-252-0"></span>curses by recalling the words God had spoken at Sinai, setting Israel apart as a nation (Ex. 19:5–6). The assembly was led by God to declare that they were his treasured possession (Deut. 26:18). At Sinai Israel became a holy people, not just one nation among others. The covenant words are resumed after the description of the ceremony itself.

<span id="page-252-6"></span><span id="page-252-4"></span>The crossing of the Jordan is mentioned twice (27:2, 4), each time followed by the dictate to set up stones on which the commandments are to be written. Are the commandments written on the stones of the altar, which must be rough and natural, or are they written on stones that have been appropriately prepared for engraving? Although the question is vigorously debated, the text makes clear that the commandments are engraved for perpetuity and proper burnt offerings and community offerings are made on the altar. The stones in verse 8 should not be understood as the altar stones; they are the stones of verses 2–4. The inscription of the Torah is made upon these stones. The altar ceremony is included as a part of the rite for inscribing the stones. The scribes have inserted it within the account so that verses 4 and 8 are an inclusio around the altar description. The altar sacrifice is a separate event from the act of inscribing the Torah on pitched stone. Altars are not the place for inscriptions.

<span id="page-252-8"></span><span id="page-252-7"></span><span id="page-252-5"></span>Procedures for the ceremony at Ebal and Gerizim describe the making of a covenant in which blessings and curses are declared (vv. 9–13). Nothing is said about the content of these blessings and curses. The curses that follow in verses 14–26 are a part of a third ceremony in which anyone breaking the covenant that has been sworn is anathematized. This is carried out by the Levites; the assembly responds only with an "Amen" of affirmation. These two sections should not be read as part of the same ceremony.

<span id="page-252-1"></span>The ceremonies at Shechem are one with the teaching of Moses in Moab. The chapter is a bridge within the teaching of the covenant, which ends with this theme in chapter 26 and takes it up at the beginning of chapter 28. It is likely that all three ceremonies—the altar sacrifices, the declaration of the Torah, and the anathema—took place on the occasion when Israel established the altar at Shechem.

- II.E. Covenant Ceremony at Shechem (27:1–26)
	- 1. Erection of an Altar (27:1–8)
		- a. Inscription of the Commandments (27:1–3)
		- b. Offering of Sacrifices (27:4–8)
	- 2. Instructions for the Ceremony (27:9–26)
		- a. Blessings and Curses (27:9–13)
		- b. Curses for Secret Sins (27:14–26)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-252-3"></span>27:1–3 The enactment of the covenant is ambiguous regarding various questions. As is evident in translation, the stones are to be set up on the day when the people cross the Jordan. It is impossible to travel from Gilgal, the point where Israel enters the land, to Shechem in one day. Joshua carries out the ceremony after the conquest of Jericho and Ai, which must be the intended sense, despite the way the account reads.

"All the words of this law" includes everything that is part of the second sermon of Moses. Inscribing in stone the words that are to endure as public reference was a common way of permanently publicizing a text. The use of plaster would be much less durable, giving the impression that this law is a temporary provision for consulting the words of the teaching of Moses once they enter the land. It may be assumed that upon entry of the land Israel would not have the luxury afforded established empires to publicize documents engraved in stone.

<span id="page-253-4"></span><span id="page-253-3"></span><span id="page-253-1"></span>27:4–8 The altar at Shechem is a contradiction to the requirement of Deuteronomy that worship be at the one place God will choose, but it is interpreted as a temporary provision before the establishment of the tabernacle at Shiloh (Josh. 18:1). Shiloh is the location where the land is allocated once it is subdued (Josh. 18:8–10). Just as there is some time between the entrance to the land and the covenant ceremony at Shechem, more time will be required before a more permanent place can be found for the tabernacle. The altar at Shechem is the immediate but temporary location of worship.

Mount Ebal is on the north side of the valley above Shechem. It is the highest mountain in the vicinity, with a height of over 3,000 feet (900 m), providing a commanding view of the Promised Land: Hermon to the north, Jordan and Gilead to the east, the hills of Jerusalem to the south, and the Mediterranean to the west. This may be what makes it ideal for a ceremony celebrating Israel's arrival in the land. The altar built there follows the requirements of Sinai given in Exodus 20:24–26. Altars made for God must have no appearance of the craft of idolatry. The peace offering celebrates the well-being of the community. It is the only offering consumed largely by those making the offering and thus is most appropriate for celebration.

<span id="page-253-2"></span><span id="page-253-0"></span>27:9–13 The division of tribes in the covenant ceremony places the central tribes of Judah and the northern hill country on Mount Gerizim; the more peripheral tribes of Galilee and those across the Jordan are stationed on Mount Ebal. The expressions used for the blessing and the curse are significantly different from each other. The tribes on Gerizim proclaim a blessing for the people or make a declaration blessing the people. The tribes on Ebal stand as supervisors or observers of the curse. To "stand . . . for the curse" is a circumlocution to avoid the sense that someone is being cursed. The import of the actions is not expressly given. Perhaps each group acts only as an audience for the other, or they may be acting on behalf of everyone. The intent may be that the group on Gerizim pronounces a blessing on the assembly while the group on Ebal stands as representatives for the curse. The blessings and curses are the divinely imposed consequences of obedience or rebellion, life or death.

<span id="page-254-0"></span>Nothing is said about the actual contents of the blessings and the curses, but Deuteronomy 11:27–29 states that these are circumstantial descriptions of reward and punishment. They declare the results of obedience or disobedience of the covenant stipulations in specified situations, as is typical of covenant ceremonies.

<span id="page-254-3"></span>27:14 This verse introduces the Levites who will speak to all the assembly of Israel in a loud voice. This stands in contrast to the division of tribes on Gerizim and Ebal, in which six tribes speak a blessing and the other six a curse. The Levites are not said to have a distinguished role in those proceedings. In this ceremony the Levites do the speaking and the people make a one-word response. There is no reference to blessings in this ceremony, and no actual curses are laid on anyone. Various actions are interdicted. An oath or imprecation against a person guilty of these actions is declared with the response of "Amen."

<span id="page-254-5"></span>27:15–26 Twelve common prohibitions are given in this list. All but the twelfth comprehensive statement are found in the commandments elsewhere. The first and the last are distinguished in form, though this is obscured in translation. They read "cursed be anyone who . . ." (AT), while the others simply say "cursed be." As the introduction and conclusion, they deal with the sins emphasized the most, namely, idolatry, which violates fundamental allegiance to the holy, and subversion of the teaching that the Holy One has given.

<span id="page-254-4"></span>The ceremony is designed to prevent these offenses and to declare divine punishment for violations. An anathema is pronounced upon anyone who commits them. The response of "Amen" is a commitment by those hearing the words spoken that they will not do these things. All the offenses listed take place in secret and therefore are impossible to detect and punish. The word "secret" is specified in the case of making an idol (v. 15) and striking a fellow citizen (v. 24). The most sinister of idolatries and assaults are done clandestinely; these are the ones intended here. The other crimes are also secret in nature: cursing parents, moving a boundary, misleading the blind, subverting justice, engaging in sexual sin, and taking a bribe to cover up murder. This is an appropriate warning and oath once the people have entered the land. There can be no thought of feigning allegiance to the sovereign God who has shown such mercy and granted them the privilege of land.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-254-2"></span><span id="page-254-1"></span>The ceremonies at Shechem are set in the context of Israel's pondering its role as the people who belong to God (27:9–10). The events at Shechem establish the profound significance of what has happened in Moab. "Keep silence" translates a word used only in verse 9 and is otherwise found only in the Akkadian word *sakātu*. The command is significant not only to Israel but to the church. The distinction of Israel as the nation of priests informs the identity and calling of the church. This is a sacred responsibility that must be remembered every hour and minute.

Deuteronomy makes the establishment of the identity of the people of God central to its message. The teaching of the Ten Words and the exhortation to love <span id="page-255-1"></span>and fear God were concluded with the directive that Israel would carry out the covenant ceremony at Shechem (11:29–30). Chapter 27 returns to more detailed information concerning this covenant ceremony as the exposition of this Torah concludes. The inclusion of the ceremony at Shechem binds together the terms of the covenant as a cohesive unit. It joins the prologue of the covenant (chs. 5–11) to the exposition (chs. 12–26), and it points forward to the time in the Promised Land at which Israel will take the vow of obedience.

<span id="page-255-2"></span><span id="page-255-0"></span>The three ceremonies prescribed in this chapter are critical to the spiritual life of Israel. The burnt offerings are a declaration of giving to God the life he has given to them. Such sacrifices provide no personal benefit to anyone. The peace offerings are communal. They are holy in that they belong to God, but they are eaten as a communal meal in drawing the assembly together in unity and equality. The taking of a vow over the written commandments is a declaration of commitment to doing the will of God as a holy people. The ceremony of anathema is a warning to remember that there is no escaping the consequences of the breaking of the covenant. Choosing to reject God does not mean that he will no longer be involved in the life of the disobedient person. God is with his people in either the blessing or the curse.

<span id="page-255-5"></span>The church as the people of God performs all of these same functions. Sacrifices for the Christian are expressed in praise (Heb. 13:15–16). These sacrifices are the confession of our lips and the sharing of good deeds, sacrifices that are well-pleasing to God. True worship, according to James, is to care for the orphans and the widows (James 1:27), but this does not displace the good confession (1 Tim. 3:15– 16). The church is a pillar of truth, the unshakeable work of God (Gk, *hedraiōma*, "buttress"; 1 Tim. 3:15). Great is the confession of the mystery of godliness:

<span id="page-255-4"></span><span id="page-255-3"></span> He was manifested in the flesh, vindicated by the Spirit, seen by angels, proclaimed among the nations, believed on in the world, taken up in glory.

An early Christian song such as this has its continuation in modern hymns that declare the same mystery of faith. Ponder the words of Michael Perry:

 Then hear, O gracious Saviour, accept the love we bring, that we who know your favour may serve you as our king; and whether our tomorrows be filled with good or ill, we'll triumph through our sorrows and rise to bless you still:

 to marvel at your beauty and glory in your ways, and make a joyful duty our sacrifice of praise.70

The sacrifices made to sing these profound words are no less worthy than all those associated with the making of the vows of the covenant at Shechem.

<span id="page-256-0"></span>The church also has its anathemas. Paul offers a stern warning for the Galatians. If anyone should declare a gospel contrary to what they have received, even if it be a messenger from heaven, "Let him be accursed [*anathema*]" (Gal. 1:8, 9). Paul concludes his first letter to the Corinthians in his own hand with the words, "If anyone has no love for the Lord, let him be accursed [*anathema*]" (1 Cor. 16:21–22). But it is not only denial of the truth that leads to anathema. In 1 Corinthians 5:11 Paul writes instructions not to associate with anyone called a brother who is a fornicator, a drunkard, or a swindler, or who is greedy, idolatrous, or abusive; the Corinthians are not even to eat with such a person. The church must distinguish between those who claim membership in its ranks just as Israel did. Conduct contrary to the covenant is a denial of the covenant.

#### *Section Overview: Covenant Blessings and Curses*

<span id="page-258-3"></span><span id="page-258-2"></span><span id="page-258-1"></span>The blessings and curses of this chapter are typical of those found in other treaties. The list of blessings is short in comparison to the curses. The blessings and curses of the first section of the chapter (28:1–44) are deliberately arranged. The chapter begins with a resumption of the declaration of the covenant in Moab (v. 1) and then declares three pairs of comprehensive blessings (vv. 2–6). The second pair is amplified with explanation. These are the kind of pronouncements that might be made by an official. They have corresponding declarative curses (vv. 15–19). The blessings are followed by promises of prosperity (vv. 7–14). The corresponding list of threats is considerably amplified (vv. 20–44). The threats are extended with two further sections, which conclude with a reversal of Israel's situation. Instead of living in the land, they will be in exile.

<span id="page-258-10"></span><span id="page-258-8"></span><span id="page-258-6"></span><span id="page-258-5"></span><span id="page-258-4"></span>The long list of curses in this chapter breaks down into three sections: blessings countered by amplification of corresponding curses (vv. 1–44), horrors of siege warfare (vv. 45–57), and despair of exile (vv. 58–68). All of these evils are assured if the oath of the covenant is not kept; the oath is broken if the people place faith in some other god than Yahweh. Faithfulness in the covenant relationship will make them a people holy to God (v. 9), those called by the name of the Lord (v. 10). The way of trust will not be easy; the danger of turning to something else will always be present (v. 14). As Moses warned in chapter 6, both riches (28:10–15) and poverty (vv. 16–19) can be temptations, either to trust in one's own strength or to test God. The force of these anathemas and gruesome description of consequences is to generate vigilance against the deception of forgetting the oath taken.

<span id="page-258-9"></span><span id="page-258-7"></span><span id="page-258-0"></span>Many scholars believe that the general sequence of the threats in 28:23–37 and some of the verbal similarity to the vassal treaty of Esarhaddon indicate that the scribes of these curses had access to a copy of that treaty and made use of it in developing the curses of the covenant in Deuteronomy. Paragraphs 63–64 of Esarhaddon's treaty ask the gods to "shrink the ground to the size of a brick for you. May they make your ground like iron so that nothing sprouts from it. Just as rain does not fall from a

sky of bronze, so may rain and dew not visit your fields and meadows. Instead of rain, may charcoal fall on your land."71 While such verbal similarity cannot demonstrate scribal dependence on this treaty, it does show that the curses of Deuteronomy are a common literary form in ancient Near Eastern culture. This genre would be familiar at virtually any period of Israel's history and would have communicated forcefully.
