#### *Comment*

<span id="page-259-2"></span><span id="page-259-1"></span><span id="page-259-0"></span>28:1 This verse resumes the sermon in Moab in which Moses is teaching Israel about its covenant with Yahweh. This is a repetition of 26:18–19; those verses were the conclusion of a transition in the sermon from an exposition of the stipulations to the announcement of consequences (26:16–19). In transitioning to the consequences of keeping the covenant, Moses reminds the assembly of its special calling as a treasured people.

<span id="page-259-3"></span>28:2 The pronouncement of blessings is stated in the form of agency: "all these blessings shall come upon you" (v. 2). This is not full personification, since it is evident that God is the agent bringing about these actions. But this does emphasize the result of knowing and following the will of God.

<span id="page-259-4"></span>28:3–6 The blessings are stated in three pairs that are a type of merism; that is, they include everything in their scope. The first is stated in terms of location: city and field; the second in terms of fecundity: animals and crops; the third in terms of activity: when you come and when you go. The middle pair is expanded by

<sup>71</sup> A translation of the treaty with helpful commentary and notes may be consulted in Jacob Lauinger, *COS*, 4.36. The treaty consists of about 670 lines and is sealed with three divine seals of the Assyrian national god Assur, not just the usual seals of the vassal taking the oath.

describing the fertility of the two main agricultural animals (bovine and sheep: calving and lambing) and the gathering and preparation of food (basket and kneading bowl). Both will be in abundance. The last pair is a generic expression inclusive of all activity, domestic and public, individual and collective. The blessings are inclusive in every way.

<span id="page-260-2"></span>28:7–8 The concisely stated blessings are elaborated by divine promises. The blessings do not come as a kind of natural consequence but are the direct result of divine action. One kind of coming and going encompasses war and the necessity of self-defense against the enemy that rises against them. God will provide for their protection. The second promise elaborates God's provision in the country and the city. Storage for food will be abundant; the generic word for storage indicates every kind of crop. God will bless "all that you undertake" (v. 8). God will not only give them the land but bless them in it.

<span id="page-260-4"></span><span id="page-260-3"></span>28:9–10 These verses return to the motif that introduces the blessings and curses. To be a holy people involves a dedicated calling that sets Israel apart from the life of all other nations in the common. The name of the Lord is known through these people. To be the means of knowing the name of the Lord is not a part of ordinary activity in the world; it is a high calling that extends the significance of their world to that which is *outside* the world, to the one who has given life to them and to all things in the world.

<span id="page-260-5"></span>28:11–13a The Lord will grant Israel a surplus from their animals and fields. Life and the food that sustains it come from another dimension, here called "the heavens." There is no such thing as "Mother Nature." Such an expression is the hubris of a culture that presumes human autonomy. The nation that knows its dependence on God will be the one that lends to others. They will be the ones who take the lead since their destiny is sure.

<span id="page-260-6"></span>28:13b–14 The condition of blessing is mutable. Loyalty to God cannot be compromised. This is both complex and profound. As the curses anticipate, the profundity of such loyalty is beyond the ability of Israel to grasp, both intellectually and volitionally. Israel will find ways to rationalize fatal compromise of this requirement. The blessings begin and end with virtually the same words (cf. vv. 1, 13b). Such words are another way of stating the agency of the blessings; they are in no sense a natural consequence, and they cannot be manipulated in any way.

<span id="page-260-7"></span><span id="page-260-1"></span><span id="page-260-0"></span>28:15–19 These lines are the converse of the opening (vv. 2–5). They employ the same expression in saying that the curses will "overtake" the people. The intended effect of the curses is seen in the response of King Josiah in hearing the content of the Torah (2 Kings 22:11, 19): he tears his garments and repents.

<span id="page-260-9"></span><span id="page-260-8"></span>28:20–24 The evils sent by Yahweh are introduced with a triad of terms that are alliterative in Hebrew, describing the effect on the people: curse, panic, and futility. These are a natural sequence. The noun "curse" (*me'erah*) is from the root of the verbal form "cursed" (*'arur*). Living under the curse leads to turmoil, a confusion of mind, and an inability to know what to do. This is what happens in war or the breakdown of social order. Inability to plan any sensible course of action leads to futility and frustration. Every option is a bad one, and there is no way forward for improvement. Such a condition extends to everything the hand may touch, the same expression used in verse 8. The result is complete annihilation.

<span id="page-261-1"></span>The pestilence that will not leave them is described with seven terms. There are no exact referents for these terms, nor is it even possible to know if they all refer to human ailments or if the last four pertain to crops, as interpreted by the ESV. The Masoretic Text reads "sword" (*hereb*) for "drought" (*hareb*), a meaning for the lexeme *hrb* that seems unlikely in this list, though war is the subject following drought (vv. 25–26). If all seven terms are interpreted as human afflictions, the last four terms would refer to illnesses of fever, heat, sallowness (yellowish skin), and jaundice. The ESV assumes a transition to drought, which is the result of a sky of bronze that rains dust.

<span id="page-261-7"></span><span id="page-261-3"></span><span id="page-261-2"></span>28:25–26 The threat of defeat in battle is the reverse of Israel's victory in battle (cf. v. 7). Corpses left on the battlefield for the consumption of wild animals is a stock motif in military rhetoric (1 Sam. 17:43–46). It is an appalling image to think of scavengers' tearing at human bodies the way one observes vultures at roadkill. Deuteronomy 28:26 is identical to Jeremiah 7:33; this curse is found six times in the prose sermons of Jeremiah. Jeremiah 7 is known as the temple sermon, in which Jeremiah uses covenant formulations drawn from Deuteronomy to warn Judah of the coming end of Jerusalem.

<span id="page-261-9"></span><span id="page-261-4"></span><span id="page-261-0"></span>28:27–29 Seven human sicknesses are named in these verses; four have to do with skin rash or eruption while three describe a mental disorder. The first is a skin inflammation referred to in the plagues (Ex. 9:9). The second is vocalized (read in the synagogue) as hemorrhoids, which is the way it is interpreted in the LXX. Itch and scab are a type of skin disease (dermatitis).

<span id="page-261-10"></span><span id="page-261-8"></span>The three terms for madness are found in Zechariah 12:4, where the curse against Israel is turned on her enemies. Madness is the term that describes David in feigning insanity while seeking to avoid the wrath of Achish, king of Gath (1 Sam. 21:13–16). Bewilderment or confusion describes the horses in Zechariah. Blindness in these contexts is to be taken metaphorically; it describes people unable to think logically because they cannot see what is right. The image is of Israel groping to find its way even in the light of noon, like a blind man or a person in the dark. The horrors of chronic disease and war leave their victims robbed and abused, deprived of sense and bewildered, unable to see light regardless of how they try to plan.

<span id="page-261-6"></span><span id="page-261-5"></span>28:30–34 A theme of helplessness characterizes the content of these threats. Social order will break down as marriage is violated (Deut. 28:30); the plunder of war will disrupt the establishment of a new home (v. 30). Victims will be powerless

<span id="page-262-5"></span><span id="page-262-4"></span><span id="page-262-3"></span>when their children are taken in captivity (v. 32); they will be abused and crushed as others consume their harvest (v. 33) until they are driven to madness (v. 34), as stated in the list of illnesses (v. 28). Even those essential life events that could exempt a soldier from battle will be desecrated (cf. 20:5–7). The loss of children in war is indescribable; eyes are exhausted in tears.

<span id="page-262-9"></span><span id="page-262-6"></span><span id="page-262-0"></span>28:35–37 Debilitating skin disease and exile are in store for those who do not keep faith. The effect of this disease is like that suffered by Job (Job 2:7). It is chronic, if not fatal, and affects the whole body. The description is like that of small pox, an extremely contagious and deadly viral disease. Since the time of ancient Egypt, small pox has been one of the deadliest diseases among humans. Fever and pain are followed by a rash that develops into abscesses filled with pus, leaving scars.

Four Israelite kings are eventually exiled: Hoshea to Assyria, Jehoahaz to Egypt, and Jehoiachin and Zedekiah to Babylon. Beginning with the exile of northern Israel to areas of the Tigris, Israelites come to be in exile everywhere from southern Egypt to Persia. The demise of Israel will be an example known and taunted among the nations.

<span id="page-262-7"></span><span id="page-262-1"></span>28:38–42 One pair of blessings was fertility, the fruit of the womb and of the land (Deut. 28:4). This blessing was expanded to describe the fecundity of animals and harvest. It is utterly negated in these verses. The land will become a possession of crickets. Only insects will survive the devastation.

<span id="page-262-8"></span><span id="page-262-2"></span>28:43–44 These curses and threats reverse the state of the blessing given in verses 12–13. Israel will fall into perpetual need, always needing to borrow. The settlers in their place will be the ones who are prosperous.

#### *Response*

Blessings and curses as found at the conclusion of the covenant are strange to the contemporary reader, but this would be an expected format for about a millennium beginning before Moses and extending to the end of the Assyrian period. This reality of covenant would have been familiar to Israel from Moses until the exile. It may also seem strange that the blessings are so few and general in comparison to the curses. This feature would also not be surprising. The main benefit of keeping the treaty was to avoid the punishment. In many ancient Near Eastern treaties, blessings are omitted. But a lengthy list is always included of curses invoked upon violation of the treaty. These are inflictions of the gods outside the control of the lord making the treaty—the essence of a curse.

One example is the first curse by Barga'yah, king of a territory near Aleppo, against the king of Arpad: "(seven rams shall tup) a ewe, but let her not conceive."72 The curses invariably declare the utter destruction of the unfaithful party, with

<sup>72</sup> Sefire I (a treaty between two eighth-century kings in Syria written in old Aramaic), line 21. Cf. John C. L. Gibson, *Textbook of Syrian Semitic Inscriptions*, vol. 2, *Aramaic InscriptionsIncluding Inscriptions in the Dialect of Zenjirli*  (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1975), 29. A helpful commentary on this treaty is found in Gibson, 18–56. This treaty contains only curses.

great pain and distress. As Barga'yah warns, "Just as this piece of wax is burned with fire, so shall Arpad and [her daughter cities] be utterly burned."73 The purpose of curses is intimidation. The gods of ancient times are always unpredictable. The god of the suzerain may abandon him, in which case the curses would be impotent. This could be viewed as an occasion to rebel. Deuteronomy must be read in a theological context. Israel has experienced the frightful presence of Yahweh; Moses has reminded the nation of its fear at the mountain. The people must love and fear God always. The curses of this book are inevitable if the covenant is not obeyed.

A treaty known all over the world of the late Assyrian Empire was promulgated by Esarhaddon in 672 BC. This treaty was to ensure that Esarhaddon's son Assurbanipal would be his successor, even though he was a younger son. Copies of this treaty were made with vassal states throughout Esarhaddon's empire. Archaeological excavation in the Syrian temple at Tell Taʻyinat shows that a copy of the treaty was placed vertically in the throne room of the god so that it could be read by walking around it. The date of the treaty was during the time of Manasseh. Given the idolatries of that king, it is likely that this treaty was also placed in the temple in Jerusalem at the demand of Esarhaddon. It may have displaced the ark and the covenant words of Deuteronomy contained in it. The treaty text is notable for its length and state of preservation. A further notable feature is that copies of the treaty like that found at Tell Taʻyinat are officially inscribed with seals declaring it to be the national god Assur's "Seal of Destinies."74 This seal made the stipulations of the treaty the immutable destiny of the person taking the oath. If Esarhaddon's treaty was one of the items purged from the temple during Josiah's cleansing described in 2 Kings 22:8–20, the reader can only imagine the consternation caused when king, priest, and people realized that God had made just such a treaty with Moses, which they had broken. The form of Deuteronomy was significant in its impact long after its being inscribed on prepared stones at Shechem.

<span id="page-263-1"></span><span id="page-263-0"></span>The last warning of Scripture concludes with a curse derived from the words of Deuteronomy. John bears testimony against all who read the words of his prophecy written in his book (Rev. 22:18–20). If anyone adds anything to them, God will add to that person the plagues written in the book. These plagues include not only the last judgment in the lake of fire but also the inflictions incurred by the ungodly throughout the time prior to that judgment. The warning is primarily directed not to those *outside* the church community but specifically *to* the church community, just as the curses of Deuteronomy were directed toward Israel. Those who do not heed the warnings may profess to be Christians, but their deeds show that their allegiance is not to Christ. They not only suffer the loss of their inheritance but also experience the suffering of all those that follow the beast.

#### *Section Overview: War and Exile*

<span id="page-265-2"></span>The threats that will reduce Israel to being the least of all nations are further developed in a sequence of events that will reverse the entrance to the land now underway. Through war and plagues Israel will return the way they have come. They will be in exile as they were in Egypt. Two transitional verses divide this section into two topics. Deuteronomy 28:45 is a transitional recapitulation of verse 15, forming an inclusio around the curses. Proof of the disobedience of Israel will be evident through invasion and siege warfare. The horrors of such warfare are graphically described. Verse 58 repeats the condition of obedience and transitions to the decimation of Israel and its ultimate exile.

<span id="page-265-6"></span><span id="page-265-5"></span><span id="page-265-4"></span><span id="page-265-3"></span><span id="page-265-1"></span><span id="page-265-0"></span>The threats of this section are given in terms reminiscent of Israel's experience in the bondage of Egypt. The plagues that led to the liberation of Israel were to be a proof of the presence of Yahweh forever, which they would perpetually tell their children in the celebration of the Passover and redemption from Egypt (Ex. 10:1–2). In contrast, the proof of disobeying the Torah will be seen by all nations in Israel's decimation, a perpetual testimony to their descendants (Deut. 28:46). Israel will once again enter bondage in service to its enemies (v. 48), and all the diseases of Egypt will come upon them (v. 60). Instead of being as numerous as the stars of heaven, they will be few in number, as when they entered Egypt. Finally, they will be taken back to Egypt, where they will sell themselves into

<span id="page-266-10"></span>slavery (v. 68). Failure to keep the Torah will be the reversal of the blessing of receiving this Torah.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-266-5"></span><span id="page-266-4"></span><span id="page-266-0"></span>28:45–48 Curses will overtake Israel—the last clause of verse 15 becomes the first clause of verse 45. The structure is almost poetic. Verse 45 serves as a conclusion to the preceding threats and an introduction to the signs and proofs to follow. Signs and proofs are the terms used for the ten plagues (4:34; 6:22). These disasters will be proofs of the disobedience of Israel, a warning that it is impossible to escape the consequences of failure to uphold loyalty to God.

The yoke is a picture of an animal in service pulling a load. Usually yokes were made of wood, but this one is of iron. The iron yoke amplifies the harshness of the servitude and the inability to escape from it.

<span id="page-266-6"></span>28:49–51 War will descend like the swoop of an eagle. The speed and power of the attack will capture Israel as a victim, just as the prey of an eagle. War is ruthless; there is no respect for its victims, whether young or old. It brings devastation. Produce of land and animals will be lost. The terminology repeats that of the blessings (vv. 4–5), though it does not include the fruit of the womb. In the gruesome description of the famine of siege (vv. 54–57), cannibalism produces food that will not be shared.

<span id="page-266-9"></span><span id="page-266-8"></span><span id="page-266-7"></span><span id="page-266-2"></span><span id="page-266-1"></span>28:52–57 Trust in high walls is a fatal failure (v. 52). Trust in military strength is among the warnings issued to the future king (17:16). The very walls in which Israel trusts under siege become a prison that forces the people of the city into starvation.

The desperation of starvation during time of siege is described in horrifying detail. All respect for humanity and natural affection of family are subordinated to a desperate quest for survival. People are reduced to cannibalism; husbands and wives turn against each other; the most pampered of women turn to the most disgusting of foods. The desperation of cannibalism is described in the siege of Samaria, in which a woman complains to the king that she has shared her child

<span id="page-267-4"></span><span id="page-267-3"></span>with a neighbor, but now that neighbor has hid her child and will not share it (2 Kings 6:28–29). The natural appetite of the invader (Deut. 28:51) and the extreme desperate behavior of Israel (v. 53) make for a drastic contrast. But Israel must never be mistaken about the cause of this desperate distress. These enemies do not act independently of the sovereignty of Yahweh, who has sent them from a distant land. Israel has not been abandoned by God; rather, this is a sign that God remembers his oath.

<span id="page-267-5"></span>28:58 The reference to "this book" anticipates that Moses will write down all of these instructions, which will be ever present to teach Israel. The purpose of this book, which contains all these warnings, is to generate fear. Israel must fear the name, which is a way of saying that they must fear God himself. Fear of God is a good thing, for it will be the way in which Israel learns to love God and keep his commandments.

<span id="page-267-6"></span>28:59–62 Israel will be decimated by disease. This is a consequence of siege, in which people are confined without food or space. Decaying corpses allow rodents and disease-carrying pests to multiply. The diseases of Egypt are just a sample of the suffering that will come to Israel. The inclusion of things not written is a stock motif in ancient writing.

<span id="page-267-8"></span><span id="page-267-7"></span><span id="page-267-1"></span>28:63–68 The "delight" of the Lord is a euphemism used to express the resolve of the divine will—that which is determined by the purpose and character of God. The expression is meant to connote not a feeling of joy but a purpose of mind. Israel's turning to other gods will result in exile to a distant land, where they will be compelled to serve other gods. Instead of coming into a land that will be its resting place (3:20; 12:10), Israel will be in a foreign land, where it can never find a place of rest (v. 65). Israel will be brought to a place of longing, despondency, and agitation (v. 65). The lives of the people will be suspended (Hb. *tala'*; "shall hang"); they will never know from one day to another what their future may be. By day they will long for the rest of night, but the agitation and worry of a sleepless night will make them long for the morning. Just as it was the resolve of God to bring his people to the Promised Land, so also is the curse of their removal from it certain if they do not love and fear him.

<span id="page-267-0"></span>In the final reversal of the history, Israel will return to Egypt and sell themselves as slaves. They will return to the place where God had said they would never go again (Ex. 14:13). Israel does not return as slaves; instead they journey to Egypt by ship and, once there, offer themselves up as slaves. The final indignity is that there will be no one to buy them. This is the ultimate irony: the nation that once refused to let Israel go is now so indifferent that it will not even accept Israel as slaves so that its poverty can be relieved.

<span id="page-267-9"></span><span id="page-267-2"></span>29:1 "These are the words of the covenant" must refer to the words of this Torah, including Deuteronomy 5:6–26:19 and 28:1–68. The words that follow are not the words of a covenant but rather describe the act of making the covenant and <span id="page-268-2"></span><span id="page-268-1"></span><span id="page-268-0"></span>the consequences. This verse restates where the words were spoken and makes clear that said words are expected to become part of a covenant relationship. They form a conclusion to 1:1–5. This verse may be compared to Exodus 31:18, which constitutes a conclusion to Exodus 24:18, where Moses goes up into the mountain to receive words from God. According to Deuteronomy 4:13; 5:2–19, the words of the covenant consisted of the words written on the two tablets of stone. But the words concerning the structure and function of the tabernacle in Exodus and these words in Deuteronomy are also a part of the covenant words Moses received on the mountain. Deuteronomy 29:1 brings the two covenants together, distinguishing them only in time and place. The words of each covenant are of equal standing and are virtually identical. The words at Moab have a covenant relationship as their expected outcome.

<span id="page-268-3"></span>This verse is also transitional to the next section, which anticipates Moses as the covenant mediator. The text of the covenant is found in the previous words of Moses, but the ritual of making the covenant is alluded to in the remainder of the discourse, though it is not actually described. The Hebrew Masoretic Text accordingly makes 29:2 the beginning of the next chapter. The other versions are divided on the break in the text.

#### <span id="page-268-4"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-268-6"></span><span id="page-268-5"></span>The story of Israel was one of covenant disobedience, and so the end of Israel occurred precisely as described in these verses. The city of Jerusalem came under a three-year siege, by which time terrible famine had occurred. The city collapsed and its leaders fled but were captured (2 Kings 25:1–7). The Babylonian king appointed Gedaliah (a member of a noble family of Judah) to rule in Judah (2 Kings 25:22–26). Hatred of the Babylonians resulted in the assassination of Gedaliah. Ishmael (a member of the royal family) and other Judahites had escaped from Jerusalem before the siege began. Ishmael killed numerous other people, including eighty men who had come from Shechem and Shiloh to bring offerings as a rite of mourning (Jer. 41:1–7). The people of Judah, fearful of Babylonian revenge, fled to Egypt and forced Jeremiah and Baruch to go with them (Jer. 43:4–7). All of this was contrary to the word of the Lord as declared by Jeremiah. Even when under the curse of the covenant, the people preferred their own way rather than listening to the word of a prophet. The words of Moses were prophetic in declaring the word of the Lord. The path of disobedience left no doubt that the future of Jerusalem would end in famine and exile.

<span id="page-268-8"></span><span id="page-268-7"></span>The gruesome nature of famine is not exaggerated in these curses, nor is it limited to the methods of ancient warfare. Modern warfare has created the same horrors, except in numbers inconceivable in ancient times. Perhaps the worst of all time was the Soviet-inflicted genocide estimated to have killed up to ten million Ukrainians in 1932–1933, known as Holodomor. The word *holod* means "hunger," and *mor* means "plague"; the expression *moryty holodom* means to "inflict death by hunger." The story of this terror-famine has been documented again with great precision by Anne Applebaum in her book *Red Famine*. 75 Applebaum cites descriptions of this error: "People with swollen legs, covered in sores, could not sit. 'When such a person sat down, the skin broke, liquid began to run down their legs, the smell was awful, and they felt unbearable pain.'"76 Elsewhere she writes, "One woman remembered a girl who was so emaciated that 'one could see how her heart was beating beneath the skin.'"77 Starvation causes the heart to fail, sometimes suddenly and without warning. A child would die while sitting at a school desk. What Applebaum provides that are not found in Deuteronomy are beautiful and ugly plates of numerous scenes of state confiscation and starvation of peasants (farmers). It will not do to attempt to avoid such realities by not talking about them. The truth of Deuteronomy will continue to be repeated because of human pride, pursuit of power, and denial of God, just as in Deuteronomy.

#### *Section Overview: Covenant Responsibility*

The third address of Moses consists of two chapters that warn of the consequences of the curses and give assurance of restoration. A new narrative sequence begins in the third person, telling us how Moses assembles all of Israel. In the structure of Deuteronomy, the sermon begins with a recapitulation of the covenant that prepares for the acceptance of the oath in the following chapter.78 The first chapter of the third address is largely a recapitulation, including a review of the history of Israel with Yahweh (vv. 2–9), the oath of the covenant (vv. 10–15), and finally

<span id="page-270-0"></span><sup>78</sup> Cf. Introduction: Genre and Literary Features for a full discussion of the covenant form of Deuteronomy in the pattern of treaties known from the second millennium.

<span id="page-271-8"></span>the warnings of disobedience (vv. 16–29). The warnings begin with the individual who might think that disregard of the covenant stipulations will not affect him. The consequence of such disobedience is the astonishment of the nations, as they contemplate what offense could have caused the God of the covenant to leave his people in such total ruin.

<span id="page-271-1"></span><span id="page-271-0"></span>As is typical of covenants, the suzerain making the covenant reminds the people he is summoning to be mindful of the great saving deeds he has exercised on their behalf. For Israel this is a recollection of the exodus, in which they were to learn the meaning of the name Yahweh, which they had not known previously (Ex. 6:3). The name Yahweh had been used since the days of Seth and Enosh (Gen. 4:26), but the person of Yahweh was not known as being with them in the manner of this covenant. Such knowledge would be gained through God's work among the nations, as God told Moses in explaining why Pharaoh would not let the people go (Ex. 7:3–5). Through God's dealings with Pharaoh and the other nations Israel would come to know Yahweh as the God present with and merciful to them. This chapter is a reminder of what Israel has learned.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-271-7"></span><span id="page-271-6"></span><span id="page-271-5"></span><span id="page-271-4"></span><span id="page-271-3"></span>29:2–4 God revealed to Israel his exclusive sovereignty over all of creation, all other peoples in creation, and all other gods in the exodus and the giving of the covenant. God brought the people through "great trials" (Deut. 29:3), such as at Mount Sinai (Ex. 20:20). The test at Mount Sinai was followed by those in the wilderness (Deut. 8:2). These were lessons in learning to fear and love God, but they were also feats of God's accomplishment, signs and marvels, exploits of God over the nations and the fearsome wilderness. The problem was that Israel saw only miracles. Seeing only miracles, they came to demand miracles at every encounter of hardship, as occurred immediately at Rephidim, before they even arrived at Sinai (Ex. 17:1–7). Situations in which God overcame adversity for Israel became occasions on which they would test God. God brought Israel through the tests of deliverance at the Red Sea and the provision of manna when they had no ability to provide for food. Israel, failing to learn that they did not live by bread alone,

could not learn to love and fear God. Rather than fear God, they tested him at every turn. Israel needed a "heart to understand." The name Yahweh designated a God who was with them, not a God standing by to rescue them every time they faced a challenge. Instead of a heart to understand God, Israel was governed by its own insecurities. A heart to understand God is a gift from God for those willing to submit to God and trust him. It is not achieved merely because the proofs of God's sovereign work are immediately present.

The heart to understand God had not been given "to this day (Hb. *'ad hayyom hazzeh*). Israel now does have that heart, which is why Moses is prepared to lead them in renewal of the covenant. This is not to their credit; they are not wiser than the previous generation or somehow superior in perception. Yahweh has *brought* them to this place, to the humility to love and fear him. This had not been possible for the previous generation; judgment had come upon them, which determined that they would die in the wilderness.

<span id="page-272-2"></span><span id="page-272-1"></span><span id="page-272-0"></span>29:5–9 The wilderness wandering has had a specific purpose: "That you may know that I am the Lord your God" (Deut. 29:6). This is the very phrase that explains why Pharaoh does not let the people go (Ex. 7:5). God speaks in the first person, so the words conform precisely to those in Exodus. Israel has already begun to inherit the land. The lessons learned by this generation are the basis of hope, that they may "keep the words of this covenant" (Deut. 29:9). Recapitulation of the covenant words is intended to impress on those about to take the oath the importance of not taking the name in vain.

<span id="page-272-8"></span><span id="page-272-5"></span><span id="page-272-4"></span><span id="page-272-3"></span>29:10–15 Covenants were constituted through the taking of an oath, paraphrased as a "sworn covenant" (v. 12). In Hebrew this is the covenant (*berit*) and its curse (*'alah*). The curses of a covenant are punishment levied against the person who fails to observe its terms (e.g., 2 Chron. 34:24). A curse is a punishment carried out by God. This declaration of punishment involves the use of the divine name since the oath is declared before Yahweh. The use of the name in taking the oath of the covenant must not be insincere, and the name must not be taken in vain.

The participants in the oath are inclusive: the leaders and those doing the most menial of tasks; men, women, and children; those of Israel and all those living among them, both those present and those future. The result of the oath is a sworn relationship, not unlike that of a marriage, the most common picture of the relationship of God and Israel. Israel is to God a people; Yahweh is to Israel a God (Deut 29:13)—the standard definition of covenant found repeatedly in the Law and the Prophets. The commitments made in the taking of the oath are binding not only for those present but for all future generations.

<span id="page-272-7"></span><span id="page-272-6"></span>29:16–17 Passing through Moab and the experience of Baal-peor was a very recent reminder of the mortal danger of other religions and the futility of following gods that could be represented by wood and stone. Derogatory terms are used for these other gods; they are "detestable" (Hb. *shakketz*) and something that <span id="page-273-7"></span>is spurned. "Idols" (*gillulim*) is not a neutral designation.79 It is used to convey a sense of disgust and revulsion.

<span id="page-273-2"></span><span id="page-273-1"></span>29:18–21 The taking of an oath is a personal matter and is not a case of representation. This is expressed in the inclusion of both genders. Moses describes the man or woman who thinks he or she can participate in this covenant but still go his or her own way in the stubbornness and willful independence of his or her mind (v. 18). The reflexive translation of the Hebrew verb *barak* ("bless") as "blesses himself" cannot fully express the sense of the tense used. Grammarians describe this as an "estimative-declarative" use of the verb, a construction used to express what a person is thinking.80 This is a particularly appropriate way to express the violation of covenant. Such persons think they will be blessed even though they break the covenant. Instead of the curse (*'alah*), they presume prosperity (*shalom*). The assumption is that God will not notice one offender.

<span id="page-273-10"></span>Such a person is a root that grows poison and bitterness. Disobedience affects not only the individual sinner; sin is like yeast because it also affects all those around the one committing it. "Moist and dry" (v. 19) is a merism indicating totality. The analogy is ambiguous; it may be related to the metaphor of the cursed and blessed man in Jeremiah 17:5–8. The cursed man is a dried tamarisk in the desert, while the blessed man is a tree planted by streams of water. The terminology of this metaphor fits the covenant context. The merism, then, would refer to the destruction of the entire tribe or nation, those cursed and blessed. The disobedience of one person will not escape notice among everyone else in the tribe, as this person seems to think. The Lord will single that person out for punishment (Deut. 29:21). All the curses written here will come upon the disobedient person, but the end will be the sweeping away of all (v. 19), as the rest of the passage bears out. The disobedience of one is a root that bears poison that kills all.

<span id="page-273-8"></span><span id="page-273-5"></span><span id="page-273-4"></span><span id="page-273-3"></span>29:22–24 Sodom and Gomorrah are the prototypical example of divine judgment on a people; Isaiah uses the same metaphor for Jerusalem (Isa. 1:7–8). The result of God's judgment is infertility of soil, a land that cannot grow food or sustain a people, like the cities near the Dead Sea. Two groups of people will see the devastation God brings upon Israel, namely, a later generation and other nations. Both will ask the same question: what could so provoke the Lord that he would bring such utter destruction upon his people and his land?

<span id="page-273-9"></span>29:25–28 It seems that those who ask the question are the ones able to answer it, based on what Moses has written here. They worship gods outside their own

experience, ones they do not know, gods never given to them for worship. They understand the curses written in this book and the reasons for exile.

<span id="page-274-0"></span>29:29 These words can be applied in more than one way, and each of them may be relevant. The way in which God brings his people to himself so that they will be in covenant relationship with him remains a mystery. The operation of divine grace cannot be explained. But the will of God is not a mystery. The words of the covenant are known; they are for mortals. People do have knowledge of the will of God.

These words may be applied to the history of the nation. Why was it that Nebuchadnezzar destroyed Jerusalem in 586 BC? Why was that the time at which God's mercy prevailed no longer? If mercy pertained in the days of Hezekiah and the attack of Sennacherib, why should the leaders of Jerusalem not believe such a deliverance would be repeated when the Babylonian armies surrounded Jerusalem? These ways of God remain a mystery. What is known is acted on by Hezekiah and Josiah. Both of these kings could lead the nation in covenant renewal, in a commitment to be loyal to God, but neither could determine the future of Jerusalem.

Targum Pseudo-Jonathan interprets this in a personal way. Concealed sins are known only to God, and he will punish them. Overt sins that violate the words of the covenant are the responsibility of those who take the covenant oath. The community must act accordingly.

The lesson of these words is relevant within the community and for the future of the people. God's work is hidden; the future is unknown. The present is known, and our task is to do the will of God immediately. But some things about the future *are* known, namely, that God will act according to his revealed will. Although no individual knows what this may mean in the future, it is enough to know what is right in the present.

#### *Response*

Another generation and other nations will see the desolation of the people of the covenant and their land, left as Sodom and Gomorrah, and ask, "Why this great rage?" The answer comes from Jeremiah and Ezekiel, two of the prophets of the exile. Both declared their messages unequivocally during the process of time that Jerusalem came under siege until it was destroyed. The ministry of Jeremiah began sometime after the death of Josiah in 609 BC, when the Egyptians set a ruler on the throne of Judah. Ezekiel was taken into captivity with the exiles of 598 BC. Both preach warnings of the judgment to come until the fall of Jerusalem in 586 BC. Both testify to the intractable mindset of a people that could not recognize their doom during the twenty-year period in which it was already underway.

<span id="page-274-1"></span>The apostle Paul understands this mentality to have continued until his time. His burden is the question of the salvation of Israel in Romans 9–11.81 This is an inevitable question as the apostle provides an exposition of salvation from

<sup>81</sup> For a discussion of the apostacy and redemption of Israel according to Paul see August H. Konkel, "What is the Future of Israel in Romans 9–11?," in *The Letter to the Romans: Exegesis and Application*, ed. Stanley E. Porter and Francis G. H. Pang, MNTSS 7 (Eugene, OR: McMaster Divinity College Press, 2018), 115–127.

<span id="page-275-4"></span><span id="page-275-0"></span>the Scriptures in his letter to the Romans. "Has God rejected his people? By no means!" (Rom. 11:1). Proof of this is the apostle himself, an Israelite from the tribe of Benjamin. Jews of Paul's time knew their lineage; they were not lost genealogically no matter their tribe. Jews such as Paul might be as few as the remnant in Elijah's day during the terror of Jezebel, but they were not eliminated. In Romans 11:8 the apostle refers to Deuteronomy 29:4, in which Moses says God has not given the Israelites a heart to understand, eyes to see, or ears to hear "to this day." Humans do not come to know God through what they see or hear. Faith is a gift of mercy. Israel is proof of that truth. Paul, however, expresses the reality of Israel in a manner that is direct and harsh. God has given them a "spirit of deep sleep," a phrase found in Isaiah 29:10. The present state of Israel is part of the plan of God no less than the creation of Israel was God's divine plan of redemption.

<span id="page-275-6"></span><span id="page-275-5"></span><span id="page-275-3"></span><span id="page-275-2"></span>This explains why Paul is in such a minority. This rejection of the saving mercy of God continues "to this day." This day is as true in the time of Paul as it was at any other time Deuteronomy was read. But the punishment of the exile was not the end of the hardness of Israel; the time of mercy will come to Israel as well. According to Isaiah 59:20 a redeemer will come from Israel who will remove the transgression of Jacob and restore the covenant (cf. Rom. 11:26–27). The mercy of God is irrevocable. "All Israel" (Rom. 11:16) will be saved. Paul views the salvation of Israel as a future eschatological event that fulfills the promises to the fathers.

#### *Section Overview: The Way of Life and Death*

<span id="page-276-11"></span><span id="page-276-8"></span><span id="page-276-4"></span><span id="page-276-3"></span>Chapters 29–30 are marked as a unit by the introduction of 29:2, in which Moses assembles the people, and the introduction in 31:1, in which the narrator says that Moses spoke "these words to all Israel." The summary character of the call to choose life in 30:15–20 forms a conclusion to the purpose of Moses in assembling the people in 29:2. The anticipation of the covenant in 29:10–15 is concluded by the call to accept the covenant in 30:15–20. This chapter is a renewed call to love the Lord your God (30:6, 16, 20). This call is an obvious echo of the chief imperative of the main section of this Torah, which summarized the covenant requirement with a call to love at the beginning (6:5) and the conclusion of the exhortation (11:1). The people's need is a circumcised heart (10:16; 30:6). The external sign of the covenant has no significance apart from an internal commitment to obedience.

<span id="page-276-6"></span><span id="page-276-5"></span><span id="page-276-2"></span><span id="page-276-1"></span>The dire situation of exile is reversed by God's restoring and renewing his people (30:1–10). Experience of the curse is not the end of the covenant. Although the people find themselves in exile, restoration is possible. This hope was held out by Moses in concluding his first sermon in 4:29–31. Those words are substantially repeated here, binding together the book.

<span id="page-276-7"></span><span id="page-276-0"></span>The requirement of restoration is unchanged: it is the necessity of love for God. The responsibilities of love are not far removed or hard to understand (30:11–14). <span id="page-277-10"></span>When the words of the Torah are in the people's mind, it is possible for them to carry out the duty of love. The choice, however, is stark: life or death (vv. 15–20). There is no such thing as a partial love for God. If Israel understands and fears God, they will have life. If they serve any other god, they do not understand God at all. Knowing Yahweh excludes the possibility of other gods. The result of seeking such gods is death. Moses concludes his sermon with the only logical option: choose life.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-277-3"></span><span id="page-277-1"></span>30:1–10 The passage begins with a long conditional sentence comprising the first three verses. The first two verses state the condition: in the future, Israel will have experienced the blessing and the curse. The thought returns to the covenant at Moab as given in chapter 28. Once Israel has experienced the curse of exile, she will turn to God as she lives among all the nations, regardless of where she has been scattered. This brings about the apodosis: then God will restore Israel's fortunes, show mercy, and gather her back to her land. The protasis and apodosis play on the Hebrew word *shub*, which simply means to turn. When in exile Israel will turn to God (30:2). Once it has met this condition, God will then "restore [its] fortunes" (*shab weshebut*), literally "turn their turnings" (v. 3). The condition of the protasis is a repetition of words found in the key summary of the covenant found in 6:5: the people turn to the Lord with all their mind and all their desire. The possibility of mercy is not past, even though they are in exile.

<span id="page-277-7"></span><span id="page-277-6"></span><span id="page-277-5"></span><span id="page-277-4"></span><span id="page-277-2"></span><span id="page-277-0"></span>The passage is structured around the central requirement of a circumcised heart (30:6). The blessing is expressed in variations of the Hebrew word for good (*tob*). If Israel in exile turns to the Lord with all its heart (vv. 1, 2), God will show mercy and make the people prosperous (*hetibeka*) so that they become more numerous than their fathers (v. 5). When they love God with a circumcised heart (v. 6), God will make their land fertile for prosperity (*letobah*), and the Lord will "take delight" in making them prosperous (*letob*), with a delight like he had for their fathers (v. 9). The requirement is that Israel must hear the voice of the Lord according to everything written in this book of the Torah (v. 10). The effect of this structure is to make the circumcised mind the central point of emphasis:

- <span id="page-277-9"></span><span id="page-277-8"></span>(A) "Obey his voice in all that I command you." (v. 2)
	- (B) "He will make you more prosperous and numerous." (v. 5)
		- (C) "The Lord your God will circumcise your heart." (v. 6)
- (B') "The Lord your God will circumcise your heart. . . . The Lord will again take delight in prospering you." (v. 9)
- (A') "Obey the voice of the Lord your God, to keep his commandments." (v. 10)

<span id="page-278-2"></span><span id="page-278-1"></span><span id="page-278-0"></span>In 10:16 God exhorted Israel to circumcise their hearts. In this passage God promises to circumcise their minds once they have turned to him. Unlike the Greek language, Hebrew does not have a word that means "mind." The two words commonly used for mind are *leb* ("heart") and *ruakh* (spirit). In Deuteronomy the emphasis of keeping the covenant is on the mind (6:5). Israel must remember how God tested them to know their mind (8:2), and they must know with their mind that God has instructed them as a father teaches a child. Remembering, learning, and knowing are all functions of the mind (*leb*). The Ten Words end on the activity of the mind, the command not to covet. In the new covenant the Torah will be written on the mind (Jer. 31:33), and there will no longer be any need to teach the other to know the Lord, because they will all know him.

<span id="page-278-13"></span><span id="page-278-10"></span><span id="page-278-9"></span><span id="page-278-8"></span><span id="page-278-7"></span><span id="page-278-3"></span>30:11–14 The will of God is not unintelligible or inaccessible. His teaching has been given to Israel, and they know everything necessary to have life. Knowledge for Israel is not access to the mysteries of the universe. Job 28, the powerful poem on wisdom, twice asks the question of where wisdom may be found (Job 28:12, 20). The answer is that only God knows the way to the mysteries of the universe. His instructions for mortals are to fear God and turn from evil (Job 28:28). Life is not to be found in trying to probe the mysteries of life's origins. The psalmist confesses freely concerning the subject of embryogeny (the beginnings of animate existence): "Such knowledge is too wonderful for me; it is high; I cannot attain it" (Ps. 139:6). Job, who sought to know the mysteries of the universe, is forced to concede, "Therefore I have uttered what I did not understand, things too wonderful [*niphla'ot*] for me, which I did not know" (Job 42:3). In contrast, Moses declares that God's teaching is not too wonderful (*niphle't*; "hard") for them; it is not far off. Knowledge of God's will is "in your mouth," an idiom that means it can be recited by memory (cf. Deut. 31:19). The will of God is well understood and can be obeyed.

<span id="page-278-12"></span><span id="page-278-11"></span><span id="page-278-6"></span><span id="page-278-4"></span>30:15–20 To set life and death before Israel is more than an invitation to accept the covenant. It is a reminder that rejection of the covenant has a certain consequence. Israel took the oath at Mount Sinai and will take it again in the Promised Land at Shechem. The covenant given at Moab is the content of that oath that will be written on the stones at Shechem when Israel renews its commitment to God.

<span id="page-278-5"></span>Witnesses are a part of every covenant. God calls such witnesses to give testimony to the oath that Israel is taking (v. 19). In ancient covenants the witnesses were gods that carried out the curses. The heavens do withhold the rain and the earth does become like stone, but in Deuteronomy they are not independent <span id="page-279-6"></span>agents. The heavens and earth are the material or common representation of the presence of God that will forever give testimony to the words spoken. The prophet Isaiah will use this testimony to reveal the way in which the leaders of Jerusalem have utterly violated the word and will of God (Isa. 1:2). It is part of a literary form in which the truth of the covenant can be brought to bear on a specific situation.

<span id="page-279-5"></span><span id="page-279-4"></span><span id="page-279-3"></span>The call to life begins and ends with the imperative of love (Deut. 30:15–16, 19–20), which is to walk in all God's ways and to hear his voice and cling to him. Knowledge essential to all mortals is that "he is your life" (v. 20). If this knowledge is forfeited, no other knowledge will matter.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-279-7"></span>One of the enigmas of the fulfillment of salvation is the defiance of the Jews in response to the teaching of Jesus and the proclamation of the gospel. Gentiles not familiar with the promises to Israel or the covenant with God respond in great numbers. The evangelism at Antioch is so successful that it raises the attention of the church at Jerusalem. They send Barnabas to investigate (Acts 11:20–26). Seeing the size of the response, Barnabas seeks out Saul from Tarsus, who gathers the believers in such numbers that they soon become distinguished as a movement and identified as Christians. They are no longer just another sect of the Jews. On the other hand, Jews across the Roman Empire resist and hate these people. In his letter to the Romans Paul turns to the third speech of Moses in the book of Deuteronomy in order to address this dilemma. Paul feels so strongly about the rejection of his people that he would consider himself anathema on their behalf (Rom. 9:1–3). This is not possible, but the message of Moses convinces Paul that redemption for his people will be found in Christ.

<span id="page-279-13"></span><span id="page-279-12"></span><span id="page-279-11"></span><span id="page-279-10"></span><span id="page-279-9"></span><span id="page-279-8"></span><span id="page-279-2"></span><span id="page-279-1"></span><span id="page-279-0"></span>Paul assesses the situation of the Jewish people in Romans 9:30–10:21. His answer comes in two parts. Paul discusses the nature of the gospel (Rom. 9:32–10:13) then God's relationship to Israel through the gospel (Rom. 10:14– 21). Israel has stumbled at the stone of scandal in pursuing a righteousness of works. They do not understand that Christ is the goal of the Torah (10:4). Paul discusses covenant renewal for Israel in 10:6–11. He reads Deuteronomy 30 as an announcement of covenant renewal following the judgment and exile described in Deuteronomy 29. The exile of Deuteronomy had continued until the time of the Messiah. With Jesus renewal becomes possible. The means of covenant renewal is found in Deuteronomy 30:11–14. Paul applies what is said of the Torah to the Messiah. He has come down, so when the word about him is accepted by faith, the work of the new covenant has taken place. Deuteronomy thus offers a fresh vision for the fulfillment of the covenant. Paul sees this vision as performed by Christ and fulfilled in the Christian by the Holy Spirit (Rom. 8:5–8). Confessing faith in Christ is the surprising and paradoxical fulfilling of the Torah taught by Moses (Rom. 10:5). Righteousness is reckoned by faith in Christ; it is not by faith in fulfilling the law, as taught at Qumran, a view found in a document called 4QMMT (Miqṣat Maʻaśê ha-Torah).82 Faith in Christ is the sign of covenant membership.

<span id="page-280-2"></span><span id="page-280-1"></span>The stumbling of Israel is not outside of divine providence (Rom. 10:14–21). God's method is to provoke Israel to jealousy through a nation that does not understand (Rom. 9:19; cf. Deut. 32:21). The gospel has been offensive to Israel, while Gentiles believe in order to make Israel jealous so that God may reach out to the people he foreknew.

Behold, even today while I am yet alive with you, you have been rebellious against the Lord. #### *Section Overview: Provisions for Covenant Continuity*

The epilogue shifts from reported speech to narrative action that includes instructions and poems. Covenant making and law giving give way to provisions for the future. The words spoken by Moses have been given. The narrator turns to reporting the events that conclude not only Deuteronomy but the entire Torah. They describe the steps taken by Moses to prepare Israel for the future in his absence. The death of Moses and the provision to transfer leadership to Joshua set the scene (vv. 1–8). The appointment of Joshua as successor, the deposition of the written Torah, and the memorization of the song are the repeated topics.

<span id="page-282-1"></span>Chapter 31 does not relate the closing events in sequence. The rabbis referred to this phenomenon as "nothing early and nothing late," their way of expressing the observation that material in the Torah is given topically. Continuity of the covenant is the burden of the epilogue. Israel is told repeatedly that future generations will not be obedient (e.g., vv. 16, 20, 27). This truth makes the reading of the Torah and the memorization of the song under the new leadership of Joshua an urgent concern.

<span id="page-282-8"></span><span id="page-282-7"></span><span id="page-282-6"></span><span id="page-282-5"></span><span id="page-282-3"></span>The actions of Moses could not have taken place in the sequence reported in the narration. Moses speaks to Israel about his death and then to Joshua before all Israel to designate him as successor (vv. 1–8). Joshua and Moses are stationed at the entrance to the tabernacle (vv. 14–15). Moses is given instructions to write the song and teach it to the people (vv. 16–22). After the song is taught to the assembly, Yahweh appoints Joshua as successor to Moses at the tabernacle, saying, "I will be with you" (v. 23). The divine anointing of Joshua is interrupted with the teaching of the song. The deposition of the Torah is repeated in two separate sections. The arrangement makes the giving of the written Torah and the teaching of the song the emphasis of the chapter. The chapter is arranged as a chiasm to place the giving of the Torah at the beginning and the end, with the teaching of the song in the very center:

- <span id="page-282-4"></span>(A) Moses writes the Torah and gives it to the priests. (vv. 9–13)
	- (B) Joshua and Moses are stationed at the entrance to the tabernacle. (vv. 14–15)
		- (C) Moses writes the song and teaches it to all the people. (vv. 16–22)
	- (B') Yahweh commissions Joshua at the tabernacle. (v. 23)
- <span id="page-282-9"></span>(A') Moses gives the written Torah to the Levites who place it in the ark. (vv. 24–26)

This technique inextricably binds together the song with the reading of the Torah, which is the intent of the epilogue.

<span id="page-282-10"></span><span id="page-282-2"></span><span id="page-282-0"></span>The narration of the epilogue continues with Moses' issuing a directive to assemble all the leaders of Israel so that they may learn the words of the song. It will be their responsibility to teach it. The reporting of the speech of Moses begun at 31:1 is concluded in 32:44–47 after the giving of the words of the song. The song is introduced with calling the heavens and earth to act as witness (31:28–30), just as they did in the taking of the vow (30:19). In the main Masoretic Text (Leningrad Codex and Aleppo Codex) the introduction to the song is purposefully distinguished by separating each word with dots (31:28–30). The song itself is set in parallel lines. The epilogue is constructed so that both the written Torah and the Song of Moses act as an eternal witness to God's relationship with his people.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-283-4"></span><span id="page-283-3"></span>31:1–6 "Moses continued to speak" to all Israel is a paraphrase of either "Moses went [*wylk*] and spoke" (MT) to all Israel or "Moses finished speaking [*wykl*]" (1QDeutb II, 4 [Dead Sea Scrolls])83 to all Israel. The difference is a common scribal error called metathesis, the interchange of the last two letters of the word. It is impossible to tell which direction the error occurred, but the reading of the Qumran manuscript and the Greek is more natural as a transition. The narrator is saying that the words of Moses as reported beginning at 29:2 are now complete. The same phrase is used at the end of the song in 32:45: "Moses had finished speaking" to all Israel. All the words of Moses have been faithfully reported. The narrator now brings the book to a conclusion, reporting the last words and actions of Moses in biographical style. The first key topic immediately taken up is the designation of Joshua as the successor to Moses. The whole section will end with the account of the death of Moses on Mount Nebo.

<span id="page-283-5"></span><span id="page-283-2"></span><span id="page-283-1"></span><span id="page-283-0"></span>Moses was eighty years old at the time of the exodus (Ex. 7:7), and since that time forty years have transpired in the desert (Deut. 1:3). In biblical representation, three generations would be one hundred twenty years, a concept reflected already in Genesis 6:3 at the time of the flood. There are individuals who live one hundred twenty years, but this may not be the import of the statement concerning the age of Moses. Moses is telling the people that he has lived through three generations: the times of slavery in Egypt, of exile in Midian, and of wandering in the desert. This is now a change of era for Israel.

The first point of importance is to remember that the battle belongs to the Lord, the one going before them. This is the only basis for the exhortation to "be strong

<sup>83</sup> D. Barthélemy and J. T. Milik, *Qumran Cave 1*, DJD 1 (Oxford: Clarendon, 1955; Reprinted 2003), plate X.

<span id="page-284-12"></span>and courageous," words that will be given to Joshua and that Joshua in turn will give to the people (Josh. 1:6–9). Yahweh has shown repeatedly that he does not fail.

<span id="page-284-2"></span><span id="page-284-1"></span>31:7–8 The formal commissioning of Joshua is described in Numbers 27:18–23. There Moses lays hands on Joshua in the presence of Eleazar the priest and all Israel, imparting to him the divine authority and power he himself had received. This event is described as taking place in Deuteronomy 34:9. In these verses Joshua is designated as the one who will lead the people to inherit the land.

<span id="page-284-11"></span><span id="page-284-3"></span>31:9–13 These verses are descriptive of the earliest formation of Scripture. The words are written down, as in other cultures, and deposited in the care of the religious and civil leaders. They in turn are responsible to make these words known to the people. One of the means to do so is aural; every seven years at the fall festival the Torah is to be read to the entire assembly that has gathered at the central place. This event exhibits a democratic emphasis—it must include women, children, and all those who live within the territory of Israel. The Torah affects the entire community, since its requirements are relevant to every person.

<span id="page-284-5"></span><span id="page-284-4"></span>31:14–15 The tent of meeting is the covered portion of the tabernacle; it is given this name because it is the place that represents the presence of God as he meets with the people. Verse 15 seems somewhat inconsistent, suggesting that God appears inside the tent rather than at the door, the usual place he is seen. The Greek version is clear: the cloud remains at the door of the meeting place. It may be that the preposition in verse 15a should not be pressed. The cloud encompasses the tent as it did when glory descended upon it at its completion (Ex. 40:34). Joshua and Moses remain at the entrance.

<span id="page-284-8"></span><span id="page-284-7"></span><span id="page-284-6"></span><span id="page-284-0"></span>31:16–22 Israel will be disobedient and will suffer the many evils of the curses of the covenant. It is not clear whether the people will recognize that this is because they have abandoned the Lord God or because the gods they have served are not with them (Deut. 31:17). The Hebrew term *'elohim* ("God" or gods) is not qualified, suggesting a double error. They have followed false gods and do not understand that their problem is that not only the gods they followed but also Yahweh has hidden his face from them.

<span id="page-284-9"></span>Moses is to put this song "in their mouths" (v. 19), and Israel must learn the song by memory. They must be able to recite it. These words will stand as an eternal testimony so that the people will always know that their trials are entirely just on the part of their merciful God. It is a sad irony that divine provision of plenty becomes the very reason God is abandoned. This is no surprise to God, who already knows their thinking. This song, always in the minds of the people and their descendants, will confront them with the reality of the results of serving other gods.

<span id="page-284-10"></span>31:23 God appoints Joshua as leader. This is the completion of the action begun in verses 14–15. It is the first time God speaks directly to Joshua.

<span id="page-285-4"></span>31:24–27 The Levites are responsible to preserve the document. Ancient documents were typically kept in the sacred shrine of the sanctuary. It is an eternal testimony to the fact that Israel has accepted the terms and conditions of the covenant. Moses knows well the behavior of the Israelites; they have not been able to keep the terms of their oath while he has been alive, and will be even less able to do so after his death.

<span id="page-285-6"></span><span id="page-285-5"></span>31:28–30 The transition to the poem is logical, as it will also be a testimony ever present in their memory. The heavens and the earth are divine agents, in both giving testimony to the oath and carrying out its curses. "In the days to come" (v. 29) is "the latter days," but this does not have the significance of the last days as in the Prophets (e.g., Isa. 2:2). Here it simply means times like those of the judges, when Israel constantly turns away from God.

#### <span id="page-285-8"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-285-3"></span><span id="page-285-0"></span>The epilogue returns to the themes of the historical prologue that introduce the book (cf. Introduction: Genre and Literary Features). The time is after Sihon and Og have been defeated in Transjordan (Deut. 31:4). Moses will not cross the Jordan (31:2; cf. 3:23–26), but Joshua will be his successor (31:3; cf. 3:28). Moses will die in Mount Nebo, the high point of the Pisgah range (32:49–50), as stated in the prologue (3:27). The epilogue brings closure to covenant renewal, the vital component to choosing life.

<span id="page-285-7"></span><span id="page-285-2"></span><span id="page-285-1"></span>The warnings of the epilogue make crystal clear that there are only two options in life. Humans created to represent God may abandon him, but God will never abandon them. Abandonment of God does not provide an escape from him. The intention of just one individual to ignore the requirements of the divine relationship will not escape divine notice (29:18–20). The curse of covenant violation will be lurking for that individual; there will be no escape. Failure to observe the requirements of a relationship with God will occur. This is different from turning away to follow other gods, mostly represented in the wood, stone, and molded metal of earthly pursuits.

Faithfulness is impossible apart from discipline, especially discipline of the mind. The instruction of God demands regular repetition. Focus of the mind requires words that are known and can be repeated. A technological age leads to a tendency to minimize memorization and to assume that things can be looked up rather than learned. But technology cannot be exchanged for the spiritual work Moses demands in this epilogue. Learning and retaining instruction is never finished. It takes the presence of spontaneous words to have clear vision, the hearing of the covenant responsibilities, and the words of instructive song.

#### *Section Overview: Song of Moses*

Songs are among the most important means of communicating and retaining theology, especially in a time when access to writing is limited to a small number of people. As is typical of Hebrew poetry, this song is characterized by parallel lines (rhythmic units) that complement each other. Unlike narrative, poems are not structured by sentences in grammatical sequence. Thoughts are incorporated within lines or in combinations of lines. In the oldest Masoretic manuscripts, lines of this song are separated. There is repetition but not redundancy. Verse 24 may be taken as an example, given a somewhat over-literal equivalent:

<span id="page-289-0"></span>Ravaging famine Consuming plague Raging pestilence Fangs of beasts I will send against them With venomous creepers in dust. (AT)

The staccato lines create the effect of sensing the sequence of sudden disasters that come without warning. The subject and verb of the sentence are left to the penultimate line, where they have a higher impact. All this occurs because God is with them. He is the one advancing these disasters, because he has given them a covenant. This Israel agreed to when they took the oath.

As most poems, the song has unusual vocabulary and succinct memorable expressions. In the lines quoted above, the words for "plague" (Hb. *reshef*) and raging (*qeteb*; "pestilence") are the names of spirit gods (demons) here used metaphorically, the first along the lines of storm or destruction and the second of burning or flashes of lightning. In some ways it is impossible to translate metaphors; even if an equivalent referent can be given, the sense that goes with the expression is lost. The reader must be aware of the limitations to translating any poem from another culture or language. The power of the poem would have a greater impact on an Israelite in the circumstance of Moab than can be rendered in translation.

<span id="page-290-6"></span><span id="page-290-5"></span><span id="page-290-4"></span><span id="page-290-2"></span>The poem is a eulogy to the redeemer of Israel. He is their Rock, not in the sense of being a refuge but in his constant and unmovable care and presence. Heaven and earth are called on to be witnesses to the divine Word (32:1). The Rock is introduced as faithful but is betrayed by the children he has begotten, who are non-children (vv. 2–6). Creation imagery comes to mind as God finds Israel in the howling wilderness and hovers over them as an eagle guarding its young (vv. 10–11). God's loving care for Israel is rewarded with rebellion; they kick back like an overfed animal (vv. 15–18). God in turn will light a fire that burns to the depths of death (vv. 19–25). He does not utterly consume Israel, because the nations would misunderstand (vv. 26–31). The pride of the nations is avenged by God, who alone has such a prerogative (v. 35). The Lord takes an oath by himself that he will sharpen his sword and bring about vindication (vv. 40–41). The song ends with a coda of praise (v. 43). In reciting this song Israel will understand its place among the nations.
