#### *Comment*

<span id="page-290-12"></span><span id="page-290-3"></span><span id="page-290-1"></span><span id="page-290-0"></span>32:1–6 The first three verses are a prologue or exordium, given in the first person to a universal audience. They are similar to Psalm 49:1–4, which appeals to all people everywhere to hear the psalmist's testimony of coming to understand the ways of God. The Song of Moses is a covenant setting that begins with the motif of the heavens and earth as bearing witness (cf. Deut. 30:19; 31:28). These words are like life-giving water. The song is a doxology (v. 3), giving praise to the wonderful works of Yahweh. His deeds are flawless, and he is always faithful. This is a contrast to Israel, who is corrupt, perverse, and foolish.

<span id="page-291-8"></span><span id="page-291-7"></span><span id="page-291-6"></span><span id="page-291-4"></span>Verse 5 is challenging in structure, but when understood correctly it is a commanding poetic line. The key term is *non-children* ("no longer his children"), which has its parallel to *non-gods* in verse 17, *non-faithfulness* in verse 20, and *non-gods* and *non-people* in verse 21. These non-children are the subject of the verb "dealt corruptly." The line is succinct and compelling: "His non-sons, their blemish, have behaved corruptly toward him" (AT). Those God has created to be his children have disowned their pedigree.

<span id="page-291-5"></span><span id="page-291-0"></span>The rhetorical questions of verse 6 establish the key theological premise of the poem. The Rock is the Father and creator of Israel. The metaphor of fatherhood conveys the concept of procreation, as does the verb "create" (Hb. *qanah*). This word is used in Genesis 4:1 as the name of the firstborn son of Adam and Eve. As she says, "I have gotten [*qaniti* ] a man with the help of the Lord," so she named him *qayin*  ("Cain"). Every child is a creation of God. Israel was created, made, and secured by God. This is what it meant for him to choose Israel, as Isaiah says repeatedly (Isa. 43:1; 44:1–2). Israel is not distinguished from other nations in being more special than they in her own right. Rather, her relationship to God is much more fundamental. Her very existence is by divine choice. It is a bitter irony that Israel could be so foolish as to repay their progenitor and sole provider with perverse rebellion.

<span id="page-291-13"></span><span id="page-291-9"></span><span id="page-291-1"></span>32:7–14 These verses develop the theological premise that Israel holds a distinct role among the nations. It begins with an imperative to remember Israel's origins. God assigned the territorial, familial, and national divisions of the entire human race, as explained in Genesis 10. The peoples listed number precisely seventy, representing all nations on earth. Genesis does not provide the enumeration, but the symbolism is clear. Seventy signifies the total of human families, all under the dominion of Yahweh. This number corresponds to the number of the "sons of Israel" (Deut. 32:8 MT; cf. ESV mg.). The sons of Jacob are counted as seventy when each of the names is counted (Gen. 46:27; Ex. 1:5; Deut. 10:22). God made the seventy sons of Israel his own possession. Israel has become the special assignment of Yahweh among the seventy nations. This is the fundamental premise of the poem.

<span id="page-291-15"></span><span id="page-291-14"></span><span id="page-291-12"></span><span id="page-291-11"></span><span id="page-291-10"></span><span id="page-291-3"></span><span id="page-291-2"></span>This distinction of numbers raises exegetical questions that cannot be glossed over. Stephen says the number of the sons of Jacob is seventy-five (Acts 7:14), a number that he derives from the enumeration of individuals found in Genesis 46 in the LXX. This is a calculation determined by the placement of the five sons of Joseph. They can be considered as born in Egypt or can be included in the total of those who went down to Egypt. The Hebrew traditions have it both ways, but the number seventy-five does not conform to the seventy sons of Israel in verse 8. Other Hebrew texts do not include Israel in this verse. They say that God set the boundaries of the nations according to the sons of Elohim (cf. 4QDeutj [Dead Sea Scrolls] and most of the Greek tradition), meaning the number of members in the divine council. "Sons of God [*elohim*]" corresponds to the phrase used in Job 1:6, where the divine council gathers before God. Daniel 10:13 assigns heavenly princes to different nations. God has a court, as expressed in various psalms (Pss. 29:1;

<span id="page-292-7"></span>82:1; 89:7). The various members of his court are given assigned territories. The distinction of Israel is that God has made its territory his own allotted space. It is not assigned to court members like the other nations.

<span id="page-292-0"></span>The textual change of "sons of God" to "sons of Israel" in verse 8 is described by the rabbis as a *tiqqun soferim* ("change of the scribes"). There is a great deal of discussion over when the change was made to verse 8 and the possible reasons for it.84 This change requires the number of the sons of Israel be counted as seventy and not as seventy-five, in Acts 7:14. The theological statement is clear: Israel is the allotted territory God chose for himself when he divided the nations.

<span id="page-292-9"></span><span id="page-292-8"></span><span id="page-292-2"></span><span id="page-292-1"></span>The image of God as a father caring for his children is developed by a description of Israel in the howling desert waste of Sinai, where he embraced her and fixed his attention on her as the apple of his eye. He guarded her as an eagle takes care of its nest. The Hebrew word *'ir* (Deut. 32:11) is found in Ugaritic with the meaning of "guard" or "protect," which is the meaning that fits the poetic lines. This was a time when Israel was uncorrupted by other gods (v. 12), a confession to which Isaiah will call Israel to bear witness after the exile (Isa. 43:12). Virgin Israel was triumphant, riding the high hills, living from the produce of the field and drawing honey from the mountains. She enjoyed the richest of food from cattle and sheep, the fattest animals from the abundant hills of Bashan, thick kernels of wheat from the hills, and the juiciest grapes that provided wine. The father spared nothing in caring for his daughter.

<span id="page-292-3"></span>32:15–18 The use of the name "Jeshurun" in the context of Israel's rebellion is a potent poetic irony. The name carries the connotation of one that is upright (Hb. *yashar*), but the effect of all of God's bounteous provision for Israel was like that of a fatted unruly animal that kicks against the person who cares for it. Israel replaced its maker with non-gods, referred to here as demons (*shedim*), which correspond to the protective spirits and household gods known in Akkadian as *shedu*. 85 Instead of trusting the God they knew from experience as their Maker, they offended him with newly discovered non-deities. They forgot the Rock who had given birth to them, the one who had nursed them with honey from a stone.

<span id="page-292-6"></span><span id="page-292-4"></span>32:19–25 The worship of non-gods vexes the Rock, who justly acts in accordance with the covenant. He turns away from the non-faithful and provokes them with those who are a non-nation, probably a reference to nomadic peoples such as the "Midianites and the Amalekites and the people of the East" (Judg. 6:2–6). The anger of God is described as a hot flame that burns to the roots of the mountains or sharp arrows that pierce to their core. Divine punishment comes in a succession of disasters of diverse kinds (cf. Section Overview, esp. discussion of Deut. 32:24).

<span id="page-292-5"></span><sup>84</sup> Cf. D. Barthélemy, "Les Tiqquné Sopherim et la critique textuelle de L'Ancien Testament," in *Congress Volume, Bonn 1962*, ed. John Emerton, VTSup 9 (Leiden: Brill, 1963), 285–304. Barthélemy identifies this verse as a *tiqqun soferim* ("change of the scribes"). A further study on the time of this change was done by Innocent Himbaza, "Dt. 32:8, une correction tardive des scribes: Essai d'interprétation et de datation," *Bib* 83/4 (2002): 527–548.

<span id="page-293-1"></span>The metaphors of verse 24 use analogies characterized by local deities. The creeping vermin "in the dust" could be poisonous snakes, insects, or scorpions. Sword without and dread within will terrorize everyone—the best of men and maids, nursing children and the elderly.

<span id="page-293-4"></span><span id="page-293-2"></span>32:26–31 The song transitions with a conditional statement stating the reason God did not fully destroy the nation he had made. He would have removed Israel from human memory had it not been for the attitude of the nations. The enemies of Israel misjudge the situation; they think their dominance is because of their own power. The nations do not recognize the judgment of the Lord against Israel because they are utterly devoid of understanding. Verse 29 introduces a second unreal condition. If the nations had any understanding, they would perceive the circumstances of their victory. Their "latter end" (Hb. *'aharit*) here carries the sense of understanding why things have come about, the reasons for their situation. How was it possible for one soldier of Israel to rout a thousand of the enemy? The enemy has never considered this. Israel could be defeated only by its own betrayal of its Lord. The enemy should have discerned the work of the Rock, who had sold them to their enemies. The enemy should have recognized that the Rock of Israel is not as their rock, that is, their own god. The gods of the enemy could never have won such victories as they have witnessed for Israel.

<span id="page-293-6"></span><span id="page-293-3"></span><span id="page-293-0"></span>The rendering of 31b, "Our enemies are by themselves," renders an obscure poetic line. The difficulty is with the Hebrew word *pelilim*, which means either "judges" or "judgments." It occurs in Exodus 21:22, where judges must decide the damages to be paid in the case of an injury. The enemy has made the wrong assessment in thinking its god (rock) has been victorious. If the nation of Deuteronomy 32:28 is taken to be Israel, then the reasoning of verses 29–31 applies to Israel as the misguided nation, and the judgment ( *pelilim*) would be the reasoning of Israel concerning its enemies. This is the meaning of the ESV: Israel assesses its enemies to have no god ("our enemies are by themselves"; v. 31). Though the nation of verse 28 is ambiguous, the sequence could suggest it is the enemy that falsely considered itself triumphant.

<span id="page-293-7"></span><span id="page-293-5"></span>32:32–35 The poem now turns to judgment upon the nations; God will judge the enemy as he has judged such arrogant attitudes in the past. The enemy will suffer the same fate as did Sodom and Gomorrah. They will drink the wine served from the same vines as those condemned cities. Clusters of grapes will be poisonous, and their wine will be like the venom of a snake. The mercy of God cannot be presumed. For the arrogant, who claim their own independent strength, poisonous wine is sealed up and stored away. One of the most common artifacts found in Judean fortified cities is pot handles stamped with the Hebrew *lmlk* ("to the king"), with the name of the king often included as well. These are fragments of wine and oil jars sealed and stored by the king in fortified cities to serve as reserves in either commerce or preparation for war. The Song of Moses uses this as the image for God's storehouse when he goes to war.

<span id="page-294-17"></span><span id="page-294-12"></span><span id="page-294-2"></span>Vengeance belongs to God alone (v. 35). This important concept is quoted by Paul (Rom. 12:19) and the writer to the Hebrews (Heb. 10:30) in their exhortations to Christians concerning the conduct they must exhibit when wronged. The same principle was true in the covenant of Deuteronomy for personal conduct (cf. Prov. 25:21–22). In the Song of Moses this phrase is applied to the enemies of Israel. Jesus applies this verse to speak of the future desolation of Jerusalem in AD 70 (Luke 21:22), a direct application of the concept in Deuteronomy.

<span id="page-294-16"></span><span id="page-294-11"></span><span id="page-294-9"></span><span id="page-294-4"></span><span id="page-294-3"></span><span id="page-294-0"></span>32:36–42 Israel will be reduced to utter weakness; she will no longer have any leaders (Deut. 32:36). The expression "bond or free" (Hb. *'atsur we'azub*) is usually taken as a merism to mean everyone, but it has the more technical meaning of "redeemer-savior", referring to a king or leader. The construction is a hendiadys, in which two nouns or adjectives are joined to complement each other (e.g., "nice and warm"). The word *'atsur* means "ruler" or "restrainer" (e.g., 1 Sam. 9:17; "restrain"), while *'azub* is a word meaning "helper" or "deliverer" (e.g., Ex. 23:5; "rescue"). The meaning of redeemer-savior can be seen at 2 Kings 14:26. These terms are used in conjunction with the expression "every male" (lit., "everyone who urinates against the wall") to speak of all the male members of a royal family (1 Kings 14:10; 21:21; 2 Kings 9:8; cf. 1 Kings 16:11).86 The concept of the poem is the same as that expressed in the judgments of Isaiah against Jerusalem in Isaiah 2:6–4:1: Jerusalem will be brought to utter loss of leaders before God establishes his rule on his holy mountain (Isa. 2:2–4). In the poem of Deuteronomy God points out the futility of Israel's turning away from the Rock to serve other gods (32:37). In a taunting rhetorical question God demands to know how these gods will rise to serve as Israel's protection.

<span id="page-294-15"></span><span id="page-294-14"></span><span id="page-294-13"></span><span id="page-294-10"></span><span id="page-294-5"></span><span id="page-294-1"></span>The song returns to the fundamental statement Moses asserted earlier in his exhortation to Israel: "There is no god beside me" (v. 39; cf. 4:35, 39). The language of the absolute unity of God is used by Isaiah to confront blind Israel when she is helpless and despondent (Isa. 43:10–13). Israel is the witness to the truth that there can be no other God than the one who has delivered her. It is only this God who can give life, just as he is the one who brought the death of judgment.

<span id="page-294-6"></span>God now takes an oath by himself (Deut. 32:40). He has sharpened his sword and will take vengeance against his enemies. His arrows will be drunk with the blood of the enemy when he grasps justice in his hand. The significance of the hairy heads of the enemy is not clear. The hair might indicate they are chiefs, or it might be a symbol of strength now defeated. It is unlikely, however, to be a reference to the story of Samson, since that would not be relevant in the context of the enemies of God.

<span id="page-294-8"></span>32:43 The coda of the poem returns to the theme of the opening apostrophe in addressing the heavenly beings and calling on them to give praise. It concludes the theme of verse 41, which is that God will "take vengeance" on his enemies.

<span id="page-294-7"></span><sup>86</sup> For a full study cf. Shemaryahu Talmon and Weston W. Fields, "The Collocation ועזוב ועצור בקיר משתין and Its Meaning," *ZAW* 101/1 (January 1989): 85–112.

It advances this thought by saying that God will cleanse the land that has been polluted by idolatries and other abominations, such as the shedding of innocent blood. Israel is freed not only from the calamities that it has so long endured but also from the sins that have been committed there.

There has been considerable textual corruption in the transmission of this verse. The Masoretic Text, which is found in most English translations, calls upon the nations to acclaim God's deliverance and punishment of the enemy. Such a call to the nations implies the significance of the salvation of Israel for all the world.

<span id="page-295-3"></span>The best-preserved version of the closing stanza is in a fragment of a Qumran scroll now identified as 4QDeutq . 87 In this scroll, three-quarters of a final column contain Deuteronomy 32:41d–43. The stitching is still present to the right of the column. Six lines of verse 43 are preserved complete and clearly. The strophes of the parallel lines appear as follows:

- <span id="page-295-4"></span>(1a) O heavens rejoice with him
- (1b) Bow to him all deities
- (2a) For he will avenge the blood of his sons (2b) Return vengeance on his foes
- (3a) Repay those who reject him (3b) Cleanse his people's land.

The Masoretic Text is missing line 1b and 3a, which is quite clearly deficient, as it breaks up the parallelism of the strophes. The Greek translations have eight lines because they retain an alternate version of the first two lines. It is probable that some of these variations are due to the existence of more than one version of the poem, or at least the closing coda.

<span id="page-295-5"></span><span id="page-295-2"></span><span id="page-295-0"></span>32:44 The subscription recapitulates the reference to the song in 31:22, 30. Moses comes from where he received instructions to teach the poem, or from where he wrote it, and teaches it to the people. According to the Masoretic Text, Moses is assisted by "Hoshea" in the reading of this poem. The name of the successor of Moses was changed to Joshua, according to Numbers 13:16. The difference between "Hoshea" and "Joshua" is the inclusion of the name of God at the beginning of the name.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-295-1"></span>The most important metaphor of the Song of Moses is the one used for God. God is the Rock (Hb. *tsur*)—a crag, an outcropping of a mountain, a large rock formation that can be used as a place of refuge or shelter. In Deuteronomy 8:15 God brought water from the flint stone in the desert. This *tsur* was not a mere stone but the dry barren cliff of a mountain in a parched desert. It is quite logical that the most common application of *tsur* with reference to God is to describe him as a refuge,

<sup>87</sup> This fragment was first published by Patrick W. Skehan, "A Fragment of the 'Song of Moses' (Deut. 32) from Qumran," *BASOR* 136 (December 1954): 12–15.

<span id="page-296-8"></span><span id="page-296-1"></span>a place of protection (e.g., Pss. 18:2; 19:14; Isa. 26:4). This is one of the rare words used more often as a metaphor for God than as an actual feature of the landscape. However, its application to the God of the covenant in the Song of Moses is unique in Scripture.88 Understanding this metaphor is key to understanding the poem. God is introduced by his covenant name, Yahweh (Deut. 32:3). The next verse gives the equivalent of this name as Rock, whose work is perfect. He is characterized by being fair in his dealings, faithful, correct, and upright. This contrasts his covenant partner; they are corrupt, perverse, and twisted. Apart from this perspective it is impossible to appreciate the development of the song.

<span id="page-296-10"></span><span id="page-296-5"></span><span id="page-296-2"></span><span id="page-296-0"></span>The change in emphasis in the poem is the moral character and righteousness of God as *tsur* rather than as a Rock of deliverance and refuge. This concept is also found in a few other passages, such as Psalm 92:15, in which Yahweh is called "upright." In Deuteronomy 32 God as *tsur* is the one who has made Israel and brought them salvation (v. 15). The metaphor of the rock as savior is common, but the present text is not about deliverance from danger. The unique reference here is to the deliverance of Israel when God brought them to Egypt, where they became a great nation, and then brought them out of their slavery. God's choice of Israel expresses his plan, which was to create a nation. Israel was not selected from among existing nations. God's choice was to create a people for himself (vv. 6, 12). The birth of Israel required infant care, and Israel sucked (*wayyeneqehu*) honey from a stone and oil from the flint rock (v. 13). The care of the Rock is like that of a mother who has power to draw food from rock. In this song the Rock of Israel is contrasted with the gods of the nations. The nations have been misled. The rock to whom they have made sacrifices has failed them (vv. 36–38); they will come to realize that the reason for Israel's curses is that their Rock has sold them into the power of their enemy. Enemies of Israel will realize that the Rock of Israel is not like their own rock.

<span id="page-296-7"></span><span id="page-296-4"></span><span id="page-296-3"></span>The development of the theme of how the Rock of Israel has dealt with his people is culturally compelling in covenant exhortation. In the religions surrounding Israel, gods were identified with mountains and the features associated with them. The concepts of strength, safety, and refuge have been taken over from the divine epithet *tsur*. Ancient temples depicted fertility and abundance in images of mountains and rivers. In Canaan this was particularly true of Baal, who was associated with the peak Zaphon (a mountain "in the far north"; Ps. 48:2). The Rock gave birth to Israel, and he was the one who gave them life (Deut. 32:17–18). Concepts of begetting and nurturing were common to the gods of Canaan. The covenant people must always know that these activities belong solely to Yahweh.

<span id="page-296-9"></span><span id="page-296-6"></span>Christians should ponder this poem no less than Israel should. One of the most abused terms in the English language is the word *God*. It is used with only a

This stimulating study shows how the poem develops several images for the care of the covenant God around the Hebrew term *tsur*.

vague of idea of what might be meant. Israelites who memorized this song knew exactly what they meant when they spoke of their God. This was much more than abstract concepts such as omnipotence and omniscience. Israel knew the character and conduct of the person in relationship with them.

#### *Section Overview: The Blessing of Moses*

The Song of Moses and the deposit of the Torah for regular reading are concluded with the assurance that these are all the words taught by Moses and with the warning that these words cannot be ignored, because the life of Israel depends on them. God then summons Moses to his death, which provides a transition and an introduction to the parting blessing of Moses.

The blessing of Moses is a poem, though the ancient scrolls do not lay it out in poetic format as they do the song. The poem has obscure words and textual failures, so that often it is difficult to tell whether one is, or both are, making interpretation very difficult. As a poem it may have long been transmitted in ancient script, contributing to the problem. The poem recalls Mount Sinai, in a sense bringing in the experience of the divine presence at the initiation of the ministry of Moses in order to conclude his leadership of Israel in the same way. Moses provides a glimpse into the future of Israel and their life in the Promised Land, somewhat as he did in the song. However, the blessings describe the potential and abundance of the individual tribes, anticipating their opportunities, much as the blessing of Jacob in Genesis 49. Some of the blessings are petitions; others address the tribes themselves. Even those blessings that are descriptions of the tribes are meant as blessings.

<span id="page-300-0"></span>Except for Levi, each of the tribes is spoken of as an individual person. The blessing of some of the tribes are a play on their name; three are compared to animals whose qualities manifest warrior skill. The tribes are not addressed in their order of birth but follow a geographical pattern. Simeon is not mentioned, but it did not have a separate territory, so likely it is to be included with Judah. The poem begins with Reuben, the firstborn, but the tribes are also stationed in the territory that belongs to Reuben. The next tribe is Judah, just across the Jordan, followed by Levi. Since Levi did not have a territory but was based in Jerusalem as the priestly tribe, it logically follows. The list then moves northward listing the Joseph tribes, then west to east (Zebulun, Issachar, and Gad), and finally north and west (Dan, Naphtali, and Asher). The poem concludes with the blessedness of Israel with God as its provider and protector.
