#### *Comment*

<span id="page-400-8"></span><span id="page-400-5"></span><span id="page-400-4"></span><span id="page-400-2"></span>8:30–32, 34–35a The frequent mention of Moses here makes an emphatic assertion of obedience to the divine command given through him. Prominence is given to this in Joshua 8:31, and it is also echoed in each of the two succeeding sections of this small passage (vv. 33, 34). This ceremony forms a link in the chain comprising 1:7, 13; and 4:10, which likewise connect the actions of Joshua and the people to Moses' commands. These are pivotal moments in the life of the community. The benchmark of fidelity to God's word through Moses is an integral part of Israel's progression into the land.

<span id="page-400-0"></span>As noted in the Section Overview, several elements in this passage reflect earlier commands of Moses recorded in Deuteronomy. Here, however, emphasis falls on Ebal, the altar, and the sacrificial "peace offerings" (Hb. *shelamim*) made upon it. These offerings, described in Leviticus 3; 7:11–18, are festival meals in which the priests and laity alike participate. The essence of the ceremony, then, contributes to the sense of unity among the whole people of God.

<span id="page-400-9"></span><span id="page-400-6"></span><span id="page-400-1"></span>Alongside the gathering for worship and sacrificial offering is also the promulgation of the Word. Joshua's writing of the law (Josh. 8:32) and the subsequent reading of it (vv. 34–35) call to mind the responsibility laid on kings to write a "copy of this law" and to "read in it all the days of his life" (Deut. 17:18–20). Here, however, Joshua writes not in a book for personal devotion but on plastered tablets for public display. He is no king, and, as will be seen below, he leads a remarkable people in this covenant ceremony that will—in the current form of the book—strike fear into the hearts of Canaanite kings (Josh. 9:1–2). But this "is not a 'monarchical' polity, with Joshua as Israelite 'king' in place of the expelled Canaanite kings. A new kind of people now has possession of Canaan."76

<span id="page-400-11"></span><span id="page-400-10"></span><span id="page-400-7"></span>8:33, 35b Appearing centrally in this brief passage, verse 33 presents a detailed roster of "all Israel" attending the ceremony. It is a remarkably inclusive list, but inclusive in a different way than its echo in verse 35b, which concludes this pericope. The grouping is conveyed slightly differently in the Hebrew text than in translation. All of the key Israelite participants—elders, officers (cf. 1:10), judges, and priests—are first enumerated, and then this company is glossed with the qualifier "sojourner as well

<span id="page-400-3"></span><sup>76</sup> McConville and Williams, *Joshua*, 46.

as native born." The phrase is embedded at about the halfway point of the lengthy verse, punctuating the report and providing a transition to the actions on Gerizim and Ebal in obedience to Moses' command. It is a remarkable detail. The book has already demonstrated through the story of Rahab that the barriers to belonging are graciously porous. It now appears that the makeup of "all Israel" includes those who are not ethnically Israelite. Whether these include, decades later, the descendants of the camp followers who left Egypt with Israel (Ex. 12:38) is impossible to say. The language that aligns treatment of the "sojourner" with the "native" is familiar from Exodus (12:19, 49), Leviticus (17:15; 18:26; esp. 19:34), and Numbers (15:29–30). It remains a fundamental principle for Ezekiel's legislation for renewed Israel in the only legal code in the OT outside the books of Moses (Ezek. 47:22).

<span id="page-401-7"></span><span id="page-401-3"></span><span id="page-401-1"></span><span id="page-401-0"></span>The priests are glossed as those who "carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord," recalling the precise language of the Jordan crossing in Joshua 3–4. Here, as there, this signals the presence of Israel's God with the gathered community.

<span id="page-401-4"></span>This passage concludes with another inclusive catalog of those representing the "assembly" [or "congregation"; *qahal*] of Israel" (Josh. 8:35b). Here women and children are explicitly included. The three-member set of men, women, and children occurs regularly in the OT (over twenty-five times), always to emphasize the complete community and often to signal its vulnerable and dependent nature. The sojourners are once again specified, the last mentioned as "those sojourners who were traveling in their midst" (AT; cf. ESV mg.). This account of the composition of the gathered community thus emphasizes the welcome that nonnative Israelites may have as they respond in worship and obedience to the covenant God of Israel.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-401-5"></span>As we now read this passage in its canonical context—the renewal of the covenant in the participation of the whole community gathered for worship, alongside Joshua's declaring the covenant blessings and curses and "publishing" God's word—it is this incident that, "as soon as all the kings who were beyond the Jordan . . . heard of this," induces them to gather "as one to fight against Joshua and Israel" (9:1–2). There is a political logic here, as the covenant declarations assert God's sovereignty over all nations.77 After three chapters of intense military activity, this account of all Israel gathered for worship provides a brief but clear moment of pause. The rightly ordered people, living in obedience to and fellowship with their covenant God, prove even more offensive to the watching nations than does their military prowess. It is impossible to miss the dynamic shared with the attitude of the kings of the earth hostile to the universal reign of God in Psalm 2.

<span id="page-401-6"></span>The nature of this covenant community was explored above. This is an inclusive community, with a central feature of the account being the presence of women and children and—twice mentioned—the sojourners among them, in addition to the men of Israel and its officials. Origen's ninth homily on Joshua treats this

<span id="page-401-2"></span><sup>77</sup> Cf. Creach, *Joshua*, 80. Creach notes in particular the provocative nature of Deuteronomy 28:1, 7, 10.

<span id="page-402-8"></span><span id="page-402-6"></span>passage. His proclivity for allegorical interpretation inclines him in this sermon to associate the earthly stones of Joshua's altar with the "living stones" (1 Pet. 2:5) of the church. The notion of building with stones takes him also to Ephesians 2:20, which describes how the church is "built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Christ Jesus himself being the cornerstone." Origen draws out the lesson: "In this edifice of the Church, there must also be an altar."78 It is not his interest to note the wider setting of his Ephesians quotation, although it is particularly apt for reflection on this passage in Joshua. There Paul is setting out the "mystery" (Eph. 3:2–6) that one people of God has been made possible through the gospel of Christ Jesus as it has come to those who were both "far off" and "near" (Eph. 2:17), so that Gentiles have become fellow citizens with the "commonwealth of Israel" (Eph. 2:12). The gathering with Joshua at Ebal, incorporating the sojourner in the covenant community, is at least a hint toward the fuller realization of God's purpose to draw to himself in worship every "nation, from all tribes and peoples and languages" (Rev. 7:9).

<span id="page-402-9"></span><span id="page-402-7"></span><span id="page-402-5"></span><span id="page-402-4"></span><span id="page-402-3"></span><span id="page-402-2"></span><span id="page-402-1"></span>The reading of the law in its entirety also attracts Origen's attention. While for him the association is made through 2 Corinthians 3:15–16 to the difference it makes when Jesus reads the law,79 there is another, more simple lesson for the church here. The practice of the public reading of Scripture varies considerably between local churches; in my experience, however, the tendency is toward neglect. Those traditions that use a lectionary may be helped in this. But the careful, articulate, thoughtful reading of God's Word among God's people is a powerful thing. It can bring kings to their knees (2 Kings 22:10–11). Reading is active on the part of the reader, but so too is listening (Luke 8:18).

Then all the congregation murmured against the leaders. **19**But all the leaders said to all the congregation, "We have sworn to them by the Lord, the God of Israel, and now we may not touch them. **20**This we will do to them: let them live, lest wrath be upon us, because of the oath that we swore to them." **21**And the leaders said to them, "Let them live." So they became cutters of wood and drawers of water for all the congregation, just as the leaders had said of them.

**<sup>22</sup>** Joshua summoned them, and he said to them, "Why did you deceive us, saying, 'We are very far from you,' when you dwell among us? **23**Now therefore you are cursed, and some of you shall never be anything but servants, cutters of wood and drawers of water for the house of my God." **<sup>24</sup>**They answered Joshua, "Because it was told to your servants for a certainty that the Lord your God had commanded his servant Moses to give you all the land and to destroy all the inhabitants of the land from before you—so we feared greatly for our lives because of you and did this thing. **25**And now, behold, we are in your hand. Whatever seems good and right in your sight to do to us, do it." **<sup>26</sup>** So he did this to them and delivered them out of the hand of the people of Israel, and they did not kill them. **27**But Joshua made them that day cutters of wood and drawers of water for the congregation and for the altar of the Lord, to this day, in the place that he should choose.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-403-0"></span>The account of the Gibeonites is told over two chapters, as with that of Jericho (Joshua 2; 6) and Ai (chs. 7–8), and is the third of three specific encounters with <span id="page-404-4"></span>the inhabitants of the Promised Land in the first part of the book. Also like those battles the narrative of Gibeon involves a single city. But it implies a larger alliance, the so-called tetrapolis named in 9:17, and effects a transition to wider military engagements. From this point onward, as Israel subdues the whole territory, the "conquest" gathers momentum and spreads regionally.

The earlier texts involved individuals, Rahab and Achan, whose sharply contrasting identities, commitments, and fates had a clear evaluation and purpose. One is a Canaanite who, with her family, lives; the other is an Israelite who, with his family, dies. The story of the Gibeonites admits no such clear assessment. Commentators over the centuries have been vexed by Israel's lax treatment of the Gibeonites and troubled over how to regard the incorporation of Gibeon into the community of Israel. Given this difficulty, the exegesis of this passage proceeds in a different manner than that of the preceding chapters. The comment on content will proceed fairly rapidly, and then overarching questions in evaluating the story theologically will be considered. Who is acting on Israel's behalf? What theology do the Gibeonites hold? And how should the covenant made between Israel and Gibeon be regarded?

<span id="page-404-2"></span><span id="page-404-1"></span>The narrative outlines of the account are clear enough. Following the notice of the reaction of the Canaanite kings of the central lowlands to the Israelite covenant ceremony (9:1–2), a contrasting reaction is registered on the part of the city of Gibeon. Rather than participating in the hostile stance of the other Canaanites and risking destruction at the hands of the Israelites, the Gibeonites instead successfully seek a treaty ("covenant"; v. 15) with Israel by deception (vv. 3–15). Shortly thereafter their ruse is discovered by Israel, which leads to the question of what to do next. In view of the covenant made with Israel they are spared, but on condition of becoming "servants . . . for the house of my God," as Joshua puts it (v. 23), in perpetuity (vv. 16–27).

#### <span id="page-404-5"></span><span id="page-404-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- I.K. The Gibeonite Ruse (9:1–27)
	- 1. The Canaanite Kings Assemble (9:1–2)
	- 2. The Gibeonite Treaty (9:3–15)
		- a. The Gibeonites Seek a Treaty (9:3–7)
		- b. The Parley with Joshua (9:8–13)
		- c. Joshua's Treaty; Leader's Oath (9:14–15)
	- 3. The Israelite Discovery (9:16–27)
		- a. Israel Informed, Pursues (9:16–17)
		- b. Community Dissension and Agreement (9:18–21)
		- c. Joshua and the Gibeonites Negotiate (9:22–25)
		- d. Gibeonites Spared but Subject to Servitude (9:26–27)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-404-0"></span>9:1–2 The nature of the reaction of these Canaanite kings has been discussed in the Response to 8:30–35 in relation to the covenant renewal ceremony recounted <span id="page-405-8"></span>in those verses (due to the textual complications of its placement in the flow of the narrative). In the canonical text the kings' reaction is occasioned by that ceremony, with its assertions of the supreme sovereignty of Israel's God and the claims this implies for the land. This notice has counterparts in 10:1–5; 11:1–5, in which kings of the central and southern regions, and then again in the north, have the same hostile reaction. As these passages portray it, all of these kings and their cities "fight against" or "make war against" Israel.

The story of Rahab has already alerted the reader to the fact that it did not need to be so; this outcome was not automatic, and it is the further contribution of the story of the Gibeonites to demonstrate that other possibilities for Canaanites were possible for whole communities, not merely for individuals and their families. But throughout this opening part of the book the predominant pattern is that of hostility and aggression provoked by Israel's presence and the power of Israel's God.

<span id="page-405-7"></span><span id="page-405-4"></span>9:3–5 The identity of Gibeon is not fully disclosed at once, and the information appearing in 9:17 and 10:2 adds to the understanding of who it is that now approaches Joshua and the Israelites. Gibeon was a city about 19 miles (31 km) due west of Gilgal, the Israelite camp to the east of Jericho, and only 6 miles (10 km) southwest of Ai. Although it is named as acting on its own behalf as the account begins, it becomes clear that Gibeon is the leading member of a coalition of cities in the region. Its status and power are, then, on quite a different level than Ai's (cf. 10:2).

<span id="page-405-10"></span><span id="page-405-1"></span>Whether the Gibeonites are to be regarded with sympathy or antipathy rests to some extent on how their characterization here is understood; the key to this is found in the word the ESV translates as "cunning" (Hb. *ʿormah*). When used in the context of what wisdom provides (Prov. 1:4; 8:5, 12), this word is translated in the ESV as "prudence." Beyond these instances the word is used only once more in the OT: at Exodus 21:14. This verse describes murder by stealthy intent; there the ESV also reads "cunning."80 A welter of other options appears across English versions, reflecting differing moral evaluations of the Gibeonites' actions; "wily" (KJV), "shrewd" (ISV), and "deceptive" (CSB) demonstrate the range. At this point in the narrative readers lack sufficient data to come to an informed judgment; a more neutral term such as "clever" (NET) might capture the sense. But even if the judgment is a negative one, this is not the first time in the book that deception works in keeping with God's purposes (cf. comments on 2:2–7 [regarding Rahab]; 8:3–9 [regarding the ambush of Ai]).

<span id="page-405-6"></span><span id="page-405-5"></span><span id="page-405-3"></span><span id="page-405-2"></span>9:5–7 The ruse is a simple one: the Gibeonites contrive to look as if they have traveled a vast distance by exhibiting stale provisions and dilapidated equipment, reinforced by their own claim in verse 6, emphatic in Hebrew: "From a distant land we have come[!]," fronting the origin of the journey in the clause. With Gibeon less

<span id="page-405-9"></span><span id="page-405-0"></span><sup>80</sup> The related Hebrew adjective *ʿarum* is used eleven times in the OT, famously at Genesis 3:1 of the "crafty" serpent (cf. Job 5:12; 15:5, both Eliphaz). It appears eight times in Proverbs, each time with a positive nuance and consistently translated in the ESV as "prudent."

than 20 miles (32 km) to the west of Gilgal, if they departed in the morning they could have arrived comfortably that same afternoon—hardly time for bread to go moldy or clothes and sandals to wear out!

<span id="page-406-5"></span><span id="page-406-2"></span><span id="page-406-1"></span><span id="page-406-0"></span>They explicitly request a "covenant" with Israel. This raises a further question regarding Gibeonite intentions: what do they know of Israel's traditions? Two passages in Deuteronomy bear directly on the Gibeonite initiative: (1) Deuteronomy 7 (cf. comment on 6:15–19) contains instructions for *kherem* relating to the nations to be dispossessed in Canaan; (2) Deuteronomy 7:2 stipulates, "You shall make no covenant with them and show no mercy to them." However, the laws governing warfare in Deuteronomy 20 include the requirement to offer conditions of peace and servitude only for those "that are very far from you, which are not cities of the nations here" (20:15). The passage goes on to stipulate terms of *kherem* for the near inhabitants along the lines set out in Deuteronomy 7. This matter will be further explored below in connection with the status of the Gibeonite covenant. But as representatives of Gibeon present themselves to Joshua and the initial interrogation begins, the terms in which the negotiations proceed appear to have these Deuteronomic laws specifically in mind.

<span id="page-406-11"></span><span id="page-406-9"></span><span id="page-406-8"></span><span id="page-406-3"></span>Although the Gibeonites have come to Joshua at Gilgal (Josh. 9:6) and address him (also vv. 8, 9–13), the "men of Israel" (v. 7) intervene, and both Joshua and these men are involved as the initial phase of negotiations concludes (vv. 14, 15). The "men of Israel" raise the initial concern about the proximity of these strangers, and only then does Joshua take up this line of questioning. The interaction between Joshua and this wider group will require closer investigation below.

<span id="page-406-10"></span><span id="page-406-7"></span><span id="page-406-4"></span>9:8–13 The Gibeonites now provide an account of their actions in keeping with the terms of the plan already set out in verses 4–5. But first they declare their distant origins—omitting any orientation in the landscape as to where their "very distant country" might lie—and their reason for seeking a covenant with Israel in their knowledge of Israel's God. Like Rahab (2:10), news of what Yahweh has done in Egypt and of the destruction of the Amorite kings Sihon and Og looms large in their reckoning. Pointedly, they do not betray any knowledge of the real trigger for their actions: the recent conquests of Jericho and Ai (9:3). There is no need, since the reputation ("name") of Israel's God is fully established on the basis of those more historically distant events, and any mention of Jericho and Ai might raise suspicions about their access to news of Israel's very recent battles.

<span id="page-406-6"></span>Their regard for Israel's God is left to implication rather than outright confession. While the Gibeonites show an awareness of God's power and actions on behalf of Israel in more distant times, they make no further avowals of respect. The counsel of their elders to seek a covenant is all the reaction described, with attention directed to the evidence of their provisions and equipment rather than to their regard for the Lord God.

<span id="page-406-12"></span>9:14–15 The response from Israel's side comes quite quickly and with remarkable trust in the Gibeonites' words. Three parties on Israel's side are involved in <span id="page-407-5"></span><span id="page-407-4"></span>concluding the covenant. First, the "men" whose suspicions sparked Joshua's line of questioning (v. 8) test the claims of the Gibeonites via closer inspection of their goods. At this point (v. 14) we find a very brief, and very rare, intervention on the part of the narrator: "But [they] did not ask counsel from the Lord." The phrasing in Hebrew draws attention to this lapse and uses distinctive language in doing so: "counsel from the Lord" translates *pi yhwh* ("mouth of Yahweh"). This is a phrase used often for the direct revelation of a command of God and one that concludes Deuteronomy 8:3, in which Moses declares that "man does not live by bread alone, but man lives by every word that comes from the mouth of the Lord." Here the men of Israel consider bread only, ignoring what might come from the mouth of God.

<span id="page-407-3"></span><span id="page-407-1"></span>With the "men" of Israel satisfied, now Joshua makes "peace" and a "covenant" with the Gibeonites to "let them live," this last phrase making explicit the implication of the covenant and providing an echo of the treatment Joshua ensured for Rahab (Josh. 6:17, 25). A third party now briefly is added to these proceedings, the "leaders of the congregation," whose oath confirms the arrangements. And the thing is done.

<span id="page-407-6"></span>9:16–17 Although crucial for the larger narrative, the Israelite discovery and confirmation of the deception is recounted with extreme economy. The discovery comes after "three days," and the journey to investigate is concluded on "the third day" after the Israelite delegates depart. The reason such a short journey should have taken this long is of no interest to the narrator. It may imply simply a passage of some days, using a conventional number; perhaps the Israelite investigators are also confirming the locations of all the members of the tetrapolis mentioned in verse 17. In any case, the true facts of the matter are now known to Israel.

<span id="page-407-8"></span><span id="page-407-7"></span>9:18–21 The question now arises of what to do in response to the Gibeonites' ruse. Two of the three parties involved in confirming the arrangements with Gibeon are now at loggerheads. Joshua's absence from this moment of community crisis is conspicuous. The "people of Israel" seem inclined to destroy those who have duped them. But the "leaders" allay the hostilities of the people—also termed "all the congregation"—by pointing to the oath sworn "by the Lord, the God of Israel" (as had been done by the spies with Rahab; 2:12, 17), which cannot be broken. Joshua 9:21 reports the outcome, slightly elaborated subsequently, that the Gibeonites will be allowed to live, but only as "cutters of wood and drawers of water *for all the congregation*," that is, among the general Israelite populace, in accord with the leaders' commitments.

<span id="page-407-11"></span><span id="page-407-10"></span><span id="page-407-9"></span><span id="page-407-2"></span><span id="page-407-0"></span>9:22–23 Only now does Joshua intervene, and the rest of the scene is played out between the Gibeonites and Joshua himself. He first names the Gibeonite action as one of deceit, using a fairly uncommon Hebrew verb that carries the nuance of fraud and betrayal (*ramah*; used only eight times in the OT); it is used, for example, of Laban's marrying Jacob to Leah rather than to Rachel (Gen. 29:25) and of Michal's ruse to protect David in 1 Samuel 19:17. Further, Joshua directs their role as "cutters of wood and drawers of water" toward service of the "house of my God" rather than being among the people as a whole. It is difficult to know just what to make of Joshua's refining of the leaders' assignment of servitude to the Gibeonites. Service to the community at large would appear to be in keeping with the stipulation of Deuteronomy 20:10–11, that distant cities offered terms of peace "shall do forced labor for you and shall serve you."

<span id="page-408-9"></span><span id="page-408-6"></span><span id="page-408-1"></span>9:24–25 The Gibeonites reply in mitigation and defense, filling out their account first offered in Joshua 9:9–10. Now they provide a more personal reaction to their knowledge of the actions God had commanded to perform in the land: they came in self-preservation. And so they willingly submit to the terms Joshua has placed on them.

<span id="page-408-10"></span><span id="page-408-8"></span>9:26–27 The final verses draw the threads together, wholly described in terms of Joshua's decisions that bear on the future of the Gibeonites. Their continuing existence is confirmed; they are "delivered" from the people who would rather have killed them (cf. v. 18). Their role among the Israelites is now described as "altar" service, using the distinctive language of Deuteronomy, "in the place that he should choose"81—an anticipation of Jerusalem, but at this point referring to anyplace the Lord's altar might be. This is further considered below in our evaluation of the Gibeonite covenant.

#### <span id="page-408-4"></span>*Excursus on Joshua 9:1–27*

Three questions bearing on a response to this passage have been deferred until the narrative could be seen as a whole. With the commentary above in mind, these questions can now be tackled.

#### WHO ACTS FOR ISRAEL?

At various points in this episode different parties speak for and act on behalf of Israel: (1) the "men of Israel," possibly to be identified also with the "congregation"; (2) the "leaders" (Hb. *nesiʾim*) of the congregation; and (3) Joshua himself.

<span id="page-408-5"></span><span id="page-408-3"></span><span id="page-408-2"></span>Four things are noteworthy here. (1) The "elders," who took a significant leading role throughout the Achan/Ai episode (in lament, 7:6; in mustering Israel, 8:10; in the covenant renewal, 8:33), are absent. The reason for this absence is a matter for speculation, but, given the general failure of alertness in this episode, the absence is regrettable. (2) It is difficult to know whether to correlate the "men of Israel" (9:6, 7, 14) with the people as a whole or with those later designated as "leaders" (vv. 15, 18). (3) Joshua's two interventions seem to be derivative and secondary; in both instances they are a reaction to a situation already unfolding, or perhaps even unraveling. (4) The "leaders of the congregation" take unusual initiative, as they appear as active agents only here in Joshua.82 The "leaders of the congregation"

<span id="page-408-7"></span><sup>81</sup> This phrase is used twenty-three times in the OT, with all but two instances being found in Deuteronomy

<span id="page-408-0"></span><sup>12–31.</sup> Elsewhere it is used only at Joshua 9:27 and at Nehemiah 1:9.

<span id="page-408-11"></span><sup>82</sup> They also appear in a list at Joshua 22:30.

<span id="page-409-2"></span><span id="page-409-1"></span>appear several times in the exodus narratives (Ex. 16:22; Num. 4:34; 31:13; 32:2), typically acting in concert with Moses. Numbers 31 is notable as another occasion on which inappropriate leniency is shown to enemies of Israel. On that instance, the aftermath of the Baal of Peor episode, the leaders join Moses in confronting the military commanders at fault.

This summary suggests that the line of command in Israel is somewhat confused, with both its strategic and its spiritual instincts occluded. Perhaps the most concerning of these elements is the role of Joshua. In light of his failure of judgment in the Achan/Ai episode, one would hope for increased vigilance. Here, however, we find another lapse of judgment; this will emerge again as the distribution of the land unfolds later in the book (Joshua 13–19). The criticism leveled via the unusual intrusion of the narrator's voice in Joshua 9:14 appears to be directed to the "men [of Israel]," but the fact that the very next verse relates Joshua's action as a consequence implicates him in their negligence.

<span id="page-409-11"></span><span id="page-409-10"></span><span id="page-409-8"></span>There is, then, something of a cautionary tale emerging as Joshua's leadership is subject to scrutiny (cf. Ps. 146:3). The first incremental steps toward the downward spiral that accelerates in the book of Judges have already been taken.

#### WHAT IS THE GIBEONITES' THEOLOGY?

Parallels between the Gibeonites and Rahab have often been observed. Rahab's confession was seen above to be quite a profound, even startling, expression of faith in the God of Israel, as its wording suggestively aligned her with Moses and Solomon (Josh. 2:9–11; cf. comments there).

<span id="page-409-7"></span><span id="page-409-4"></span>The outlook expressed by the Gibeonite representatives shares something of this character without achieving the depth of understanding that Rahab's words convey. Unlike Rahab's confession, made entirely before the arrangement and promise reached with the spies, the Gibeonites' confession comes in two stages, first in 9:9–10 and then again in verse 24. In both of these stages their self-account is given in response to questioning from Joshua, and both times it is embedded in their plea to be allied to Israel (in vv. 6, 11 regarding the "covenant" and again in v. 25 to be shown mercy). How these two confessions compare can be seen in tabular form (table 2.2).

<span id="page-409-6"></span><span id="page-409-3"></span>

| Shared Elements   | Rahab                                 | Gibeonites                     |
|-------------------|---------------------------------------|--------------------------------|
| Knowledge         | "I know that" (2:9)                   | "We have heard a report" (9:9) |
| Israel's God      | the Lord                              | the Lord                       |
| Action Attributed | has given land                        | has done                       |
| Reaction          | afraid                                | afraid                         |
| Israel's History  | Egypt, Sihon, and Og                  | Egypt, Sihon, and Og           |
| Conclusion        | Yahweh is the God of heaven and earth | feared greatly for their lives |

<span id="page-409-9"></span><span id="page-409-5"></span><span id="page-409-0"></span>TABLE 2.2: The Confessions of Rahab and the Gibeonites Compared

<span id="page-410-2"></span>Of the six shared elements, three align and three differ. The similarities are that both parties (1) name Israel's God by his covenant name, (2) know the essential political history of the exodus and the conquest of the Amorite kings Sihon and Og, and (3) express fear. The differences, however, are the following: (1) Whereas Rahab frames her confession in terms of personal knowledge, the Gibeonites point to an indirect report of unspecified origin, which they share. Their real reason remains the recent destruction of Jericho and Ai (9:3). (2) Whereas Rahab sees the land as in Yahweh's gift; the Gibeonites are a step removed, speaking simply of God's act and the command through Moses to destroy. (3) Tellingly, Rahab's statement reaches a climax with the recognition of Yahweh as "God of heaven and earth," an insight that places her in the company of Moses and Solomon; the Gibeonites' climactic statement is not about who God is but about their concern for their own self-preservation. The upshot of all this is that, while Rahab commits herself to Israel's God, the Gibeonites entrust themselves to Israel (9:25), or even to Israel's leader, Joshua.

<span id="page-410-3"></span>What does it matter that Gibeon's approach is less in recognition of who Israel's God is and more about self-preservation? Could it meet with the kind of divine favor that Rahab's alliance with Israel clearly did? There are connections here with the next question, regarding the status of the covenant itself. Provisionally, however, it appears that even self-interest arising from craven fear in combination with a lack of understanding of the character of Israel's God can lead in a good direction. It will shortly transpire that God appears to be so gracious that even base, self-interested fear, if it drives us to him, can be a foundation for a meaningful relationship with him.

#### HOW OUGHT WE REGARD THE GIBEONITE COVENANT?

The Gibeonites declare fear for their lives to be their starting point for seeking a covenant with Israel. In contrast to the common responses of fight, flight, or freeze—fight being the response of their Canaanite neighbors—the Gibeonites' avoidant action involves fraud. Their means of reducing fear is not to attempt battle and military conquest, subjecting Israel to them or destroying Israel and eradicating the source of danger, as is mostly the case (5:1; 9:1–2; 10:1–5; 11:1–5). Rather, they subject themselves to Israel, on whatever terms Israel will give (9:25). What they desire, though, is a "covenant," and that is what they get, even if on unattractive terms by the end of the chapter.

<span id="page-410-1"></span><span id="page-410-0"></span>How is this "covenant" to be evaluated? The case of Rahab creates a precedent, although the Gibeonite case is more complex than hers. Likewise, we have noted that some "sojourners" (or "aliens"; Hb. *gerim*) are included in Israel's covenant community (8:33, 35), and this too suggests a place for incorporating nonnatives into the covenant community. But the case of Gibeon itself requires taking a wider, although still selective, view of their place in biblical history. The following factors are relevant:

(1) The very next chapter of Joshua will demonstrate that the Gibeonite assumption—that Israel would respect any covenant forged between themis correct. The next phase of Israel's action in taking the Promised Land has as its foundation the very covenant with Gibeon, put into effect here under such apparently dubious circumstances.

<span id="page-411-2"></span>(2) During Saul's reign he apparently slaughtered Gibeonites, and this transgression of the covenant demanded the destruction of Saul's remaining offspring (Mephibosheth excepted) during the reign of David (2 Sam. 21:1–14). Saul's action is not recorded in the OT, but it has often been associated with the killing of the priests at Nob, for whom the Gibeonites were servants (1 Samuel 21–22).83 The Gibeonite covenant remained in force in David's day and demanded justice.

<span id="page-411-4"></span><span id="page-411-1"></span>(3) Gibeon was the scene of Solomon's dream in which the Lord gifted him with wisdom (1 Kings 3:4–15). The Chronicler (1 Chron. 16:39; 21:29) provides the additional information that the high place of Gibeon, said to be a favorite for sacrifice in 1 Kings 3:4, was also the home for the tabernacle, or at least a "tent sanctuary," providing it some status.84

<span id="page-411-3"></span>On balance, then, although there might be lingering qualms about the origins of the Gibeonite covenant, and a failure of vigilance on the part of Israel and (particularly) its leaders can be discerned from their making it, nonetheless this covenant became the basis for their continued existence among the people of God.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-411-0"></span>Jerome Creach asks the pertinent question of this passage: "To whom is Joshua 9 good news?"85 It is good news, first of all, to those who, like the Gibeonites, believe they face destruction from this God of Israel. Although the approach the Gibeonites initiate is flawed, the outcome is clear: they live. And not only that, for they will go on to receive both protection and justice within the covenant community and from their covenant God. There is a contrast here with Rahab. She harbored Israel's spies, at least; the only thing Gibeon did for Israel was to feed them stale bread—and this only to promote their deception! Like Rahab, however, even if on a basis less "deserving," the Gibeonites realized they did not need to be destroyed but could in fact find hope and a future in submitting to the God of Israel.

<span id="page-411-6"></span><span id="page-411-5"></span>Joshua 9 is also good news to those who, like the Israelites, believe that God's preferred option is destruction. And yet, on certain terms this God is willing for his word to "come false" rather than true. Both the OT (Ezek. 18:23, 32; 33:11) and the NT (2 Pet. 3:9) assure us that the Lord does not wish that "any should perish, but that all should reach repentance." The much later example of God's reaction to Ninevite repentance in the book of Jonah is one of the clearest examples of this lavish grace of the God of Israel.

There is also good news here for those whose reliance on this God has wavered and who have lived without reference to their sovereign Lord. Joshua 9 does not

<sup>84</sup> Cf. H. G. M. Williamson, *1 and 2 Chronicles*, NCBC (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 1982), 130–132.

<sup>85</sup> Creach, *Joshua*, 88.

give blithe permission to ignore seeking the will of God, nor does it justify being a muddled believer. But it does testify again to the truth that human failure cannot thwart God's good designs.

### <span id="page-412-0"></span>JOSHUA 10:1–28

10 As soon as Adoni-zedek, king of Jerusalem, heard how Joshua had captured Ai and had devoted it to destruction,*<sup>1</sup>* doing to Ai and its king as he had done to Jericho and its king, and how the inhabitants of Gibeon had made peace with Israel and were among them, **2**he*<sup>2</sup>* feared greatly, because Gibeon was a great city, like one of the royal cities, and because it was greater than Ai, and all its men were warriors. **<sup>3</sup>** So Adonizedek king of Jerusalem sent to Hoham king of Hebron, to Piram king of Jarmuth, to Japhia king of Lachish, and to Debir king of Eglon, saying, **<sup>4</sup>** "Come up to me and help me, and let us strike Gibeon. For it has made peace with Joshua and with the people of Israel." **5**Then the five kings of the Amorites, the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon, gathered their forces and went up with all their armies and encamped against Gibeon and made war against it.

**<sup>6</sup>**And the men of Gibeon sent to Joshua at the camp in Gilgal, saying, "Do not relax your hand from your servants. Come up to us quickly and save us and help us, for all the kings of the Amorites who dwell in the hill country are gathered against us." **<sup>7</sup>** So Joshua went up from Gilgal, he and all the people of war with him, and all the mighty men of valor. **8**And the Lord said to Joshua, "Do not fear them, for I have given them into your hands. Not a man of them shall stand before you." **<sup>9</sup>** So Joshua came upon them suddenly, having marched up all night from Gilgal. **10**And the Lord threw them into a panic before Israel, who*<sup>3</sup>* struck them with a great blow at Gibeon and chased them by the way of the ascent of Beth-horon and struck them as far as Azekah and Makkedah. **11**And as they fled before Israel, while they were going down the ascent of Beth-horon, the Lord threw down large stones from heaven on them as far as Azekah, and they died. There were more who died because of the hailstones than the sons of Israel killed with the sword.

**<sup>12</sup>**At that time Joshua spoke to the Lord in the day when the Lord gave the Amorites over to the sons of Israel, and he said in the sight of Israel,

"Sun, stand still at Gibeon,

and moon, in the Valley of Aijalon."

**<sup>13</sup>** And the sun stood still, and the moon stopped,

until the nation took vengeance on their enemies.

Is this not written in the Book of Jashar? The sun stopped in the midst of heaven and did not hurry to set for about a whole day. **14**There has been

no day like it before or since, when the Lord heeded the voice of a man, for the Lord fought for Israel.

**<sup>15</sup>** So Joshua returned, and all Israel with him, to the camp at Gilgal.

**<sup>16</sup>**These five kings fled and hid themselves in the cave at Makkedah. **<sup>17</sup>**And it was told to Joshua, "The five kings have been found, hidden in the cave at Makkedah." **18**And Joshua said, "Roll large stones against the mouth of the cave and set men by it to guard them, **19**but do not stay there yourselves. Pursue your enemies; attack their rear guard. Do not let them enter their cities, for the Lord your God has given them into your hand." **20**When Joshua and the sons of Israel had finished striking them with a great blow until they were wiped out, and when the remnant that remained of them had entered into the fortified cities, **<sup>21</sup>** then all the people returned safe to Joshua in the camp at Makkedah. Not a man moved his tongue against any of the people of Israel.

**<sup>22</sup>**Then Joshua said, "Open the mouth of the cave and bring those five kings out to me from the cave." **23**And they did so, and brought those five kings out to him from the cave, the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon. **24**And when they brought those kings out to Joshua, Joshua summoned all the men of Israel and said to the chiefs of the men of war who had gone with him, "Come near; put your feet on the necks of these kings." Then they came near and put their feet on their necks. **25**And Joshua said to them, "Do not be afraid or dismayed; be strong and courageous. For thus the Lord will do to all your enemies against whom you fight." **26**And afterward Joshua struck them and put them to death, and he hanged them on five trees. And they hung on the trees until evening. **27**But at the time of the going down of the sun, Joshua commanded, and they took them down from the trees and threw them into the cave where they had hidden themselves, and they set large stones against the mouth of the cave, which remain to this very day.

**<sup>28</sup>**As for Makkedah, Joshua captured it on that day and struck it, and its king, with the edge of the sword. He devoted to destruction every person in it; he left none remaining. And he did to the king of Makkedah just as he had done to the king of Jericho.

1That is, set apart (devoted) as an offering to the Lord (for destruction); also verses 28, 35, 37, 39, 40 2One Hebrew manuscript, Vulgate (compare Syriac); most Hebrew manuscripts *they* 3Or *and he*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-413-1"></span><span id="page-413-0"></span>Whatever conclusions we might draw concerning the covenant made with the Gibeonites, one thing remains clear: it is this event that finally plunges Israel into the sequence of battles in which they will claim God's gift of the Promised Land. Up to this point they have made a set of small steps probing its central region, still quite near their base of Gilgal, between Jericho and the River Jordan. But the Gibeonite covenant triggers a coalition of five kings in the central-southern region to make war against Israel. The result of this campaign will be a further push into the cities deeper to the south and west (10:29–43), and success in those battles sparks a similar coalition of kings in the cities in the north (11:1–5). Israel's campaign passes its early, hesitant phase and finally gathers momentum, and the

<span id="page-414-8"></span>covenant with Gibeon is the fulcrum. We find a similar dynamic in the spreading of the early church recounted in Acts. The apostles lingered for some time in the environs of Jerusalem before a "great persecution" arose in the wake of Stephen's execution that "scattered" the Christians (Acts 8:1–4), so that Jesus' commission was finally being fulfilled to be his witnesses not only "in Jerusalem" but also "in all Judea and Samaria, and to the end of the earth" (Acts 1:8).

<span id="page-414-7"></span><span id="page-414-2"></span><span id="page-414-1"></span>The central campaign comprises two distinct stages. The first part has as its focal point the action against Gibeon (Josh. 10:1–15). Once the coalition formed at the initiative of the king of Jerusalem takes action (vv. 1–5), the Gibeonites respond with a plea to their covenant partners to come to their aid. Israel then acts on behalf of Gibeon, delivering the city from its enemies and securing its environs. The narrator shapes Israel's own actions as moving from and returning to Gilgal (vv. 6–15). This battle includes one of the most dramatic and mysterious of God's interventions on behalf of Israel, as at one point "the sun stopped in the midst of heaven" (v. 13).

<span id="page-414-5"></span><span id="page-414-4"></span><span id="page-414-3"></span>During the rout of Gibeon's enemies, however, the coalition kings flee. The account of their pursuit and execution is narrated in the second stage of this passage, still as a consequence of involvement with Gibeon (vv. 16–28). These were the kings responsible for making war on Israel; like other hostile kings that both precede and follow them, they learn the truth of Psalm 2 in their own fates.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-414-0"></span>10:1–5 Gibeon is not the only neighbor to react to the destruction of Ai. But the peace with Gibeon makes an even greater impact on Adoni-zedek, king of Jerusalem. Both his name and his city deserve notice. As for the city, this is the first mention of Jerusalem in the Bible. It is striking that the city that will be the place at which the Lord will choose "put his name and make his habitation" (Deut. 12:5) is, at the moment of its first appearance in the biblical story, hostile to the invading Israelites and their God. The place will be transformed as well as its people. The king's name, meaning "the Lord of righteousness" or "my Lord is righteous,"

<span id="page-415-13"></span>is very close to the name of the first king engaged in battle by Israel in the book of Judges, Adoni-bezek, who is also associated with Jerusalem (Judg. 1:5–7).

<span id="page-415-6"></span><span id="page-415-5"></span>Gibeon's initiative in seeking peace with Israel confronts Adoni-zedek with a dilemma. The defeat of Jericho and Ai would be cause enough for alarm. But, as Joshua 10:2 clarifies, the status and prowess of Gibeon were on a different scale than Ai's—and yet they sought terms from Israel rather than confronting them in battle. It is this, rather than the military conquests, that makes Adoni-zedek "fear greatly." What is he to do? Rather than capitulate, he outnumbers the Gibeonite tetrapolis (cf. 9:17) and gathers a coalition of five cities: Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon. They fan out to the southwest of Jerusalem,86 thus placing themselves even farther from Gibeon, which lies just less than 6 miles (9.7 km) to the north of Jerusalem. It is telling that the circumstance he announces in his summons to the four kings is that Gibeon has "made peace" and is the target of their aggression, rather than pointing to the defeat of Ai or Jericho and coming against Joshua and Israel. The coalition is formed and lays siege to Gibeon, chief city of the tetrapolis.

<span id="page-415-7"></span><span id="page-415-4"></span><span id="page-415-2"></span><span id="page-415-1"></span>10:6–8 The summons issued by Adoni-zedek in verses 3–4 finds a close counterpart in the Gibeonite response of verse 6. As the king of Jerusalem "sent" to his allies (v. 3), so too do the Gibeonites to theirs. The terms of their requests are shifted: whereas Adoni-zedek's plea is to "come up . . . help . . . and let us strike" (v. 4), the Gibeonite request to Joshua is for Israel to "come up to us quickly and save us and help us." The demands of the covenant agreement mean not only Israel's preservation of Gibeon but also the latter's salvation.

<span id="page-415-11"></span><span id="page-415-9"></span><span id="page-415-8"></span><span id="page-415-3"></span>Joshua's response is immediate, marching the army of Israel to Gibeon (v. 7). Given the preceding history, one might wonder whether some attempt to seek God's guidance would have been prudent; the absence of such an inclination has proved damaging to Israel's standing before the Lord previously. However, the reassurance comes in verse 8, in forthright terms. The formula "Not a man of them shall stand . . ." is a distinctive divine assurance in the book of Joshua, occurring again at 21:44 as confirmation of the fulfillment of God's promises to Israel and at 23:9 as Joshua himself reflects on God's faithfulness.87 On this occasion, then, Joshua has discerned rightly: fidelity to the covenant with Gibeon requires this response on Israel's part. God's reassurance of victory, however, is not so much corroboration of good judgment as confirmation that Israel's progress into the Promised Land is to move forward.

<span id="page-415-12"></span><span id="page-415-10"></span>10:9–11 Israel's rapid mobilization takes place at night. Its remarkable nocturnal march from Gilgal provides an element of surprise as it encounters the coalition forces the next morning at Gibeon. Israel does not act alone, however. Just as Joshua's initiative of verse 7 meets with divine partnership in verse 8, so again

<span id="page-415-14"></span><span id="page-415-0"></span><sup>86</sup> Of these four Jarmuth is closest to Jerusalem, roughly 16 miles (26 km) west-southwest, while Lachish and Eglon—if correctly identified with Tel ʾEton—are farthest, about 26 miles (43 km) southwest of Jerusalem. 87 These are the only three uses of this formula as a promise; variations are also found in Deuteronomy 7:24 and Esther 9:2, the only other occurrences in the Hebrew Bible.

<span id="page-416-3"></span>the Israelite action of verse 9 as they engage in combat with the enemies of the Gibeonites—now also their enemies—is matched by the intervention of the divine warrior, who makes here the first of three actions on Israel's behalf in this battle. The Lord brings panic into the ranks of the coalition at the same time Israel "struck them with a great blow" (v. 10). The very thing that Adoni-zedek sought to inflict on Gibeon with the help of his allies (v. 4) Israel inflicts on the coalition as they come to the aid of their covenant partner.

<span id="page-416-5"></span><span id="page-416-4"></span><span id="page-416-2"></span><span id="page-416-1"></span><span id="page-416-0"></span>The coalition warriors flee, with Israel in pursuit (vv. 10–11). Their route takes them to the north of the Gibeonite tetrapolis before veering south in the general direction of Jarmuth. And just as at the battle's inception, so again during the flight and pursuit are the actions of Israel supported by the intervention of the divine warrior. While Israelite swords work, so too does divine hail, first described as "large stones." Hail (Hb. *barad*) stirs memory of the seventh plague God brought against Egypt (Ex. 9:13–35); both the hail in Egypt and the hail in this battle are destructive (cf. Ex. 9:19, 25) and selective (Ex. 9:26), striking down the Egyptians and Canaanites but in neither case touching the Israelites. More widely, hail is very much part of the divine arsenal, celebrated as such in Psalm 18:13–14, announced as such in the theophany of Job 38:22–23, and wielded by the Lord also against Assyria in Isaiah 30:30–31. While the origins of the panicked confusion the Lord threw on the fleeing coalition might have been difficult to discern, the torrent of destructive hail is much more clearly the action of the divine warrior.

<span id="page-416-11"></span><span id="page-416-10"></span><span id="page-416-9"></span><span id="page-416-8"></span><span id="page-416-7"></span><span id="page-416-6"></span>10:12–14 The third of the Lord's interventions in this battle is by far the most dramatic, and the most famous. We have seen at least one celestial phenomenon of note in this episode, the cataclysmic fall of hail; there might have been another, if the light of the moon assisted Israel's nighttime march from Gilgal to Gibeon. The climax of dramatic celestial signs comes in these verses, as the "sun stood still, and the moon stopped" (Josh. 10:13) in response to Joshua's cry (v. 12). The preservation of the prayer and reply in poetry, along with the reference to the "Book of Jashar" (known otherwise only from a similar remark introducing David's lament over Saul and Jonathan; 2 Sam. 1:18), further evokes a sense of mystery that is already roused by the astonishing and awesome event itself. Attempts to provide some explanation for the miracle either look to natural phenomena that might explain the account, such as an eclipse, or appeal to parallels from ancient Near Eastern literature that provide the event some religious or cultural context.88 All such explanations evacuate the event of its primary meaning. Calvin remarked that "the question of how the sun stood still in Gibeon is no less unseasonably raised by some than unskillfully explained by others." The editor of the nineteenth-century English edition of Calvin astutely remarks, "The rebuke here administered to those who attempt to explain the miracle applies with double force to those who attempt to explain it away."89 The fundamental point to be

<sup>88</sup> For a useful overview and evaluation cf. Hess, *Joshua*, 215–218; Pekka M. A. Pitkänen, *Joshua*, ApOTC 6 (IVP Academic, 2010), 224. Cf. also McConville and Williams, *Joshua*, 154–170. 89 Calvin, *Book of Joshua*, 153.

made to any who seeks to rationalize the miracle is that, in any case, explanation of mechanism is not the same as explanation of meaning. For example, explaining the biological processes involved in a mother's giving birth does not explain the meaning of a human life.

<span id="page-417-9"></span><span id="page-417-3"></span>The point concerning Gibeon is made with some force by the narrator in Joshua 10:14 regarding the incomparability of this day: "for the Lord fought for Israel." More helpful, then, is the parallel in the prayer of Habakkuk 3:11, which describes how "the sun and moon stood still in their place at the light of your arrows as they sped." There, like here, the heavenly bodies are subject to the one who made them; God's own "weapons" take precedence.90 It has further been observed that this intervention by God—indeed, all three of them (the confusion, the hail, and the longest day)—were not strictly required in military terms. Israel's army is well on its way to victory.91 The narrator's brief but pointed summary, repeated again at Joshua 10:42, when all the events set in train by the Gibeonite covenant have been concluded, remains the essential one: the Lord fights for Israel.

<span id="page-417-8"></span><span id="page-417-4"></span>10:15 Gilgal remains Israel's base of operations, in spite of the distant pursuit of the Jerusalem coalition. Although Gibeon has been secured, their enemies remain at large. For the moment, however, Israel rests. This may seem an unusual pause. As action resumes in the succeeding verses, Israel is back in the environs north of Jarmuth, where the dramatic events in the valley of Aijalon took place. Whether we are dealing with a narrative like that of chapters 3–4, which does not unfold in strict chronological order, or whether this conveys the movements of Israel in the campaign, is difficult to determine.

<span id="page-417-6"></span><span id="page-417-5"></span><span id="page-417-0"></span>10:16–21 Attention reverts to the five kings of the coalition who seek to evade capture by hiding themselves in "the cave at Makkedah." It may be that this is a known site ("*the* cave"), as the question arises why the kings should shelter here rather than in their own fortified cities. The simplest explanation is that they are on the run from Israel; as verse 19 suggests, the battle persists in the field. Joshua's strategy is to deal with the enemy while it is exposed and not protected by its fortifications, much as he learned to do in the successful battle against Ai (ch. 8). Makkedah is about halfway between Lachish and Hebron, just north of Eglon (if it is to be identified with Tel ʾEton).

<span id="page-417-7"></span><span id="page-417-2"></span><span id="page-417-1"></span>Before attending to the kings, however, Israel must bring its action against the coalition armies to a conclusion (10:20). The Hebrew is curiously emphatic in describing the finality of Israel's defeat of the coalition. The "great blow" (cf. v. 10) Israel inflicts is framed by two terms conveying completion and finishing, the latter in a phrase that often implies something done to death (Hb. *ʿad-tumam*). But it is curious in the sense that some refugees manage to escape back to their fortified cities. That some element of life is left is clear also from the later story

<sup>90</sup> Cf. Creach, *Joshua*, 92.

<sup>91</sup> Levin, "Wars of Joshua," 41.

<span id="page-418-6"></span><span id="page-418-5"></span>of Caleb, which involves taking the city of Hebron (14:13–15; cf. also Debir, 10:38–39; 15:15).

<span id="page-418-1"></span><span id="page-418-0"></span>Earlier in the Joshua narrative, especially around the crossing of the Jordan, we saw numerous parallels that aligned the entry of Israel into the Promised Land with the departure of the exodus generation from Egypt under Moses. One of the last of these in Joshua is encountered here in the defeat of the Jerusalem coalition. As the defeat of their armies is completed, the narrator records: "Not a man moved his tongue against any of the people of Israel" (Josh. 10:21). This is an evocative description of the regard in which the populace holds Israel. More than that, the Hebrew idiom "cut [the] tongue" (*harats* + *lashon*) means "snarl" (cf. NJPS). It occurs only one other time in the Hebrew Bible. In Exodus 11:7 Moses is instructing the people concerning the final plague of death to the firstborn of Egypt and the lamentation it will arouse: "Not a dog shall growl against any of the people of Israel, either man or beast, that you may know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel." So here in Joshua, not a man "growls" against Israel. The lesson that Moses applied in Egypt should also be understood here in the conquest context. The Lord is making a distinction between the Amorite kings, and their armies, and Israel. The scenes about to unfold are among the bloodiest of the book. And yet, as this distinction is drawn, the fact that this engagement has been provoked by the coalition on account of Gibeon's peace with Israel implies that it need not have been so.

<span id="page-418-3"></span><span id="page-418-2"></span>10:22–27 As the fate of the kings draws near, again they are patiently enumerated. A somewhat strange ceremony now unfolds, as Joshua instructs the "chiefs of the men of war" (Josh. 10:24) to place their feet on the necks of the five kings. This sort of ritual humiliation finds parallels in the ancient Near East. Of several examples of victorious kings' treading down their vanquished foes, perhaps the closest parallel to this moment is found in an inscription of Tukulti-Ninurta I (c. 1244–1208), who declared regarding Kashtiliash IV (c. 1242–1235) of Babylon: "I placed my feet upon his lordly neck as a footstool."92 God is speaking to and through Joshua and to the Israelites in a language that Bronze Age people would understand.

<span id="page-418-7"></span><span id="page-418-4"></span>In these circumstances Joshua's further encouragement to his chiefs to "not be afraid or dismayed; be strong and courageous" (v. 25) may seem obvious enough. Although the positive and negative pairs of these verbs appear often enough, only in Chronicles is the combination of all four found again. On two occasions these are the terms in which David encourages Solomon to be faithful in constructing the temple and arranging its worship (1 Chron. 22:13; 28:20). Likewise, Hezekiah rallies the people of Jerusalem as preparations are made to face the Assyrians by declaring, "There are more with us than with him. With him is an arm of flesh, but with us is the Lord our God, to help us and to fight our battles" (2 Chron. 32:7–8). There is an element here of summons to simple, physical courage in the face of temptation to be cowed or craven. But more than that, and perhaps predominantly,

<span id="page-418-10"></span><span id="page-418-9"></span><span id="page-418-8"></span><sup>92</sup> F.J. Stendebach, "לֶג ֶר, "*TDOT*, 13:312. Further symbolic parallels are found in David's enemies' falling under his feet (Ps. 18:38) and in Psalm 110:1, "The Lord says to my Lord: 'Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies your footstool'" (quoted by Jesus, Matt. 22:44ff.; cf. Heb. 1:13).

is a further spiritual dimension to be obedient to the claims of service owed to the sovereign Lord, who fights with and for his people.

<span id="page-419-6"></span><span id="page-419-2"></span>The execution of the five kings, their exposure, and the final disposition of the corpses follows the pattern of the treatment of the king of Ai (Josh. 10:26–27; cf. 8:29), and, as on that occasion, the strictures of Deuteronomy 21:22–23 are followed. The close alignment of this sequence with the Deuteronomic law implies the fulfillment of the conditions for that law to be enacted—a sin ("crime") "punishable by death" (Deut. 21:22)—and further brings a recognition of the judgment of that sin on the victim: "for a hanged man is cursed by God" (Deut. 21:23; cf. Num. 25:4). As in the other cases of stone memorials in Joshua, the site serves to maintain the community's memory.

<span id="page-419-7"></span><span id="page-419-5"></span><span id="page-419-3"></span><span id="page-419-1"></span><span id="page-419-0"></span>10:28 The city of Makkedah brackets this subsection, which began at Joshua 10:16. Its king is likewise executed and the city subject to *kherem*, with Jericho cited as the precedent. Although *kherem* has not been prominent in the immediately preceding chapters, it now returns to the forefront of the narrator's account. As such, this verse also serves as a transition to the sequence that follows in verses 29–39 (cf. comment there), each successive conquest resonating with this account of Makkedah.

#### <span id="page-419-8"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-419-4"></span>This episode is deliberately framed in terms of the activities and fate of the "five kings" of the coalition who come together at the behest of the king of Jerusalem (10:5, 16, 26). Although the first inclination of Christian readers to passages such as this one (and those that follow) is to ask who is on the Lord's side, the frame of the story puts the opposite question with urgency: what of those opposed to the Lord's side? As the writer to the Hebrews states, "It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God" (Heb. 10:31). As noted above, strong parallels are evident between the fate of these five kings and the king of Ai. Like him, their primary opponent is the God of heaven and earth, the God of Israel—not Joshua, not Israel, and certainly not Gibeon in the case of this coalition.

<span id="page-419-10"></span><span id="page-419-9"></span>Within that frame the narrative brings two kinds of fighting to the fore. In the first phase God fights for Israel—as well as for Gibeon. Whatever qualms we might have about the way in which the Gibeonites entered into a covenant with Israel, God at any rate regards it as a genuine relationship. There is such a thing as failing to enter by the "Wicket Gate," in terms of Bunyan's *Pilgrim's Progress* (cf. Matt. 7:13–14), but perhaps entry through that gate can take place in what we might think are unusual ways. And so three times the divine warrior fights with his people against his enemy and, in the case of the hail, accounts for greater enemy losses. The Westminster Shorter Catechism speaks to this situation.

Question 26. How doth Christ execute the office of a king? Answer: Christ executeth the office of a king, in subduing us to himself, in ruling and defending us, and in restraining and conquering all his and our enemies.

<span id="page-420-1"></span><span id="page-420-0"></span>In the second phase Israel fights for God. The kind prominence of divine action seen in Joshua 10:6–14 does not continue as the rest of the battle unfolds. Yet God is not therefore absent. Rather, Joshua understands the meaning of God's plain words (v. 8) as demonstrated in those three interventions. This becomes the basis for his urging Israel to complete the battle (v. 19). Israel is growing in its understanding of obedience and of the nature of the sovereignty of the God its serve.

<span id="page-420-4"></span><span id="page-420-2"></span>Christian readers may well discern a trajectory to a very different king in Jerusalem, who would bear divine wrath rather than provoke it and be exposed on a stake, entombed in a cave, and barricaded behind a stone—but neither stone nor death could hold that king, whom God highly exalted and on whom he bestowed the name at which every knee should bow (cf. Phil. 2:8–10).

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-421-1"></span>The summary of the defeat of Makkedah in Joshua 10:28 sets the tone for a campaign onward in the southern region. While the armies of the Jerusalem coalition were defeated in the field, the fortified cities still have not been conquered, and three of those cities form part of the ensuing campaign; Jarmuth and Jerusalem itself do not feature in this list, while Libnah and Debir are included. A strong shared pattern is seen among the accounts of the defeat of the five cities (six, if one counts Gezer, which joins in of its own accord; v. 33) against which Joshua leads Israel. The shared elements do not appear in each of the five segments, but patterns emerge. Rather than dealing with each city in turn, then, the comments below tease out the patterns and draw attention to the salient features for interpretation.

#### <span id="page-421-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- I.M. The Southern Campaign (10:29–43)
	- 1. Libnah (10:29–30)
	- 2. Lachish with Gezer (10:31–33)
	- 3. Eglon (10:34–35)
	- 4. Hebron (10:36–37)
	- 5. Debir (10:38–39)
	- 6. Southern Summary (10:40–43)

The regularity of the contents can also be expressed in tabular form (table 2.3), here including Makkedah from the previous section (v. 28).93 The rows represent each of the cities conquered; the numerical sequence in the row is the order in which the various elements are found for that city. It can immediately be seen how much Makkedah participates in this scheme, even while it is related back to verse 16. No two cities share the same pattern, although Hebron and Debir come closest to each other.

#### <span id="page-421-0"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-421-2"></span>10:29–39 The southern campaign takes place as a consequence of the battle in defense of Gibeon and the subsequent pursuit of the coalition army toward its regional heartland. Libnah is only about 8 miles (12.9 km) north-northwest of Makkedah; Lachish is only 6 miles (9.7 km) south-southeast of Libnah. This is the

<span id="page-422-2"></span>point at which the force from Gezer joins the fray. It is difficult to know why, as the report (v. 33) is very sparse. Gezer is over 20 miles (32 km) to the north of Lachish. Eglon, Hebron, and Debir are all farther to the east and south.

Clearly much is shared between the five (six, if Makkedah is included) reports of city destruction, although no one report includes all the elements shared between them. Of the thirteen features, six are common to each report: (1) the formulaic that "Joshua and all Israel with him passed on from . . . ," which sets the trajectory to the next city; (2) "fought against" (Makkedah is not part of this sequence); (3) the two place names (PN) as links in the chain, except Makkedah and Debir (first and last), where the name of that city alone appears; (4) that they were "struck . . . with the . . . sword"; (5) that this fate came to "every person in it"; and (6) a back reference to previous action in the phrase "as he had done . . ." A seventh feature, the notice that "he left none remaining," is missing only from the Eglon report. In spite of the irregularities, a significant amount of overlap remains.

<span id="page-422-4"></span><span id="page-422-3"></span><span id="page-422-1"></span>One of the striking aspects of these connected accounts is the way in which insistent and inclusive language of total extermination only partially intersects with the language of *kherem*. The immediate import of this is not to distinguish Libnah and Lachish as in some way not being subject to *kherem* but rather to observe that in each case the total annihilation called for in Deuteronomy 7 has been inflicted by Israel under Joshua's leadership. From the perspective of Deuteronomy, this bespeaks the obedience of Israel to the terms in which God set out for their inheritance of the Promised Land. Subtler is the observation that a number of these cities will be encountered again in the next part of the book or in Judges. The observation has been made that "the Joshua narrative elsewhere describes how there were quite a few local inhabitants left; see e.g. 11:22; 13:1–7; 15:63."94 While registering this datum does not soften the rhetoric of destruction in this passage, it nonetheless alerts modern readers to the presence of some hyperbole in the account.

<span id="page-423-2"></span>Certain of the infrequent features remain noteworthy. Of only two cities, Libnah and Lachish, do we read that "the Lord gave it . . . into the hand of Israel" (Josh. 10:30, 32). Since the overarching theological import of the narrative is that "the Lord fought for Israel" (vv. 14, 42), perhaps persistent reiteration is unneeded in the individual reports of the cities conquered—but this only makes the cases of Libnah and Lachish a little more odd: why *these* two? We cannot say with certainty. It is noteworthy, though, that this mention comes in the first two cities beyond Makkedah. If it is right to discern the gradual withdrawal of the Lord from overt involvement in battle, then the training has its intended effect, as the remaining cities are likewise captured by Israel. Another feature occurs only twice: a "siege" is employed in the warfare against the cities of Lachish and Eglon. The impression left by the sequence of reports is of a very rapid conquest, carrying on the momentum of the preceding section's narrative of the pursuit of the coalition army. Pausing for siege warfare would seem like an impediment to the flow, except for the notices in only these two cases of how long the engagement lasts: Lachish is captured on day two of the siege (v. 32) and Eglon apparently on the first day (v. 35). These are very short sieges!

<span id="page-423-4"></span><span id="page-423-3"></span>The oddity of Gezer's involvement (v. 33) was noted above. It is also significant that the city itself is not here engaged or overthrown. It was well outside the line of march of the Israelite army, at least at this time. Although Gezer is located in the northern Shephelah, and thus part of what might be thought of as the territory of Judah, it persists under Canaanite control (cf. Judg. 1:29) at least until the time of Solomon (1 Kings 9:16).

<span id="page-423-9"></span><span id="page-423-8"></span><span id="page-423-7"></span><span id="page-423-6"></span><span id="page-423-5"></span>10:40–43 The final summary emphasizes the rapid success of Israel under Joshua (Josh 10:42) and sketches the boundaries of the territory represented by these conquests: basically, from the line of Gibeon south to northern reaches of the Sinai (Kadesh-barnea) and east-west from the coastal plain to Israel's base at Gilgal. This is an extensive region, suggesting much greater reach than would be accounted for by the conquered cities and their hinterland alone. Beside this geographical attention, we also find a theological assessment. The conjunction of the application of *kherem* and obedience to the word of the Lord is now made explicit (v. 40). Israel's obedience meets with covenant blessing (cf. Lev. 26:7–8), as the notice first encountered at Joshua 10:14, ("the Lord fought for Israel") is again repeated (v. 42). Even if the Lord is receding from prominence in terms of narrative attention, it is clear that the actions of Israel undertaken obediently find a counterpart in the empowering action of the divine warrior.

#### <span id="page-423-1"></span><span id="page-423-0"></span>*Response*

The elements recurring through this conquest account bring into the foreground the essential features for Israel's actions, the Canaanite destruction, and God's <span id="page-424-1"></span>intentions. For Joshua and Israel the emphasis falls on their obedience and its consistency. The lessons of chapter 7 have been learned; this is a people who now fights fittingly. This must account for the repetition of the inclusive elements throughout the accounts ("every person," "left none remaining"); not only is the destruction total but so too is Israel's obedience in carrying out God's commands. The consistency is seen in the "just as" statements that typically refer back to the preceding site, so that the individual accounts are framed with a backward glance (the "went up from" element with toponyms) and a present update. Each of these cities, joined in opposition to Israel and Israel's God, suffers the same fate.

<span id="page-424-4"></span>The use of *kherem* reaches something of a crescendo in this passage. There are five occurrences in the space of these verses; the only other passage in Joshua that rivals this density is the Achan episode of chapter 7, where it is not application of the *kherem* that is in view but Israel's failure to observe the demands of *kherem*, leading to its moment of military collapse. Now, in the southern campaign, *kherem* is consistently observed. Perhaps this represents Israel's carrying out in conquest something God himself performed in exodus, with the final plague bringing death to those Egyptians hardened against the purposes of God. (This will be signaled more clearly in Josh. 11:20; cf. comment on 11:16–20) This does not set a precedent, and certainly not a pattern, for the actions of God's people in time to come: *kherem* will fade away. It persists briefly into Judges, but such is the decline of God's people that by Judges 21:11 it comes tragically to be applied internally in Israel. It is last employed in the destruction of the Amalekites under Saul, in the transition to rule by kings (1 Samuel 15). Here in Joshua *kherem* is carried out against those cities that have chosen to oppose the purpose of God through an attack on those most recently brought into covenant relationship with him: the Gibeonites.

<span id="page-424-6"></span><span id="page-424-5"></span><span id="page-424-2"></span>Another prominent aspect of these accounts (omitted from Lachish and Eglon) is the attention given to kings, with reference back twice to the king of Jericho as the series begins. Is it merely a coincidence that the one great city said not to be "royal," Gibeon (Josh. 10:2), is the one to seek peace with Joshua? The suggestion has been made that, as Rahab finds a counterpart in Achan, so too the Gibeonites find their counterparts in these kings opposed to the rule of Israel's God.95 The contrast here is not between outsider-turned-insider and insider-turned-outsider but rather between nonroyals who (rightly) seek servitude and royals who (wrongly) assert sovereignty. The evident pride of kings seems to escalate when the greatest of the royal cities to the north reacts to these events in chapter 11. As biblical royal theology asserts, kings rule well only when their rule is subject to the King of kings (Deut. 17:18–20; 1 Sam. 12:13–15; Ps. 72:1–4) and when they reflect his kingship faithfully (cf. Isa. 33:22; Jer. 23:5–6). Ultimately the tension between the royal pretensions of kings of the earth and the royal rule of God will be resolved only when he himself takes on human flesh and is exalted to the heavenly throne (Ezek. 34:14, 24; cf. Rev. 7:15–17).

1That is, setting apart (devoting) as an offering to the Lord (for destruction); also verses 12, 20, 21

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-426-3"></span><span id="page-426-2"></span><span id="page-426-1"></span><span id="page-426-0"></span>The broad resonances of the account of the northern campaign with the southern are readily apparent. A coalition is formed at the behest of the king of the leading city in the region, whose armies march out as aggressors against Israel (11:1–5). Battle is joined in the field, and with divine reassurance and assistance Joshua and the army of Israel rout the enemy (vv. 6–9). With the defeat of the armies, the cities of the coalition themselves are defeated by Israel (vv. 10–15). All of this in broad outline echoes what has taken place in the south, recounted in chapter 10. Here the account includes some narrative features that give this episode the feeling of a climax; even so, it is much more compact than chapter 10. The exact makeup of the coalition is vaguer than the one formed by the king of Jerusalem. The various battles are still situated in the landscape, as in the account of the southern campaign, but with less detail and precision. Both accounts make theological observation, but this takes on greater prominence in the northern campaign.

<span id="page-426-4"></span>The work of the narrator is cumulative, as the summary now attached to the northern campaign (11:16–20) looks back also to the southern and central regions in giving an overview of all the territory taken since the first encounter with Jericho. The practice of combining geographical and theological overview seen in earlier summaries is found again here. This is itself a further signal of the deep interconnection between God, place, and people in biblical theology.

<span id="page-426-5"></span>The brief notice of the encounter with and destruction of the Anakim is somewhat enigmatic (vv. 21–22). Outside the territorial operations of Israel, yet integrated by the narrator as a last gasp of this opening phase of the book, the Anakim represent a foe of a different kind than the cities of Canaan who have come together to fight Israel.
