- I.N. The Northern Campaign (11:1–15)
	- 1. Northern Coalition Formed (11:1–5)
	- 2. Battle of the Waters of Merom (11:6–9)
	- 3. Hazor and Its Allies Defeated (11:10–15)
- I.O. Conquest Summary (11:16–23)
	- 1. Geographical Summary Updated (11:16–17)
	- 2. Theological Summary Updated (11:18–20)
	- 3. Destruction of the Anakim (11:21–22)
	- 4. The Land Had Rest from War (11:23)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-427-4"></span><span id="page-427-2"></span><span id="page-427-0"></span>11:1–5 Israel's victories over the kings of the southern region now provoke northern aggression. Another "Jabin, king of Hazor" is later encountered in the war of Deborah and Barak in Judges 4:2, much as Adoni-zedek of Jerusalem in Joshua 10:1 finds an echo in Adoni-bezek of Judges 1:6–7. A cuneiform tablet containing a letter to an "Ibni-[Adad?]" found at Hazor in 1991–1992 excavations at that site adds credence to the notion that "Jabin" was a royal dynastic name at Hazor.

<span id="page-427-1"></span>The name Ibni-Adad is the Akkadian form of the West Semitic name Yabni-Hadad, of which the name Jabin, king of Hazor (Josh. 11.1; Judg. 4.2), is a possible linguistic derivation. The Jabin referred to in the books of Joshua and Judges postdates Ibni-Adad of the Mari archive by more than 500 years, indicating that the name must have been a dynastic name, borne by more than one of the kings of Hazor.96

Hazor itself remains an impressive site, its large extent and massive fortifications bearing witness to its power and status during the Bronze Age.97 Excavations in the 2010s yielded further cuneiform texts that demonstrated how Hazor even operated its own legal system—a sign of its elite status.98 Hazor's role in forming a northern coalition is in keeping with this regional prominence and status.

The precise locations of the first three cities summoned are all disputed, although some identifications have a greater degree of likelihood than others; the names of Madon and Shimron also have textual variants. The trajectory described by these place names lies to the southwest of Hazor: Madon about 16 miles (26 km) to the south, just west of modern Tiberias; Shimron about 30 miles (48 km) away on the northern edge of the valley of Jezreel; and Achshaph roughly 26 miles (42 km) west-southwest in the plain of Acco, just over 4 miles (7 km) from the Mediterranean coast.99 The cascading regional designations and gentilics in Joshua 11:2–3 map out a broad territory stretching every direction from Hazor. The intention is clearly not to provide a complete inventory of participants, as was the case for the more limited Jerusalem coalition in the southern region. Rather, the impression builds of a vast territory and an overwhelming

97 "Tel Hazor constitutes the largest mound in Israel" (ibid., 107; cf. 108–109).

Neil Asher Silberman and David Small, JSOTSup 237 (Sheffield, UK: Sheffield Academic Press, 1997), 126.

<sup>98</sup> Wayne Horowitz, "Hazor: A Cuneiform City in the West," *NEA* 76/2 (2013): 98–101.

<sup>99</sup> For detailed discussion cf. Eero Junkkaala, *Three Conquests of Canaan: A Comparative Study of Two Egyptian Military Campaigns and Joshua 10–12 in the Light of Recent Archaeological Evidence* (Turku: Åbo Akademis Förlag, 2006), 117–120, 144–145, 165–166, 262–267.

<span id="page-428-3"></span>force — precisely the scene conveyed by the narrator in verse 4, in fact. However imposing the southern coalition might have appeared, it is now dwarfed by the force assembled at the instigation of the king of Hazor.

<span id="page-428-4"></span>The definitive modern location of the battle site, the "waters of Merom" (v. 5), has also eluded modern scholars. The account suggests, however, that it is not far north of Hazor, and the course of the Nahal Dishon is one good possibility in which case it would only be just over 2 miles (3.2 km) north-northeast of Hazor.

<span id="page-428-5"></span><span id="page-428-1"></span><span id="page-428-0"></span>11:6–9 As in the case of the battle against the southern coalition (10:8), so here Joshua is given an oracle of divine reassurance. This goes beyond the previous word spoken by the Lord to Joshua in both providing timing ("tomorrow at this time") and conveying military instruction. The destruction of chariots has been previously encountered in the flight from Egypt, as the Egyptian chariots were first immobilized and then destroyed by the Lord (Ex. 14:25; 15:4). Here chariotry adds to the imposing and superior nature of this army, in contrast to the earlier southern campaign. Destroying these weapons of the aggressor and would-be oppressor is, then, not only divinely mandated by historical precedent and this word (cf. Ps. 46:9) but also clearly prudent as well. The hamstringing of the horses may seem to contemporary readers to pose another kind of ethical question. In social and historical context, however, this is not so barbaric as may be imagined. It involves

<span id="page-428-7"></span>a simple incision damaging the horses' single front flexor tendon after the battle. As a result, the horses are not able to lift the front leg so they are no longer appropriate to be put to a chariot and can only be used for more peaceable purposes as agriculture and haulage. So the hamstringing is not some kind of battle tactic, but a way of making the horses useless for future battles.100

<span id="page-428-2"></span>The note that Joshua and his warriors come on their enemies "suddenly" provides another link to the preceding chapter (Josh. 10:9) in this terse battle account. Again Israel pursues an army fleeing before them. The trajectory of flight is remarkable. Rather than fleeing toward their cities to the south and west, the opponents flee to the north. Identification of two of the place names remains uncertain, but together these names appear to sketch the northern boundary of later tribal allotments from the coastal plain north of Acco on the west as far north as Sidon and toward the east in the direction of Mount Hermon.101 And again victory is complete: the vast northern coalition and its territories fall to Israel in one swift action. Israel on her part complies fully with the demands of the Lord.

<span id="page-428-6"></span>11:10–13 Unlike in his account of the southern campaign, which gave a detailed list of sites engaged by Israel, here the narrator is content with a broad summary statement implying the conquest of the whole region and its cities, whether

<sup>100</sup> Koert van Bekkum, *From Conquest to Coexistence: Ideology and Antiquarian Intent in the Historiography of Israel's Settlement in Canaan* (Leiden: Brill, 2011), 276. 101 Ibid., 177–181.

<span id="page-429-5"></span><span id="page-429-3"></span>fortified or not. This summary shares with the previous account an emphasis on the application of *kherem*, here specified in verses 11–12. As in the case of Ai, this is a qualified *kherem*, with some goods available to Israel as plunder. The distinctive element in this case is the attention given to Hazor. The destruction of Hazor has received attention similar to that of the debates surrounding the archaeology of Jericho in scholarly literature, but for something like the opposite reason. In the case of Jericho, a purported absence of archaeological evidence in combination with the supernatural circumstances recounted in Joshua 6 have fueled the debate. In the case of Hazor, abundant archaeological evidence of destruction by fierce fire in the thirteenth century BC, in combination with a clear statement in Joshua 11:11, 13 that Joshua's forces were responsible for just such a conflagration, has made joining these dots all too easy. Such a connection was forthrightly drawn by Yigael Yadin but has been resisted by those of a more skeptical bent and those who require a higher standard of proof.102 One can say that, at the least, in the Bronze Age incineration of Hazor is a remarkable intersection between biblical memory and contemporary archaeology.

<span id="page-429-6"></span><span id="page-429-4"></span>11:14 As noted above, the application of *kherem* in this campaign allows Israel to take "spoil . . . and the livestock" as plunder. The mention of livestock provides a further contrast to the treatment of the coalition's war horses. The application of the *kherem*, then, is "unambiguous against horses and chariots (representing citystates and dominance), but ambiguous against cattle (who represent an alternative future)."103

<span id="page-429-7"></span><span id="page-429-2"></span><span id="page-429-1"></span><span id="page-429-0"></span>11:15 The narrator's notice in summary of this campaign—that the chain of command has Yahweh as the source and Moses as the first recipient, who transmitted orders to Joshua—is on first sight somewhat jarring at this point. Joshua has been in direct receipt of the Lord's commands and, since the crossing of the Jordan, affirmed as being on the same level as Moses himself (3:7; 4:14). And yet 11:12, with its mention of "Moses the servant of the Lord" (cf. 1:1), has subtly prepared for this perception of Joshua's performance here. The only other moment displaying this kind of command structure is at the crossing of the Jordan in 4:10, where the priests' bearing the ark of the Lord's presence is connected to Moses' "command" to Joshua—the only two places in the Hebrew Bible where this collocation is found. There seems to be, then, a deliberate recognition that, having come to this point, the campaign has reached a threshold. The moment of entry into the Land of Promise finds a counterpart in the final regional campaign, in which the gifted land has been taken by Israel. Work yet remains, but the boundaries of the land have been secured.

<span id="page-429-8"></span>11:16–20 The sense that the narrator is approaching an ending of sorts is signaled in another way in the geographical summary that follows the victory over the northern coalition. This summary describes not only the territories just defeated

<sup>102</sup> For the current state of the debate cf. Brendon C. Benz, "The Destruction of Hazor: Israelite History and the Construction of History in Israel," *JSOT* 44/2 (2019): 262–278.

<sup>103</sup> Peter M. Sensenig, "Chariots on Fire: Military Dominance in the Old Testament," *HBT* 34/1 (2012): 76.

<span id="page-430-4"></span><span id="page-430-3"></span>but the entire extent of the conquered land since the crossing of the Jordan—and then some. The topography described in verse 16 maps out the central, eastern, and western regions, while the two mountain ranges of verse 17 stretch from the southernmost to northernmost points that define the extent of the land. The summary is remarkably inclusive, yet it culminates in a statement of a more political kind, that "all their kings" had been captured and killed. As the book has demonstrated previously, the key antagonism is not between peoples but between the kings of the earth and the King of kings.

<span id="page-430-5"></span><span id="page-430-2"></span>This provides a natural segue from the geographical summary to the theological. The claim of verse 18 that Joshua "made war a long time with all those kings" may come as a surprise, given the way that the accounts of the southern and northern campaigns both assert the suddenness of the Israelite response (10:9; 11:7), while the rapid narration conveys the impression of the swift action of Joshua and the army of Israel. A comment attributed to the medieval Jewish commentator Rashi takes the verse as a rebuke to Joshua for prolonging the subjugation of the land in order to lengthen his own life: once the conquest was completed, his life's purpose would be fulfilled and his days at an end. Modern commentators see this verse rather as attesting to the compressed narration of this phase of conquest, from which many details have been omitted.

Yet the "theology of history" contained in these verses is "especially arresting."104 Enemy intransigence is turned to the purpose of fulfilling a divine plan carried out through Israelite obedience. We find a resonance here with the purpose of God fulfilled in the choices of the king of Egypt in Exodus; here the kings of Canaan likewise choose to oppose Israel's God. "Thus the gracious action of Yahweh, hidden behind human choices, and the fidelity of Israel worked together to bring the divine will to fruition."105 In this case the initiative of the Gibeonites, here identified as Hivites, proves an exception, and this recognition appears again to imply that it was possible to make peace with Israel and her God. A note of grace is also strongly implied, as these verses also suggest that the hearts of the Gibeonites were not "hardened."

<span id="page-430-7"></span><span id="page-430-6"></span><span id="page-430-1"></span>11:21–22 It seems like it is all over—only for another enemy to appear. The synchronism "at that time" remains vague; it seems the narrator is preserving this brief report of the destruction of the mysterious Anakim by placing it here. Once again the term *kherem* is used, the last time it will be applied in the book. (The one further usage, 22:20, is a reference to the account of Achan.) These descendants of Anak (Deut. 1:28), dispersed throughout the land, were the "giants" (Num. 13:33 KJV) who so filled with fear ten of the Israelite spies that the exodus generation as a whole was prevented from proceeding into the land (Num. 13:28–33). This decisive moment lived on in memory, as Moses reminded the conquest generation of the intimidating presence of the Anakim and of the reality that "he who goes

<span id="page-430-0"></span><sup>104</sup> Richard D. Nelson, *Joshua: A Commentary*, OTL (Louisville: Westminster John Knox, 1997), 152. 105 Ibid., 152.

<span id="page-431-0"></span>over before you as a consuming fire is the Lord your God. He will destroy them and subdue them before you" (Deut. 9:1–3). The Anakim are, then, both the first and the last enemy in the land. Another link is thus forged between the wilderness and conquest experiences, the parents' failure to confront this enemy now being rectified under Joshua.

<span id="page-431-10"></span>11:23 Only now can the "whole land" be said to have been taken, so that the "land had rest from war." This will prove to be only a pause, however, and the phrase will be heard again in the book in different forms (but in exactly this form once more; 14:15)106 before the conquest and settlement is finally complete.

#### <span id="page-431-11"></span>*Response*

The success of Israel against the southern cities might well seem to be a notable achievement and an opportunity for rest. It is not to be so. For all its resonances with the southern campaign, the northern campaign represents an appreciable crescendo of force marshaled against Israel. The foe is greater, their weapons stronger. If confusion, hail, and a prolonged day helped Israel's engagement of the Jerusalem coalition, against the much more impressive Hazor coalition there is only the renewed word of the Lord to Joshua not to be afraid (11:6)—although by now the Lord's word is more than enough. It is not an inevitable pattern, but it is familiar enough in Scripture and in life: winning one victory leads not to the end of struggle but to another battle with a stronger enemy.

<span id="page-431-9"></span><span id="page-431-8"></span><span id="page-431-6"></span><span id="page-431-5"></span><span id="page-431-4"></span>With the victory over the royal cities of the northern coalition (vv. 11, 12; 21 [summary]) and the ancient Anakim (v. 22), *kherem* ends, at least as a feature of the Israelite settlement of the land in Joshua. As noted above, its future application will be rare and exceptional, as too its application here should be. It is notable that, as this phase of Israel's warfare draws to a close, explicit connection is made back to the Lord's command through Moses. For Israel this has been a matter of obedience to the divine command, limited for the most part to those royal powers that gathered military force against them; the kings of Canaan sought to annihilate Israel but were themselves "devoted to destruction" (11:20). Perhaps there is yet another way of understanding the conjunction between verse 18, which speaks of how "Joshua made war a long time with all those kings," and verse 19, which points out that only the Hivite inhabitants of Gibeon "made peace with the people of Israel." Just as there was space in Achan's story for repentance and turning to God, so here we can see implied the possibility for the kings of Canaan to have come to a different conclusion and to have understood, as Rahab did, that everything they knew of Israel's God meant that he alone had the right and the power to dispose of the land as he would and that any future lay not in opposing but in worshiping him. But it was not to be.

<span id="page-431-7"></span><span id="page-431-3"></span><span id="page-431-2"></span><span id="page-431-1"></span><sup>106</sup> The combination of a form of the Hebrew *shaqat* ("to be quiet, at peace") with "the land" is the formula that marks the pauses from crisis in the book of Judges (3:11, 30; 5:31; 8:28; 18:7). It differs from the notices about "rest" (a form of *nuakh*) that are the typical notices of cessation from war, punctuating Joshua (1:13, 15; 3:13; 4:3, 8; 6:23; 21:44; 22:4; 23:1).

<span id="page-432-7"></span><span id="page-432-6"></span><span id="page-432-5"></span><span id="page-432-4"></span><span id="page-432-3"></span><span id="page-432-1"></span><span id="page-432-0"></span>The closing observation, that the "land had rest from war" (v. 23), provides not only a glimpse of peace but a sign of hope. The Hebrew verb used here, a form of *shaqat*, has more to do with quiet repose and peace than does another Hebrew verb typically translated as "rest," (*nuakh*) which typically refers instead to that time of relaxation after work (1:13, 15; 22:4 [in connection with the Transjordan tribes]). This rest, even if temporary, is nonetheless real. The reflection of the psalmist on God's establishment of his reign in Judah clearly signals victory over Egypt in Psalm 76:6, but the observation that the "earth feared and was still" (Ps. 76:8) echoes this language from Joshua. The psalmist's association of the coming of the just rule of God with the rejoicing of the "humble" (Ps. 76:9)—that is, the afflicted poor—at God's cutting off the "kings of the earth" (Ps. 76:12) joins with Psalm 2 in giving another perspective on the defeat of the hostile kings of Canaan. Although Joshua does not feature as prominently in the book of Hebrews as does either Moses or Aaron, he is included there as one who provided a kind of rest, even if it was to prove in some sense incomplete, even inadequate (Heb. 4:8). But this is an eschatological note, pointing to a future, fuller, final rest for the people of God.

### <span id="page-432-8"></span><span id="page-432-2"></span>JOSHUA 12:1–24

12 Now these are the kings of the land whom the people of Israel defeated and took possession of their land beyond the Jordan toward the sunrise, from the Valley of the Arnon to Mount Hermon, with all the Arabah eastward: **<sup>2</sup>** Sihon king of the Amorites who lived at Heshbon and ruled from Aroer, which is on the edge of the Valley of the Arnon, and from the middle of the valley as far as the river Jabbok, the boundary of the Ammonites, that is, half of Gilead, **<sup>3</sup>** and the Arabah to the Sea of Chinneroth eastward, and in the direction of Beth-jeshimoth, to the Sea of the Arabah, the Salt Sea, southward to the foot of the slopes of Pisgah; **<sup>4</sup>** and Og*<sup>1</sup>* king of Bashan, one of the remnant of the Rephaim, who lived at Ashtaroth and at Edrei **<sup>5</sup>** and ruled over Mount Hermon and Salecah and all Bashan to the boundary of the Geshurites and the Maacathites, and over half of Gilead to the boundary of Sihon king of Heshbon. **<sup>6</sup>**Moses, the servant of the Lord, and the people of Israel defeated them. #### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-433-2"></span><span id="page-433-0"></span>Having connected the obedience of Israel under Joshua to the commands of the Lord through Moses up to the defeat of the northern coalition, and with the extent of the land now subdued, the narrator pauses to provide a summary of all the kings conquered by Israel both east and west of the Jordan under both Moses and Joshua. The two Amorite kings defeated by Moses have taken on almost a symbolic quality of the power of God to subdue kings opposed to him. These battles were narrated in the book of Numbers; here the narrator provides some details about them, along with their geographical territories (12:1–6). These lands are to be settled by the so-called Transjordan tribes (cf. 1:12–18), which form an early part of the land settlement passages in 13:8–32. The rest of the chapter provides an extended inventory of the thirty-one kings defeated by Joshua (12:7–24). Most of these names are familiar from the immediately preceding narratives, although some have not previously been mentioned. The chapter as a whole signals that a turning point has been reached in the progress of God's people into the Promised Land.

#### <span id="page-433-4"></span><span id="page-433-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- P. Summary of Israel's Battles (12:1–24)
	- 1. Kings Conquered East of the Jordan (12:1–6)
	- 2. Kings Conquered West of the Jordan (12:7–24)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-433-1"></span>12:1 The narrator first provides a general statement of the extent of the land east of the Jordan conquered by "the people of Israel," from the Arnon River as the southern boundary to Mount Hermon marking the extent to the north. This area describes a sizeable region east of the Jordan, from the southern limit at the midway point of the ancient extent of the Dead Sea to the Hermon range over 140 miles (230 km) to the north. The verses that follow summarize the histories of <span id="page-434-3"></span><span id="page-434-2"></span><span id="page-434-0"></span>Sihon and Og previously recounted in Numbers 21:21–35 and recalled by Moses in Deuteronomy 2:26–3:11, going on to the land allotment to the Transjordan tribes in Deuteronomy 3:12–17. At this point in the Joshua account, however, Moses' name is not mentioned.

<span id="page-434-18"></span><span id="page-434-8"></span><span id="page-434-1"></span>12:2–3 The territories of "Sihon king of the Amorites" now follow, with more detail than that given in the brief statement of Numbers 21:24; this finds a counterpart in Joshua 13:9–11. The north-south extent is roughly halved, with the Jabbok dissecting this axis. The east-west dimension is given in terms that range about 50 miles (80 km) from the Jordan eastward at its largest extent.

<span id="page-434-10"></span><span id="page-434-9"></span>12:4–5 As ever with this set pair, attention now shifts to "Og king of Bashan," farther to the north. Although in the Numbers account less attention is given to Og than to Sihon, here the one tidbit of narrative detail ("one of the remnant of the Rephaim"; Josh. 12:4) attaches to Og. The regional extent is even larger; the northern edge has already identified been with Hermon, but the east-west trajectory includes a vast swathe incorporating Damascus, with the eastern extent coinciding with Salecah (v. 5), roughly 67 miles (108 km) east of the Jordan valley.

<span id="page-434-11"></span>The Geshurites and Maacathites (v. 5) are both minor Aramaean kingdoms, with Geshur to the south and Maacah to its north, with an eastern border on the Jordan River, level with the Sea of Galilee and stretching north toward Bashan. They will be noticed again in 13:11, 13.

<span id="page-434-19"></span><span id="page-434-12"></span><span id="page-434-4"></span>12:6 With the neighboring territories of the two kings having been mapped, Moses is now twice named, both times qualified as "the servant of the Lord," as in 1:1 (cf. comment there). The two mentions coincide with the two phases of activity, first the vanquishing of the enemy and then the assignment of their territories to the Transjordan tribes. Notably, these come in quick succession, as coincident as they can be (cf. Deut. 3:12–17).

<span id="page-434-13"></span><span id="page-434-6"></span>12:7–8 Attention now turns to the conquests to the west of the Jordan accomplished under "Joshua and the people of Israel." The broad extent of the land is already familiar from the summary found in Joshua 11, but here is appended also the names of the nations associated with these territories. In this case six nations are listed, omitting the Girgashites from the slightly longer list given at 3:10 (cf. comment on 3:9–13). This, one might say, is territory but not kings.

<span id="page-434-20"></span><span id="page-434-17"></span><span id="page-434-16"></span><span id="page-434-15"></span><span id="page-434-5"></span>12:9–24 By contrast, the list that now follows is interested in kings but not territories. Several of the cities enumerated are either unidentified in historical geography (e.g., Hormah, v. 14; Adullam, v. 15) or unknown outside this list (e.g., Geder, v. 13; Lasharon, v. 18; Goiim, v. 23).107 Even so, the order and import of the list is readily apparent. The sequence of names roughly follows that of the conquest accounts of the preceding chapters, beginning with Joshua and Ai (v. 9) and the kings of

<span id="page-434-14"></span><span id="page-434-7"></span><sup>107</sup> For a convenient attempt to provide identifications cf. Hess, *Joshua*, 244–253. For more detail and discussion of toponyms in chapter 12 cf. Van Bekkum, *From Conquest to Coexistence*, 196–213.

<span id="page-435-6"></span><span id="page-435-5"></span><span id="page-435-4"></span>the southern coalition forged by the king of Jerusalem (vv. 10–16a) before adding an insert that lists cities not otherwise previously mentioned but located in the central region (vv. 16b–18). Then it moves on to the northern region and the coalition formed by the king of Hazor (vv. 19–24a). As has been seen repeatedly before, however, emphasis falls on the kings defeated, not the number of cities or even the regions gained. This relates at least in part to the theological stance that has been consistently displayed: the conflict is between the kings of earth and the King of heaven and earth. There may be another element in play here, however (cf. Response section).

#### *Response*

<span id="page-435-2"></span><span id="page-435-1"></span>A turning point has been reached. The kings of the land have been defeated. Israel under two successive leaders has done so (vv. 1, 7). The theological summary has already been provided at the end of chapter 11, and further occasions in the chapters to come will provide a moment of pause and further attention to the fidelity and provision of God for his people. The perspective taken here, then, is more anthropological than theological, as Israel's part in this remarkable achievement is briefly but patiently stated.

<span id="page-435-7"></span><span id="page-435-3"></span><span id="page-435-0"></span>The two unequal sections of the chapter keep in the reader's eye the geographical division of the tribes of Israel, already stated plainly at 1:12–15. The allotment of the Transjordan tribes is again made explicit (12:6), even while the tribal allotments of the remaining tribes lay in the future. In a subtle way, this reminder keeps this circumstance before readers. Transjordanian interests also occupy the beginning of the next phase of the book, consuming almost the whole of chapter 13. Ultimately, concern for unity of Transjordan tribes with the rest of the people is seen in the dramatic account of chapter 22. Despite the commitments repeatedly given, a risk is evident in the Transjordanian arrangement. At this moment, however, the summary simply correlates the conquests and allotments east of the Jordan with the success in defeating the kings to the west of the river. Potential fissure is not an overt concern of the narrator.

<span id="page-435-8"></span>Finally, another small imbalance can be detected. Under Moses, defeat of kings and allotment of land were more or less contiguous: the latter followed hard on the heels of the former. In this sense, Moses—pointedly and repeatedly called "the servant of the Lord"—establishes an ideal pattern to which, it seems, Joshua does not quite adhere. The land has been taken; kings have been defeated. But the land remains undistributed and unsettled.

### <span id="page-436-4"></span><span id="page-436-2"></span><span id="page-436-1"></span><span id="page-436-0"></span>The first phase of the book, narrated in chapters 1–12, displays a clear progression. Progress naturally continues in the second part of the book, but the nature of the activity is now distributed throughout Israel rather than being enacted by the people of Israel as a whole, as has been the case up to this point. This more fragmented activity allows also for a different kind of arrangement of the material. The chunks constituting the settlement account can be readily seen: chapter 13 provides a reprise of the Transjordanian settlement; chapters 14–17 describe the settlement of Judah, Ephraim, and the remaining half-tribe of Manasseh (the latter two being the "Joseph" tribes; cf. 16:1, 4) arranged from Gilgal, the original Israelite camp west of the Jordan; chapters 18–19 account for the remainder of the tribal settlements managed from Shiloh; while chapters 20–21 complete the distribution with the civic allotments for refuge (ch. 20) and the tribe of Levi (ch. 21), which does not receive a landed inheritance. It is also possible to discern a deliberate pattern

- (A) Divine Command Repeated (13:1–7)
	- (B) Those with a Place (Transjordan) (13:8–33)

<span id="page-436-7"></span><span id="page-436-6"></span><span id="page-436-5"></span>emerging by arranging these components in this way:108

- (C) *Transition*: Tribal Arrangements Reiterated (14:1–5); Caleb's Inheritance (14:6–15)
	- (D) Judah and "Joseph" (15:1–17:18)
		- (E) The Allocation at Shiloh (18:1–10)
	- (D') The Remaining Seven Tribes (18:11–19:48)
- (C') Joshua's Inheritance (19:49–50);
	- (E') *Summary*: Shiloh Allotments Completed (19:51)
- (B') Those without a Place (cis-Jordan) (20:1–21:42)
- (A') Divine Promises Enacted (21:43–45)

<span id="page-436-3"></span>The outer frame (A/A') contrasts Israel's partial undertaking of God's command, supported by a reassurance that "I myself will drive them out" (13:6), with the completion of God's promises and the end of Israelite settlement. Two unusual settlement patterns are brought together in B/B': the review of the regions already allotted by Moses beyond the Jordan to the two and a half tribes and the

<sup>108</sup> Cf. Hendrik Koorevaar, *De opbouw van het boek Jozua* (Heverlee: Centrum voor Bijbelse Vorming België, 1990), English summary, 281–294; Pitkänen, *Joshua*, 247–250.

<span id="page-437-6"></span><span id="page-437-1"></span><span id="page-437-0"></span>distribution of cities on the west of the Jordan (with three "cities of refuge" also in the Transjordan; 20:8) for those who do not receive an allotment (principally Levi). C/C' frames the rest of the tribal inheritance with the allotment of the two faithful spies of Numbers 13, the only members of the wilderness generation to settle in the Promised Land (cf. Num. 14:30). These sections also represent the future southern kingdom (Caleb from Judah) and northern kingdom (Joshua from Ephraim). D (again combining future north/south) and D' contain the main business, the accounts of the settlements of the "nine and one-half tribes" (Josh. 14:2; cf. 13:7). This leaves E, the Shiloh assembly, as the central point of the extended chiastic structure.

<span id="page-437-5"></span><span id="page-437-4"></span>The result is a careful structuring of the distribution of the land. This is not simply a compendium of place names, sorting out districts under tribal claims. It is shaped around God's purpose for and fidelity in his people's taking of the Land of Promise and his inclusive care for the nation as a whole, marked by a movement toward the center of the land to a place that would be known as an early focal point for the worship life of God's people.

### <span id="page-437-2"></span>JOSHUA 13:1–7

13 Now Joshua was old and advanced in years, and the Lord said to him, "You are old and advanced in years, and there remains yet very much land to possess. **2**This is the land that yet remains: all the regions of the Philistines, and all those of the Geshurites **<sup>3</sup>** (from the Shihor, which is east of Egypt, northward to the boundary of Ekron, it is counted as Canaanite; there are five rulers of the Philistines, those of Gaza, Ashdod, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron), and those of the Avvim, **<sup>4</sup>** in the south, all the land of the Canaanites, and Mearah that belongs to the Sidonians, to Aphek, to the boundary of the Amorites, **<sup>5</sup>** and the land of the Gebalites, and all Lebanon, toward the sunrise, from Baal-gad below Mount Hermon to Lebo-hamath, **<sup>6</sup>** all the inhabitants of the hill country from Lebanon to Misrephoth-maim, even all the Sidonians. I myself will drive them out from before the people of Israel. Only allot the land to Israel for an inheritance, as I have commanded you. **7**Now therefore divide this land for an inheritance to the nine tribes and half the tribe of Manasseh."

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-437-3"></span>As the second major section of the book begins, again God speaks directly to Joshua, providing instructions for the new context in which Joshua finds himself. After the brief statement from the narrator in verse 1a, God's speech continues through to the end of verse 7. The speech first affirms what the narrator has just

<span id="page-438-8"></span><span id="page-438-6"></span>stated, and then verses 2–6a survey the "land that yet remains" (v. 2). Verse 6b interjects another note of divine promise and repeats the command, with verse 7 bringing this to focus on the tribes yet to settle.

#### *Section Outline*

- II. Inhabiting the Land (13:1–21:45)
	- A. The Land That Yet Remains (13:1–7)
		- 1. Joshua's Advanced Years (13:1a)
		- 2. God's Renewed Charge to Settle the Land (13:1b–7)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-438-5"></span><span id="page-438-4"></span><span id="page-438-1"></span>13:1 Narrative content and structural features (cf. Overview of 13:1–21:45) signal that this moment brings a new phase of life for Joshua and the people of Israel. There is a further indicator in the very structure of this verse. The condition of Israel's leader is reported, and then the Lord confirms the same information in the same words. This same pattern begins the book as a whole in 1:1–2, reporting Moses' death, after which the Lord directs Joshua to lead Israel across the Jordan.109 Here the instruction is to continue that advance into the land. Is there some implication that things have stalled? This may be an implication of the "old and advanced in years" description, found again in 23:1 and affirmed by Joshua in direct speech in 23:2. This phrase is used two other times in the OT: Abraham is "old, well advanced in years" when he seeks a wife for Isaac, the child of promise (Gen. 24:1), and David likewise is "old and advanced in years" when Abishag is found as his "nurse" and he has as yet failed to arrange for succession to the throne of Israel (1 Kings 1:1). Like Abraham before him and David in time to come, it seems Joshua has delayed this arrangement longer than he ought to have done.

<span id="page-438-11"></span><span id="page-438-10"></span><span id="page-438-9"></span><span id="page-438-2"></span><span id="page-438-0"></span>This verse begins the second-longest divine speech in the book, and the second-to-last. With the bulk of its content devoted to a litany of place names, it may seem an unusual word for Joshua to receive. Yet this speech contains most of the essential elements found in its counterpart, Joshua 1:2–9. It includes the affirmation of the new situation, a geographical notice concerning the gifted land, a promise of divine assistance, and a clear word of instruction or command. The obvious missing component in this last speech is the emphatic encouragement to bold, confident action; also absent here is the attention to the "Book of the Law" (1:7–8). Clearly, some lessons have been learned during the series of campaigns that have won victories over the hostile kings of the Canaanites. The overriding concern, however, is with what has *not* been done.

<span id="page-438-7"></span><span id="page-438-3"></span>13:2–6a The "land that yet remains" stretches from the border with Egypt in the south as far as the regions around Damascus in the northwest. The focus falls on the Philistine coastal plain and its associated cities. The trajectory runs northward up the Mediterranean coast toward the region of Tyre and Sidon, then moves eastward across the northern border with the Amorites, finishing in the hilly region associated today with the Golan Heights. Some of the toponyms used (e.g., Mearah) remain unidentified.

The Lord speaks of "land," and the speech includes a good number of place names. But there is a corresponding association with people — Philistines, Geshurites, Gebalites, "inhabitants of the hill country," Sidonians. The landscape of the Promised Land is populated, but Israel must now come into its inheritance.

<span id="page-439-4"></span><span id="page-439-1"></span><span id="page-439-0"></span>13:6b–7 "Inheritance" (Hb. *nahalah*), used twice in short compass, comes into prominence here, having been used only once previously in the book (11:23). In the settlement chapters (chs. 13–21) it is used forty-five times, and only a further four times in the book's closing chapters, three of those coming in the book's final six verses. Clearly, then, the term looms large as a conceptual marker for Israel's settlement of the land. For English speakers it summons to mind the idea of coming into possession of something at the death of its owner. However, in the context of Joshua the term refers to property, or an estate, over which one exercises rights, these rights being expected to be maintained within a family/clan across generations. Entitlement, then, is the fundamental concept, with the passing along through generations being secondary.110 As Ellen Davis notes,

<span id="page-439-5"></span>Because the complex of ideas represented by the single term *naḥălâ* focuses on land possession, elements of that complex enter into discussions about political sovereignty in a national sense. However, I am highlighting its neglected aspect, for the biblical development of the concept points not only, and maybe not primarily, to possession "from above," based on conquest, but also to possession "from below," based on care.111

Joined to the notion of *nahalah* is the related term *halaq*, used as a verb in verse 7 ("divide") but often as a noun, *heleq*, with the sense of "portion" or "share."112 Although *heleq* and *nahalah* appear to be nearly synonymous, *heleq* conveys a distributive sense not inherent in *nahalah*.

<span id="page-439-3"></span>Not to be missed as these new concepts (in Joshua) are introduced is the brief but significant word of reassurance the Lord gives to Joshua, that "I myself will drive them out" (v. 6). However, this does not absolve Israel of the responsibility of acting on this divine imperative—quite the opposite. It is the basis on which they obey.

#### *Response*

The impulse to spiritualize a passage such as this one is difficult to resist. It should never be forgotten that in this speech God depicts for Joshua a real landscape with

Habel glosses the Hebrew *nahalah* as "allotment, the holding to which [tribe and ancestral family are] entitled by virtue of the divinely approved land grant process" (34), referencing Joshua 14:2–5.

<span id="page-439-6"></span><sup>111</sup> Ellen F. Davis, *Scripture, Culture, and Agriculture: An Agrarian Reading of the Bible* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2009), 106–107.

<span id="page-439-2"></span><sup>112</sup> Occurrences of both noun (nine times) and verb (seven times) in Joshua are limited to chapters 13–22.

real inhabitants. The chapters that follow likewise relentlessly root the life of the people of Israel in the land given to them by the Lord. At the same time, the dynamic that sparks this last direct word of God to Joshua is a familiar one in both the OT and NT. Beginnings may be made, but persistence to the finish is required. Commenting on this dynamic in Joshua, Alice Hodgkin observes,

Though "all things are ours" in Christ, it remains for us to take possession of them experimentally by faith. The promise was that every place that the sole of their foot should tread should be theirs. And in the thirteenth chapter of this book the Lord said unto Joshua, "There remaineth yet very much land to be possessed." There was a slackness on the part of Israel to possess the land which the Lord had given them (xviii. 3).113

Some responsibility for that slackness appears to be attributed to Joshua. The repeated contrast of the alacrity with which Moses allotted the "inheritance" of the Transjordan tribes with the more leisurely pace under Joshua subsequent to the conquest of kings reinforces this perception.

<span id="page-440-7"></span><span id="page-440-6"></span>The claim God makes of Joshua, and through him of Israel as well, is not only for perseverance (cf. Heb. 10:32–39; 12:12) but for an unceasing endurance. There is a sense here in which vigilance and perseverance are two sides of the same coin: flagging on one side will lead to failure on the other. We can understand the calls in Revelation for the "endurance of the saints" (Rev. 14:12; cf. 13:10) to have the same sense. Meanwhile, if the theme of persistence, endurance, and perseverance with attendant obedience remains somewhat implicit here, by the time of Joshua's final speech in chapter 24 it will have grown to startling proportions.

<span id="page-440-3"></span><span id="page-440-1"></span><span id="page-440-0"></span>The language of the Hebrew *nahalah*, which brings with it some sense of "entitlement," may sit uneasily, especially with the recognition of the populated landscape to which attention has already been drawn. The underlying principle in terms of the rebellion of the "kings of the earth" (Ps. 76:12), discussed in relation to the southern and northern campaigns, may feel too distant to be helpful here. But the notion that all creation is in the gift of the Creator is also a pervasive biblical principle. It was the basis on which Israel's land regulations were framed: "The land shall not be sold in perpetuity, for the land is mine" (Lev. 25:23). The psalmists assert and sing of God's claim and ownership of all there is: "The earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof, the world and those who dwell therein" (Ps. 24:1) and, again, "The world and its fullness are mine" (Ps. 50:12). Politically, this extended also to people groups not typically associated with divine action on their behalf, expressed poignantly in Amos 9:7. This will in fullness of time be realized in a gathering together of a people of God from "every nation, from all tribes and peoples and languages" (Rev. 7:9; cf. Eph. 2:13–18). In this case, then, God exercises the right to gift the land to his people; they in turn should show it the care its Creator intended.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-442-8"></span><span id="page-442-7"></span><span id="page-442-5"></span><span id="page-442-4"></span>Before the text goes on to relate the distribution of the "land that yet remains" (Josh. 13:2) to the "nine tribes and half the tribe of Manasseh" (13:7; cf. 14:2), it first rehearses once again the apportioning of the land to the east of the Jordan under Moses. The passage divides neatly: a frame—which combines a regional overview (13:8–13, 32) with a notice about the non-inheritance of Levi (vv. 14, 33)—contains three paragraphs attending to each of the Transjordanian tribal settlements: Reuben, firstborn and first settled, in verses 15–23; Gad's allotment in verses 24–28; and the half-tribe of Manasseh in verses 29–31. Each of these paragraphs begins with a notice of what lands and holdings "Moses gave" to them and concludes with a brief summation. Within this regularity we find interesting variations.

#### <span id="page-442-9"></span>*Section Outline*

- II.B. Settlement under Moses: A Retrospective (13:8–33)
	- 1. Regional Overview of the Transjordanian Settlement, Excluding Levi (13:8–14)
	- 2. Moses Assigns Reuben's Settlement (13:15–23)
	- 3. Moses Assigns Gad's Settlement (13:24–28)
	- 4. Moses Assigns the Half-Tribe of Manasseh's Settlement (13:29–31)
	- 5. Summary of the Transjordanian Settlement, Excluding Levi (13:32–33)

<span id="page-442-0"></span>This is the fourth time the Transjordanian settlement has been reported subsequent to the original account of the defeat of the kings Sihon and Og in Numbers 21 (but cf. Num. 21:25, 35). The four accounts are the following:

- <span id="page-442-1"></span>(1) Moses' distribution after arranging for the Transjordan tribes' continued participation in the conquest of the Promised Land (Num. 32:33–42).
- <span id="page-442-2"></span>(2) Moses' rehearsal of the distribution in the sermon on the plains of Moab (Deut. 3:12–17).
- <span id="page-442-3"></span>(3) The regional summary concluding the first part of Joshua (Josh. 12:1–6).
- <span id="page-442-6"></span>(4) The preface to the settlement of the nine and a half tribes (Josh. 13:8–33).

On each occasion some association is made with the history of the defeat of the two Amorite kings, Sihon and Og, who take a special place as providing a precedent and template for further royal battles. The level of detail reported from those battles varies markedly, as do the nature and the extent of the geographical particulars provided. The distribution itself appears in summary form in the second and third accounts; more details, especially concerning the naming of cities affected within region, are provided in the first and fourth. No two are the same; each contributes in a way that meets the need of the immediate context. Here the effect of including this preface, which clearly marks an interruption in the main business of getting on to the settlement of the remaining tribes, is to set up a template for Joshua to follow: he must now do as Moses had previously done. It also provides something of a literary template for the reports that follow in chapters 14–19.

#### <span id="page-443-8"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-443-6"></span><span id="page-443-4"></span><span id="page-443-3"></span><span id="page-443-2"></span>13:8–13 The introduction to the regions settled by the two and a half Transjordan tribes echoes the one just provided at the beginning of chapter 12; they are "near neighbors" in more than one sense. Close in proximity, these introductions are also close in strategy, providing a south-to-north résumé of the settlement east of the Jordan. Sihon and Og once again are named, with Og's status as last of the Rephaim recalled once more (cf. Deut. 3:11; Josh. 12:4). The territories of the Geshurites and Maacathites were mentioned in the previous summary (12:5), but here in addition their persistent presence among the people of Israel is registered (13:3). At a number of points in the unfolding account of Israelite settlement such persistent inhabitants will be noted. They undermine superficial comparisons of Joshua and Judges that assert a total conquest in Joshua and a partial one in Judges, sometimes also set up as a contradiction between the books. Such contrasts are overdrawn.

<span id="page-443-11"></span><span id="page-443-5"></span><span id="page-443-0"></span>13:14, 33 Included in the frame of the settlement under Moses is the repeated observation that Moses provided no "inheritance" for the tribe of Levi. This, too, is a matter of obedience and right order in the constitution of God's people in the Promised Land. The arrangement is first put in place in Numbers 18:21–24, in which the tithe is recorded as priestly compensation for non-inheritance. The arrangement has an element of reciprocity: for giving the tithe, the rest of Israel receives protection from the destructive outcome of their desecrating the holy things associated with sacrifice and offerings. Along with the tithe, Numbers 35:1–8 stipulates that an allocation of cities and pasturelands should be drawn from the tribal settlements to provide for the Levites' dwelling, in conjunction with the cities of refuge. This takes place in Joshua 20–21 (cf. comments there). The non-inheritance of Levi appears again as the remainder of the settlement proceeds (14:3, 4) and yet again as the second phase of distribution is initiated (18:7).

<span id="page-443-10"></span><span id="page-443-9"></span><span id="page-443-7"></span><span id="page-443-1"></span>The two notices here in 13:14, 33 each offers a slightly different rationale for this circumstance: the tribe of Levi receives as its "inheritance" either the "offerings" (v. 14) or the "the Lord God of Israel" himself (v. 33). These two statements <span id="page-444-1"></span>reflect the regulations of the priesthood in Deuteronomy 18:1–2. The priesthood may be landless, but it is privileged nonetheless.

<span id="page-444-6"></span><span id="page-444-3"></span>13:15–23 Reuben's territory is the southernmost of the three Transjordanian allotments, and its description follows the general south-to-north trajectory of the regional summary. The distinctive feature in this account is the two embedded narrative references. Although Sihon and Og both appear again in the Gad and eastern Manasseh settlements below, in neither of those cases (Josh. 13:27, 30) is there any narrative element attached; this mention of the nature of Moses' victory over Sihon serves as reminder enough (v. 21). The execution of the other leaders of Sihon mentioned in verse 21 triggers the memory of the danger posed by the false prophet Balaam, these deaths being recorded in Numbers 31:8 during the war against Midian. The brief narrative allusions signal both triumph and danger in the earlier history of Israel.

<span id="page-444-5"></span><span id="page-444-4"></span><span id="page-444-0"></span>13:24–28 The settlement of Gad lies to the north of Reuben. It includes the remainder of Sihon's territory (Josh. 13:27) not taken by Reuben, and it extends as far north as the Sea of Galilee ("Chinnereth"; v. 27). The Jordan River lies as boundary to the east.

<span id="page-444-7"></span>13:29–32 With the region associated with Sihon disposed of, the half-tribe of Manasseh occupies the territory formerly associated with Og. This extends yet farther north toward Bashan. Here a total of the allocated cities is also included. This feature will appear again in the reports of the further tribal settlements under Joshua.

<span id="page-444-9"></span><span id="page-444-8"></span>This version of Transjordanian settlement marks the last time in the exodus and conquest accounts that the pairing of Sihon and Og is seen. The two have a prominent role as paradigmatic conquests, and this includes the settlement of the Transjordan tribes in these territories. They appear again in later parts of the OT only at 1 Kings 4:19, in the overview of Solomon's administrative arrangements, and beyond that as historical reminiscences in the prayers of Nehemiah 9:22 and Psalms 135:11; 136:19–20. It may be claiming too much to see these as firstfruits of Israel's beginning to receive the Promised Land. There is no doubt, however, that the early steps in fidelity and tenacity to God's commands in light of God's promise were taken in the victories over Sihon and Og, kings of the Amorites.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-444-2"></span>It is difficult to know why the narrator chooses to rehearse once more the settlement east of the Jordan that took place under Moses, interrupting as it does the initiation of the settlement under Joshua (cf. Josh. 13:7; 14:2). If authorial purpose is difficult to ascertain, some effects on the reader can still be noted. First, providing this review integrates the Transjordanian settlement into that of the rest of the people under Joshua. As discussed above, the final notice of Sihon and Og also suggests the importance of integrating the settlement of their territories into the full account of Israel's settlement as a whole. Weaving in this account at this point reinforces the perception of a single settlement by the whole people of Israel.

<span id="page-445-1"></span><span id="page-445-0"></span>The second point that emerges is the counterpoint to this assertion of unity. Some sense of anxiety over the unity of God's people also seems to be harbored. The flashback to the death of Balaam signals this most poignantly. Yet in all the accounts of the arrangements with the two and a half tribes something of this undercurrent is lurking. Thus in Numbers 32:1–32 Moses labors over eliciting commitment from these tribes to accompany their brothers into the land across the Jordan. So too the book of Joshua itself begins with these tribes' declaring their obedience and parroting God's encouragement to Joshua (Josh. 1:12–18). There is an element of foreshadowing here, as assertions of unity betray a fear of fragmentation, a fear realized in chapter 22.

### <span id="page-445-3"></span><span id="page-445-2"></span>JOSHUA 14:1–15

14 These are the inheritances that the people of Israel received in the land of Canaan, which Eleazar the priest and Joshua the son of Nun and the heads of the fathers' houses of the tribes of the people of Israel gave them to inherit. **2**Their inheritance was by lot, just as the Lord had commanded by the hand of Moses for the nine and one-half tribes. **3**For Moses had given an inheritance to the two and one-half tribes beyond the Jordan, but to the Levites he gave no inheritance among them. **4**For the people of Joseph were two tribes, Manasseh and Ephraim. And no portion was given to the Levites in the land, but only cities to dwell in, with their pasturelands for their livestock and their substance. **<sup>5</sup>**The people of Israel did as the Lord commanded Moses; they allotted the land.

**<sup>6</sup>**Then the people of Judah came to Joshua at Gilgal. And Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite said to him, "You know what the Lord said to Moses the man of God in Kadesh-barnea concerning you and me. **<sup>7</sup>** I was forty years old when Moses the servant of the Lord sent me from Kadesh-barnea to spy out the land, and I brought him word again as it was in my heart. **8**But my brothers who went up with me made the heart of the people melt; yet I wholly followed the Lord my God. **9**And Moses swore on that day, saying, 'Surely the land on which your foot has trodden shall be an inheritance for you and your children forever, because you have wholly followed the Lord my God.' **10**And now, behold, the Lord has kept me alive, just as he said, these forty-five years since the time that the Lord spoke this word to Moses, while Israel walked in the wilderness. And now, behold, I am this day eighty-five years old. **<sup>11</sup>** I am still as strong today as I was in the day that Moses sent me; my strength now is as my strength was then, for war and for going and coming. **<sup>12</sup>** So now

as the Lord said."

**<sup>13</sup>**Then Joshua blessed him, and he gave Hebron to Caleb the son of Jephunneh for an inheritance. **14**Therefore Hebron became the inheritance of Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite to this day, because he wholly followed the Lord, the God of Israel. **15**Now the name of Hebron formerly was Kiriath-arba.*<sup>1</sup>* (Arba*<sup>2</sup>* was the greatest man among the Anakim.) And the land had rest from war.

1*Kiriath-arba* means *the city of Arba* 2Hebrew *He*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-446-8"></span><span id="page-446-1"></span><span id="page-446-0"></span>With the review of the Transjordanian allotment complete, the stage is now set for the work identified in God's final word to Joshua (13:1). As noted in the Overview of 13:1–21:45, multiple endpoints are in view for the work that remains. All will be done finally only when the Levites have their dwellings allocated as well; this takes place in chapter 21, preceded by the provision of cities of refuge in chapter 20. The main concern here, however, is with the remaining "nine and one-half tribes" (14:2), and this activity will only be completed in chapter 19.

<span id="page-446-7"></span><span id="page-446-6"></span><span id="page-446-4"></span><span id="page-446-3"></span><span id="page-446-2"></span>The narrator provides a pronounced and explicit transition from lands east of the Jordan to the western settlement in 14:1–5. This provides a rationale for what is about to take place and offers an accounting for the tribal groupings in place as the allocation of land unfolds. Judah is the first of the cis-Jordan tribes to find a home, and its story begins with a personal focus on the settlement of Caleb (14:6–14). Caleb's story has a counterpart in the settlement of Joshua (19:49–50), which is much more briefly reported than Caleb's is here. There is clearly something distinctive about this personal story. Even the narrator's final, brief observations (14:15) lend a sense of closure to the Caleb account that seems surprising if it serves simply as the first of the tribal settlements of Judah.

<span id="page-446-5"></span>At a superficial level, then, this passage sets in motion the long-awaited process of allotting territories in the Promised Land for the remaining tribes. Lurking just below the surface, however, are issues of obedience and identity.

#### *Section Outline*

II.C. Settlement West of the Jordan Begins (14:1–15)

- 1. Remaining Settlement according to Lord's Command to Moses (14:1–5)
- 2. Caleb the Kenizzite Settles at Hebron (14:6–15)
	- a. Caleb's Request (14:6–12)
	- b. Joshua's Blessing (14:13–14)
	- c. Concluding Observations (14:15)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-447-10"></span><span id="page-447-9"></span><span id="page-447-7"></span><span id="page-447-0"></span>14:1–5 Although the divine alert came to Joshua (13:1–7) and is here put into motion under the leadership of Joshua and Eleazar, its execution is framed as Israel's obedience (14:1, 5). Before proceeding with the division of the land itself, the narrator sets out with some care the circumstances under which that division takes place. Verse 2 stipulates that, in accord with the divine command to Moses, the "inheritance" of the "nine and one-half tribes" is to be decided "by lot." This notice accomplishes two purposes: it both declares that the remaining land allotment takes place "by lot" and also by implication explains why the previous settlement of the two and one-half tribes did not. Yahweh's initial instruction to Moses concerning division by lot is found in Numbers 26:52–56, where it comes at the conclusion of the census of the twelve tribes of the conquest generation (including Ephraim and Manasseh) but precedes the census account of the tribe of Levi, which was excluded from the settlement. At this point it would appear to apply to all the tribes, but in Numbers 33:54, after the land is allotted to the Transjordan tribes under Moses and Eleazar, the Lord renews the command to Moses that the remaining tribes should inherit "by lot." On one further occasion Moses himself reports the divine stipulation, as an element of the survey of geographical limits of the Promised Land to the west of the Jordan, again after the Transjordanian allotment has taken place (Num. 34:13–15). The *requirement* to make use of the "lot" moving forward is stated in Joshua 14:2, while the *absence* of the use of lots is thus explained in 14:3. This will be an integral part of the obedience registered in verse 5. Mention of the "lot" (Hb. *goral*) is unevenly distributed through the book, with all twenty-six of the occurrences in the book found in chapters 14–21 (which account for one-third of all such occurrences in the Hebrew Bible as a whole), including twenty in Joshua 18–19; 21 alone.

<span id="page-447-16"></span><span id="page-447-12"></span><span id="page-447-11"></span><span id="page-447-8"></span><span id="page-447-6"></span><span id="page-447-5"></span><span id="page-447-4"></span><span id="page-447-3"></span><span id="page-447-2"></span><span id="page-447-1"></span>Again the non-inheritance of Levi receives prominent notice (cf. comment on 13:14, 33). The positive command to settle by lot in Numbers 26:55–56 is followed swiftly by the remark that the tribe of Levi did not participate in the census because it was not due to inherit (Num. 26:62). The requirement for the lot is repeated at Numbers 33:54 and 34:13, after which follows the arrangements for the cities and pasturelands in Numbers 35:1–8. This language is now picked up by the narrator in Joshua. The otherwise odd remark here that "the people of Joseph were two tribes" provides further explanation for the total of twelve tribes who find an inheritance when there is yet a further tribe excluded from this arrangement. The overall situation is thus accounted for, and Israel is found to be compliant, along with its leaders, Joshua and Eleazar.

<span id="page-447-15"></span><span id="page-447-14"></span><span id="page-447-13"></span>14:6–12 After this it might be thought odd that Caleb's inheritance does not come by lot. Clearly, however, Caleb's understanding is that the land for which he asks is his by promise. In verse 6 and again in verse 12 Caleb explicitly references a promise made to him by the Lord that a particular parcel of land should be his. In verse 9 this is expanded by way of confirmation of a word from Moses <span id="page-448-3"></span><span id="page-448-1"></span>in view of the wholehearted obedience Caleb showed not only on the occasion of spying out the land in Numbers 13–14 but throughout his long and faithful life (cf. Num. 32:12). The promise was not recorded in Numbers, where it might have been expected, but is reported by Moses on the plains of Moab as he begins a rehearsal of Israel's exodus experience as the conquest generation prepares to enter the land (Deut. 1:36; cf. Num. 14:24). By his behavior and his prospects in entering the land, Caleb's is a special case.

<span id="page-448-4"></span><span id="page-448-2"></span>Beyond his obedience lies a question of identity. As this story begins and ends (Josh. 14:6, 14) Caleb receives a full identification: "Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite." His membership in the tribe of Judah is only implied in the juxtaposition of the tribe's approach to Joshua with Caleb's request. Outside of this passage, his identification as a Kenizzite is found only at Numbers 32:12. Why should this affiliation be so noticeable here, then? It is common to associate the Kenizzites with a descendant of Esau, Kenaz, associated with the Edomites (Gen. 36:1–11, 40–43). At the very least, then, this identifier suggests an ancestry for Caleb that makes him a non-Israelite, yet one whose family is incorporated into Israel and whose exemplary and forceful fidelity marks him out as unparalleled in his generation. Not even Joshua, the designated successor to Moses, receives gets the approval accorded to Caleb.

<span id="page-448-5"></span><span id="page-448-0"></span>One theological nuance to Caleb's request might seem unusual. After Caleb sets out the basis for his request, points out God's promise, records his experience of God's faithfulness, and claims in no uncertain terms both his own vigor and his territory, his speech's climax seems remarkably halfhearted: "It may be that the Lord will be with me, and I shall drive them out just as the Lord said" (Josh. 14:12). In spite of Caleb's grounds for confidence in God's gift and his own ability, his "It may be . . ." (Hb. *ʾulay*, "perhaps, maybe") might seem like a failure of nerve or a lack of confidence in God's provision. On the contrary, however, Caleb is leaving open some other way for God's promise to be realized, a mark of theological humility and a demonstration of an absence of spiritual presumption. Israel's God is under no constraint to behave in the manner in which Caleb anticipates he might. This is quite a different matter than doubting either God's capacity or his willingness; everything Caleb has seen of this God through his life reassures him that he is faithful to his word, and his "maybe" does not undermine that confidence.

<span id="page-448-6"></span>14:13–14 Joshua's blessing and assignment of the land granted to Caleb comes without need for casting lots. Although Caleb has referred to his hoped-for property as "this hill country" (v. 12), it is now twice identified as Hebron. Located to the south of the area associated with the settlement of Judah, Hebron retained its association with Caleb into David's time (1 Sam. 30:14).

<span id="page-448-8"></span><span id="page-448-7"></span>14:15 The narrator's final observations associate Hebron with "Kiriath-arba." If "arba" is related to the number four, it may refer to a tetrapolis, like Gibeon and its associated cities. This could in turn explain why his request for "cities" (Josh. 14:12) results in the grant of seemingly just one. The old name bears a further <span id="page-449-1"></span><span id="page-449-0"></span>association with the Anakim (cf. comment on 11:21–22). Just as on that previous occasion, the mention of the Anakim is partnered with a notice of "rest from war," repeating the phrase from 11:23.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-449-3"></span><span id="page-449-2"></span>Comparisons between Caleb and Joshua in the OT are never sharply drawn. They remain subtle, detected only with care. Some contrast seems to emerge with this narrative. Here Caleb's exemplary character is displayed not only by his autobiographical claim (14:8) but by the affirmative recognition of the narrator (14:14). Sandwiched between these notes of wholehearted devotion to the Lord is Caleb's plea in pursuit of the promise of God in the vigor of his old age. One must be alert to the danger of overreading, but this request appears to contrast with the prompting that Joshua required in his old age to be up and getting on with it (13:1). Of the different calls to perseverance that the book provides, this adds another: the note of urgency to persist in faithfulness "even to old age and gray hairs" (Ps. 71:18). Across centuries, Caleb's bold tenacity in realizing the promise of God resonates with that of the old apostle who "pressed on toward the goal . . . of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus" (Phil. 3:14) and would later reflect on having "fought the good fight, . . . finished the race, . . . kept the faith" (2 Tim. 4:7).

<span id="page-449-7"></span><span id="page-449-6"></span><span id="page-449-4"></span>Caleb's Kenizzite status also calls for further reflection. The first part of the book gave prominent place to considering how both an individual with her family and a regional populace could find refuge among God's people. On any reckoning Caleb is an extraordinary Israelite, and yet it seems he, too, came from a family once alien to the people of God. While the second half of the book does not give equal prominence to the place of the foreigner among God's people, this theme is not absent and will be encountered again before the book concludes. The observation has been made previously that a close reading of Joshua repudiates the charges of xenophobia and genocide. Caleb's story as told here also contributes something to this rebuttal.

<span id="page-449-5"></span>A single word in Caleb's speech (Hb. *ʾulay*, "perhaps") was noticed in the comments above. It is just one word, but with it Caleb demonstrates his submission to a sovereign deity who is not bound to bring about the fulfillment of his promise in the way that mere creatures might hope for or expect. Once again we can see a Pauline parallel with Paul's own zealous commitment to know Christ Jesus in suffering and thus also to know the power of his resurrection, "that by any means possible I may attain the resurrection from the dead" (Phil. 3:11). Confidence in God's faithfulness can coexist peacefully with humility concerning the way in which that faithfulness will be shown. The joint witness of Caleb and the apostle Paul not only suggests the possibility of this combination but commends it.
