#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-451-2"></span><span id="page-451-1"></span><span id="page-451-0"></span>This account of the settlement of the tribe of Judah finds its introduction in Joshua 14:6, where the "people of Judah" approach Joshua to seek their allotment. The account of Caleb's request immediately follows, but now the story of the rest of the tribe unfolds. Caleb continues to feature prominently. The chapter falls into three main sections and concludes with a brief postscript. The regional boundaries of Judah's allotment are described with some care in the first section (15:1–12), and a detailed gazetteer of the cities contained in the region constitutes the third main section (vv. 20–62). Between them a brief narrative of Caleb again features, in this

<span id="page-452-9"></span>case joined by his daughter, Achsah (vv. 13–19). The laconic nature of this short story belies both its significance and the welter of issues it raises, partly on account of its brevity. The passage concludes with the slightly ominous note of the continuing presence within the tribal settlement of the Jebusites inhabiting Jerusalem (v. 63).

<span id="page-452-10"></span>By virtue of size and precedence, the account of the Judahite settlement achieves an undoubted prominence in the overall picture of Israel's occupation of the Promised Land. Still, an attentive reading is required to register the full implications of the narrator's choices in telling Judah's story in just this way. As will be seen, the account signals Judah's stature as not only the leading member of the tribal grouping but also one whose parameters make it the equal of the rest of the "nine and one-half tribes" (14:2) settling to the west of the Jordan.

#### <span id="page-452-2"></span>*Section Outline*

- II.D. The Settlement of Judah (15:1–63)
	- 1. Judah's Borders (15:1–12)
	- 2. Caleb's Portion; Achsah's Request (15:13–19)
	- 3. The Cities of Judah Enumerated (15:20–62)
	- 4. The Jebusites Remain (15:63)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-452-4"></span>15:1–12 For all the care lavished on the description of Judah's borders, the identity and location of a number of toponyms provided now elude identification. The overall trajectory of the account and the main outlines of the borders can be traced with reasonable confidence and are at least clear enough for the purposes of the record to be sustained. That is, the biblical account may not be identical to some administrative record that exhaustively maps territories in words, but it retains sufficient detail to convey the significance of those boundaries to later readers.

<span id="page-452-5"></span><span id="page-452-3"></span>The segments of the borders of Judah are described in a counterclockwise order, beginning with the southern border at its eastern edge, the south tip of the Dead Sea, describing a westward arc concluding at the Mediterranean coast (vv. 1–4). The description then returns to the Dead Sea, as its extent represents the eastern boundary (v. 5a). From the north end of the Dead Sea the northern boundary is described as an undulating line running westward, south of Jebus ("that is, Jerusalem"; v. 8), which is thus excluded from Judahite territory, terminating at the Mediterranean coast at the town of Jabneel, roughly halfway between Joppa to the north and Ashdod to the south (vv. 5b–11). The Mediterranean coast itself forms the natural western boundary (v. 12).

<span id="page-452-11"></span><span id="page-452-8"></span><span id="page-452-7"></span><span id="page-452-6"></span><span id="page-452-1"></span><span id="page-452-0"></span>The borders of other tribal territories will not be described in such detail (and those of Simeon, Issachar, and Dan are not described at all). Even here, the boundaries are not as distinctive as they might first appear. The southern boundary is essentially that of Canaan itself (cf. Num. 34:1–4), and the northern boundary is essentially the same demarcation as Benjamin's southern extent (Josh. 18:12–19). With the western boundary formed by the Mediterranean Sea (cf. Num. 34:6), the <span id="page-453-2"></span>distinctive element in this record is found at Joshua 15:5, which places the Dead Sea as the eastern boundary of Judah.

<span id="page-453-0"></span>Two features of this account should be noted. The first is the inclusivity of the boundary. Commentators sometimes rue the lack of a meaningful southern border for Judah and the somewhat optimistic reach westward to the Mediterranean. However, these boundaries coincide with the extent of land promised in earlier times, of which Numbers 34 is one key text. This inclines Judah's boundaries toward something like protonational borders, something more than a sharply circumscribed tribal allotment. The second feature to be noted is the exclusion of Jerusalem in Joshua 15:8, the explicit notice of its exclusion being absent from the parallel list relating to Benjamin in 18:16. Together with the final observation of the narrator regarding Judah's allotment in 15:63, again emphasizing that Jerusalem lies beyond the control of Judah, a perspective seems to be lurking that anticipates later developments concerning what will become the most important city of them all.

<span id="page-453-11"></span><span id="page-453-10"></span><span id="page-453-9"></span><span id="page-453-7"></span><span id="page-453-5"></span><span id="page-453-3"></span>15:13–19 The account of Caleb found here occurs again, with a few differences, in the opening chapter of Judges (Judg. 1:10–15). In Judges Caleb's role in "driving out" (Hb. *yarash*) the three sons of Anak is described as the sons' being "defeated" (*nakah*) at the hands of Judah. Othniel is referred to as Caleb's younger brother in Judges; this additional detail does not appear in Joshua. There are also some minor differences in wording in Hebrew. The chief difference between the accounts, of course, is their contexts. In Judges the vignette appears as one of a sequence of scenarios depicting Judah and then other tribes fighting against the Canaanites and introduces Othniel, who will become the ideal judge (Judg. 3:7–11). Here in Joshua this is an isolated account in the administrative record of Judahite territory, albeit one with an echo in the account of the settlement of Joseph, which includes a brief narrative featuring the daughters of Zelophehad (Josh. 17:3–6). Despite its brevity, or perhaps in part because of it, the text contains a number of difficulties regarding its relationship to the parallel text in Judges, the status of Othniel, the treatment of Achsah, and the legal context for the gifts from Caleb.114 The comments here focus on the present context.

<span id="page-453-8"></span><span id="page-453-6"></span><span id="page-453-4"></span>The brief account falls fairly naturally into three phases: (1) Caleb's actions (15:13–15); (2) Othniel's victory, which wins for him Achsah, Caleb's daughter, as his wife (15:16–17); and (3) Achsah's bold request of her father (15:18–19). Among the account's striking features is the insistent repetition of the verb "to give" (Hb. *natan*), found seven times in the space of these few verses and giving a heavy hint of the story's central theme.

<span id="page-453-1"></span>15:13–15 The account begins with a reprise of the traditions concerning Caleb, recounted at greater length in 14:6–15, picking out Caleb's membership in the

<sup>114</sup> On these and other issues arising in these verses see the treatment by Heidi M. Szpek, "Achsah's Story: A Metaphor for Societal Transition," *AUSS* 40/2 (2002): 245–256. For the intricate legal problems cf. Joseph Fleishman, "A Daughter's Demand and a Father's Compliance: The Legal Background to Achsah's Claim and Caleb's Agreement (Joshua 15,16–19; Judges 1,12–15)," *ZAW* 118 (2006): 354–373.

<span id="page-454-1"></span>tribe of Judah, his coming into holding the property of Hebron through the word of the Lord, and his defeat of the Anakim, here with the additional detail of the names of the three "sons," that is, descendants, of Anak. The preservation of this tradition adds a further note of antiquity to the ancient origins of the Anakim (cf. comment on 14:15).115 With Hebron secured, Caleb turns his attention to Debir (also named here as "Kiriath-sepher") and its inhabitants. Debir was one of the cities included in the southern campaign, the last of those said to have been defeated by "Joshua and all Israel" (10:38).116

<span id="page-454-8"></span><span id="page-454-2"></span><span id="page-454-0"></span>15:16–17 Persisting with the older name of "Kiriath-sepher," presumably the name by which the city was known to Caleb, Caleb's challenge goes out that the one who captures this city will be given Achsah, his daughter, "as wife." The narrator offers no clues as to why Caleb's sons do not continue the work of their father (cf. 1 Chron. 2:42–50; 4:15). Perhaps for this reason Caleb puts forward Achsah as the incentive to achieve two prizes: that land and this wife. The challenge he proposes carries an element of risk: "whoever" strikes and captures Kiriath-sepher could be anyone, and the feat is no guarantee of a worthy husband for his daughter. So Caleb's strategy strikes modern readers with an element of offense. His daughter appears to be commodified, dangled as a prize for a feat of derring-do. But Bronze Age fathers lacked modern scruples, and, in God's mercy, some good can come from a particular evil. Achsah, for her part, puts up no objection but rather, as will be seen, takes initiatives of her own to make the very best of the situation.

<span id="page-454-3"></span>In any event, Othniel rises to the challenge and is given Achsah as his wife. He is the "son of Kenaz, the brother of Caleb" (Josh. 15:17), and seems to be made of the same stuff not only in terms of military prowess but also in his devotion to the Lord, as his exemplary judgeship implies (Judg. 3:9–10).

<span id="page-454-7"></span><span id="page-454-5"></span><span id="page-454-4"></span>15:18–19 In the third phase of the story Achsah herself comes into the foreground. Like Rahab, the book's most prominent female character, she takes on an active, even bold, role and is not content to remain passive. She may appear even more bold than most English versions imply.117 A bare rendering of the first part of Joshua 15:18 would read simply "When she came," with "to him" being supplied in translation. The supplied phrase anticipates the pronoun used with the following verb, "She urged *him* to ask her father." In this rendering she appears to be prodding Othniel to seek "a field" from her father. That the one who rose to the challenge of capturing Kiriath-sepher needs such prompting seems out of character, and is not required by the Hebrew. A different, and perhaps preferable, way of translating verse 18a would be, "When she arrived, she prodded him [i.e., Caleb] by asking her

<span id="page-454-6"></span><sup>115</sup> Cf. Hess, *Joshua*, 33. Hess identifies these as Hurrian names, attesting to the mixed population in the region.

<sup>116</sup> Now commonly identified with Khirbet Rabûd, about 8 miles (13 km) southwest of Hebron. Cf. Junkkaala, *Three Conquests of Canaan*, 240.

<sup>117</sup> The translation issues are treated in detail by Paul G. Mosca, "Who Seduced Whom? A Note on Joshua 15:18//Judges 1:14," *CBQ* 46/1 (1984): 18–22.

<span id="page-455-9"></span>father for a field." The verb "urged" (or "prodded") represents a verbal form of the Hebrew root *swt*, which typically has a negative connotation: "incited" (e.g., 2 Sam. 24:1; 1 Kings 21:25), "allured" (e.g., Job 36:16), or even "mislead" (e.g., Isa. 36:18). It is not necessary to attribute some deceptive intent to Achsah here; the sense is that she is required to use persuasive speech to move Caleb, seemingly against his will. Caleb responds with a terse, pointed question whose tone is difficult to discern, let alone capture in translation. There is no verb used, and perhaps the closest English idiom would be "What's with you?"

<span id="page-455-3"></span>The clustering in Joshua 15:19 of four of the seven uses of the verb "give" in this short story brings matters to a head. The landholdings already in Othniel's possession appear to be inadequate as productive, arable land. Achsah's request, then, is to be given "springs118 of water." Just as Rahab had sought a future for herself and her family, so too Achsah ensures that her possession with Othniel will contain the means to sustain life and to flourish. Caleb for his part responds generously, whether goaded into action by Achsah's persuasion or recognizing the shortcomings of the land he had gifted, providing two springs in response to Achsah's bold intervention.119 The daughter, like her father, ensures she settles well.

<span id="page-455-4"></span><span id="page-455-2"></span>15:20–62 With the account of Caleb, Othniel, and Achsah completed, the text returns to the settlement of the "people of Judah" (vv. 12, 20) as a whole. Attention is now given to the "cities with their villages" in which Judah settles. The description reads as a straightforwardly administrative account, and it falls into regular patterns. It moves district by district, each concluding with a summary total of cities. The districts are arranged into two roughly equivalent south-to-north panels, with verses 21–44 on Judah's western side (toward the Mediterranean) and verses 48–62 on the eastern side (toward the Jordan River). The pattern breaks in verses 45–47, in which Ekron, Ashdod, and Gaza fall outside any named district, lack a summary total, and appear to demarcate the north and west extremities of the tribal allotment.

<span id="page-455-7"></span><span id="page-455-6"></span><span id="page-455-5"></span><span id="page-455-1"></span>What are we to make of this remarkably full inventory of Judahite towns? As with the account of the borders in verses 1–12, there seems to be some significance in the attention to these details beyond a simple provision of data. The numbers are not provided for purposes of administration and accounting alone. The total of the cities tabulated in the summaries is 112 (excluding the three exceptions in vv. 45–47, which would bring the number to 115). Perhaps surprisingly, this total equals the number of cities enumerated for the rest of the tribes combined. Given that the number of cities named and the numbers given in total in the summaries do not always match, the summary numbers would seem to be intentionally balanced. Judah's regional holdings match those of the rest of the tribes combined.

<span id="page-455-8"></span><span id="page-455-0"></span><sup>118</sup> Hebrew *gullot* is used only here and in the parallel passage in Judges 1:15 ("springs"), for which the normal Hebrew word is *ʿayin* (e.g., Ex. 15:27). The word usually refers to a basin or bowl, so possibly Achsah's request is more for "pools of water" than "springs"; alternatively, the language of her request may be associated with the names of the water features, the "upper" and "lower" *gullot*.

<sup>119</sup> If the identification of Khirbet Rabûd with Debir/Kiriath-sepher is sustained, the account of its two nearby wells is striking. Cf. Moshe Kochavi, "Khirbet Rabûd = Debir," *TA* 1/1 (1974): 2–3, 29–30.

<span id="page-456-8"></span><span id="page-456-7"></span>15:63 Having lavished so much attention on what Judah does possess, the text ends on a somewhat somber note, meticulously recording a significant city, Jerusalem, and its inhabitants, the Jebusites, who could not be dispossessed. This skews the border (15:8) and blots the account of Judah's otherwise remarkable achievement. Jerusalem awaits a later moment, and Israel's greatest king, to be integrated into Judah as the national capital (2 Sam. 5:6–10).

#### <span id="page-456-11"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-456-1"></span>This lengthy, and for the most part administrative, account may make for tedious reading, but it contains matters of significance nonetheless. The bulk of the chapter maps in words the tribal borders and then adds a detailed inventory of its civic holdings. Together these convey the significance of Judah's settlement, reflected also in the priority of this account's coming first of all. Judah's borders echo in certain respect the boundaries of the Promised Land as a whole, and internally its provision is a match for the rest of the tribes combined. Judah's preeminence among the twelve tribes has been growing ever since the Joseph narrative, when its patriarch learns the meaning of repentance (Genesis 38) and demonstrates a remarkable transformation of character, developing from a leader in rage (Gen. 37:26–27) to the one prepared to sacrifice his life for the sake of his father and youngest brother (Gen. 44:18–34). In Jacob's blessing, Judah is accorded a striking and quasi-royal prominence (Gen. 49:8–12). In the wilderness encampment Judah is listed first (Num. 2:3) and sets out on march first (Num. 2:9). The account of Judah's allotment thus joins in this trajectory, as it will be Judah from which Israel's great king, chosen by Yahweh as a man "after his own heart" (1 Sam. 13:14; cf. Acts 13:22), shall also come. In a sense, Judah is here presented as a nation in embryo.

<span id="page-456-13"></span><span id="page-456-10"></span><span id="page-456-6"></span><span id="page-456-5"></span><span id="page-456-4"></span><span id="page-456-3"></span><span id="page-456-2"></span><span id="page-456-0"></span>Judah is also exemplary among the tribes as the only one of which it is said that it initiates with Joshua the giving of its allotment (Josh. 14:6), and that initiative is immediately paired with the request of Caleb to be granted his own settlement (14:6–12). What Judah does as a tribe thus finds its outstanding example in Caleb, and this continues into the narrative here. The embedding here of the account of Caleb, Othniel, and especially Achsah may seem odd, but it serves to root the national story in the lives of individuals, much as has been seen positively in Rahab and negatively in Achan in the preceding chapters. Although the brief vignette has for the careful reader a hint of frisson: Who will win Achsah in marriage? What is bothering Achsah? How will Caleb respond to her request? Both Othniel's responsiveness and Achsah's boldness bring the story to a satisfying conclusion. As is often remarked, this is a story of settling well, and it thus stands as a mute rebuke to other members of Israel that they do not seek such a settlement.

<span id="page-456-12"></span><span id="page-456-9"></span>It was not without its risks, of course. Caleb's dramatic challenge anticipates that of a later father, Jephthah, who makes a rash vow that leads not to ensuring his daughter's life but rather to her (implied) death (Judg. 11:30–31, 34–40). On Achsah's side, her briefly prominent role portrays her very much as the "excellent wife" (Hb. *ʾeshet hayil*) of Proverbs 31:10–31, actively taking initiative to provide <span id="page-457-3"></span>for her household in all circumstances as one who "considers a field and buys it" (Prov. 31:16). Modern readers may have qualms about how she comes to be a wife, but her actions in that role depict her as the female counterpart of her father.

<span id="page-457-1"></span><span id="page-457-0"></span>If there is a hint of warning in Caleb's rash vow, it is amplified in the two notices in this account of Jerusalem and of Judah's failure to take it (Josh. 15:8, 63). The superficial comparison between the books of Joshua, in which everything goes right, and Judges, in which it all goes wrong, can often be shown to be not only facile but misleading. The way the narrator has framed this best of the tribal allotment accounts demonstrates an acute eye, not only on the successes among God's people but on those lingering failures that will develop in such destructive ways as they are left to fester. These, then, are the narrator's stage whispers—quiet enough that we might miss them, loud enough that they should be heeded.

### <span id="page-457-2"></span>JOSHUA 16:1–17:18

16 The allotment of the people of Joseph went from the Jordan by Jericho, east of the waters of Jericho, into the wilderness, going up from Jericho into the hill country to Bethel. **2**Then going from Bethel to Luz, it passes along to Ataroth, the territory of the Archites. **3**Then it goes down westward to the territory of the Japhletites, as far as the territory of Lower Beth-horon, then to Gezer, and it ends at the sea.

**<sup>4</sup>**The people of Joseph, Manasseh and Ephraim, received their inheritance.

**<sup>5</sup>**The territory of the people of Ephraim by their clans was as follows: the boundary of their inheritance on the east was Ataroth-addar as far as Upper Beth-horon, **<sup>6</sup>** and the boundary goes from there to the sea. On the north is Michmethath. 1The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-458-0"></span>The general south-to-north pattern in Joshua continues, as the settlement accounts move from the leading tribe of the south, Judah, to the leading "tribe" of the north, Joseph. A shared southern border is first plotted (16:1–3) before respective

<span id="page-459-9"></span><span id="page-459-8"></span><span id="page-459-5"></span><span id="page-459-1"></span>allotments are described, first Ephraim (16:5–10) then Manasseh (17:1–13), following their order of precedence rather than birth (cf. Gen. 48:14–20). Manasseh's account has embedded within it the conclusion to the record of the inheritance mandated for Zelophehad's daughters (Josh. 17:3–6), providing an echo of the Judah account of the land that went with Achsah in her marriage to Othniel (15:18–19). As the passage begins with "Joseph," so it ends (17:14–18), albeit on a querulous note, as Joshua is called upon to enlarge their portion. On the whole, there is much less detail provided for Ephraim and Manasseh than for Judah's settlement, but this will be the case for each of the tribes moving forward.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-459-6"></span>16:1–3 Only one boundary line for "Joseph" is described in these verses, the one partially shared by Ephraim and Manasseh. As was the case with the account of Judah's borders, the starting point for mapping territory is located near the juncture of the Jordan River and the Dead Sea. Here this happens to coincide with the point of entry of Israel into the Promised Land, narrated in chapters 3–4. From this point an undulating line is drawn westward to the Mediterranean coast.

<span id="page-459-7"></span><span id="page-459-4"></span>16:4 In spite of the clear precedence that Ephraim achieved over Manasseh, the order in which they are mentioned varies. The two census accounts in Numbers both introduce the sibling tribes as "Joseph" (Num. 1:32–35; 26:28–37), with Ephraim first in the earlier record but Manasseh first in the later one. Over the wilderness period Manasseh has also grown more numerous than Ephraim (cf. table 2.4)

<span id="page-460-6"></span>16:5–9 The boundaries of Ephraim are plotted in a somewhat irregular fashion and are also left fairly notional. The first line roughly evokes the southern boundary already mapped in verses 1–3 (vv. 5–6a). Michmethath is then identified as the point marking the northernmost extent of Ephraim's territory; it appears to be just to the southeast of Shechem, perhaps 5 miles (8 km) or so. From this point the next line is drawn north-to-south, parallel to the Jordan River, terminating near Jericho (vv. 6b–7). The account then returns to the environs of Michmethath, as Tappuah lies southwest of it, and from this point a trajectory is plotted to the Mediterranean (v. 8a). The summary of verses 8b–9 provides no numeric tallies of cities and towns in Ephraimite possession.

<span id="page-460-9"></span><span id="page-460-8"></span><span id="page-460-7"></span>16:10 Just as the Judah record concluded with the note that Jerusalem lay beyond its control, so too the city of Gezer—an ancient and prominent toponym—continues to belong to Canaanites, who are nonetheless "made to do forced labor." Gezer comes under Israelite control in the biblical record as dowry to Solomon at his marriage with the daughter of the king of Egypt (1 Kings 3:1; 9:16).

<span id="page-460-13"></span><span id="page-460-10"></span><span id="page-460-0"></span>17:1–2 The turn to Manasseh brings with it in the first instance attention to people rather than place. The rest of the tribal accounts each include the phrase "by their clans," with small variations on a few occasions, but only in the case of Manasseh is any attention devoted to the identity of these clans. Two possible reasons may be suggested. Machir's origins go back to Egypt (Gen. 50:23) and during Moses' time achieved as a clan its settlement west of the Jordan in the Gilead, the region to the west of the Jordan for most of the extent between the Dead Sea and the Sea of Galilee (Num. 32:39–40). Machir, described as a "man of war," appears to be analogous to Caleb. The second reason is the close associations with Zelophehad (cf. 1 Chron. 7:14–15), whose daughters play a significant role in Numbers and whose story concludes in Joshua 17:3–6. Thus the opening verses of the Manasseh settlement account link the portions of the tribe on both sides of the Jordan.

<span id="page-460-14"></span><span id="page-460-12"></span><span id="page-460-11"></span><span id="page-460-5"></span><span id="page-460-4"></span><span id="page-460-3"></span><span id="page-460-2"></span><span id="page-460-1"></span>17:3–6 The daughters of Zelophehad appear twice in the book of Numbers (Num. 27:1–11; 36:1–12). The very distribution of these episodes is significant for the structure of Numbers: they bracket the last section of the book, following on from the second census (Numbers 26) to the book's conclusion. Together, then, they frame the latter portion of the book, which moves toward settlement in the Promised Land, with the initiatives of these women, who deliberately seek an inheritance and memorial for sonless Zelophehad. It is a rare example of case law establishing a precedent for female inheritance in biblical law. As in the account of Caleb (cf. Josh. 14:9), in the present context a decision of the Lord delivered through Moses comes to be ratified by Joshua and, in this case, Eleazar (17:4)—and, as with Achsah (15:18–19), involves female characters. But these sisters' case differs from Achsah's, whose property comes through marriage and does not establish a legal precedent. On the other hand, both texts in their different ways highlight the initiative taken by women in Israel to achieve a lasting settlement. In practical terms, this conclusion to the notices of Zelophehad's daughters explains explicitly the reasons for settlement of these clans within the tribe of Manasseh on both sides of the Jordan (17:5).

<span id="page-461-7"></span><span id="page-461-6"></span><span id="page-461-5"></span><span id="page-461-4"></span>17:7–13 The territory of Manasseh west of the Jordan is described with some economy: shared borders are referred to by tribe, and the care in plotting precise demarcations declines—or the information available to the historian diminishes. Again the overall movement is from south to north, with verse 7a marking the extremities of its reach, but from Asher in the north to Michmethath in the south. The southern border is drawn from east to west in verses 7b–10, with the northern border described only in terms of the neighboring tribes to its north, Asher and Issachar. Verse 11 provides some inventory of cities of settlement, but verse 12 sounds the increasingly familiar note that Canaanites remain, beyond the power of Manasseh to dispossess. Like Ephraim in 16:10, Manasseh comes to subject these remaining Canaanites to forced labor (17:13).

<span id="page-461-15"></span><span id="page-461-13"></span><span id="page-461-12"></span><span id="page-461-11"></span><span id="page-461-10"></span><span id="page-461-9"></span><span id="page-461-8"></span><span id="page-461-3"></span><span id="page-461-1"></span>17:14–18 Israel came into a land to inhabit "great and good cities that you did not build" and to enjoy "vineyards and olive trees that you did not plant" (Deut. 6:10–12). That expectation appears to lie behind the complaint that the tribes of Joseph bring to Joshua. The initial complaint is over lack of space for so numerous a people (17:14). Joshua's solution is to spur them on to clearing forested (uncultivated) land and so provide for their many inhabitants (v. 15). Joseph sees a problem here: the hill country is rejected as being insufficient, which leads to a second complaint. They observe that the Canaanites living in the cities of the coastal plain have superior military technology, "chariots of iron," and are unassailable (v. 16; cf. 1 Sam. 13:19–21). Joshua shows no sympathy either for the complaint or for the line of reasoning presented (Josh. 17:17–18). What is regarded by the Joseph tribes as unfit for settlement, the "hill country," Joshua reckons as suitable for the effort of clearing and cultivation, giving them the space they desire within the boundaries of the allotment assigned to them. Nor does the supposed might of the Canaanites impress Joshua at all; as might be expected of this warrior, Joshua retains his confidence in the capacity of Israel to dispossess the Canaanites, as he has believed from the beginning (Num. 14:6–9).

#### <span id="page-461-14"></span><span id="page-461-0"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-461-2"></span>Correspondences are evident between the account of the Joseph settlement and that of Judah in Joshua 15, despite their even more marked differences. Machir and the daughters of Zelophehad evoke in a different, more muted register the dynamics of Caleb and Achsah. In spite of great gains, both cases display lingering failure, potentially sowing seeds of later damaging developments.

The most important reflections on the initiative of the daughters of Zelophehad belong to the book of Numbers, as indicated above. Still, they are here for a reason and are a further reminder of a long faithfulness in seeking God's best for God's people. It is their initiative that occasions a development in the law of Israel.

Such developments take place in later times, too, as situations arise for which the guidelines for faithful living appear to be opaque. On this third occasion of seeing the results of bold actions on the part of female characters in Joshua—so on every such occasion, then—the outcome works good for God's people. In the case of these seven daughters it is the impulse to justice that leads to their favorable settlement—and not only for them but for women similarly circumstanced who will come after them.

<span id="page-462-3"></span><span id="page-462-2"></span><span id="page-462-1"></span><span id="page-462-0"></span>A different trajectory is also at work in the final scenario of this Ephraim/ Manasseh account (Josh. 17:14–18). The only places that "blessing" is mentioned in the allotment accounts are with Caleb's being "blessed" from Joshua when he receives his inheritance (14:13), in Achsah's request to Caleb, to which he responds with generosity (15:19), and in the initial complaint of the Joseph tribes to Joshua (17:14). There is an element of irony here. The complaints show, on the one hand, a desire for the kind of settlement that would allow for flourishing, perhaps like that of Othniel and Achsah, only now on the level of the tribe rather than the clan or household. On the other hand, the complaint arises out of simple dissatisfaction and an unwillingness to apply themselves to achieving goals already in their grasp if they would only spend some effort to realize them. Once again, in a book with so much to celebrate, only a superficial reading would overlook elements such as this that anticipate, and in some way lay the foundation for, the scenes found in the opening chapters of Judges.

### <span id="page-462-4"></span>JOSHUA 18:1–10

18 Then the whole congregation of the people of Israel assembled at Shiloh and set up the tent of meeting there. The land lay subdued before them.

**2**There remained among the people of Israel seven tribes whose inheritance had not yet been apportioned. **<sup>3</sup>** So Joshua said to the people of Israel, "How long will you put off going in to take possession of the land, which the Lord, the God of your fathers, has given you? **4**Provide three men from each tribe, and I will send them out that they may set out and go up and down the land. They shall write a description of it with a view to their inheritances, and then come to me. **5**They shall divide it into seven portions. Judah shall continue in his territory on the south, and the house of Joseph shall continue in their territory on the north. **6**And you shall describe the land in seven divisions and bring the description here to me. And I will cast lots for you here before the Lord our God. **7**The Levites have no portion among you, for the priesthood of the Lord is their heritage. And Gad and Reuben and half the tribe of Manasseh have received their inheritance beyond the Jordan eastward, which Moses the servant of the Lord gave them."

<span id="page-463-6"></span>**<sup>8</sup>** So the men arose and went, and Joshua charged those who went to write the description of the land, saying, "Go up and down in the land and write a description and return to me. And I will cast lots for you here before the Lord in Shiloh." **<sup>9</sup>** So the men went and passed up and down in the land and wrote in a book a description of it by towns in seven divisions. Then they came to Joshua to the camp at Shiloh, **<sup>10</sup>** and Joshua cast lots for them in Shiloh before the Lord. And there Joshua apportioned the land to the people of Israel, to each his portion.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-463-4"></span><span id="page-463-3"></span>This brief but significant episode serves as the transition point in the account of the tribal settlements in chapters 13–21 (cf. Overview of 13:1–21:45). Without any fanfare the narrator relocates the main Israelite camp from Gilgal to Shiloh (18:1) and observes that seven tribes remain without land (v. 2). Joshua upbraids these tribes for dallying in the settlement process, outlining a plan for allocating a territory to each: tribal representatives will undertake a land survey and propose seven divisions (vv. 3–7). On the basis of this work Joshua will make the final assignments "before the Lord in Shiloh" (v. 8). A taut summary (vv. 9–10) reports that it was done.

<span id="page-463-7"></span><span id="page-463-5"></span>In spite of their fairly pedestrian appearance, these few verses mark a significant staging post in the move to Shiloh, draw into prominence the involvement of Yahweh in this final stage of land allotment, and signal a transition away from the primarily military nature of the settlement as it has been experienced up to this point.

- 2. Arranging Allotments for the Seven Remaining Tribes (18:2–10)

	- b. Joshua's Challenge to the Seven Tribes (18:3–7)

	- d. Joshua Apportions the Land for the Remaining Tribes (18:9–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-463-2"></span><span id="page-463-1"></span><span id="page-463-0"></span>18:1 Ever since Israel crossed the Jordan River and entered the Promised Land (chs. 3–4), its base of operations has been the camp at Gilgal, near Jericho (4:19). There the people made themselves fit to occupy the land gifted to them by God (5:9, 10). To Gilgal they returned after the main regional military campaigns (10:15, 43), and from Gilgal the first distribution of tribal settlements took place (14:6). But Gilgal was only ever meant to be a temporary staging post as Israel gained a foothold in the land—a border outpost in a marginal zone.

<span id="page-464-7"></span>With Israel now well established in the land, even if not fully settled, a new and more geographically central location becomes the place of convocation. Shiloh is a sensible choice: located 11 miles (18 km) south of Shechem, in Ephraim, it is roughly in the middle of the major Judah/Joseph territories already allotted. This relocation is not simply practical, however. The notice that here Israel "set up the tent of meeting" provides the first of only two references to the tabernacle in the book of Joshua; the other reference (19:51) brackets this second phase of settlement. With Jerusalem playing no special role in the book—it is still a Canaanite enclave (15:63)—Shiloh is not only a geographical center but a religious one as well. Later tradition understands Shiloh to be the place of God's "dwelling" among his people (Ps. 78:60), and as late as the time of Jeremiah it is still remembered as the place "where I made my name dwell at first" (Jer. 7:12).120 Although the reference here is brief and understated, the impact made on the social memory of Israel is deep and lasting.

<span id="page-464-10"></span><span id="page-464-9"></span><span id="page-464-4"></span><span id="page-464-1"></span>The last clause of this deceptively simple verse likewise signals something of significance: "The land lay subdued before them." There will be no further military campaigns in the book. Although the settlements of Judah and Joseph entailed some military activity, such is absent from the account of the settling of the seven remaining tribes. The practice of *kherem* was last mentioned when the regional campaigns in the north came to a close (11:21), and from the land distribution at Shiloh forward warfare of any kind does not feature in Israelite settlement. Does Israel no longer seek to dispossess the Canaanites? Is there no further resistance? Or is the land now understood to be empty? The book of Joshua does not give an explicit answer to these questions, although Judges provides some further perspective on them and inclines toward the first of these explanations. Here, however, the notice that "the land lay subdued before them" implies its full subjugation. This same language was used by Moses as the condition that would release the Transjordan tribes from military service to return to their own settlements (Num. 32:22, 29). Likewise it forms part of David's encouragement to Solomon that he will enjoy the prospect of peace in which to construct the temple (1 Chron. 22:18). The verse marks not only geographic and religious transitions but a military transition as well.

<span id="page-464-8"></span><span id="page-464-5"></span><span id="page-464-3"></span><span id="page-464-2"></span><span id="page-464-0"></span>18:2 Of the "nine and one-half tribes" (Josh. 14:2) to settle west of the Jordan, only two and a half have received their territorial allotment; seven remain. Both tribal groups of "two and one-half" (14:3), east and west of the Jordan, that have already settled will be mentioned in Joshua's speech that follows. This provides a further balance, then, in the literary presentation of the tribal settlements.

<span id="page-464-6"></span>18:3–7 Joshua's opening gambit to the seven tribes has been called "more motivational than accusatory,"121 but the chiding tone is difficult to suppress. In "How long will you *put off*," the Hebrew has *mitrappim*; this form of the verb *raphah* is

<sup>120</sup> Shiloh was destroyed in the eleventh century, so it did not serve this function for long. Cf. John Day, "The Destruction of the Shiloh Sanctuary and Jeremiah vii 12, 14," in S*tudies in the Historical Books of the Old Testament*, ed. J. A. Emerton, SVT 30 (Leiden: Brill, 1979), 87–94. 121 Nelson, *Joshua*, 210.

<span id="page-465-11"></span><span id="page-465-3"></span><span id="page-465-1"></span>used elsewhere only in Proverbs 18:9 and 24:10, both to do with the deleterious effects of laziness (some English translations offer "slack" here) and carrying also the sense of a lack of courage. Some sense of rebuke—much as Joshua himself received from the Lord in Joshua 13:1—would be felt in such a charge. Added to this is the way in which Joshua refers to the land as having been gifted by "the Lord, the God of your fathers." This precise designation of Israel's covenant God is the one used after the revelation of the divine name in Exodus 3:15–16; it is used eight times in Deuteronomy, typically with reference to God's promises of land in particular and, of these, twice precisely with the responsibility to take the land (Deut. 1:21; 4:1). It is used only here in Joshua, and once again in Judges 2:12 in conjunction with Israel's apostasy. Referring to the land as God's gift in this way emphasizes the lax attitude of the seven remaining tribes.

<span id="page-465-5"></span><span id="page-465-2"></span>Joshua's plan involves tribal representatives' mapping the remaining territory into seven divisions and submitting the boundary descriptions to Joshua, who will "cast lots . . . before the Lord" (cf. comment on 14:1–5) and so assign them to these tribes. Joshua also confirms the territories of those who have already received land in their two sets—Judah and Joseph to the west of the Jordan in the familiar south/north order and the two and a half tribes to the east—and once again excludes the tribe of Levi from receiving an inheritance.

<span id="page-465-10"></span>18:8–10 The survey is undertaken, the representatives return, and Joshua apportions the divisions to the tribes. No time frame is placed on these activities by the narrator. The issue now is not how long they took but that the task is undertaken and completed.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-465-0"></span>An intriguing connection has often been observed between the way this passage begins, that the "land [*ʾerets*] lay subdued [*nikbeshah*] before them" (v. 1), and the creation mandate in Genesis 1:28, "fill the earth [*ʾerets*] and subdue it [*kibshuha*]." Both use forms of the verb *kabash* with reference to the *ʾerets* ("earth/land"). Although the resonance between these two texts is subtle, it is suggestive. The creation intention that God's human creatures should be stewards of a flourishing natural world finds a partial fulfillment in Israel as the curators of the Land of Promise—and, with the relocation of the tabernacle in the same moment, there is, as in the garden, a meeting place for God and his people.

<span id="page-465-9"></span><span id="page-465-8"></span><span id="page-465-7"></span><span id="page-465-6"></span><span id="page-465-4"></span>Two words recur with some frequency through these ten verses, both of which are names: "Shiloh" is named four times (Josh. 18:1, 8, 9, 10) and Yahweh (= "Lord") six times (18:3, 6, 7 [2x], 8, 10). The former has been discussed above; the latter deserves some notice too by way of response. Yahweh featured at various points in the preceding land allotment in chapters 14–17, in particular in connection with Caleb's settlement (e.g., 14:6, 8, 12), but also with Zelophehad's daughters (17:4) and the wider tribes of Joseph (17:14). As the account of the assignment of the portions to the seven remaining tribes unfolds, such references are conspicuous <span id="page-466-2"></span>by their absence; Yahweh will not be named again until the brief report of Joshua's own settlement in 19:50 and in the final summary of this section in 19:51 (cf. comment there). God remains involved in this distribution, but his contribution is contained in the actions taken at Shiloh: God has gifted the land, and the casting of lots is done "before the Lord" (18:6, 8, 10). Thus God has directed; it remains for his people to act on that direction.

<span id="page-466-0"></span>Three elements thus come together in this brief but pivotal passage: land "subdued," divine direction given, and work yet still to be done. Victory has been won, but the task remains incomplete. There is a call here for the perseverance of the saints. John Piper reflects on reasons Christians "might grow weary of the battle and consider giving up on Christianity." As an encouragement, he points to the fact that

the victory is assured. Our assurance is not destroyed by the demands for endurance. The key to assurance is not to eliminate the biblical commands for endurance, but rather to magnify grace as a future power to believe, as well as a past pardon for sin."122

This is the situation in which Israel finds itself here, poised in the midst of coming into the inheritance it has received as God's gift but as a nation not yet having found rest. For the Christian the terms are shifted, but the dynamic is the same. God has given, the victory is won, and there is still work yet to do. This is well summed up in 2 Peter 1:3–5 (cf. v. 10):

<span id="page-466-3"></span>His divine power has granted [*dedōrēmenēs*, perfect tense] to us all things that pertain to life and godliness . . . he has granted [*dedōrētai*, perfect tense] to us his precious and very great promises. . . . For this very reason, make every effort . . .

### <span id="page-466-1"></span>JOSHUA 18:11–19:51

1See 15:9; Hebrew *westward* 2Septuagint; Hebrew *to the shoulder over against the Arabah* 3Septuagint, Syriac, Vulgate; Hebrew *the Jebusite* 4Hebrew *Gibeath* 5Septuagint; Hebrew *Kiriath* 6Compare Septuagint; Hebrew *Mehebel*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-469-4"></span><span id="page-469-0"></span>In spite of some regularities in the settlement accounts in Joshua 15–17, no stable formula was established for reporting the districts into which the tribes moved. Likewise here there is some similarity between accounts, especially relating to city inventories, but considerable variation in the reports of apportioning of territories to these seven remaining tribes. Boundary lines are described with sometimes more, sometimes less, detail, sometimes preceded by city inventories, sometimes followed by them (and in the case of Asher, both). The "lot" is chosen first for Benjamin (18:11–28), and the report of its territory most closely resembles those of Judah and Joseph from the Gilgal distribution. Its account is by far the longest of the remaining tribes. Then follow the reports concerning Simeon (19:1–9), Zebulun (19:10–16), Issachar (19:17–23), Asher (19:24–31), and Naphtali (19:32–39), with the last of the remaining seven, Dan (19:40–48), involving something of an odd case of failed inheritance. Following the typical pattern, the sequence moves roughly from south to north; Dan, although initially allocated land in the central western region, finally settles as the northernmost tribe of all.

#### <span id="page-469-9"></span><span id="page-469-8"></span><span id="page-469-7"></span>*Section Outline*

II.G. Territories and Cities of the Seven Remaining Tribes (18:11–19:51)

- 1. The Settlement of Benjamin (18:11–28)
- 2. The Settlement of Simeon (19:1–9)
- 3. The Settlement of Zebulun (19:10–16)
- 4. The Settlement of Issachar (19:17–23)
- 5. The Settlement of Asher (19:24–31)
- 6. The Settlement of Naphtali (19:32–39)
- 7. The Settlement of Dan (19:40–48)
- 8. Joshua's Portion (19:49–50)
- 9. The Settlement from Shiloh Concluded (19:51)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-469-6"></span><span id="page-469-5"></span><span id="page-469-3"></span><span id="page-469-2"></span><span id="page-469-1"></span>18:11–28 Benjamin is a Rachel tribe, à la the Joseph tribes (Ephraim and the halftribe of Manasseh), who settled in chapters 16–17. The lot places Benjamin on Judah's northern border. As in the earlier accounts, especially that of Judah, a very full description of boundary lines is provided here (18:11–20), including a repeat of the boundary shared with Judah, already recounted in chapter 15. A list follows of cities incorporated into the district (18:21–28). One of the striking features of this account is the way in which the holdings of Benjamin and Judah are seen to interpenetrate, even though the division of land seems clear. Verse 14 describes Kiriath-jearim as within Benjamin's territory, but its civic membership lies with Judah. Similarly, "Jebus (that is, Jerusalem)," falling just outside Judah's border in 15:8; 18:16 and so belonging to Benjamin, nonetheless seems to be associated with Judah. These anomalies are registered without further comment or evaluative judgment from the narrator.

<span id="page-470-3"></span>19:1–39 The accounts of the next five tribal settlements—Simeon, Zebulun, Issachar, Asher, and Naphtali—provide a mix of profiles and strategies of reportage. Simeon is the most unusual, having no defined borders but instead making its home within the territory of Judah, "because the portion of the people of Judah was too large for them" (v. 9). Thus it has a record only of city allocations. With Simeon settled in the south, the rest of this group makes its home to the north of Manasseh's territory, above the Valley of Jezreel.

<span id="page-470-6"></span><span id="page-470-5"></span><span id="page-470-4"></span>19:40–48 The case of the Danites is both the last and the strangest of the tribal settlements—or, rather, nonsettlement. After the lot assigns to them a territory with cities running eastward inland from the environs of Joppa, a brief notice confirms that "the territory of the people of Dan was lost to them" (v. 47a), using the Hebrew idiom *yatsaʾ* ("go out") plus *min* ("from"), sometimes translated "slipped from their grasp" (e.g., JPS). The form of words leaves Dan surprisingly passive in this loss, and no explanation is offered. Dan becomes active in recovering some territory for itself in verse 47b. Its new home is in the far north, opposite Mount Hermon, and taking it involves military action. This, however, is not part of the post-Shiloh settlement but rather follows sometime later, as the more detailed and troubling—parallel account in Judges makes clear (cf. Judg. 18:1, 7–10).

<span id="page-470-16"></span><span id="page-470-15"></span><span id="page-470-14"></span><span id="page-470-13"></span><span id="page-470-9"></span><span id="page-470-8"></span><span id="page-470-7"></span>19:49–50 The land grant to Caleb by divine promise (14:9–12) and command (Hb. *ʾel pi yhwh*; 15:13) began the account of Israel's settlement, and now the land grant to Joshua by divine command (*ʿal pi yhwh*; 19:50) concludes it. This allocation to Joshua contains something of a role reversal, as now it is the Israelites who give Joshua a portion (v. 49). The same language is used of the "people of Israel" giving Levi its cities (21:3, 8; cf. 1 Chron. 6:64 [6:49 MT]); these are the only occasions in which the people of Israel are said to give anything. This too is a signal that the inheritance is complete and that possession of the land has now, under God, come to Israel.

<span id="page-470-12"></span><span id="page-470-11"></span>As noticed above in relation to Caleb, that faithful warrior has much more attention paid to him than does Joshua here. There is no indication anywhere that Joshua has any family; he is a lone figure, whose life is wholly bound up with his calling to lead God's people into the Land of Promise (cf. comment on 24:14–15). Timnath-serah is roughly 15 miles (24 km) southwest of Shechem and 8 miles (13 km) north of Lower and Upper Beth-horon, on the Ephraimite border. It borders the Valley of Aijalon, where Joshua won a dramatic victory over the Amorites (10:12–14). Joshua's own vigor and initiative may not be as prominent in this pithy notice as Caleb's were in his more expansive accounts, but the note that Joshua "rebuilt the city and settled in it" (19:50) is at least a gesture in that direction.

<span id="page-470-10"></span><span id="page-470-2"></span><span id="page-470-1"></span><span id="page-470-0"></span>19:51 The final summary notice of the activity of Eleazar and Joshua at Shiloh concludes the settlement of the seven remaining tribes (cf. 18:1). Only here is it explicitly recorded that the distribution by "lot" took place "before the Lord, at the entrance of the tent of meeting." This is a precise and significant location. In Exodus 29:42, in the instructions Moses receives from God for the construction of the tabernacle, the "entrance" is designated as the place "where I will meet with you, to speak to you there." And so it proves to be on many occasions. Here the additional detail reinforces the sense that, although God's presence is not a narrative feature of this phase of settlement, said settlement nonetheless takes place in accord with his purpose and plan.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-471-0"></span>The literary shaping of the Shiloh phase of the distribution of the land is clearly signaled in the echoes between Joshua 18:1 and 19:51. The allocation by "lot" and "before the Lord" lends a quasi-prophetic aspect to the proceedings. And yet the narrator has not crafted an idealized picture either of the settlement of the remaining tribes or of the land inheritance of Israel as a whole. If anything, the surface details of this passage imply something like the opposite. Simeon's territory is a nonterritory, a clutch of cities carved out of another tribe's domain. Those tribes settling to the north see their regions only patchily reported. The last of the tribes to settle, Dan, fails to hold its divinely allocated portion and goes rogue, although the narrator here is restrained enough not to put this point too sharply, leaving it to the book of Judges. There is a tension in the crafting of the account in just this form, as we see the provision and aspirations for the ideal infused with the partial and problematic of the real. The vagaries of the literary landscape are resolutely retained. It will take an Ezekiel, centuries later, to reimagine an idealized version. Here Israel inhabits the Land of Promise, its settlement characterized by quirks and defects—yet at the same time the nation is poised to live as the people of God in the place in which he has put them.

### <span id="page-471-1"></span>JOSHUA 20:1–9

20 Then the Lord said to Joshua, **<sup>2</sup>** "Say to the people of Israel, 'Appoint the cities of refuge, of which I spoke to you through Moses, **<sup>3</sup>** that the manslayer who strikes any person without intent or unknowingly may flee there. They shall be for you a refuge from the avenger of blood. **4**He shall flee to one of these cities and shall stand at the entrance of the gate of the city and explain his case to the elders of that city. Then they shall take him into the city and give him a place, and he shall remain with them. **5**And if the avenger of blood pursues him, they shall not give up the manslayer into his hand, because he struck his neighbor unknowingly, and did not hate him in the past. **6**And he shall remain in that city until he has stood before the congregation for judgment, until the death of him who is high priest at the time. Then the manslayer may return to his own town and his own home, to the town from which he fled.' "

<span id="page-472-9"></span>**<sup>7</sup>** So they set apart Kedesh in Galilee in the hill country of Naphtali, and Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim, and Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron) in the hill country of Judah. **8**And beyond the Jordan east of Jericho, they appointed Bezer in the wilderness on the tableland, from the tribe of Reuben, and Ramoth in Gilead, from the tribe of Gad, and Golan in Bashan, from the tribe of Manasseh. **9**These were the cities designated for all the people of Israel and for the stranger sojourning among them, that anyone who killed a person without intent could flee there, so that he might not die by the hand of the avenger of blood, till he stood before the congregation.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-472-1"></span><span id="page-472-0"></span>The first asylum seeker in the Bible was Cain, whose life was preserved by God in his fugitive state (Gen. 4:13–15). A mechanism for regularizing asylum in the case of manslaughter was part of God's plan for the life of his people in the Promised Land as early as Exodus 21:12–14, where "a place" is promised for this purpose and the provision of altar asylum implied. Prior to this moment immediately following Israel's settlement, full statements of the conditions and procedure for city asylum in cases of manslaughter were given at Numbers 35:9–34 and again at Deuteronomy 19:1–13. This passage in Joshua reflects the wording of these earlier texts at certain points. Here the concern is more with the identification of the cities of refuge than with procedure, which receives more attention in the earlier passages, although a brief statement of purpose and legal process is also included.

<span id="page-472-8"></span><span id="page-472-4"></span><span id="page-472-3"></span><span id="page-472-2"></span>Joshua 20:1–6, then, contains the final divine speech to Joshua in the book, comprising direct reminders of the instructions already given to Moses to provide "cities of refuge" (Num. 35:1). Joshua 20:7–8 names three cities on each side of the Jordan. Verse 9 adds a full summary for such a brief passage and includes the further detail that the provision of asylum is for native and sojourner alike.

#### *Section Outline*

- II.H. The Cities of Refuge (20:1–9)
	- 1. God Directs Joshua to Designate Cities for Refuge (20:1–6)
	- 2. The Cities Identified; Summary (20:7–9)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-472-7"></span><span id="page-472-6"></span><span id="page-472-5"></span>20:1 Once again, and for the last time recorded in the book, the Lord addresses Joshua (cf. comments on 1:2; 13:1). For some reason the narrator varies the speech formula: rather than the familiar Hebrew *wayyoʾmer yhwh ʾel* ("and the Lord said to"; e.g., 1:1), these words are introduced by *wayedabber yhwh ʾel* ("the Lord said to"). The more restricted pattern seems to be associated with more strongly directive statements in somewhat stereotyped settings, although no hard and fast distinction can be drawn. Still, the variation of formula sets this divine statement apart from the rest in the book.

<span id="page-473-11"></span><span id="page-473-8"></span>20:2–6 While the Lord addresses Joshua with the reminder of the command earlier given to Moses, the instruction is intended for the "people of Israel," and "they" will make the allocations in verses 7–8. A consistent feature of the provision of the cities of refuge is that eligibility is restricted to manslaughter and thus does not apply to any other form of asylum seeking. The conditions are stated here in verses 3 and 5 and again in the summary of verse 9. They display a notable relationship with the earlier texts (cf. table 2.5).

<span id="page-473-9"></span><span id="page-473-0"></span>TABLE 2.5: Conditions of Manslaughter

<span id="page-473-4"></span><span id="page-473-2"></span>

|                                                     | Numbers | Deuteronomy | Joshua  |
|-----------------------------------------------------|---------|-------------|---------|
| 1. bishegagah = "without intent"                    | 35:11   |             | 20:3, 9 |
| 2. bibli daʿat = "unintentionally"                  |         | 4:42; 19:4  | 20:3    |
| 3. loʾ soneʾ mitemol = "did not<br>previously hate" |         | 4:42; 19:4  | 20:5    |

<span id="page-473-6"></span><span id="page-473-1"></span>Numbers 35 sets out the representative actions that qualify as either murder or manslaughter, while Deuteronomy 19 provides a smaller set of such instances. The summary condition of Numbers 35:11, that the action that occasions death occurred *bishegagah* ("without intent"), is different from simple absence of intent and is close to the restatement of Deuteronomy, that it occurred *bibli daʿat* ("unintentionally") or, in both cases, "unawares." That is, it was purely accidental. The third condition might at first glance appear to be without malice aforethought, but this simply stipulates that the "manslayer" had no previous record of enmity with the deceased.

The process thus ensures that private vengeance does not further pollute the land nor contribute to an escalation of injustice in Israel. It does not assume or ensure the innocence of the one who flees to escape a vendetta killing, but rather ensures that justice will be done when due judicial process has taken place. Somewhat akin the case of Cain, who was protected while wandering, continued and enforced residence in the city of refuge is itself a punishment for causing a neighbor's untimely death—it is a sort of exile.

<span id="page-473-12"></span><span id="page-473-10"></span><span id="page-473-7"></span><span id="page-473-5"></span><span id="page-473-3"></span>20:7–8 The assignment of six cities had previously been commanded by God (Num. 35:13–14; Deut. 19:2, 8–9), and here it is implemented by the people of Israel. The first slate of three cities (Josh. 20:7) comes from among the tribal settlements west of the Jordan and proceeds from north to south, the reverse of the typical pattern in Joshua. Kedesh, in the region of Naphtali, is about 16 miles (26 km) north of the Sea of Galilee. Shechem is centrally located but toward the southern border of Manasseh in the hill country of Ephraim. Hebron is in the south, part of Caleb's inheritance in 14:14. The Transjordan cities (20:8), previously named in Deuteronomy 4:43, are listed from south to north in the manner typical of the book. None of the three has been identified with certainty. Bezer in the "wilderness on the tableland" probably aligns roughly with the north end of the Dead Sea, but some distance to the east. Ramoth in Gilead is in Gad's territory. Joshua 20:1–9 474

In the north, Golan beneath Bashan roughly aligns with the Sea of Galilee, laying some way east.

<span id="page-474-4"></span><span id="page-474-3"></span>20:9 The extended summary includes material from Numbers 35:12, 15, adding the inclusion of the sojourner in the provision of the asylum cities. In ending with these details and repeating the necessity of standing "before the congregation" to receive justice, the narrator accomplishes at least two things: First, this elevates asylum in the newly settled land, emphasizing the practice of justice in the new nation. Second, it signals obedience to the Lord's decree, a running theme in the settlement texts.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-474-2"></span><span id="page-474-1"></span><span id="page-474-0"></span>As noted in the introduction to this passage, Cain is the earliest asylum seeker for homicide, but there is a nearer case: Moses, too, fled to find safety after killing an Egyptian (Ex. 2:11–15). Moses' action was not accidental, but it could qualify for asylum under the "did not previously hate" condition (cf. table 2.5). For him Midian provided refuge and a home for forty years until "the king of Egypt died" (Ex. 2:23), much as the death of the high priest would occasion release for the manslayer here.123 Such cases are now provided for in Israel's landscape. There are as yet no courts, but there is at least the possibility that the life of one who in innocence shed innocent blood would not be taken in wrongful vengeance. In the Genesis account God hears the cry of innocent blood: "The voice of your brother's blood is crying to me from the ground" (Gen. 4:10), and asylum is offered to the killer. The writer to the Hebrews comments on this blood-spoken word in reflecting on the situation of Abel (Heb. 11:4), concluding that Jesus' blood "speaks a better word than the blood of Abel" (Heb. 12:24). Those responsible for Jesus' death are given much greater provision than asylum: for them—for us—there is the possibility of salvation.

### <span id="page-474-7"></span><span id="page-474-6"></span><span id="page-474-5"></span>JOSHUA 21:1–42

21 Then the heads of the fathers' houses of the Levites came to Eleazar the priest and to Joshua the son of Nun and to the heads of the fathers' houses of the tribes of the people of Israel. **2**And they said to them at Shiloh in the land of Canaan, "The Lord commanded through Moses that we be given cities to dwell in, along with their pasturelands for our livestock." **<sup>3</sup>** So by command of the Lord the people of Israel gave to the Levites the following cities and pasturelands out of their inheritance.

<sup>123</sup> Cf. Jonathan P. Burnside, "Exodus and Asylum: Uncovering the Relationship between Biblical Law and Narrative," *JSOT* 34/3 (2010): 250–251, 263.

**<sup>4</sup>**The lot came out for the clans of the Kohathites. So those Levites who were descendants of Aaron the priest received by lot from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, thirteen cities.

**<sup>5</sup>**And the rest of the Kohathites received by lot from the clans of the tribe of Ephraim, from the tribe of Dan and the half-tribe of Manasseh, ten cities.

**<sup>6</sup>**The Gershonites received by lot from the clans of the tribe of Issachar, from the tribe of Asher, from the tribe of Naphtali, and from the half-tribe of Manasseh in Bashan, thirteen cities.

**<sup>7</sup>**The Merarites according to their clans received from the tribe of Reuben, the tribe of Gad, and the tribe of Zebulun, twelve cities.

**<sup>8</sup>**These cities and their pasturelands the people of Israel gave by lot to the Levites, as the Lord had commanded through Moses.

**<sup>9</sup>**Out of the tribe of the people of Judah and the tribe of the people of Simeon they gave the following cities mentioned by name, **10**which went to the descendants of Aaron, one of the clans of the Kohathites who belonged to the people of Levi; since the lot fell to them first. **11**They gave them Kiriath-arba (Arba being the father of Anak), that is Hebron, in the hill country of Judah, along with the pasturelands around it. **12**But the fields of the city and its villages had been given to Caleb the son of Jephunneh as his possession.

pasturelands, and Kartan with its pasturelands—three cities. **33**The cities of the several clans of the Gershonites were in all thirteen cities with their pasturelands.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-476-3"></span><span id="page-476-2"></span><span id="page-476-1"></span>Levi's exclusion from the territorial allotment has been noted throughout the settlement account (cf. comment on 13:14, 33; cf. also Josh. 14:3–4; 18:7). The command to provide cities for Levi to inhabit was given by the Lord through Moses (Numbers 35:2, 6–8). Deuteronomy is subsequently concerned for the care and maintenance of the Levites, who are without their own inheritance (Deut. 10:9; 12:12; 14:27; 18:1), while elsewhere in Numbers attention to the Levites has more to do with their duties and responsibilities. With the land now apportioned among the inheriting tribes, the time has come for Israel to allocate cities for the Levites in accord with the parameters of the command in Numbers 35, attending in particular to the total provision of forty-eight cities. The list here bears a close relationship to that provided in 1 Chronicles 6:54–81 as an appendix to the genealogy of Levi.

<span id="page-476-9"></span><span id="page-476-8"></span><span id="page-476-7"></span><span id="page-476-6"></span><span id="page-476-5"></span><span id="page-476-4"></span><span id="page-476-0"></span>The introduction to the process is framed in Joshua 21:1–3. The assignment of cities to the individual Levitical clans is then summarized in verses 4–7. Verse 8 introduces the detailed breakdown of the identities of the cities given by the inheriting tribes in verses 9–40, still organized by the Levitical clans and in the same order as provided in the summary verses. Verses 41–42 provide a summary conclusion noting the total number of cities as forty-eight, in accordance with God's command.
