#### *Comment*

<span id="page-477-3"></span><span id="page-477-0"></span>21:1–3 The approach of the leaders of the clans of Levi to Eleazar and Joshua in verses 1–2 matches closely the approach of the daughters of Zelophehad in 17:4. On both occasions the time has come to implement divine decision made earlier in the wilderness period. Whereas Zelophehad's daughters receive their inheritance in the Gilgal phase of land settlement, the clan of Levi receives its non-inheritance of cities from Shiloh (v. 2), the explicit naming of that location a reminder of Israel's still new central place of convocation (cf. 19:51).

<span id="page-477-10"></span><span id="page-477-6"></span><span id="page-477-5"></span><span id="page-477-4"></span><span id="page-477-1"></span>21:4–7 It might have been sufficient to move directly to the catalog of cities pertaining to the Levitical clans, but it is delayed while a summary of the divisions and the donating tribes is outlined. This provides a sort of table of contents for the detailed list that follows from verse 9, which remains a helpful overview for later readers. The Kohathites, the subclan of the descendants of Aaron "the priest" (v. 4)—this status being crucial for the position of eminence here—are provided with homes in the environs of Jerusalem, although Jerusalem itself remains outside of Israel's control. The rest of the Kohathites receive their cities along the border to the north of Judah (v. 5). The Gershonites and Merarites are distributed across the northern and Transjordan tribes (vv. 6–7). This leaves the central region remarkably underrepresented, with Shechem (v. 21), one of the cities of refuge, notable among the exceptions.

<span id="page-477-12"></span><span id="page-477-9"></span><span id="page-477-8"></span><span id="page-477-7"></span>21:8–40 The details of this distribution are now provided. The tribal contributions bear a remarkable symmetry:

<span id="page-477-13"></span><span id="page-477-11"></span><span id="page-477-2"></span>One of the most prominent points of relative consensus on the nature of the Levitical Cities List is its fundamentally schematic structure (at least in Joshua 21) that, with a few exceptions, assigns four cities from each tribe. . . . The three exceptions are Judah and Simeon, who are listed together and whose collective contribution adds up to nine cities (Josh. 21:13–16; cf. 1 Chron. 6:[39–41], 42–44), and Naphtali, which donates only three cities (Josh. 21:32 = 1 Chron. 6:61). The overwhelming regularity of this system, in which most of the tribes donate a fixed number of cities (9 tribes × 4 cities = 36) and the other three a commensurate number between them (9 + 3 = 12 cities, averaging 4 apiece), is too obvious to miss.124

<span id="page-478-1"></span>Another feature of note in this scheme is the integration of the cities of refuge among the Levitical cities. This was already incorporated into the command of Moses in Numbers 35:6, that the total number cities for Levi should comprise the six asylum cities, plus a contribution of a further forty-two. Here they appear as Hebron (Josh. 21:13)—the mention of which occasions a detour recalling its assignment to Caleb—Shechem (v. 21), Golan (v. 27), Kedesh (v. 32), Bezer (v. 36), and Ramoth in Gilead (v. 38).

<span id="page-478-7"></span><span id="page-478-6"></span><span id="page-478-5"></span><span id="page-478-4"></span>21:41–42 The language of the summary reverts to that of the introduction to the chapter, providing a sense of closure as well as reinforcing the implication of obedience on Israel's part in carrying through on these civic assignments.

#### *Response*

At least two aspects of this passage are immediately apparent: its ideal schematization and the incorporation of the cities of refuge into the allocation of Levitical cities. Both contribute to the nation building of Israel at the moment of its inception in the Land of Promise.

<span id="page-478-8"></span>In the biblical story Israel has grown from the family of Jacob in Genesis to the nation now settled into the landscape of the patriarchal sojourning. The narrator will reflect on this remarkable moment in the following brief passage, but this designation of cities as a joint project by the twelve settled tribes for the non-inheriting tribe of Levi forges the entire people into one integrated whole. In this context the list of Levitical cities is much more than an administrative record of the kind found in the corresponding passage of 1 Chronicles 6. Here there is a clear narrative context and trajectory, beginning not from the process of settlement in this macrosection of Joshua but all the way back from the promises to Abraham and the election of Israel in the book of Genesis. The close context in the book of Joshua, however, accounts to some degree for the presentation of the city list here. In the first part of the book the Levitical priests bear the ark of God in the midst of the nation (chs. 3–4, 6), and now with their distributed presence they bear still, in a more diffuse way, God's presence among his people, for whom they serve as custodians of spiritual welfare (Ex. 32:29; Num. 8:19; cf. Deut. 10:8).

<span id="page-478-3"></span><span id="page-478-2"></span><span id="page-478-0"></span>If the schematized presentation lends a sense of unity to this new nation, the blending of the cities of asylum with their further civic spaces makes the Levites not only custodians of Israel's spiritual welfare but also to some extent guardians of justice before any other judicial institutions have been established. Whether there is merit to the suggestion that the adjudication of the case of the fugitive

<sup>124</sup> Jeremy M. Hutton, "The Levitical Diaspora (II): Modern Perspectives on the Levitical Cities Lists (A Review of Opinions)," in *Levites and Priests in Biblical History and Tradition*, ed. Mark Leuchter and Jeremy M. Hutton, AIL 9 (Atlanta: SBL, 2011), 60–62.

manslayer had a paradigmatic function,125 this remains a powerful tool for inculcating the deliberation of the community in seeking just outcomes in these cases of death and life. It is not too much of a stretch to see these as leading Israel on a path to discern just outcomes in lesser cases, too.

<span id="page-479-4"></span><span id="page-479-0"></span>The responsibility, provision, and privilege of Levi is connected by Stephen Williams to the designation of Israel in Exodus 19:6 as a "kingdom of priests."126 As the Levitical priesthood was to Israel, so Israel was among the nations. Peter finds in this phrase something that applies to the NT people of God: the identity of the NT church, too, involves being a "royal priesthood" (1 Pet. 2:9). This comes with a purpose: to display the "excellencies of him who called you" to a watching world. The distribution of Levi throughout the territories of Israel and especially at its boundaries sets a suggestive trajectory for the Peter's identification of the church with Israel's "royal priesthood," as it too lives out and attests to a standard of justice and righteousness needed in a world prone to asserting self-seeking rights regardless of the cost to the wider community.

### <span id="page-479-3"></span>JOSHUA 21:43–45

**<sup>43</sup>**Thus the Lord gave to Israel all the land that he swore to give to their fathers. And they took possession of it, and they settled there. **44**And the Lord gave them rest on every side just as he had sworn to their fathers. Not one of all their enemies had withstood them, for the Lord had given all their enemies into their hands. **45**Not one word of all the good promises that the Lord had made to the house of Israel had failed; all came to pass.

#### *Section Oerview*

<span id="page-479-2"></span><span id="page-479-1"></span>The second major section of the book, chapters 13–21, now concludes with a ringing statement of God's faithfulness. In the corresponding passage in this carefully arranged section, 13:1–7, God himself spoke to remind Joshua of the necessity to possess the land, pressing a leader, who was perhaps tired and lingering, into action. Now it is done—and the narrator's summary reflects entirely on the complete faithfulness of Israel's God in fulfilling his promises to his people.

#### *Section Outline*

II.J. God's Promises Fulfilled (21:43–45)

<sup>125</sup> Burnside, "Exodus and Asylum," 262.

<sup>126</sup> Cf. McConville and Williams, *Joshua*, 106–107.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-480-6"></span>21:43 Even in translation the remarkable balance and elusive symmetry of these verses is apparent. The resonances are clear but not complete or mechanical. The first verse combines space (or place; "all the land") with time ("their fathers"). It combines divine action ("the Lord gave") with human action in response ("they took possession . . . they settled").

<span id="page-480-10"></span><span id="page-480-8"></span><span id="page-480-1"></span>21:44 The inclusive "every" of English translation does not have a direct counterpart in the Hebrew but is implied in the idiom "to bring rest" (Hb. *nuakh*) plus "on every side," which is used several times with reference to enemies and implying the condition for some activity given the absence of hostility (cf. Deut. 12:10; 25:19; 2 Sam. 7:1; 1 Chron. 22:9). As in the previous verse, this is recorded as the fidelity of a promise of God spoken to previous generations. Also as in the previous verse, the divine decree has its corresponding human response, this time in the impotence of Israel's enemies to stand against them.

<span id="page-480-9"></span><span id="page-480-7"></span>21:45 The two particular promises of Josh 21:43–44 concerning land and victory are now expanded to include every word spoken by the Lord on Israel's behalf. In the distinctive diction of Deuteronomy the case is stated both negatively and positively as the narrator strains to convey the comprehensive character of God's gift and its reception.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-480-5"></span>The conclusion of the military campaigns in the first part of the book finished with a summary statement of the taking of the land promised by God and the arrival of rest (Josh. 11:22–23). There the focus fell on Joshua as the leader of God's people through the territorial wars against aggressive kings. Here, by contrast, in the summary concluding the book's second section the emphasis falls entirely on God's fidelity as that which enabled Israel's success.

<span id="page-480-4"></span><span id="page-480-3"></span><span id="page-480-2"></span><span id="page-480-0"></span>The text bears echoes back to the beginning of the book, particularly to the words of the Transjordan tribes to Joshua regarding their commitment to accompany their brothers into the land west of the Jordan; this is seen especially in 21:44 and the provision of "rest" (cf. 1:13–15). But the arc of this summary goes far beyond that. Twice it identifies the recipients of these promises of God as "their fathers." Clearly in context this refers to the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (cf. Ex. 4:5) and again makes a connection to the language that began the book (cf. Josh. 1:6; 5:6). This reach back into the patriarchal promises is deeply significant. The books of Moses come to an end in Deuteronomy 34 with those promises still unfulfilled: Israel remains outside the land on the plains of Moab, poised and prepared to progress, yet outside the Land of Promise all the same. Here, as the two phases of settlement—identified with Gilgal and Shiloh—have been completed and provision of cities for refuge and Levi has been made, that promise now stands fulfilled.

This emphatic and inclusive statement of the fulfillment of God's promise rings with clarity, which is its primary purpose. However, there may be a subtle message between the lines. The overt and definitive statement of God's comprehensive faithfulness to his good promises to Israel throws into relief the partial, flawed, and incomplete nature of Israel's settlement noted at various points as the territorial inheritance has taken place. The dominant surface message of these verses has often been superficially juxtaposed by some with the more pessimistic trajectory of the book of Judges, as if these books told two contradictory, or at least incompatible, stories. But it is not so, as the final chapters of Joshua will further clarify.

### <span id="page-481-3"></span>OVERVIEW OF JOSHUA 22:1–24:33

<span id="page-481-5"></span><span id="page-481-2"></span>The last three chapters of Joshua each depict Joshua as "summoning" (22:1; 23:2) or "gathering" (24:1) either part of Israel (22:1) or the whole of Israel (23:2; 24:1). Each chapter in different ways addresses the theme of living in obedience to God in the Land of Promise. In each of the three chapters speeches figure heavily. Chapter 22 includes more narrative development than the final two chapters, which form a close-knit pair, but all have defined narrative contexts, each of which answers a question relevant to this moment in Israel's history (cf. table 2.6).

| Chapter | Question                    | Answer Form                  |  |  |
|---------|-----------------------------|------------------------------|--|--|
| 22      | Will Israel Survive Intact? | Dialogue: Israel with Israel |  |  |
| 23      | How shall Israel live?      | Monologue: Joshua to Israel  |  |  |
| 24      | Whom shall Israel serve?    | Dialogue: Joshua with Israel |  |  |

<span id="page-481-0"></span>TABLE 2.6: Relevant Questions in Joshua's Final Three Chapters

<span id="page-481-6"></span><span id="page-481-4"></span><span id="page-481-1"></span>If chapter 22 presents a story of risk and danger to the unity of Israel, with chapters 23–24 being concerned for its fidelity, then the double ending of Joshua (Joshua 22; 23–24) has some resonance with the double ending of Judges (Judges 17–18; 19–21), which likewise has all to do with the failed fidelity and shattered unity of Israel.

### <span id="page-482-0"></span>JOSHUA 22:1–34

Therefore turn and go to your tents in the land where your possession lies, which Moses the servant of the Lord gave you on the other side of the Jordan. **5**Only be very careful to observe the commandment and the law that Moses the servant of the Lord commanded you, to love the Lord your God, and to walk in all his ways and to keep his commandments and to cling to him and to serve him with all your heart and with all your soul." **<sup>6</sup>** So Joshua blessed them and sent them away, and they went to their tents.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-484-1"></span>Over chapters 13–21 the land has been apportioned between the twelve inheriting tribes, and the non-inheriting tribe of Levi has been provided with cities from each of the other tribes for its dwelling, including the cities of refuge. Israel as a whole can now begin to enjoy a settled life in the Land of Promise. It is both ominous and alarming, then, that the first narrative after settlement is one that is fraught with danger and flirts with apostasy.

<span id="page-484-14"></span><span id="page-484-5"></span><span id="page-484-4"></span><span id="page-484-3"></span><span id="page-484-2"></span><span id="page-484-0"></span>Now that Israel has "rest on every side" (21:44), the time has come for the Transjordan tribes to return to the homeland granted them by the Lord through Moses (cf. 1:12–15; cf. also comments there). The formal discharge from service at Joshua's initiative is narrated in the opening section of the chapter (21:1–8). Having gathered the warriors of these two and a half tribes (v. 1), Joshua reviews the arrangements (vv. 2–3) and acknowledges the fulfillment of the conditions of their settlement to the east of the Jordan (v. 4), adding an exhortation to faithful obedience on their return (v. 5). He blesses them, and they disperse (v. 6). Verses 7–8 provide the further observation that Manasseh is the tribe of two halves, distributed on either side of the Jordan (v. 7), and also instruct the returning warriors to divide their share of the spoil among those who remained in their districts during the military campaigns (v. 8).

<span id="page-484-9"></span><span id="page-484-8"></span><span id="page-484-7"></span><span id="page-484-6"></span>Verse 9 narrates the return of the warriors of these tribes and serves as something of a transition. In some structural arrangements this appears as a conclusion to the dispersal scene of verses 1–8. However, given both the ancient paragraph marker at the end of verse 8 (Hb. *petukhah*), which places the division at this point, and the narrative impetus that verse 9 initiates in the following events, it seems best to include verse 9 as the first, introductory element of the longer narrative sequel rather than as the conclusion to Joshua's dispersal of the Transjordan tribes in verses 1–8.

<span id="page-484-11"></span><span id="page-484-10"></span>That narrative unfolds in five movements. Following the return of the Transjordan warriors to their homes, news reaches Israel that a massive altar has been constructed east of the Jordan; the people assemble to prepare for war (vv. 9– 12). Alarmed, a delegation headed by Phinehas is dispatched to investigate, warn, and castigate their brothers (vv. 13–20). The defensive speech in response by the two and a half tribes, the longest portion of the narrative, asserts their fear of being cut off from Israel and also their commitment to faithful, obedient worship of the Lord (vv. 21–29). Satisfied, Phinehas and his delegation reassure the Transjordan tribes (vv. 30–31) and return and report to Israel, with war averted (vv. 32–33).

		- 1. Dismissal of the Transjordan Tribes (22:1–8)
			- a. Joshua Dismisses, Exhorts, and Blesses the Transjordan Tribes (22:1–6)
- b. Transjordan Tribes Sent Home with Spoil (22:7–8)
- 2. The Altar of the Transjordan Tribes (22:9–34)
	- 1. Return; Altar as Provocation to War (22:9–12)
	- 2. Phinehas and Delegation: Accusation (22:13–20)
	- 3. Transjordan Tribes Confession and Defense (22:21–29)
	- 4. Phinehas and Delegation: Acquittal (22:30–31)
	- 5. Return; Altar as Witness to Peace (22:32–34)

<span id="page-485-4"></span>A variety of chiastic structures have been suggested for the narrative of the altar dispute in 22:9–34, some more fine grained than others. The account does appear to display at least an overall symmetry:

- <span id="page-485-5"></span><span id="page-485-3"></span>(A) Return [Transjordan tribes] + Altar Built + Israel: War Proposed (22:9–12)
	- (B) Phinehas and Delegation: Accuse and Warn (22:13–20)
		- (C) Transjordan Tribes Confession and Defense (22:21–29)
	- (B') Phinehas and Delegation: Acquit and Affirm (22:30–31)
- <span id="page-485-13"></span><span id="page-485-12"></span>(A') Return [Delegation] + Israel: War Averted + Altar Named (22:32–34)

It is also possible to discern a similar chiastic arrangement to the long speech of the Transjordan tribes. A number of elements are repeated through the speech, but the following form emerges:

<span id="page-485-6"></span>Confession! (22:22a)

- <span id="page-485-8"></span><span id="page-485-7"></span>(A) Altar Built neither in Rebellion nor for Sacrifice (22:22b–23)
	- (B) Motivation: Fear of Division between Descendants (22:24–25)
		- (C) Altar Built for Witness, Sign of Fidelity, Maintain Unity (22:26–27)
	- (B') Motivation: Averting Division between Descendants (22:28)
- <span id="page-485-11"></span><span id="page-485-10"></span><span id="page-485-9"></span>(A') Altar Not Built in Rebellion; Only One Altar for Sacrifice (22:29)

If these chiastic structures have some merit, then the speech of the Transjordan tribes is nested in the center of the overall chiasm, with its own center being the full statement of the purpose of this altar, which is to prevent the disinheritance of the tribes east of the Jordan from the rest of Israel and thus to safeguard the nation's unity.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-485-2"></span><span id="page-485-1"></span><span id="page-485-0"></span>22:1–6 The discharge of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh from accompanying the rest of Israel during the conquest of the land west of the Jordan has clear echoes back to the beginning of the book. In 1:12–15 these tribes were reminded of their obligation to honor the command of Moses given to this group on the granting of their inheritance east of the Jordan. When "rest" had come through God to Israel (1:15), they could then return to their "rest" (1:13). Joshua's speech here overlaps significantly with that previous address to these tribes, now

<span id="page-486-8"></span><span id="page-486-7"></span><span id="page-486-5"></span>in recognition of their faithful service (22:2–3). After the formal discharge itself (v. 4) the roles that Joshua and the Transjordan tribes adopted in the prologue to the book are reversed. There, the accompanying tribes affirmed their willing obedience to the word of Moses, to Joshua, and to the Lord (1:16–18). Now, with the job done, it is Joshua's turn to admonish them, speaking of obedience to the law out of love for their God in language strongly resonant with that of Deuteronomy. Yet with the piling up distinctive phrases, no one exemplar from Deuteronomy serves as an original. Probably Deuteronomy 10:12–13 contains the strongest concentration, but several other passages also align markedly with the phrases of Joshua 22:5.127 This is an emphatic call to wholehearted fidelity.

<span id="page-486-18"></span><span id="page-486-9"></span><span id="page-486-6"></span><span id="page-486-1"></span>It remains only for Joshua to add his blessing and send them home, just as he did for his old comrade, Caleb, in 14:13. The same actions of blessing, sending, and going to "their tents" come together again only in 1 Kings 8:66 in the aftermath of the prayer of dedication of the temple, as Solomon sends the people home and that is immediately followed in 1 Kings 9 by a word of warning to the king concerning the dangers of disobedience and serving other gods.

<span id="page-486-19"></span><span id="page-486-11"></span><span id="page-486-10"></span>22:7–8 The narrator's notice in Joshua 22:7 that Manasseh is the one tribe divided into two by the Jordan seems odd here. This very literary oddity, however, gives pause, and its observation perhaps hints at the tensions soon to arise. In any case, Joshua now instructs the warriors to "go back" (a form of the Hb. verb *shub*; v. 8) and share the spoil with those who remained in the Transjordan during the military campaign ("your wives, your little ones, and your livestock"; 1:14), following the principle laid down in Numbers 31:25–27. Having delivered these instructions, Joshua's voice fades, and so does he from this narrative. He will be neither seen nor heard from again until chapter 23.

<span id="page-486-17"></span><span id="page-486-12"></span><span id="page-486-4"></span><span id="page-486-0"></span>The verb for "go back" (*shub*) which can mean "turn" or "return" (or even "repent," although it does not bear that nuance in this chapter), runs like a thread through this chapter. It is used in this form seven times (22:8, 9, 16, 18 [in the speech of the delegation], 23, 29 [in the speech of the Transjordan tribes], 32 [as the delegation returns "to the land of Canaan"]).

<span id="page-486-16"></span><span id="page-486-14"></span><span id="page-486-13"></span>22:9–12 In a moment it all seems to be undone. The men of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh leave Shiloh and return—the verb *shub* is the first word of verse 9 in Hebrew—to their land. En route ("in the land of Canaan") they build "an altar of imposing size" (v. 10). The Hebrew here is "a large altar for seeing" (Hb. *mizbeah gadol lemarʾeh*), stressing not so much its size as its visibility—thus the rendering of a number of English versions as "conspicuous" (EHV, TLV). News comes back to the rest of Israel (v. 11), and a council of war convenes at Shiloh (v. 12).

<span id="page-486-15"></span>With dizzying speed all the benefits of the toil, trial, and trauma that have preceded in the book to bring Israel to this point seem about to be undone. So

<span id="page-486-3"></span><span id="page-486-2"></span><sup>127</sup> Cf. Elie Assis, "'For It Shall Be a Witness between Us': A Literary Reading of Josh 22," *SJOT* 18/2 (2004): 211–212. Assis lists in addition Deuteronomy 11:22; 19:9; 30:20. To these should be added Deuteronomy 13:4–5, which employs these phrases as a warning against apostasy.

<span id="page-487-10"></span><span id="page-487-9"></span><span id="page-487-5"></span><span id="page-487-2"></span><span id="page-487-1"></span><span id="page-487-0"></span>swift and natural is the revulsion shared between Israel and later readers of Joshua toward this altar that seldom is the question asked of why it is built in the first place. Joshua himself had led a covenant ceremony at an altar built on Mount Ebal, the construction of which is narrated with some care (8:30–31; cf. comment on 8:30–32, 34–35a). Abraham (Gen. 12:7–8; 13:18; 22:9), Isaac (Gen. 26:25), and Jacob (33:20; 35:7) were all altar builders. After Joshua's time, Gideon built an altar (Judg. 6:24), and Manoah's "rock" (*tsur*) is called an "altar" (Judg. 13:19–20). Modern commentators are typically more interested in identifying the altar's location (impossible) while neglecting to ask why it was a problem in the first place. Calvin at least addresses the question: his indignation at the audacity of the altar is palpable ("the work might be deemed vicious," "detest its sacrilegious audacity," etc.), but he offers Exodus 20:24 as the law's "strict prohibition" against two altars, although this is not the original concern of that legislation.128 Keil comes closer in suggesting the same issue but from a different text: the regulations concerning centralization of worship in Deuteronomy 12:4—although the restriction to a single altar is not explicit here, either.129 The medieval Jewish commentator Rashi explained the reaction of Joshua 22:12 by asserting, "High places were prohibited once the tabernacle was established at Shiloh." The new status of Shiloh (cf. comment on 18:1) provides the key. Deuteronomy 12 indeed informs the explanation, but more likely in verses 13–14, which warn, "Take care that you do not offer your burnt offerings at any place that you see, but at the place that the Lord will choose in one of your tribes, there you shall offer your burnt offerings." Rashi's identification of Shiloh as initiating this restriction clarifies the logic.

<span id="page-487-8"></span><span id="page-487-7"></span><span id="page-487-6"></span><span id="page-487-4"></span><span id="page-487-3"></span>The narrator stresses the rapidly rising tension via an unusual reiteration of names through these verses. "The people of Reuben and the people of Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh" are explicitly identified fully three times in Joshua 22:9, 10, 11. Three times the "people of Israel" (Hb. *bene yisraʾel*) are named in verses 11, 12 (2x in this short verse). The protagonists are thus held firmly before the reader's eyes.

Not only are the names of these potentially warring factions repeated but so too are the features of the landscape patiently, even insistently, detailed. In verse 9 the departing warriors go to the "land of Gilead, their own land." Their altarbuilding activity takes place in the "region of the Jordan . . . by the Jordan" (v. 10), reported in verse 11 as the "region about the Jordan." The river as boundary line thus becomes a liminal zone between the estranged tribes. The identity of Israel's land as the "land of Canaan" is a striking designation used three times in verses 9, 10, and 11—like the names of the protagonists. The first occurrence of these uses appears as a gloss to the location of Shiloh (v. 9), the place from which, we now learn, the discharge of the Transjordan tribes has taken place. And as they left from Shiloh, so too in verse 12 the rest of Israel gathers to "make war against them" in Shiloh, bracketing these few verses.

<sup>128</sup> Calvin, *Book of Joshua*, 253–254.

<sup>129</sup> Keil, *Joshua, Judges, Ruth*, 218.

<span id="page-488-18"></span><span id="page-488-16"></span>This is the last time Shiloh is named in Joshua; the site where Israel meets for its final gathering is Shechem (24:1). The next time Shiloh ("where I made my name dwell at first"; Jer. 7:12) is encountered will be in a prelude to civil war (Judg. 18:31).

<span id="page-488-17"></span><span id="page-488-10"></span><span id="page-488-8"></span><span id="page-488-7"></span><span id="page-488-6"></span><span id="page-488-0"></span>22:13–14 Rather than immediately dispatching an army, however, the council sends a delegation comprising ten tribal leaders—in other words, one from each of the "nine and one-half tribes" (Josh. 14:2), with the western half of Manasseh (22:7) included as one of the ten—headed by Phinehas, from the tribe of Levi. It might seem odd that neither Joshua nor Eleazar is involved, as these two together have provided leadership in Israel up to this point (14:1; 17:4; 19:51; 21:1). But Phinehas is an appropriate figure for a mission such as this. A son of Eleazar (and so grandson of Aaron; Ex. 6:25), he came to prominence in his swift, violent, and decisive action stemming from the plague of God's judgment at Peor (Num. 25:1–13). This won for him and his descendants a "perpetual priesthood" (Num. 25:13). He previously acted in a leadership capacity in the campaign against Midian (Num. 31:6), and so he has proven not only his zeal for the Lord, vital in this moment of apparent communal infidelity, but also his capacity to provide a priestly focal point for the army of Israel.

<span id="page-488-12"></span><span id="page-488-11"></span><span id="page-488-9"></span><span id="page-488-5"></span><span id="page-488-4"></span><span id="page-488-2"></span>22:15–20 The site of the delegation's meeting with the Transjordan tribes is not reported, but the implication of the narrative is that it takes place wherever the disputed altar was built. No details are provided of the encounter apart from the speeches made by both parties. The delegation from Israel of the "land of Canaan" (Josh. 22:9) speaks first, making its accusation with warrants in verses 16–20. On behalf of the "whole congregation of the Lord" they level the blunt charge of apostasy (v. 16) rooted in rebellion against Yahweh, the Hebrew *marad* being used four times in these few verses (vv. 16, 18, 19 [2x]). Rather than threatening war, however, the appeal of verse 19 is for these tribes to relocate to "the Lord's land where the Lord's tabernacle stands," west of the Jordan. This entreaty seems to be based on the assumption that the altar building is a perverted attempt by the Transjordan tribes to sanctify their land.

<span id="page-488-15"></span><span id="page-488-14"></span><span id="page-488-13"></span><span id="page-488-3"></span>This imploring invitation from the delegation for the altar builders to reconsider their actions and their inheritance, under threat of divine judgment on disobedience, is bracketed by two precedents: (1) the incident of apostasy involving Baal of Peor and its destructive outcome, with which Phinehas is so deeply associated (vv. 17–18; cf. Num. 25:1–18), and (2) the more recent disobedience of Achan, for which in God's "wrath" (*qetsef*) "he did not perish alone [*ʾish ʾehad*]" (v. 20). For the latter case it has been observed that the wording here suggests an association with Numbers 16:22.130 That verse records the response of Moses and Aaron to God's threat to consume the whole "congregation" in the rebellion of Korah: "And they fell on their faces and said, 'O God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, shall

<span id="page-488-1"></span><sup>130</sup> A. Graeme Auld, "Pluralism Where Least Expected? Joshua 22 in Biblical Context," *ExpTim* 122/8 (2011): 376–377.

one man [*ʾish ʾehad*] sin, and will you be angry [*tiqtsof*] with all the congregation?'" These are the only places in the Hebrew Bible in which the anger of God and the seemingly innocuous phrase "one man" come together. The intertextual association further deepens the gravity of the situation as perceived by the delegation: the very survival of the nation is at stake.

<span id="page-489-5"></span><span id="page-489-4"></span><span id="page-489-3"></span><span id="page-489-2"></span>22:21–29 The Transjordan tribes immediately repudiate the charge of rebellious behavior (Hb. *marad*, Josh. 22:22, 29; cf. comment on 22:15–20). They begin with a threefold confession of the God of Israel, emphatically declared twice (v. 22). They vehemently deny any intent to use the altar for sacrifice of any kind (v. 23) but claim that its construction arose out of fear of rejection by the descendants of those living across the Jordan, since they have been divided from the rest of the nation by divine will (vv. 24–25). With that premise, verses 26–27 spell out their intentions for this altar: it will not provide a place of sacrifice but rather will stand as witness that their offerings are devoted to the Lord. Verse 28 explains once more that this altar will prevent estrangement between their descendants; the speech concludes in verse 29 with a reiteration of their repudiation of rebellion and an affirmation that the Lord's one altar is located at the tabernacle.

<span id="page-489-15"></span><span id="page-489-14"></span><span id="page-489-7"></span>The insistent, repetitive rhetoric of this reply bespeaks the urgency with which it is delivered. Like the speech of the delegation, it too contains intertextual elements undergirding its argument; unlike such elements in the previous speech, these are not explicitly signaled. The combination of the three divine names confessed as they begin (v. 22) is found again only at Psalm 50:1, which invokes this God as he who "summons the earth from the rising of the sun to its setting" (thus from east to west). He then calls his covenant people together, informing them that he has no need of their sacrifice (Ps. 50:5–15). This resonates strongly with the concerns here of the Transjordan tribes. As they go on (Josh. 22:22), a second phrase evokes another psalm, this time Psalm 44. "He knows" in this grammatical form used of divine knowledge is found only here and at Psalm 44:21, part of a protest of innocence that asserts God knows the "secrets of the heart."131 At least for attentive readers, these intertextual echoes reinforce the Transjordan tribes' claim of innocence.

<span id="page-489-13"></span><span id="page-489-12"></span><span id="page-489-10"></span><span id="page-489-6"></span>An unusual feature emerges in the hypothetical speech of the future Israelites in Joshua 22:25: Reuben and Gad are named; Manasseh is missing. This pattern continues in verses 32, 33, and 34, while the expected trio of names returns in verses 30–31, the response of the delegation. Here again the divided existence of Manasseh first signaled in verse 7 seems to play a role.

<span id="page-489-9"></span><span id="page-489-8"></span><span id="page-489-1"></span>22:30–31 The delegation under Phinehas hears this speech with approval. Even its brief reply of verse 31 has allusive overtones, but suggestive of very different claims. "The Lord is in our midst" is an assertion of God's holy presence, its closest comparison being found in Exodus 29:45–46, the culmination of the ordination

<span id="page-489-11"></span><span id="page-489-0"></span><sup>131</sup> Cf. ibid., 377–378. On "he knows" cf. also Job 28:23–24 (using a different form of the Hebrew verb), which affirms that God alone knows "everything under the heavens."

<span id="page-490-3"></span><span id="page-490-0"></span>of the priests and the meeting of God and people through sacrifice. There is only one other place that the phrasing Phinehas uses here is found: Numbers 16:3, in the context of the rebellion of Korah already alluded to in this passage (Josh. 22:20). But in Numbers this phrasing is used by the rebel party, a combination of representatives from the tribes of Levi and Reuben, in asserting their parity with Moses and Aaron. This, then, is a more ambiguous datum. Here at any rate it spells an end to divine judgment, not its inception.

<span id="page-490-6"></span><span id="page-490-4"></span>22:32–34 The delegation returns "to the land of Canaan, to the people of Israel," satisfied that God's honor is intact and Israel's fidelity is sound. The altar's purpose as explained by the Transjordan tribes in verse 27 ("to be a witness between us and you") becomes the name by which it is known.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-490-2"></span>Two intertwined themes dominate Joshua 22: the nature of unity and the importance of fidelity. The history of a perceived threat to national unity because of one faction's supposed infidelity is often regarded positively by commentators, since at its conclusion national unity is affirmed and true worship upheld. Others see it as a moment of tension that comes to nothing. The threat was illusory, the infidelity never more than hypothetical in the minds of the accusers. Even so, it remains a salutary lesson, as the episode demonstrates that "staying" as Israel might be as fraught as "joining" Israel—cf. Rahab, the Gibeonites—especially as their negative counterpart, Achan, is explicitly identified (v. 20) to illustrate the potential gravity of the situation. But all that evaporates with the discovery by the delegation (led by Phinehas, no less) that it was all just a mistake. As the story concludes, all parties are satisfied not only that their present moment can be peaceful but that their future together before God is assured.

<span id="page-490-7"></span><span id="page-490-5"></span><span id="page-490-1"></span>Yet cause for concern persists. A nonsacrificial altar is the oddest of memorials to leave for future generations to remember their solidarity before their God. The very concept of such an altar seems to be a fundamental oxymoron, like a book intended not to be read, a knife not for cutting, or a gun not for shooting. At one level, analogies to this mute witness in stone have been encountered before in the book; the memorial stones put in place as part of the crossing of the Jordan in chapters 3–4 are the best example, although it was also seen how those stones bearing a message for future generations had a grisly counterpart in the stone cairns erected over the corpses of Israel's enemies. Still, the memorial stones by the Jordan seem a much safer symbol than a large and attractive altar also by the Jordan! The ambiguity of the final intertextual resonance in the passage (cf. comment on 22:30–31) likewise hints at some foreboding. Shiloh's legitimacy and centrality as the one place the Lord has chosen to receive his people's sacrificial offerings is affirmed—but soon Shiloh will be destroyed (cf. Ps. 78:58–61). Yes, Phinehas takes a lead—but is his judgment slipping, as Joshua's did at least once? At the next, and last, time we catch a glimpse of Phinehas he is again in the thick of <span id="page-491-2"></span>violence, only on that occasion it is full-blown civil war, thirty thousand Israelites having been killed on the two previous days by Benjaminites (Judg. 20:28). By then things have clearly gone very wrong.

There are lessons here for God's people who find their unity under threat. The history of the Christian church is littered with fractures and fragmented communities that attest to the continuing need of learning such lessons, wherever they might be found. The lesson here is not that preserving unity promotes a generous plurality. The deadliest enemy, as this passage rightly conveys, is not the Canaanites but rather the Israelites' own propensity to idolatry. When community difference takes this character, what is at stake is not simply the "unity" of God's people but rather their joint focus of attention on God.132 Whatever imperils that attentive relationship is deadly, and the alarm of Israel over the rogue altar is well founded. We can be grateful that a latter-day Phinehas does not carry a literal spear—and that there was one who was pierced by the spear, else we would all deserve to be at the sharp end of business with Phinehas. More important than the relationship of Israel's tribal groupings with each other is their common standing before God.

<span id="page-491-0"></span>That would appear to be settled by the end of this chapter. But the anxiety over the nature of this memorial in stone and the hints the narrator leaves that things could be better imply a warning for the careful listener and reader and prepare for the explicit warnings that will come from Joshua himself in chapters 23–24 in his final two speeches of the book. But it is not just the last two chapters that sound warnings; this chapter certainly does as well.

### <span id="page-491-1"></span>JOSHUA 23:1–16

#### *Section Overview*

As the end of the book draws nearer, connections to its beginning also loom. This speech of Joshua has clear links back to the first chapter of the book, as the words addressed by God to Joshua there come to be used by Joshua here as he speaks now to the nation.

Commentaries typically bemoan the resistance of this passage to structural analysis and suggest a welter of outlines to capture its flow. The text displays a strong compositional unity and a pronounced overall sense of progression, but at a finer level similar concerns and themes recur throughout, inhibiting discernment of a clear structure. The analysis here is based on two interlocking patterns. At a macro level Joshua's speech can be seen to fall into two large parts, with verses 2–10 predominantly offering positive exhortations based on past observations and verses 11–16 predominantly offering negative warnings based on future possibilities.

<span id="page-492-5"></span><span id="page-492-4"></span><span id="page-492-3"></span><span id="page-492-2"></span><span id="page-492-1"></span><span id="page-492-0"></span>At the same time a sequence of three situations and responses can also be discerned, which would divide the speech slightly differently. The first situation looks back at what the Lord and Joshua have done (vv. 2b–5), giving rise to the corresponding encouragements (vv. 6–8). The second situation describes what God and the people themselves have done (vv. 9–10), with the corollary of being devoted to the true God (vv. 11–13). The final situation is Joshua's own imminent demise and

<span id="page-493-10"></span><span id="page-493-9"></span>God's proven faithfulness (v. 14), which works out in a warning that abandoning God's covenant will equally surely bring his destructive response (vv. 15–16). It is this second pattern that informs the analytical outline below.

Either way the speech has a strong coherence, framed by the opening celebration of Israel's inhabiting the Land of Promise through God's fidelity and the concluding prospect of their enjoyment of that land being taken from them should they prove unfaithful.

#### *Section Outline*

III.B. How Shall Israel Then Live? (23:1–16)

- 1. Joshua Summons Israel (23:1–2a)
- 2. Joshua Exhorts Israel to Obedience (23:2b–16)
	- a. God Fought for Israel; Joshua Allotted the Land (23:2b–5)
	- b. Exhortation: Obedience to God's Word (23:6–8)
	- c. God Drove Out the Nations; Israel Unstoppable (23:9–10)
	- d. Exhortation: Devotion to God (23:11–13)
	- e. Joshua's Impending Demise; God's Complete Fidelity (23:14)
	- f. Warning: Possibility of Rejection If Israel Proves Unfaithful (23:15–16)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-493-7"></span><span id="page-493-2"></span>23:1–2a The narrator of the book of Joshua does not, on the whole, devote much effort to indicating chronology. In the opening chapters the precise details of "three days" (e.g., 1:11; 2:16) proved problematic, but beyond that there are few, if any, fixed time references. The same is true here, although the text's phrasing combines with earlier notices (13:1; 18:3) to impress the reader with the passage of time since the seemingly rapid campaigns of chapters 2–11.

<span id="page-493-6"></span><span id="page-493-3"></span>The whole nation is summoned, although to what location is not specified one assumes Shiloh, but this is only a guess, for this is a "long time afterward," and presumably Joshua himself is well settled at Timnath-serah, not very far from Shiloh. The speech that follows is addressed especially to the leadership of Israel, identified with four titles in two categories, the civil ("elders and heads") and the administrative ("judges and officers"). The last title named provides some closure back to the beginning of the book, as the "officers" were the group responsible for implementing Joshua's orders as the move across the Jordan took place (1:10; 3:2). The full array of titles is used again in the Bible only at 24:1, further linking these two chapters together, although three of these titles (without "heads") are also found for the earlier covenant ceremony on Mount Ebal (8:33).

<span id="page-493-8"></span><span id="page-493-5"></span><span id="page-493-4"></span><span id="page-493-1"></span><span id="page-493-0"></span>23:2b–5 As Joshua's speech begins, it bears a striking resemblance to the first speech in the book, of God to Joshua (1:2–9). Both reiterate the narrative situation, mention the gift of the land, circumscribe briefly its boundaries, and provide assurance of God's capacity to act on Israel's behalf. The element absent here found in the speech

Joshua 23:1–16 494

<span id="page-494-12"></span><span id="page-494-4"></span>of chapter 1—the necessity of obedience to God's word—is what Joshua will go on to require by way of response in 23:6–8. Clearly there is some intention to align Joshua's address to the nation here with God's words to Joshua as the book began.

<span id="page-494-9"></span><span id="page-494-8"></span><span id="page-494-7"></span><span id="page-494-6"></span>Another kind of intertextual link is forged in verse 3 with the reminder that "it is the Lord your God who has fought for you." These are the words used to such striking effect in 10:14, 42, which marked the first of the territorial wars into which Israel was drawn, initially by the Canaanite reaction to the covenant with the Gibeonites and then in the aftermath of the ensuing battle. The phrase will be used again in 23:10, thus framing the first half of the speech (cf. Section Overview of 23:1–16). These two occurrences align with the two occurrences in chapter 10, with two in Exodus 14:14, 25 (at the Red Sea crossing in relation to the pursuing Egyptians), and with two in Deuteronomy 1:30; 3:22 (in which Moses anticipates God's actions across the Jordan). These references combine to weave together the entire exodus story. Such parallels between the entry into the land with the exodus from Egypt were in greater supply in the first part of the book, but continue here. Joshua's speech in chapter 24 will go beyond allusion to direct narration.

<span id="page-494-17"></span><span id="page-494-10"></span><span id="page-494-2"></span><span id="page-494-1"></span>Joshua 23:5 signals that, even though a resting place has been achieved, it is not all over yet. Some future struggles are anticipated, as they are again in the latter part of this chapter (v. 13).

<span id="page-494-15"></span>23:6–8 To the observations that God has dislodged the nations on Israel's behalf and that Joshua has allotted the land, the response called for is one of obedience to God's word as made known through the law of Moses. If the parallels between the first verses of Joshua's speech and God's words to Joshua in chapter 1 were thematic and structural, as Joshua now spells out the response invited in light of these things, the connection between the two speeches deepens to verbal overlaps, especially between 1:7 and 23:6–7 (cf. table 2.7).

<span id="page-494-16"></span><span id="page-494-14"></span><span id="page-494-13"></span><span id="page-494-5"></span><span id="page-494-3"></span>The "Book of the Law" mentioned in 23:6 is likewise named in 1:8. Such generosity and faithfulness on God's part calls for complete devotion from Israel, in negative terms by not naming, serving, or bowing down to foreign gods—the latter two also being cited as incurring God's wrath in 23:16, again providing some correspondence between the two halves of this speech (v. 7). Positively, such a rejection of false gods implies or even requires a "clinging" to the true God (v. 8), which is one of the distinctive exhortations of Moses to this same generation of Israelites in Deuteronomy (10:20; 11:22; 13:4 [Hb. v. 5]; 30:20).

<span id="page-495-9"></span><span id="page-495-7"></span><span id="page-495-1"></span>23:9–10 The first premise in Joshua 23:2b–5 combined divine action with Joshua; this second premise associates divine action with Israel. God has dispossessed the nations, but Israel has proved unstoppable "since it is the Lord your God who fights for you." Here Joshua's terms are rooted in the covenant promise of Leviticus 26:8: "Five of you shall chase a hundred, and a hundred of you shall chase ten thousand." However, the wording here is even closer to that of the Song of Moses (Deut. 32:30), which uses this same language to describe Israel's being handed over by God to their enemies for abandoning him:

<span id="page-495-4"></span> How could one have chased a thousand, and two have put ten thousand to flight, unless their Rock had sold them, and the Lord had given them up?

Perhaps there is an irony here, then, in Joshua's positive statement drawing on the covenant blessings that still manages to recall the negative image of the Song of Moses. The scenario envisaged in the song is the very one that Joshua's exhortation is intended to prevent.

<span id="page-495-12"></span><span id="page-495-10"></span><span id="page-495-8"></span><span id="page-495-3"></span><span id="page-495-2"></span>23:11–13 So the second response calls on Israel to "love the Lord your God." The exhortations to "cling" (v. 8) in the first response and "love" here distribute the parts combined by Moses in Deuteronomy 11:22, associated with driving out the nations, and Deuteronomy 30:19–20, in which Moses urges Israel to "choose life," as Joshua will go on to do in Joshua 24. Failure to do so will result in God's "no longer driving out these nations before you," with dire consequences, graphically described. Tragically, the outcome that Joshua's warning is designed to preclude is exactly what Israel experiences through their disobedience in Judges 2:3. If Joshua's words had any effect, it did not last very long (cf. Josh. 24:31).

<span id="page-495-14"></span><span id="page-495-13"></span><span id="page-495-11"></span><span id="page-495-6"></span><span id="page-495-5"></span>23:14 Joshua's mortality is again in view as yet another element in the speech forges a connection with a significant earlier moment in the book. The conclusion to the settlement account occupying chapters 13–21 made an emphatic statement of the complete faithfulness of God to his promises to Israel (21:43–45). The end of that conclusion is woven here into Joshua's final situation demanding a response (cf. table 2.8).

There are only minor differences between the two verses, their wording being even closer in Hebrew than is apparent in translation. Just as the beginning of Israel's venture under God to return to the Land of Promise is linked in the beginning of the speech, so too is their endpoint of enjoying settled life in the land connected to the end of that process.

<span id="page-496-6"></span><span id="page-496-4"></span><span id="page-496-1"></span>23:15–16 Verse 13 made the shift from past response to future possibility, and the future could be problematic if Israel defaulted on the covenant with Yahweh. This painful and tragic possible future is laid out by Joshua as the conclusion to the speech. He ends not with an optimistic hope but rather with a realistic warning. Israel has demonstrated its capacity for apostasy in too many ways over the long exodus journey, and even through Achan (ch. 7) in its mission of conquest. The inevitability in case of apostasy is that God will "destroy you from off this good land" (23:15). The action here might well be translated "annihilate," reflecting a deliberate obligation to destroy objects or enemies. The thread of this lexeme through Joshua is instructive: aside from 7:12, where it is used with reference to the items of *kherem* taken by Achan, elsewhere it is used of the action of either Yahweh or Israel against the Canaanites (9:24; 11:14, 20; 24:8 [of Amorites across the Jordan]). Here it is applied, at least potentially, against Israelites.

<span id="page-496-7"></span><span id="page-496-5"></span><span id="page-496-3"></span><span id="page-496-2"></span>The possibility that Israel might "go and serve other gods and bow down to them" (v. 16) brings before Israel again this specter first raised in verse 7, although there as a statement of what they should avoid in the life of obedience. Here it is identified as the action that will incur God's wrath. While the speech began by appreciating the blessing of settled life in the Promised Land under God, it ends by warning of the risk of perishing from the land—still under God. Or, in other words, living in such a way that places them in opposition to Yahweh will lead them to be regarded just as the Canaanites were—and to experience the same fate.

#### *Response*

To the modern ear the closing encouragement of the aged Joshua to Israel might not sound very encouraging. But it is most definitely what Israel needs to hear, and it is good for later generations of God's people to hear it too.

The situation-and-response structure to the speech brings two elements into the foreground. The first is the strong emphasis throughout on what God *has* done for Israel. Israel's role seems remarkably passive; even in the recounting of the resounding success of Israel's army it all comes down to the Lord's action on Israel's behalf. The Lord fights and Israel possesses.

<span id="page-496-0"></span>The opening moments and their invocation of God's own words to Joshua in 1:1–9 do more than provide a long narrative arc to bring some closure for a book about to end. Beyond that, as Joshua redirects God's words to him at the beginning of his leadership to the settled nation as his time comes to an end, he is in effect making a nation of "Joshuas": "The careful obedience that was placed upon Joshua as an individual at the start of the book now becomes the duty of the entire people and of their collective leadership."133

Altogether this calls positively for a response of obedience and negatively for a rejection of apostasy. As Joshua frames it, memory undergirds both sides of the demand for devotion, both the clinging to and loving of their covenant God and the spurning and rejecting of any fakes or rivals. The emphasis on what God *has* done, then, sets up what Israel *ought* to do. It seems at a superficial level to be the opposite of what Paul declares in his emotive and evocative letter to the Philippian Christians: "One thing I do: forgetting what lies behind and straining forward to what lies ahead, I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus" (Phil. 3:13–14). Oliver O'Donovan explains Paul's words this way:

<span id="page-497-2"></span>On the face of it Paul is simply opposed to remembering . . . But in fact, of course, Paul never stopped remembering. The whole of this passage, like so much else that he wrote, springs from that infinitely fruitful focus of his memory, the event on the Damascus road. So the question is not whether to remember, but how to. Memory, like every other movement of the mind, has to serve the upward call. It has to prepare us to recognize that moment, not shield us against it. . . . To remember constructively is, in one sense, to disown the past, not in the sense of denying it, but gaining a distance on it, *discounting it*, in Paul's metaphor, against the gain that is offered us on the other horizon. And how do we discount it? By setting it to God's account. That is why we are so often told by the apostles to give thanks. Thankful memory transfers events out of our own field of action into the record of God's deeds for us.134

If O'Donovan is right, then the "how" of memory taught by Paul is of the same quality as that urged by Joshua on Israel and its leaders. All that they enjoy is God's doing; how should they then live? By clinging to, by loving, the God whose every good word to them brought life.

<span id="page-497-1"></span>There is warning in the end. Here too there are Pauline parallels, notably in his warning directed to the Gentile Christians in Rome, and in which the Jewish Christians in Rome were also implicated: "They were broken off because of their unbelief, but you stand fast through faith. So do not become proud, but fear. For if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will he spare you" (Rom. 11:20–21). It is not just Paul. Jesus conveys his message to the churches in Asia through John on Patmos and warns the Ephesians, "I will come to you and remove your lampstand from its place, unless you repent" (Rev. 2:5; cf. 2:16; 3:3, 17, 19). Joshua's speech urges God's people to see that contentment as a consequence of triumph is time not for complacency but for deep concern and devoted commitment.
