" And his young man thrust him through, and he died. **55**And when the men of Israel saw that

return on their heads, and upon them came the curse of Jotham the son of

<span id="page-592-2"></span>1Septuagint; Hebrew *and he said* 2Or *at Tormah* 3Hebrew *besieging*, or *closing up* 4Hebrew *You see*

#### *Section Overview*

Jerubbaal.

Gideon refused to rule over Israel as king because he understood that the Lord was Israel's true King. It is tragic, therefore, that on the heels of Gideon's confession we encounter one of his sons seizing the office of king in an illegitimate manner. Deuteronomy legislates kingship for Israel upon settlement in the land, but the king must be the one "whom the Lord your God will choose" (Deut. 17:15). After murdering all but one of his seventy brothers, Abimelech makes himself king.

<span id="page-592-5"></span><span id="page-592-4"></span>The Abimelech narrative is divided into three unequal parts: the rise of Abimelech, the curse of Jotham, and the fall of Abimelech. The epilogue to the Gideon account (Judg. 8:29–35) provides the background for the Abimelech narrative. Gideon had seventy biological sons because he had numerous wives, a harem of sorts (v. 30). However, he also had an additional son, Abimelech, with a concubine living in Shechem (v. 31). We also learn that, upon the death of Gideon, Israel returned to whoring after other gods (v. 33) and so forgot the goodness both of the Lord and of Gideon to Israel (vv. 34–35). The combination of numerous wives, idolatry, and terrible judgment appears again in the assessment of Solomon's kingship in 1 Kings 11.

<span id="page-592-10"></span><span id="page-592-8"></span><span id="page-592-7"></span><span id="page-592-6"></span><span id="page-592-1"></span>Abimelech is the anti-judge in the book of Judges. He is not raised up by God but rather raised up by himself. He does not deliver God's people but rather kills and oppresses them. He does not bring rest to the land but rather pollutes it with innocent blood. We are reminded of Numbers 35:33: "You shall not pollute the land in which you live, for blood pollutes the land, and no atonement can be made for the land for the blood that is shed in it, except by the blood of the one who shed it" (cf. Gen. 9:5–6). In the end God will make atonement for the land with the death of Abimelech and the destruction of the men of Shechem.

#### <span id="page-592-0"></span>*Section Outline*

II.B.2. Abimelech (9:1–57; anti-judge)

- a. The Rise of Abimelech to Kingship (9:1–6)
- b. The Curse of Jotham (9:7–21)
- c. The Fall of Abimelech from Kingship (9:22–57)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-592-9"></span><span id="page-592-3"></span>9:1–2 Abimelech is identified as the son of Jerubbaal, the name given to Gideon when he tore down the altar of Baal in Judges 6. Now Abimelech is about to tear down Gideon's family in his quest to become king. The name Abimelech means <span id="page-593-1"></span>either "my father is king" or "father of a king." Either way the name is striking, given the context. It is not clear what prompts Abimelech to seize power in this fashion. However, the question put to his mother's family clearly recalls Israel's request and Gideon's refusal of kingship in the previous chapter. The verb "to rule," used four times in 8:22–23, appears two more times here in verse 2. "Which is better for you . . . ?" seems to imply that the seventy sons of Gideon are ruling over Israel at the time. This may be true, but it may also be a deceptive scheme of Abimelech to provoke Shechem's allegiance and the securing of funds to establish a mercenary army. He grounds his request in the fact that he is biologically related to his mother's family. This is ironic, given that he is also related to the seventy men he is about to murder.

<span id="page-593-4"></span>9:3–5 The family of Abimelech's mother persuades the "leaders" of Shechem to support Gideon's cause. The Hebrew for "leader" is the same word rendered "Baal" throughout Judges. This is an intentional play on words. Israel worships Baal, and the Shechemites take the money to support Abimelech from the temple of "Baalberith." The worshipers of Baal have become the baals of Shechem. It is true that we become what we worship: "Those who make them become like them; so do all who trust in them" (Ps. 115:8). Taking money from the temple of Baal-berith connects the actions of Abimelech and the people of Shechem to their idolatry. They have forsaken the way of the Lord and all of his good laws that protect and provide for life. The way of Baal is the way of death, which is what follows.

<span id="page-593-9"></span><span id="page-593-0"></span>Gideon's mercenary army consists of "worthless and reckless fellows." The word translated "worthless" means "empty," the same word used to describe empty jars in Judges 7:16 and the men who gather to Jephthah in 11:3. It is not clear whether this word describes the character of these men or their status. They are free or empty from any other connection or commitment and thus able to join with Abimelech. The term translated "reckless" can mean "insolent, undisciplined, reckless" and certainly describes their poor character. They are reckless and available, and Abimelech pays them off to do his evil bidding.

<span id="page-593-7"></span><span id="page-593-5"></span><span id="page-593-3"></span>The ironic theme of biological kinship continues in these verses. The Shechemites agree to support Abimelech because "he is our brother" (9:3). With their support, however, he plans to murder "his brothers" (v. 5). The Shechemites should have considered the situation more carefully. Family ties mean nothing to Abimelech, for he will soon return to kill all of the people of Shechem and destroy their city (vv. 45–49). In the end, no one survives except Jotham, the youngest son of Gideon. The death of Gideon's sons is tragic, later characterized as the "evil of Abimelech, which he committed against his father" (v. 56). We are also reminded of the death of Gideon's brothers reported in 8:18–19. Israel's idolatry continues to pay dividends in death and ever-increasing corruption. This time, however, Israel is its own worst enemy.

<span id="page-593-8"></span><span id="page-593-6"></span><span id="page-593-2"></span>9:6 This first section of the narrative comes to an end with Abimelech installed as king following the execution of his brothers. This is also the first recorded instance <span id="page-594-1"></span><span id="page-594-0"></span>of an Israelite king ruling over God's people in the land. The Lord did promise Abraham and the patriarchs that kings would come from their bodies (Gen. 17:6, 16; 35:11), but Abimelech is not a true king. He is an anti-king. The Lord has not chosen him, and Abimelech does not govern according to the laws of kingship (Deut. 17:14–20). The true King will be raised up by the Lord in order to lay down his life for his brothers so that they might reign together with him (John 10:11–18). By way of absolute contrast, Abimelech becomes king by taking the life of his brothers.

<span id="page-594-14"></span><span id="page-594-7"></span><span id="page-594-6"></span><span id="page-594-5"></span><span id="page-594-4"></span><span id="page-594-3"></span>9:7 Of Gideon's seventy sons, only Jotham has survived, for he hid himself on the day of his brothers' massacre (Judg. 9:5). He now returns and invokes God's presence to make right this great wrong. The setting of Mount Gerizim is no accident. Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal are the mountains of blessing and cursing under the administration of the Mosaic covenant (Deut. 11:29; 27:12). Before these two mountains all Israel assembled to hear the blessings and curses stipulated for obedience (or disobedience) to the law of God, that those mountains might serve as perpetual, enduring witnesses to the covenant (Josh. 8:33). Gerizim was the mountain of blessing. The fact that Jotham stands upon this mountain suggests that Abimelech has taken something God intended as a blessing (kingship) and turned it into a curse. Jotham does not take matters into his own hands, as had Abimelech. Instead he trusts the Lord to be faithful to uphold his covenant. While it takes three years to play out, the Lord does in fact show himself faithful to curse those who are unfaithful to his covenant law (cf. Judg. 9:56–57).

<span id="page-594-10"></span><span id="page-594-9"></span><span id="page-594-8"></span><span id="page-594-2"></span>9:8–15 The curse of Jotham begins with a fable, a tale in which the elements of nature are animated and speak. In this case Jotham employs talking trees to make his point. The trees in the fable represent not only the people of Shechem in particular but also all Israel in general. Later these trees are called "cedars of Lebanon" (v. 15). Four specific types of trees (or plants) are animated in the fable: olive, fig, vine, and bramble. The first three trees are fruit-bearing trees and a source of blessing for Israel (Deut. 8:8), much like Gideon served as a blessing for God's people. The three fruit trees decline the offer of kingship because it would keep them from their intended purpose of bearing fruit. Likewise, the Lord did not raise up Gideon to be king. Rather, the Lord was their King, with Gideon simply the instrument of the Lord's deliverance. Gideon fulfilled his role in the Lord's theocratic economy without grasping for more. Once deliverance was achieved, Gideon returned to his home.

<span id="page-594-13"></span><span id="page-594-12"></span><span id="page-594-11"></span>The bramble (buckthorn, thorn bush) is a non-fruit-bearing tree, suitable only for the fire. The Hebrew word for "bramble" occurs only here in this fable and in Psalm 58:9: "Sooner than your pots can feel the heat of thorns [the bramble], whether green or ablaze, may he sweep them away!" Psalm 58 is an imprecatory psalm in which David prays that God would judge the wicked—someone like Abimelech. The final line of the psalm identifies the purpose of Jotham's curse: "Surely there is a God who judges on earth" (Ps. 58:11). The response of the bramble is unlike the three previous fruit trees'. The bramble accepts the offer of kingship, with a warning. If Israel has acted "in good faith" (truth) by making Abimelech king, then they will take refuge in his shade. But if not, then fire will break forth from the bramble and devour them.

<span id="page-595-6"></span><span id="page-595-5"></span><span id="page-595-4"></span>9:16–21 The interpretation of Jotham's fable follows. There is no reference to the three fruit-bearing trees; the focus is entirely on the bramble (Abimelech) and the cedars of Lebanon (those who installed Abimelech as king; Judg. 9:6). Jotham's interpretation implies that the leaders of Shechem have not acted in good faith (vv. 17–18)—but Jotham will not serve as judge. After delivering the fable and its interpretation he flees to Beer because of his brother (v. 21) and waits for the Lord to render his verdict. In the verses that follow fire will break forth from the bramble, consuming both the people and the bramble itself as God's judges their actions as "evil" (vv. 56–57).

<span id="page-595-10"></span><span id="page-595-7"></span>9:22 The account of Abimelech's reign begins here and runs through the end of the chapter, whereupon his death and the assessment of his actions are recorded. Abimelech's reign is short-lived at three years, covering the period from Jotham's curse to Abimelech's death—in other words, the events that follow occur during this three-year period of time. The word translated here as "ruled over" is not the same verb used in 8:22–23; 9:2, nor is it the standard Hebrew verb for kingship ("to reign, be king"). This particular verb occurs only six times in the OT (Num. 16:13 [2x]; Judg. 9:22; Isa. 32:1; Prov. 8:16; Est. 1:22), and its use here constitutes the author's tacit assessment of Abimelech's illicit reign.

<span id="page-595-12"></span><span id="page-595-11"></span><span id="page-595-8"></span><span id="page-595-3"></span><span id="page-595-2"></span><span id="page-595-0"></span>9:23–24 The Lord sets in motion the judgment of Abimelech and the "leaders" (or "baals"; cf. comment on 9:3–5) of Shechem by sending an evil spirit between them in order to incite hostility among them. The expression "evil spirit" occurs only here and at 1 Samuel 16:14, where it is sometimes translated "harmful spirit." Variations of this designation include "harmful [evil] spirit from God" and "harmful [evil] spirit from the Lord" (cf. 1 Sam. 16:15–16, 23; 18:10; 19:9), all of which occur in connection with Saul after he is rejected by the Lord as Israel's king. In the case both of Abimelech and of Saul the sending of the evil/harmful spirit begins a long, torturous process that leads to the corruption of the king's reign and the king's eventual death in battle. In this case the evil spirit has been sent because of the murder of the seventy sons of Jerubbaal. As such, the Lord stands as the avenger of blood among his people.

<span id="page-595-9"></span><span id="page-595-1"></span>9:25–29 Hostility toward Abimelech provokes the leaders of Shechem to set an ambush for him. While waiting they pillage passersby, making the land a place of oppression as in the days before Deborah (Judg. 5:6–7). The embodiment of the evil spirit from God comes in the form of Gaal, son of Ebed. In the midst of the grape harvest the people of Shechem, along with Gaal, feast in the house of their pagan god, Baal-berith. Perhaps emboldened by the wine, the people "revile" (or "curse") Abimelech. This incites Gaal to seize power by boasting in his willingness to remove Abimelech if the people will make him ruler.

<span id="page-596-7"></span><span id="page-596-6"></span><span id="page-596-1"></span><span id="page-596-0"></span>Gaal moves into the region of Shechem with his brothers and quickly garners the trust of its leaders. In verse 28 Gaal identifies himself with Hamor, father of Shechem, of the original Canaanite inhabitants of that city (Gen. 34:2). It is ironic that Gaal attempts to usurp Abimelech's rule with reference to his lineage — the exact strategy Abimelech employed when becoming king (Judg. 9:1–3). The reference to "his relatives" in verse 26 can also be rendered "his brothers," reminding us of the beginning of the narrative, in which Abimelech aligned himself with the people of Shechem ("because he is our brother"; v. 3) and then went out to murder "his brothers" (v. 5). This decay of familial fidelity plays out later, in the conclusion to the book, when the tribe of Benjamin teeters on the brink of extinction.

<span id="page-596-9"></span><span id="page-596-8"></span><span id="page-596-4"></span><span id="page-596-3"></span><span id="page-596-2"></span>9:30–33 It appears that a man named Zebul has charge of the city while Abimelech is away. In verse 28 Zebul was called "his officer," which could also be rendered "his overseer, administrator, leader, or representative," someone appointed to serve in a particular capacity on behalf of another.28 Here in verse 30 Zebul is described as "ruler of the city." The word for "ruler" is the nominal form of the verb used to describe Abimelech's rule in verse 22, strengthening the connection between the two. Zebul sends word to Abimelech after hearing the boast of Gaal. The word translated "secretly" occurs only here in the Hebrew Bible; its exact meaning is unknown. Some have suggested it means "deceitfully," with Zebul feigning allegiance with Gaal while sending messengers to Abimelech. Others have suggested the text should be emended to the proper noun "Arumah," which appears in verse 41 as the place in which Abimelech actually lives. The translation ambiguity does not dramatically impact the overall meaning or interpretation of the text. However, the nuance of deception is suggested by Zebul's later actions, as he deceives Gaal about the army of Abimelech streaming in ambush toward the city (v. 36).

<span id="page-596-14"></span><span id="page-596-13"></span><span id="page-596-11"></span>Zebul sends word to Abimelech that Gaal and his family have come to the city and are "stirring up" the inhabitants against him. This is the same verb used to describe an army encircling or besieging a city, as in 1 Samuel 23:8: "Saul summoned all the people to war, to go down to Keilah, *to besiege* David and his men." The use of this verb suggests the war between Gaal and Abimelech has already begun before the actual physical assault takes place. Zebul advises Abimelech to come and set an ambush at night, just as leaders of Shechem had schemed (Judg. 9:25).

<span id="page-596-12"></span><span id="page-596-10"></span><span id="page-596-5"></span>9:34–41 Following the plan of Zebul, Abimelech drives out Gaal and his family from Shechem. Abimelech's success is further aided by Zebul's deception of Gaal (v. 36), which allows Abimelech and his forces to reach the city before Gaal could rally his forces and mount a successful defense. The word translated "wounded" in verse 40 could also be rendered "slain," a severer outcome to the battle. The <span id="page-597-9"></span>reference to Abimelech's living in Arumah (v. 41) points to his unwelcome status in the town of his mother.

<span id="page-597-10"></span><span id="page-597-8"></span>9:42–45 Having driven out Gaal and his family from Shechem, Abimelech wages war with the inhabitants of the city. The text indicates that this occurs the very next day, implying that the people of the city go into the fields to continue the grape harvest (v. 27). This provides Abimelech with the opportunity to set another ambush. His forces divide into three companies, with the first cutting off access to the city gates so that the people cannot return and seek refuge in the city. The second two companies attack and kill the people of Shechem in the fields. The battle lasts all day. Abimelech kills the inhabitants, destroys the city, and sows it with salt. This would render the land infertile, a curse upon the land recalling God's warning for unfaithfulness to the covenant: "The whole land burned out with brimstone and salt, nothing sown and nothing growing, where no plant can sprout, an overthrow like that of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, which the Lord overthrew in his anger and wrath" (Deut. 29:23).

<span id="page-597-12"></span><span id="page-597-11"></span><span id="page-597-4"></span><span id="page-597-3"></span><span id="page-597-1"></span><span id="page-597-0"></span>9:46–49 In Judges 9:45 it was recorded that Abimelech captured the city of Shechem, killed its people, and destroyed the city. Now we return to one particular event in the destruction of the city and the death of its inhabitants. A common feature in Hebrew narrative is to begin with a summary statement of a particular event and then to provide a more detailed account of that event, with particular focus on a significant or important feature. For example, in Genesis 1:1 it is recorded that God created all things invisible (the heavens) and visible (the earth; cf. Col. 1:16). Then in Genesis 1:2–31 the author narrates how God created the earth (the visible realm) in the space of six days. Then in Genesis 2:4–25 the author returns again to provide further details about the events of day six. And so by the end of Genesis 2 the events of day six have been presented three times, with increasing level of detail. Similarly here the author returns and provides further details of the events summarized in Judges 9:45. The focus of these verses presents the destruction of Shechem as the fulfillment of the curse of Jotham. The fire has come out of the bramble (Abimelech) and consumed the inhabitants of the city for their role in the murder of Gideon's seventy sons (9:15, 20).

<span id="page-597-14"></span><span id="page-597-13"></span><span id="page-597-7"></span><span id="page-597-6"></span><span id="page-597-5"></span><span id="page-597-2"></span>"Leaders [or "baals"; cf. comment on 9:3–5] of the Tower of Shechem" refers to the leaders who made Abimelech king and provided the resources for him to murder the seventy sons of Gideon. "El-berith" appears to be another name for Baal-berith, referenced in 8:33; 9:4. The word translated "stronghold" occurs three times in these verses and then only at 1 Samuel 13:6, where it is rendered "tombs": "The people hid themselves in caves and in holes and in rocks and in tombs and in cisterns." The term appears to refer to some sort of inner chamber, a refuge of last resort to hide from an enemy. In Judges 9:49 it is associated with the Tower of Shechem. Perhaps the pagan temple, the tower, and the inner chamber or stronghold constituted a single complex that served various cultic and military functions in the city. With the leaders of the city locked in the tower, Abimelech

devises a plan to burn down the stronghold with the inhabitants of the city in it. He and his army ascend Mount Zalmon, cut down tree branches, and use the wood to burn down the stronghold containing "about 1,000 men and women." The location of Mount Zalmon is unknown. Some have suggested that it represents another name for Mount Gerizim or Mount Ebal; it appears again only at Psalm 68:14. "Zalmon" means "shadow" or "darkness" and may hint at the nature of the dark events recorded in these verses.

<span id="page-598-9"></span><span id="page-598-3"></span><span id="page-598-1"></span>9:50–55 It is not revealed why Abimelech attacked Thebez after destroying Shechem. This section focuses instead on the nature of Abimelech's death as the anti-judge, or anti-king, of Judges. The battle at Thebez parallels that at Shechem in several ways. First, Abimelech captures the city, and its inhabitants take refuge in the city tower, this time on the roof. Second, Abimelech sets out to burn the tower with the inhabitants of the city inside, as at Shechem. This time, however, a woman hurls an upper millstone from the roof and crushes Abimelech's head. This is the second time a woman has crushed the head of a man in Judges (cf. 4:21–22). Once again we are reminded of the promise of God that the seed of the woman would crush the head of the Serpent and deliver God's people from the Enemy (Gen. 3:15). The Hebrew for "skull" (Judg. 9:53) also reminds us of the place of the crucifixion of Jesus: "And he went out, bearing his own cross, to the place called The Place of a Skull, which in Aramaic is called Golgotha" (John 19:17; cf. Matt. 27:33; Mark 15:22). The account of the death of Abimelech is the OT version of Golgotha, the place where his skull was crushed.

<span id="page-598-11"></span><span id="page-598-10"></span><span id="page-598-8"></span><span id="page-598-7"></span><span id="page-598-4"></span><span id="page-598-0"></span>As the anti-judge, or anti-king, of Judges, Abimelech in death shares features with Saul, another anti-king figure. For example, both Abimelech and Saul are injured in battle but request their armor bearer to kill them in order to avoid a more shameful death (1 Sam. 31:4). The Philistines remove the skull of Saul and post it in the temple of Dagon as an act of humiliation and subjugation (1 Chron. 10:10, there the word rendered "head" is the same for "skull" used in Judges 9:53). At the crucifixion of Jesus on Golgotha the sign above his head posted by Pilate reads "King of the Jews" (John 19:19). Abimelech and Saul are anti-king figures who die because of their sin (Judg. 9:56; 1 Chron. 10:13–14). Jesus is the true King, the seed of David, but he dies for our sins so that we might one day reign with him in the new heavens and the new earth.

<span id="page-598-12"></span><span id="page-598-6"></span><span id="page-598-5"></span><span id="page-598-2"></span>9:56–57 These final verses provide the theological assessment of the Abimelech narrative. First it is stated that God has "returned the evil of Abimelech" to him with regard to the murder of his brothers. God also has returned the evil of Shechem "on their heads" for making Abimelech king. The curse of Jotham has been fulfilled: "Let fire come out from Abimelech and devour the leaders of Shechem and Beth-millo; and let fire come out from the leaders of Shechem and from Beth-millo and devour Abimelech" (Judg. 9:20). Verse 56–57 both present God as the one who has brought about judgment in the land. He himself has avenged the innocent blood of the seventy sons of Jerubbaal.

#### *Response*

Abimelech is the anti-judge in the book of Judges. The Lord does not raise up this man. Abimelech raises up himself. He does not save Israel from the enemy. He is the enemy from whom Israel needs saving. He does not bring rest to the land but ravages it. The Abimelech narratives put on full display the inner corruption of Israel, which has been spreading like a virus since the days when Joshua and his generation died. In this lengthy account the author of Judges lingers over the corruption of Abimelech and the people of Shechem, a part of the whole, the leaven in the dough. This serves as a picture of life "under the sun" (Eccles. 1:9, 14), that is, life that rejects the kingship of the Lord and covenant living. Fratricide, betrayal, war, and death are the fruits of this life. This account serves as a warning to future generations, and so the apostle Paul warns us in 1 Corinthians 10:11–13:

<span id="page-599-2"></span><span id="page-599-1"></span>These things happened to them as an example, but they were written down for our instruction, on whom the end of the ages has come. Therefore let anyone who thinks that he stands take heed lest he fall. No temptation has overtaken you that is not common to man. God is faithful, and he will not let you be tempted beyond your ability, but with the temptation he will also provide the way of escape, that you may be able to endure it.

### <span id="page-599-0"></span>JUDGES 10:1–5

10 After Abimelech there arose to save Israel Tola the son of Puah, son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, and he lived at Shamir in the hill country of Ephraim. **2**And he judged Israel twenty-three years. Then he died and was buried at Shamir.

After him arose Jair the Gileadite, who judged Israel twenty-two years. And he had thirty sons who rode on thirty donkeys, and they had thirty cities, called Havvoth-jair to this day, which are in the land of Gilead. And Jair died and was buried in Kamon.

#### *Section Overview*

In this section we encounter two more minor judges. They have been grouped together. In the first panel of judges (Othniel, Ehud, and Deborah/Barak) only Shamgar appeared between Ehud and Deborah/Barak. Now here Tola and Jair appear between Gideon/Abimelech and Jephthah. Ibzan, Elon, and Abdon will appear together as a group of three minor judges between Jephthah and Samson. There is an element of escalation in these groupings, from one to two to three. However, the reason for these groupings is unknown. The six minor judges, together with the six major judges, certainly represent the twelve tribes of Israel, but their placement in the book remains somewhat of a mystery. It is possible that they mark or introduce progressively climactic judge figures: Deborah/Barak, Jephthah, and Samson. However, this assessment excludes Gideon, who would certainly constitute a climactic figure in Judges.

#### *Section Outline*

II.B.3. Tola (10:1–2; minor) II.B.4. Jair (10:3–5; minor)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-600-7"></span><span id="page-600-6"></span>10:1–2 Tola is the second minor judge in the book. He is from the tribe of Issachar but lives in Ephraim. Issachar's inheritance is located north of west Manasseh and south of Zebulun; Ephraim's is just south of west Manasseh.29 Verse 1 states that Tola rises up to "save Israel," but the text does not provide the name of the enemy, the length of subjugation, or the nature of the deliverance. In addition to Tola's name, the names of his father and grandfather, and his place of dwelling, the text only records the fact that he judges Israel for twenty-three years before dying and being buried in Shamir, that is, in Ephraim. A Tola is also listed in Genesis 46:13; Numbers 26:23; and 1 Chronicles 7:1.

<span id="page-600-8"></span><span id="page-600-5"></span><span id="page-600-1"></span><span id="page-600-0"></span>10:3–5 Jair the Gileadite is the third minor judge. Gilead is a region east of the Jordan, straddling Gad and east Manasseh. Jair judges Israel for twenty-two years before dying and being buried in Kamon. Between the record of his service as judge in Judges 9:3 and his death in 9:5 we find a curious statement regarding his thirty sons' riding thirty donkeys and having thirty cities. This implies a harem, significant wealth, and substantial influence in Gilead. Jair is also listed in Numbers 32:41 as a son of Manasseh with the account of his capturing and naming the thirty cities or villages. The word "Havvoth" is the feminine plural form of a Hebrew noun meaning "village," thus "villages of Jair" (cf. Deut. 3:14; Josh. 13:30).

#### <span id="page-600-3"></span><span id="page-600-2"></span>*Response*

The brief accounts of Tola and Jair remind us that God continues to save and deliver his people and to provide appropriate leadership in dark and difficult times. This series of judges also reminds us of the temporary nature of their role in the theocratic economy of God—judge after judge, king after king, until the one who will come and deliver God's people with one final victory, lasting for all of eternity. "He has appeared once for all at the end of the ages to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself" (Heb. 9:26; cf. 7:27; 9:12; 10:10). When this one, Jesus, returns, he will reign forever (Rev. 11:15), and we will reign with him (Rev. 22:5).

<span id="page-600-9"></span><span id="page-600-4"></span><sup>29</sup> For a helpful display of tribal inheritance cf. Currid and Barrett, *Crossway ESV Bible Atlas*, 107, map 4.13.
