#### *Section Overview*

This first conclusion contains three scenes, each of which is followed by the summary statement that there was no king in the land at the time. Micah, from the hill country of Ephraim, is a central character in each of the three scenes. In the first scene he outfits a household shrine with cultic objects and ordains one of his sons to serve as priest. In the second scene he hires and ordains a Levite from Bethlehem of Judah to serve as priest in that shrine. Finally, in the third scene the Danites migrate north and steal Micah's cultic objects and the Levite to serve as priest for the tribe in its new settlement. The theme of this section is Israel's illegitimate worship of the Lord, including idolatry (syncretism). This theme is exemplified by way of contrast with reference to the place of worship. The narrative begins with reference to Micah's shrine, "a house of gods" in Hebrew (17:5). It concludes with reference to "*the* house of God" in Shiloh (18:31). When Israel entered the land, the people were commanded not to worship other gods and not to worship God in an illegitimate manner. This first conclusion documents Israel's clear violation of the first two commandments (Ex. 20:3–6; Deut. 5:7–10), in addition to many other violations of the covenant stipulations.

#### <span id="page-649-4"></span><span id="page-649-2"></span><span id="page-649-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- III. Conclusion to the Judges (17:1–21:25)
	- A. The Crisis of Israel's Faith: Idolatry (17:1–18:31)
		- 1. Micah's Shrine (17:1–7)
		- 2. Micah's Priest (17:8–13)
		- 3. The Danite Migration with Micah's Shrine and Priest (18:1–31)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-649-3"></span><span id="page-649-1"></span>17:1 The first conclusion to Judges opens with reference to "a man." This is Micah, from the hill country of Ephraim. Micah serves as a central character in all three scenes of this first conclusion. The use of the Hebrew noun "man" plays an important literary role in this first scene. Together with the proper noun "Micah," it brackets the account in verses 1, 5. These references to Micah as a "man" connect his actions with the theological assessment that follows in verse 6, "Everyone did what was right in his own eyes," where the word rendered "everyone" is the same

<span id="page-650-2"></span>as that rendered "man" in verses 1, 5. In this way the actions of the "man" Micah are the actions condemned by the narrator, something upright in his own eyes but not in those of the Lord. All three scenes in this first conclusion are designed to illustrate the manner in which everyone was doing what was right in his own eyes.

<span id="page-650-4"></span><span id="page-650-1"></span>17:2–5 This first scene opens with Micah's confession of stealing "1,100 pieces of silver" from his mother, the same amount each of the lords of the Philistines paid to Delilah for her betrayal of Samson (16:5). The mother's response to this confession is unexpected: she pronounces a blessing on the son who has stolen from her. When Micah returns the silver to his mother, she dedicates it to the Lord by having a portion of it made into an idol, which is then kept in the house of Micah. Micah has another house: a "shrine" (v. 5; or, "a house of gods"). Not only does Micah have a shrine filled with idols and other cultic items, but he also ordains one of his own sons to serve as priest in this illicit shrine. Since Micah's son is not a descendent of Aaron or even a Levite at all, he is not permitted to serve as a priest according to the Mosaic covenant.

<span id="page-650-0"></span>The major theme of this first conclusion is Israel's idolatry in the period of the judges—the very sin permeating the narratives of the first sixteen chapters of the book (e.g., 2:11–13, 19; 3:5–7; 6:25–26; esp. 10:6–16). What this first scene teaches us is that idolatry comes with other besetting sins. For instance, the making and worshiping of idols violates the first two commandments. Micah's mother blesses her son in the name of the Lord (Yahweh) and also dedicates an idol to his name, clearly a violation of the third commandment by using the name of the Lord (Yahweh) in an inappropriate manner. Micah fails to honor his mother when he steals from her, a violation of the fifth and eighth commandments. It could also be argued that Micah steals the silver because he covets the wealth of his mother, a violation of the tenth commandment. In only four short verses the author of this account puts on full display the extent of Israel's corruption by documenting the violation of at least six of the ten commandments intended to govern the lives of God's people both in private and in public. On the surface, Micah and his mother may appear to be good, religious people. They walk the walk; they talk the talk. They bless in the name of the Lord; they give generously to him. This is the trap of the religious system of the human heart: it seeks to worship God in its own way and not according to what has been revealed in his word and stipulated in the covenant.

<span id="page-650-6"></span><span id="page-650-5"></span><span id="page-650-3"></span>17:6 This is the first of four such summary statements appearing in the conclusions to Judges (cf. Overview of 17:1–21:25). At the literary level, the first two summary statements mark transitions between each of the scenes in this first conclusion. At the redemptive-historical level, this statement anticipates the emergence of the monarchy in Israel, as recorded in 1–2 Samuel. At the theological level, this statement indicts Israel for rejecting the Lord as its King, resulting in corruption by becoming like all of the nations around it. The Lord was Israel's King, the one who would lead out in battle and deliver the enemy into the hand of his people.

<span id="page-651-7"></span><span id="page-651-1"></span>Gideon had objected to Israel's desire to make him King: "I will not rule over you, and my son will not rule over you; the Lord will rule over you" (Judg. 8:23). The Lord himself makes the very same point when the people ask for a king later in 1 Samuel: "The Lord said to Samuel, 'Obey the voice of the people in all that they say to you, for they have not rejected you, *but they have rejected me from being king over them*'" (1 Sam. 8:7). There is a clear cause-and-effect relationship between the two parts of the statement recorded in this verse. There was no king in Israel; *therefore*, everyone was doing what was right in his own eyes. Israel's rejection of the Lord as its King is exemplified by its disobedience to the terms of the covenant, which is the cause of its corruption and subsequent oppression by the surrounding nations.

<span id="page-651-6"></span><span id="page-651-2"></span>17:7–9 In this second scene of the first conclusion to Judges we are introduced to a Levite from Bethlehem of Judah who travels to the hill country of Ephraim looking for work and a place to live. This Levite happens to cross paths with Micah, who queries him about his travels. The second conclusion to Judges begins with a Levite from the hill country of Ephraim who travels to Bethlehem of Judah—just the reverse of what occurs here (Judg. 19:1). This type of artistic repetition is one of the ways in which the author links the two conclusions. Each conclusion has its own distinct message (idolatry and inheritance), but they are connected by means of various literary devices such as this one. In this case, the connection between the two conclusions is one of cause and effect. The crisis of Israel's inheritance (the loss of a tribe) is the result of her idolatry and the additional besetting sins occasioned by false worship.

<span id="page-651-9"></span><span id="page-651-8"></span><span id="page-651-5"></span><span id="page-651-3"></span>17:10–12 Micah offers the young Levite both employment and housing. He desires for this Levite to serve as "a father and a priest" to his household. For these services Micah will compensate him with money, clothing, food, and shelter. Such an offer in the ancient world would have been difficult to refuse. The designation "father" in this context means "teacher," not a literal father (cf. 18:19). This is clear from the fact that the young Levite "became to him like one of his sons." The use of "father" for teacher is well known from the wisdom tradition of Proverbs 1–9, and Elisha uses this same designation for Elijah when the latter is taken up by chariots of fire into heaven (2 Kings 2:12). This idiom also appears in the NT teaching of Jesus (Matt. 23:8–10). In the end, the Levite accepts Micah's offer and is ordained as priest for the family of Micah, likely in the shrine Micah had built and outfitted with idols. In the previous scene Micah had ordained one of his sons to serve as family priest; it is unclear whether the Levite serves with Micah's son or replaces him. The Hebrew word translated "ordain" could be rendered "fill the hand" (cf. Ex. 28:41; 29:9, 29, 33, 35); this idiom signifies that the one ordained will receive his living (the filling of his hand) by his service as priest.

<span id="page-651-10"></span><span id="page-651-4"></span><span id="page-651-0"></span>17:13 Micah's assessment of the arrangement with the Levite betrays what has motivated him to build a shrine, make idols, and hire a Levite: he seeks to ensure that the Lord (Yahweh) will be good to him and prosper him. This is the heart of J udges 17:1–18:31 652

idolatry. Micah has constructed a religious environment in which and by which he thinks he can manipulate God. Rather than seeking the Lord according to the terms of the covenant, Micah sets up his own system of religion to provoke God's favor. Later, Samuel will condemn this very type of religion when Saul offers a sacrifice to ensure the favor of Lord:

 Has the Lord as great delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the Lord? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to listen than the fat of rams. For rebellion is as the sin of divination, and presumption is as iniquity and idolatry. (1 Sam. 15:22–23)

<span id="page-652-7"></span>It is ironic, therefore, that in the very next scene Micah will suffer the loss of his idols and his priest, the very system he has created to ensure his prosperity.

<span id="page-652-4"></span><span id="page-652-3"></span><span id="page-652-0"></span>18:1 The transition to the next scene in this first conclusion to Judges is marked by the second occurrence of the summary statement "In those days there was no king in Israel" (cf. comment on 17:6; Overview of 17:1–21:25). This next scene begins by repeating the opening phrase of the summary statement ("In those days") and records the migration of the tribe of Dan to the north and its encounter with Micah and the Levite during that migration. Dan was one of the twelve sons of Jacob, from Bilhah the maidservant of Rachel, who also bore Naphtali (Gen. 30:6; 35:25). The territory allotted by Joshua to the tribe is located on the Mediterranean coast north of Judah, south of west Manasseh, and west of Ephraim.63 The tribe of Dan, however, is unable to dispossess the inhabitants of that territory and so migrates north and occupies and renames the city of Leshem (Laish) in the northeastern region of Naphtali (Josh. 19:40–48).64

<span id="page-652-5"></span><span id="page-652-1"></span>18:2 Because Dan is unable to occupy its allotted portion of the land, the tribe sets out to find another suitable location. To do this it selects and sends out five men from its midst to explore the land. These men are from Zorah and Eshtaol, the same locations mentioned when the Lord began to stir up Samson to begin his service as judge (Judg. 13:25). During this exploratory expedition these five men happen to come across the house of Micah in the hill country of Ephraim, where they lodge during this portion of their journey.

<span id="page-652-6"></span><span id="page-652-2"></span>18:3–6 While staying with Micah these five men encounter the Levite, with whom they are already familiar. Like Micah, these men also employ the services of this false priest by asking him to inquire of the Lord for them regarding the disposition of their expedition. The priest provides a favorable response, but it is unknown how or why he comes to this assessment of the situation. Given the author's negative characterization of Micah and the Levite, we can perhaps conclude that the

<sup>63</sup> Cf. Currid and Barrett, *Crossway ESV Bible Atlas*, 107, map 4-13.

<sup>64</sup> Cf. ibid., 114–116, map 4.24.

Levite's positive response is intended to ingratiate himself to these men from Dan. As it turns out, the Levite will promote himself from serving as a family priest to serving as the priest of the tribe of Dan later in the account.

<span id="page-653-4"></span><span id="page-653-3"></span>18:7–10 After leaving the hill country of Ephraim and the house of Micah, the five spies come upon a flourishing and unsuspecting city, Laish (Leshem), in the very northern region of Israel's territory. The city is both prosperous and unprotected, exactly the type of city one would choose in such a situation. It would be easy to eliminate its inhabitants, and the spoils of war would prosper the victor. The spies return with their report and call out the Danites to go up and take the city, "for God has given it into your hands" (v. 10). The use of such language to justify one's actions is to be condemned as yet another violation of the third commandment, employing the name or reputation of God in a light or trivial manner. Micah's mother did so when she vowed to make an idol in the name of the Lord (17:3). The Levite did so when he offered blessing on the spies' journey using the name of the Lord (18:6). And now the Danite spies use this same tactic when calling their people out for war. In this final section of Judges Israel has rejected the Lord as her King and behaves in ways that seem right in her own eyes, but not in the eyes of the Lord.

<span id="page-653-10"></span><span id="page-653-5"></span><span id="page-653-2"></span><span id="page-653-1"></span><span id="page-653-0"></span>18:11–13 Six hundred men from Dan set out to take Laish. This is the same number of men from Benjamin who flee the battle in the second conclusion (20:47), providing another point of connection between the two sections. The Danites encamp near Kiriath-jearim and name that location "Mahaneh-dan" ("the camp of Dan"). This is the location at which the Spirit first stirred Samson (13:25). From this location the Danites return to the house of Micah. This encounter at the house of Micah receives considerable attention in the overall distribution of text and is a major focus of the narrative (18:14–26). It records the origin of illicit worship in Dan, which will later serve as the location of one of two golden calves set up by Jeroboam to prevent the people of Israel from worshiping at the temple at Jerusalem (1 Kings 12:26–30).

<span id="page-653-11"></span><span id="page-653-9"></span><span id="page-653-8"></span><span id="page-653-7"></span><span id="page-653-6"></span>18:14–20 The five spies divulge the known cultic contents at the houses of Micah to their fellow warriors and solicit their help in a plan to take the idols and also the Levite, to serve as their priest in their new city. The plan devised by the spies is not described but simply enacted, "Now therefore consider [know] what you will do" (Judg. 18:14). The plan consists of stealing the idols and the Levite with a show of force that will prevent Micah from retaining them. With the six hundred armed warriors standing guard at the gate of the city, the five spies remove the cultic items from the houses of Micah and march out in broad daylight. When the Levite asks about the situation, the warriors silence him and offer a promotion: "Is it better for you to be priest to the house of one man, or to be priest to a tribe and clan in Israel?" (v. 19). The priest is pleased with the offer and becomes the very one who takes the cultic objects from the city of his former employer. The Levite

J udges 17:1–18:31 654

<span id="page-654-4"></span><span id="page-654-3"></span>had become like a son to Micah (17:11), but now he betrays him with a willing and glad heart (v. 20). Theft, betrayal, and increased idolatry continue to display the ongoing corruption of Israel in the days of the judges.

<span id="page-654-6"></span><span id="page-654-5"></span><span id="page-654-2"></span>18:21–26 The Danites set out to Laish with the stolen property and priest of Micah. In response, the men living near the house of Micah are called out to confront the Danites regarding their theft. The Danites silence Micah and those with him with threats of force and loss of life. Because his neighbors are no match for the Danite warriors, Micah is forced to return home empty handed. The irony is that the man who stole "1,100 pieces of silver" (17:2) from his own mother now suffers from the very same crime. The real tragedy of Micah's idolatry, however, becomes painfully clear in 18:24. He proclaims, "You take my gods *that I made*." Micah has made his own gods, the work of his own hands, and worshiped what he has created rather than the one who created him. Moses warned Israel that this would happen: "In the days to come evil will befall you, because you will do what is evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking him to anger *through the work of your hands*" (Deut. 31:29). This type of idolatry persists in Israel and is later condemned by the Lord through the prophet Isaiah:

<span id="page-654-0"></span> Their land is filled with idols; they bow down to the *work of their hands*, to what their own fingers have made. (Isa. 2:8)

<span id="page-654-9"></span>The sin of idolatry is to worship what one has made with one's hands rather than rendering true worship to the one whose hands created the universe and fashioned humanity out of the dust. The Lord declared,

 I made the earth and created man on it; *it was my hands* that stretched out the heavens, and I commanded all their host. (Isa. 45:12)

<span id="page-654-10"></span>Micah should perhaps have rejoiced in the kind providence of God that had arranged for the removal of this great evil from his household. Rather, with the loss of his gods and a priest to manipulate them he can only lament, "What have I left?" Micah's idolatry has blinded him to the wealth of being a part of God's covenant people and of the surpassing value of covenant life. The Lord longs for his people to worship and be satisfied. Idolatry of this type never satisfies. There is only one who can fully satisfy, as the psalmist reflects, "In your presence there is fullness of joy; at your right hand are pleasures forevermore" (Ps. 16:11).

<span id="page-654-8"></span><span id="page-654-7"></span><span id="page-654-1"></span>18:27–29 The account of Dan's resettlement is brief; only the most basic details are provided. The people of Dan execute the inhabitants of Laish, burn the city with fire, rebuild the city, and then rename it after their ancestor, Dan. This same event is recorded in Joshua 19:47. The people of Laish are described as quiet, trusting (unsuspecting), and without access to aid or assistance—details included in order to disparage the behavior of the Danites.

<span id="page-655-3"></span><span id="page-655-2"></span>18:30–31 The name of the Levite first encountered in Judges 17:7 is now revealed. Such a delay is undoubtedly intended to shock and surprise the reader. He is "Jonathan the son of Gershom, son of Moses." The Hebrew for "son" can also indicate a more distant relative. Jonathan could be Moses' grandson but could also be a more distant descendent. Either way, the manner in which the author has constructed this brief genealogy is intended to portray how quickly idolatry and corruption spread throughout Israel in the days of the judges—even in the very family of Moses. This fact was considered so shameful by the scribes who preserved and transmitted the Hebrew Bible that they placed a small, superscripted *n* (*nun* in Hebrew) after the *m* (*mem* in Hebrew) in Moses' name to change the pronunciation of the word to "Manasseh."65 The idols, idolatry, and illicit priesthood will persist in Dan until the exile. In fact, at the advent of the divided kingdom Jeroboam will set up golden calves at Dan and Bethel to prevent the northern tribes from worshiping at the temple in Jerusalem (1 Kings 12:26–30). Things will not get better in Israel; they will only go from bad to worse until the Lord must finally expel his people from the land. The reference to Micah's carved image brings to an end this first conclusion to Judges by recalling the original manufacture of the idol (Judg. 17:3–4). In a very real sense, the events recorded in chapters 17–18 could be characterized as the history of Micah's idol, created out of corruption and corrupting all those with whom it comes in contact.

#### <span id="page-655-5"></span><span id="page-655-1"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-655-4"></span><span id="page-655-0"></span>Together the Former Prophets (Joshua, Judges, Samuel, and Kings) demonstrate that the Lord is always faithful to his covenant promises (cf. Josh. 21:45; 1 Kings 8:56). On the other hand, they also demonstrate how Israel struggles to remain faithful to the Lord and to the covenant that regulates and maintains their relationship. This first conclusion to Judges puts on full display Israel's covenantal infidelity as exemplified by her idolatry, that is, her whoring after other gods while forsaking and forgetting the one true God. While idolatry in the modern world may not look like the idolatry of the ancient world, its essence and impact are the same. When we worship what we create with our own hands, we cease to worship the one who created all things. This is the substance of idolatry, the worship of the "work of human hands" (Ps. 115:4). In the ancient world the conduit for such worship took the form of actual idols made from wood, stone, or precious metals. The idols represented the false gods and served as points of access to ensure prosperity and blessing — but also to allow for immoral behavior such as cultic prostitution or child sacrifice as a means for manipulating the gods in one's favor.

<span id="page-655-7"></span><span id="page-655-6"></span><sup>65</sup> The change to Manasseh may characterize the deeds of this Levite as corresponding those of King Manasseh in 2 Kings 21:1–18; cf. Block, *Judges, Ruth*, 512.

<span id="page-656-1"></span>In light of this reality, Micah's goal in building a shrine, filling it with idols, and hiring a Levite to serve as his priest is clear: "Now I know that the Lord will prosper me, because I have a Levite as priest" (Judg. 17:13). Micah set out to create a religious environment, all of it the work of human hands, in which he could control and manipulate God for his own benefit. The folly of idolatry is its impotence. By the end of this first conclusion Micah's shrine is empty and his priest gone. Where is the power or prosperity now? Could not the idols save themselves or protect Micah? One of the best descriptions of the impotence of idolatry is found in Psalm 115:5–8:

<span id="page-656-3"></span> They have mouths, but do not speak; eyes, but do not see. They have ears, but do not hear; noses, but do not smell. They have hands, but do not feel; feet, but do not walk; and they do not make a sound in their throat. Those who make them become like them; so do all who trust in them.

Idols may have the appearance of giving power and prosperity, but they are powerless. In fact, their result is just the opposite from that which is intended: rather than idols' promoting power and prosperity, they make their worshipers powerless and profane—just like they are. Every generation and culture has its own set of idols. Such idols may be related to technology, finances, relationships, possessions, achievement, fame, or any other work of human hands that cannot provide real or lasting security. There is only one place where true prosperity and lasting security may be found: at the foot of the throne of grace:

<span id="page-656-2"></span> You make known to me the *path of life*; in your presence there is *fullness of joy*; at your right hand are *pleasures forevermore*. (Ps. 16:11)

<span id="page-656-5"></span><span id="page-656-4"></span><span id="page-656-0"></span>But how do we get to this place? By yielding to and worshiping the one true image, Jesus: "He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation" (Col. 1:15). The first two commandments were intended to protect God's people by forbidding both the worship of other gods and also the making of any image representing the one true God (Ex. 20:3–6; Deut. 5:7–10). For the true image was coming, and the worship of false images blinds our minds, making us unable to see the beauty or glory of the one true image. That is why we need "the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God" (2 Cor. 4:4). By God's grace, the light of his glory has overcome the darkness of our idolatry.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-661-2"></span><span id="page-661-1"></span><span id="page-661-0"></span>This final conclusion to Judges is bracketed by a form of the summary statement, "In those days, when there was no king in Israel" (19:1; 21:25). This conclusion comprises three scenes or episodes corresponding to its three chapters (cf. Section Outline). The general theme of this conclusion is Israel's inheritance and, as such, corresponds with the first introduction to the book (1:1–2:5). In that introduction the author described how Israel was unable to occupy successfully the land of its inheritance because it had violated the terms of the covenant with the Lord (2:1–3). This introduction also highlighted the relative success of the tribe of Judah, which was then contrasted with the failure of the tribe of Benjamin. In this conclusion the tribe of Benjamin becomes the focus of the narrative. The relatively negative portrayal of the tribe of Benjamin in the first conclusion is intensified and more fully developed here. Once again, the contrast between the tribes of Benjamin (negative) and of Judah (positive) prepares us for the advent of the monarchy in Israel and the first two kings appointed to reign, Saul the Benjaminite (from Gibeah) and David the Judahite (from Bethlehem). Both Gibeah and Bethlehem serve as important locations in this narrative account (e.g., 19:1–2, 12–14, 16, 18).

<span id="page-662-10"></span><span id="page-662-6"></span><span id="page-662-2"></span>In this conclusion the theme of Israel's inheritance focuses not so much on the land as on the virtual extinction of a tribe from the midst of the tribes of Israel. This theme is nicely summarized in Israel's prayer after putting Benjamin to the ban: "O Lord, the God of Israel, why has this happened in Israel, that today there should be one tribe lacking in Israel?" (21:3). According to the terms of the covenant (Ex. 23:23–33; Deut. 7:1–5), Israel was to drive out completely the Canaanites and the people of the land so that Israel would not become corrupted by the Canaanites' worship of false gods or their abominable practices. Having failed to eliminate the Canaanites from the land, Israel becomes more and more like the nations among whom she lives until one tribe, Benjamin, reenacts the tragic events of Sodom and Gomorrah (cf. Genesis 19). This is the author's way of characterizing the fullness of Israel's corruption. Those who were once God's "treasured possession" (Ex. 19:5) have become "Not My People" (Hos. 1:9).

#### <span id="page-662-11"></span><span id="page-662-1"></span><span id="page-662-0"></span>*Section Outline*

III.B. The Crisis of Israel's Inheritance: Tribe (19:1–21:25)

- 1. The Benjaminites Have Become Sodomites (19:1–30)
- 2. Benjamin Put to the Ban (20:1–48)
- 3. Israel Finds Wives for the Remnant of Benjamin (21:1–25)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-662-7"></span><span id="page-662-4"></span>19:1a For a discussion of the opening summary statement cf. Overview of 17:1– 21:25 and comment on 17:6.

<span id="page-662-8"></span><span id="page-662-5"></span>19:1b The events described here recall similar events in Judges 17:7–8. There, following the first summary statement, an unnamed Levite from Bethlehem of Judah sojourned and came to the hill country of Ephraim. Now here, following the third summary statement, an unnamed Levite sojourns in the hill country of Ephraim and then travels to Bethlehem of Judah. The traveling adventures of both Levites trigger the events that follow in each of the accounts. This literary device is one of the ways in which the author connects the two conclusions. For additional literary connections between these two conclusions cf. Overview of 17:1–21:25.

<span id="page-662-9"></span><span id="page-662-3"></span>19:2–3 The Levite's trip to Bethlehem of Judah is occasioned by the need to retrieve his unfaithful wife, who had returned to her father's house. The Hebrew verb <span id="page-663-4"></span><span id="page-663-3"></span>translated "was unfaithful" is the same verb rendered "whored" in 2:17; 8:27; and 8:33. In each of these instances Israel "whored" after idols and false gods and so abandoned the Lord. As such, the actions of the unfaithful wife exemplify Israel's relationship with the Lord during this time. Additionally, the Levite's desire to go after his unfaithful wife and to "speak kindly to hear and bring her back" epitomizes the Lord's treatment of Israel in each of the six major judge narratives. This account does not record the way in which the Levite's wife was unfaithful to him. Perhaps she simply abandoned him, forsaking the marriage covenant by returning to her father's house. If so, this may serve as a possible OT background for Paul's instructions concerning marriage and abandonment in 1 Corinthians 7:15.

<span id="page-663-12"></span><span id="page-663-8"></span><span id="page-663-7"></span><span id="page-663-6"></span><span id="page-663-5"></span>19:4–10 At the end of Judges 19:3, the father-in-law of the Levite was happy to see his son-in-law. This joy was expressed by an extended period of hospitality. The initial stay lasted three days (v. 4) before being extended to a fourth day (vv. 5–7) and then a fifth day (vv. 8–9). The father-in-law presses for yet another day, but the Levite declines, and his party sets out late on the fifth day. With the late start on the fifth day, they make it as far as Jebus, the city that will become Jerusalem, before seeking to find lodging for the evening. This lengthy account of the father-in-law's hospitality serves two functions. First, it demonstrates that the father-in-law is truly delighted to see his son-in-law, especially with the prospect of the restoration of his daughter's marriage. Second, it slows down the narrative and creates suspense regarding the events that will soon follow. It is the calm before the storm.

<span id="page-663-9"></span>19:11–15 Because it is getting late, the Levite's young servant suggests that the traveling party stay in the nearby city of Jebus (Jerusalem) for the night. The Levite's response constitutes the key verse in this scene: "We will not turn aside into the city of foreigners, who do not belong to the people of Israel, but we will pass on to Gibeah" (v. 12). Rightly so, the Levite prefers to seek refuge among his own people, the "people of Israel." What we will discover, however, is that the Israelites in Gibeah are just as foreign as the inhabitants of Jebus—perhaps even more so.

<span id="page-663-11"></span><span id="page-663-10"></span><span id="page-663-2"></span><span id="page-663-1"></span><span id="page-663-0"></span>References to the city of Jerusalem also appear in the first introduction to Judges, the introduction that corresponds to this second conclusion by way of shared theme (inheritance). This is where Adoni-bezek died (1:7). More importantly, however, the city serves to highlight the contrast between the tribes of Judah and Benjamin. In 1:8 "the men of Judah fought against Jerusalem and captured it and struck it with the edge of the sword and set the city on fire." In 1:21, however, "the people of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem, so the Jebusites have lived with the people of Benjamin in Jerusalem to this day." The reference to the cohabitation of Jebusites and Benjaminites hints at the forthcoming corruption of this tribe, a state of corruption put on full display in this final conclusion. Additionally, when the people of Israel place the tribe of Benjamin under the ban, the Lord calls the tribe of Judah to "go up first" and lead in battle (20:18). This is yet another instance in Judges of the author's preparing us for the emergence of the monarchy in 1 Samuel, whereupon the contrast between Benjamin and Judah will reach its climax in the conflict between Saul and David.

<span id="page-664-5"></span>This particular scene comes to an end when the travelers arrive in Gibeah and sit down in the "open square of the city" (Judg. 19:15). This is the place where travelers in the ancient world would come to find lodging with one of the households in a city. It is telling, therefore, that not one Benjaminite from the city extends an offer of hospitality to the Levite and his traveling companions. This is yet another hint at the corruption of the inhabitants of the city, preparing us for the tragic events that soon follow.

<span id="page-664-6"></span><span id="page-664-4"></span>19:16–21 In the next scene an old man returning from a day of work in the field happens upon the Levite and his companions at the city square. This old man is not a native of the city but is a sojourner from the hill country of Ephraim, as is the Levite (v. 1). Perhaps because of this connection the old man extends a gracious offer of hospitality to the Levite, holding out peace, provisions, and shelter for the travelers. Having lived in the city as a sojourner, the old man is likely aware of the moral corruption of the men in that city. Thus he warns the Levite, "Only, do not spend the night in the square" (v. 20). Unfortunately, the protection of the household will not afford sufficient safety for the Levite's concubine.

<span id="page-664-8"></span><span id="page-664-7"></span><span id="page-664-3"></span>19:22–24 While the Levite's party is enjoying the hospitality of its host, the men of the city surround the house, beat on the door, and demand that the master of the house bring forth the Levite so that they can have intercourse with him. The Hebrew expression translated "worthless fellows" can also mean "wicked" or "goodfor-nothing" men. The term is used to describe someone who might lead another into idolatry (Deut. 13:13) or disregard the poor and needy (Deut. 15:9). The two sons of Eli are characterized in this way because "they did not know the Lord" (1 Sam. 2:12). Proverbs 16:27 is applicable to the events recorded here: "A worthless man plots evil, and his speech is like a scorching fire." The men of the city of Gibeah, worthless men, have indeed plotted evil in wanting to "know" the Levite, a euphemism used as a common expression for sexual intercourse. For example, in Genesis 4:1 it is recorded, "Now Adam *knew* Eve his wife, and she conceived and bore Cain" (cf. Gen. 19:5; Num. 31:17; 1 Kings 1:4).

<span id="page-664-9"></span><span id="page-664-2"></span><span id="page-664-1"></span><span id="page-664-0"></span>The wickedness of this account cannot be overstated. The men of Benjamin have become sodomites! In fact, this account shares several features in common with the account of Sodom in Genesis 19:66

- (1) Travelers arrive at a town in the evening.
- (2) A host urges the guests not to spend the night in the town square.
- (3) The host is a sojourner, not a native of the city.
- (4) All of the men in the city surround the house.
- (5) The men of the city make the same demand of the host. The parallels are striking.

<sup>66</sup> For a similar list of comparisons cf. Block, *Judges, Ruth*, 520.

- <span id="page-665-1"></span>(a) Genesis 19:5: "Bring them out to us, that we may know them."
- <span id="page-665-6"></span>(b) Judges 19:22: "Bring out the man who came into your house, that we may know him."
- (6) The host goes out to the men of the city and leaves the visitors in the house.
- <span id="page-665-2"></span>(7) The host pleads with the men of the city not to do this wicked thing. Again, the verbal parallels are striking.
	- (a) Genesis 19:7: "I beg you, my brothers, do not act so wickedly."
	- (b) Judges 19:23: "No, my brothers, do not act so wickedly."
- <span id="page-665-7"></span><span id="page-665-3"></span>(8) The host offers two women as a substitute for the men.
	- (a) Genesis 19:8: "Do to them as you please."
	- (b) Judges 19:24: "Do with them what seems good to you."
- <span id="page-665-8"></span>(9) The men of the city do not want the women as a substitute.
- (10) All the inhabitants of the city are eventually destroyed, and the city is burned with fire.

<span id="page-665-4"></span><span id="page-665-0"></span>The parallels are so numerous and overt that we are forced to read Judges 19 in light of Genesis 19. In this way, the author of the account vividly portrays the corruption of Israel as that which deserves divine, eschatological judgment. The Gibeahites are no better than the inhabitants of Sodom and Gomorrah.

<span id="page-665-9"></span>19:25–26 In Genesis 19 the angels saved Lot and his family by striking the men of Sodom with blindness so that they were unable to commit their proposed acts of wickedness. Tragically, that does not occur here with the men of Gibeah. Rather, the host seizes the Levite's concubine and sends her out to the men of the city, who "knew her and abused her all night." This unspeakable cruelty impugns not only the men of Gibeah but also the man for handing over this woman to be sexually abused all night, even to the point of death. We do not know what happens to the host's virgin daughter; she is not mentioned again. It is likely, however, that this household is destroyed when the other tribes of Israel put this city to the ban.

<span id="page-665-10"></span><span id="page-665-5"></span>19:27–28 The next morning the Levite discovers his concubine at the threshold to the door of the house. She does not respond to him, and he finds that she is apparently dead. The author of the account does not provide us with the emotional response of the Levite or his interaction with the host in light of this tragic event. Some may think the account to be cold and emotionless, or that the Levite does not love the woman or care for her well-being. But nothing could be further from the truth when we recall how all of this started: she was unfaithful to him, but he went after her to "speak kindly with her and bring her back" (Judg. 19:3). He brought her a donkey on which to return home and provisions for the trip. The author does not provide us with the emotional response of the Levite, but does not mean he has none. He does. In fact, the events that follow are precipitated by the Levite's loss and his call for justice, that the life of his concubine be avenged.

<span id="page-666-9"></span><span id="page-666-4"></span>19:29–30 In response to the horrific events at Gibeah, the Levite summons all of Israel to avenge the life of his concubine. The men of Gibeah have shed innocent blood; as a steward of the Torah, the Levite would know the guilt and corruption of shedding innocent blood: "So you shall purge the guilt of innocent blood from your midst, when you do what is right in the sight of the Lord" (Deut. 21:9). The Levite's call to arms is just as shocking as the events surrounding the death of his concubine. It is intended to typify the nature of the crime and the necessity of justice. The "twelve pieces" of the concubine represent the twelve tribes of Israel and indicate that the Levite is calling the whole nation to bear witness against the Gibeahites. The severity of the sin is summarized by the response of all who see the severed limbs of the concubine. Nothing like this has ever happened before in Israel.

<span id="page-666-11"></span><span id="page-666-5"></span><span id="page-666-0"></span>20:1–2 In response to the Levite's shocking call to arms, all the people of Israel respond by assembling at Mizpah. Laban named this site Mizpah when he and Jacob made a covenant and parted ways (Gen. 31:49); this is also the site where Israel assembled against the Ammonites under the leadership of Jephthah (Judg. 10:17). The references to Dan, Beersheba, and Gilead describe the extent of the summons: the people come from as far as Dan in the north, from Beersheba in the south, and even from the land of Gilead, east of the Jordan. At Mizpah the Levite musters a standing army of four hundred thousand men in order to avenge the death of his concubine. The author describes this group as "the assembly of the people of God," a designation found nowhere else in the OT.

<span id="page-666-16"></span><span id="page-666-15"></span><span id="page-666-14"></span><span id="page-666-13"></span><span id="page-666-12"></span><span id="page-666-10"></span><span id="page-666-8"></span><span id="page-666-7"></span><span id="page-666-6"></span><span id="page-666-3"></span><span id="page-666-2"></span><span id="page-666-1"></span>20:3–7 The Levite recounts the events of chapter 19 to the assembly of the people of God. Before he speaks, however, the author establishes the nature of the offense as "murder" (v. 4), the same word used in the Decalogue: "You shall not *murder*" (Ex. 20:13; Deut. 5:17). This is a clear violation of the moral law, also characterized as "evil" (Judg. 20:3), a designation common in Judges for the activity of Israel as those who do "that which is evil in the eyes of the Lord." In the Levite's speech he describes the actions of the men of Gibeah as an "abomination" and an "outrage" (v. 6). The Hebrew rendered "abomination" is frequently associated with egregious sexual sin (Lev. 18:17; 19:29; 20:14; Jer. 13:27; Ezek. 23:44), which would certainly apply here. The word rendered "outrage" was first used by the Levite's host when he pleaded with the men of Gibeah, "Do not do this *vile thing*" (Judg. 19:23), and again, "Do not do this *outrageous thing*" (19:24). This word is also associated frequently with sinful acts that are sexual in nature (Gen. 34:7; Deut. 22:21; 2 Sam. 13:12; Jer. 29:23). One lexicon suggests that this word conveys the idea of "willful sin, sacrilege."67 Indeed, the author's combination of words in these few verses condemns the sin of the men of Gibeah in the strongest possible terms. The Levite concludes his speech with a call to action similar to the one at the end of the previous chapter (Judg. 19:30).

<span id="page-667-7"></span>20:8–11 In response to the Levite's speech, the assembly of the people of God is united "as one man" and commits to avenge the murder of the Levites's concubine. A twofold plan is prepared. First, the people will go up against Gibeah "by lot," meaning at the direction of the Lord. Second, 10 percent of the assembly is appointed to carry the provisions for those who will fight. It will not be a quick battle. It will take some time, and so the assembly prepares to deal with this outrage and abomination. Although the fact is often overlooked, it is worth noting that four hundred thousand warriors in Israel have assembled to avenge the murder of an unfaithful, unnamed concubine. At a time in which many may not have valued the life of a woman as they should have, this display of outrage by the people of Israel over the death of a single woman is almost touching. It reminds us that everyone, both men and women, are created in the image of God (Gen. 1:27) and that the shedding of innocent blood is an offense against that very image (Gen. 9:5–6).

<span id="page-667-10"></span><span id="page-667-9"></span><span id="page-667-6"></span><span id="page-667-1"></span><span id="page-667-0"></span>20:12–17 Rather than giving the Gibeahites over to Israel to be put to death, the tribe of Benjamin assembles for war and joins itself to the wicked men of Gibeah. The focus here is on the numbers. The tribe of Benjamin has assembled twenty-six thousand warriors in addition to the seven hundred chosen men of Gibeah. These warriors are noted for their skill with the sling and their left-handedness (Judg. 20:16). The book's second major judge, Ehud, was also a left-handed man from the tribe of Benjamin (3:15). The expression "left-handed" can be literally rendered "bound in the right hand." As such it is likely that these men were trained to fight with their left hand, a special skill in battle. The LXX translates this expression as "ambidextrous," meaning they could fight with either hand. Even with such skills, however, the tribe of Benjamin is badly outnumbered by the four hundred thousand warriors assembled from the other tribes of Israel. There are, on average, just over fifteen warriors from Israel for every one warrior from Benjamin.

<span id="page-667-11"></span><span id="page-667-8"></span><span id="page-667-3"></span><span id="page-667-2"></span>20:18 The camp of Israel moves out from Mizpah to Bethel in order to engage Benjamin at Gibeah. In verse 9 it was stated that Israel would go up against Gibeah by lot. Although the text is not explicit, it appears that the method by which Israel inquires of the Lord is the casting of lots (cf. Lev. 16:8; Josh. 18:6, 8, 10; 1 Sam. 14:42). The answer is clear: "The Lord said, 'Judah shall go up first.'" The Lord's choosing of Judah to go first against Benjamin continues the pro-Judah/ anti-Benjamin theme running through the book. The theme began in Judges 1 when Judah was chosen to go up first against the Canaanites (1:1–2). The point of connection is clear: the tribe of Benjamin has become a Canaanite tribe and must now be put to the ban, just as the Canaanites themselves were.

<span id="page-667-14"></span><span id="page-667-13"></span><span id="page-667-12"></span><span id="page-667-5"></span><span id="page-667-4"></span>20:19–23 The battle against Benjamin occurs over a period of three days. On day one (vv. 19–23) Israel suffers a great loss. On day two (vv. 24–28) Israel again suffers a great loss. Then, finally, on day three (vv. 29–36a) Benjamin is defeated. The Lord sanctioned Israel's war against the tribe of Benjamin (v. 18), and it is the Lord who <span id="page-668-2"></span>will ultimately strike down that tribe (v. 35). Verses 18, 35 constitute the theological lens through which to view the events recounted in between. The structure of the first two days is as follows: (1) the men of Israel engage Benjamin in battle, (2) Israel suffers great loss, (3) Israel weeps before the Lord, (4) Israel inquires of the Lord, and (5) the Lord sanctions the battle on the next day.

<span id="page-668-4"></span>On the first day of battle Benjamin strikes down 22,000 Israelites (v. 21). This is a staggering number, given that the army of Benjamin comprises only 25,700 warriors. The author does not explain how or why Israel experiences such a great loss on the first day. The focus is on the number itself. The humiliation and murder of the Levite's concubine was not a single sin with a single consequence. It has also provoked the rebellion of Benjamin, a whole tribe, and now the death of thousands of Israelites at the hands of their brothers. In spite of such a great loss, the men of Israel "took courage" (v. 22), and the Lord commands them to return to battle on the next day: "And the Lord said, 'Go up against them'" (v. 23).

<span id="page-668-7"></span><span id="page-668-6"></span><span id="page-668-5"></span><span id="page-668-3"></span>20:24–28 The events of the second day follow the pattern of the first (cf. comment on 20:19–23). There are, however, several interesting differences in the details. First, Israel suffers the loss of eighteen thousand men on day two. This brings the total number of Israelites killed in battle to forty thousand, another staggering number. After suffering this loss, the remaining Israelites return again to Bethel, where they weep before the Lord. This time, however, they also fast and offer sacrifices. Additionally, it is noted that both Phinehas and the ark of the covenant are in Bethel at this time. This is yet another hint as to the manner in which Israel inquires of the Lord. Previously, it was noted that Israel cast lots in order to determine how to proceed in battle (v. 9). Now we understand the importance of Bethel: it is the location of the ark and of the high priest who inquires of the Lord on behalf of Israel. Finally, the Lord again sanctions the battle on day three but this time promises victory for Israel after two tragic days of loss: "Go up, for tomorrow I will give them into your hand" (v. 28).

<span id="page-668-11"></span><span id="page-668-10"></span><span id="page-668-9"></span><span id="page-668-8"></span><span id="page-668-1"></span><span id="page-668-0"></span>20:29–36a The account of the battle on the third day does not follow the pattern of the first two days'. One major difference is the attention given to the ambush Israel sets against Benjamin. The account begins, "So Israel set men in ambush around Gibeah" (v. 29). Israel engages Benjamin in battle as before, but this time it feigns defeat after suffering the loss of approximately thirty men. By withdrawing from the battle line, the Israelites lead the Benjaminites away from Gibeah to be ambushed by ten thousand chosen men of Israel. The account of this ambush is merely summarized in verses 29–36a; it is retold in greater detail in verses 36b–46. The accounting and recounting of a single event is a feature common to Hebrew narrative. The first account is usually brief and summarizes one or two important features related to the event. The second account rehearses the same event but in greater detail, with focus on a particular aspect of the event. For example, the account of day six of creation (Gen. 1:24–31) provides the initial summary of some of the more important events of that day. Then the author returns to rehearses the

<span id="page-669-1"></span><span id="page-669-0"></span>events of day six in greater detail, with an emphasis on the creation of the man and the woman and the origin of the marriage covenant (Gen. 2:4–25). In a similar fashion the account of Benjamin's defeat is summarized in Judges 20:29–36a but then retold in verses 36b–46 with greater attention to the ambush, pursuit, and defeat of the army of Benjamin.

<span id="page-669-5"></span><span id="page-669-2"></span>Another major difference on the third day is the fact that Israel defeats Benjamin with the loss of 25,100 Benjaminites—all but six hundred of their warriors. These six hundred will escape to the rock of Rimmon (v. 47); their fate is described in the upcoming and final chapter of Judges. Most commentators have identified a minor discrepancy in the number of slain Benjaminites listed in verses 35 and 46. Verse 35 states that 25,100 Benjaminites died on that day, whereas verse 46 states that only twenty-five thousand Benjaminites died, a difference of one hundred men. A variety of possible solutions to this apparent discrepancy have been offered. Some understand the first number to be the exact count and the second number a generalized summary statement. However, this seems unlikely, given the author's care and precision with other numbers in this account. Another possible solution suggests that the missing one hundred men of Benjamin would have died on the first two days of battle. This solution makes good sense and preserves the integrity of the text, though it is surprising that more Benjaminites did not perish on the first two days, given the losses suffered by Israel.68

Finally, it is important to consider the juxtaposition of the facts that "the people of Israel destroyed 25,100 men of Benjamin that day" and that "the Lord defeated Benjamin before Israel" (v. 35). The loss of over sixty-five thousand lives is certainly tragic. But it is also under the sovereign, providential supervision of the Lord as he administers his covenantal kingdom. The deaths put on full display the corruption and destruction caused by sin. They also demonstrate the extent to which the Lord is willing to go in order to remove sin and sinful activity from the midst of his people.

<span id="page-669-3"></span>20:36b–40 The narrative now pauses to rehearse the ambush of day three in greater detail. In this first scene the author recounts how the men of Israel led the men of Benjamin away from Gibeah so that the ambush could take the city. The men of Israel feigned defeat and began to retreat. The men of Benjamin thought they were about to have another day of victory over their brothers. This time, however, the ambush snuck into the city behind the pursuing Benjaminites and put Gibeah to the sword, killing all of its inhabitants and setting the city on fire. The smoke from the fire signaled to the men of Israel that the city had been taken and that there was no refuge or retreat for the army of Benjamin.

<span id="page-669-4"></span>20:41–46 This next scene describes the defeat of the army of Benjamin in three stages. Once the men of Israel saw the smoke of the city, they turned to engage the men of Benjamin, moving from defense to offense. After cutting off Benjamin's return to Gibeah, Israel struck down eighteen thousand men east of Gibeah. Then

<sup>68</sup> Cf. Webb, *Book of Judges*, 493–494; Chisholm, *Commentary on Judges and Ruth*, 503–504.

Israel pursued Benjamin to the rock of Rimmon (Hb. for "pomegranate"), where an additional five thousand were killed. Finally, Israel pursued Benjamin to Gidom, where they struck down the last two thousand men, bringing the total number killed of the army of Benjamin to twenty-five thousand.69

<span id="page-670-3"></span>In verse 43 it is recorded that Israel surrounded the Benjaminites and then pursued them as they defeated them in battle. The ESV represents an excellent translation of this verse as it stands. However, it is difficult to imagine how Benjamin could have fled if it was surrounded by the army of Israel. One possible solution comes from the LXX, which translates the Hebrew verb meaning "to surround" as "to cut off." In other words, Benjamin was cut off by the ambush in Gibeah and so could not return to the city in order to take refuge. As such, the warriors were forced to flee into the open. The LXX rendering could be supposed via minor variation to the Hebrew text. The verb translated "to surround" is *ktr*; switching the second and third letters yields *krt* ("to cut off"). The Hebrew verb *ktt* ("to crush to pieces") has also been suggested as a possible reading.70

<span id="page-670-4"></span>20:47 These six hundred men now constitute the remnant of the army of Benjamin and soon the remnant of the entire tribe of Benjamin. After hiding in caves at the rock of Rimmon for four months, they will emerge as subjects of the final chapter of the book.

<span id="page-670-5"></span><span id="page-670-0"></span>20:48 The horror of the events recorded in this verse cannot be overstated. After defeating the army of Benjamin, the Israelites return to destroy the cities, people, and livestock of the entire tribe of Benjamin. Because Benjamin has become Canaanite in its actions, it is put to the ban as all the other Canaanites in the land were. This means the total destruction of every living thing: remaining men, women, children, and livestock, along with the complete destruction of Benjamin's cities. The regulations of the ban are stipulated in Deuteronomy 7:1–10, which includes no allowance for mercy. Under the terms of the Mosaic covenant and in the context of the (temporary and typological) Land of Promise, the Lord "repays to their face those who hate him, by destroying them. He will not be slack with one who hates him. He will repay him to his face" (Deut. 7:10). This is a stark and startling reminder of the nature of the final, eschatological judgement to come. It should provoke us to examine our hearts and then to rejoice in the gospel of Jesus Christ, who suffered the curse of the ban on our behalf so that those who once hated the Lord could be made to love him by the power of his Spirit.

<span id="page-670-6"></span><span id="page-670-2"></span><span id="page-670-1"></span>21:1 At the Levite's call to arms, all of the people of Israel had come out and assembled at Mizpah, where the Levite had explained what had taken place in Gibeah of Benjamin (Judg. 20:1–3). We now learn that the people of Israel had made two vows before the Lord concerning their battle with Benjamin. First, no Israelite

<sup>69</sup> For discussion of this number versus the 25,100 men mentioned in Judges 20:35 cf. comment on 20:29–36a.

<sup>70</sup> *HALOT*, 2:506–507; Block, *Judges, Ruth*, 566n358.

<span id="page-671-9"></span><span id="page-671-5"></span>would give his daughter to any surviving Benjaminite in marriage (21:1, 7). Second, the people of Israel would put to death anyone who did not arise and fight to avenge the death of the Levite's concubine (v. 5). This created both a problem and an opportunity. The six hundred surviving Benjaminites would not be able to take wives from Israel, and the tribe would eventually perish upon the death of these survivors; however, wives could be acquired from those who did not come out to Mizpah for the assembly. It is grievous that Israel's insistence that Benjamin not marry women from other tribes comes in the context of Israel's own inability to obey the Lord's command not to take Canaanite wives (3:5–6). Everyone was truly doing what was right in his own eyes.

<span id="page-671-7"></span><span id="page-671-6"></span><span id="page-671-4"></span><span id="page-671-2"></span>21:2–4 The people of Israel return to Bethel and weep before the Lord. This recalls Israel's response to having suffered great losses on the first two days of battle (20:23, 26). This time, however, the weeping intensifies as they weep "bitterly" (or "a great weeping"). Judges 21:3 provides the reason for the weeping: the people are now concerned that one of their own tribes will be cut off from Israel. The emphasis on tribal solidarity is highlighted by the three references to "Israel" in this verse, including in the title of Yahweh as the "God of Israel." It is surprising that the people of Israel had not considered this possibility before the battle, given that the Lord had sanctioned the extermination of Benjamin on three different occasions (20:18, 23, 28). Nevertheless, in response the people build an altar and offer offerings on the next day (21:4). This certainly seems like an appropriate response, but in fact it is little more than a baptizing of their own plans in a certain amount of external religion in order to justify their upcoming actions.

<span id="page-671-11"></span><span id="page-671-10"></span><span id="page-671-8"></span><span id="page-671-3"></span>21:5–7 In verse 7 the people of Israel address the dilemma of wives for the tribe of Benjamin. Verse 6 provides the reason: "Israel had compassion for Benjamin their brother." Verse 5 hints at the solution to their dilemma with its reference to a second oath taken at Mizpah. This was not just any oath but a "great oath" by which they would put to death anyone who had not attended that assembly. It appears the Israelites have identified a loophole that will allow them to provide wives for the surviving Benjaminites without violating their vow. This workaround provides the background and context for the upcoming events.

<span id="page-671-12"></span><span id="page-671-1"></span><span id="page-671-0"></span>The reference to Israel's compassion for Benjamin appears both here in verse 6 and in verse 15. This compassion is eventually expressed in the slaughter of Jabesh-gilead and the stealing of women as wives for Benjamin. In the regulations concerning the ban (holy war), the people put under the ban are to be completely destroyed, with no survivors: every man, woman, child, and animal (Deut. 7:1–11). Additionally, the regulations stipulate, "You shall make no covenant with them and show no mercy to them" (Deut. 7:2). Thus the sparing of the remnant of Benjamin and the provision of wives is a clear violation of the stipulated sanctions. It appears that Israel's compassion is misplaced; the people should have finished the job they started by putting to death the survivors taking refuge at the rock of Rimmon. The tribe of Benjamin will later become a snare for Israel in the establishment of

<span id="page-672-7"></span>the monarchy and the selection of its first king, a king like all the other nations' (1 Sam. 8:5, 20).

<span id="page-672-2"></span>21:8–12 The Israelites devise a plan to solve the problem created by one oath by enacting the curse of the second, involving the complete destruction of those who had not come up to the assembly at Mizpah. When the people are mustered, or counted, it is discovered that the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead had not come up to the assembly. Israel thus plans to put these people to the ban but to keep alive any young virgins who could be given as wives to the remnant of Benjamin. In other words, they plan to solve the problem created by putting Benjamin to the ban by putting the people of Jabesh-gilead to the ban. In each instance, however, the ban is not complete, and violation is heaped upon violation in a land in which everybody is doing what is right in his own eyes. In the end, they are able to collect four hundred young virgins from Jabesh-gilead for the six hundred survivors of Benjamin. The deficit of two hundred wives provides the background and context for the events that follow.

<span id="page-672-4"></span><span id="page-672-3"></span><span id="page-672-1"></span><span id="page-672-0"></span>21:13–15 The Israelites return to the rock of Rimmon and proclaim peace or reconciliation (Hb. *shalom*) to the six hundred survivors of Benjamin. This proclamation is attended with the presentation of four hundred virgins from Jabesh-gilead as wives for the survivors. But the obvious is stated: "They were not enough for them" (Judges 21:14). This statement provides the background and context for the upcoming and final scene of the book and also serves as the final link in the chain of events spanning chapters 19–21. The reason for Israel's offer of peace and change of heart is explicitly stated in 21:15, which is a restatement of verse 6: "The people had compassion on Benjamin because the Lord had made a breach in the tribes of Israel" (v. 15). Once again the author makes clear that it was the Lord himself who had sanctioned the complete destruction of Benjamin, just as he had with the Canaanites, who were also to be completely removed from the land because of their abominable practices. One of the major points of this final conclusion to Judges is that Israel's progressive corruption and sin will eventually result in her own destruction and exile. The destruction of Benjamin serves as both a warning and a harbinger of things to come in the economy of the kingdom of God.

<span id="page-672-5"></span>21:16–18 The elders of the congregation scheme to make up the difference between the six hundred survivors and four hundred virgins so that "a tribe [will] not be blotted out from Israel." There is, however, the dilemma created by the oath taken in Mizpah. Israel cannot *willingly* provide wives for Benjamin without coming under the curse of the oath. Another loophole in the oath must be found in order to provide wives without coming under the curse.

<span id="page-672-6"></span>21:19–22 The plan is one of ambush and abduction. This is the second ambush in this final conclusion to Judges. In the first instance the army of Israel set an ambush to take Gibeah. In this second instance the survivors of Benjamin set an ambush to take wives from Shiloh. The plan is simple. At the feast of the Lord in Shiloh,

<span id="page-673-9"></span><span id="page-673-6"></span>the men of Benjamin will lie in wait for those virgins who come out of the city dancing in the procession. They will then abduct the girls and abscond to the land of Benjamin. When the families of the stolen girls come out to protest, the elders of the Israelite congregation will convince the families to yield to the offense so that they will not become guilty of breaking the oath and falling under its curse. The loophole is in the fact that the families of Shiloh will not *willingly* give their daughters in marriage to Benjamin. The Hebrew verb rendered "snatch" (v. 21) appears only here and then twice at Psalm 10:9, again in the context of a deceitful ambush and the activity of the wicked: the evil man "lurks that he may *seize* the poor; he *seizes* the poor when he draws him into his net." These young women are abducted by the wicked in a time in which everyone is doing what is right in his own eyes. The rape and death of the Levite's concubine led to the decimation of the tribe of Benjamin and the death of tens of thousands of Israelites. These events then led to the extermination of the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead and the abduction of four hundred virgin daughters, which then required the ambush and abduction of two hundred virgins from Shiloh—sin upon sin, tragedy following tragedy.

<span id="page-673-7"></span><span id="page-673-5"></span>21:23–24 The enactment of the plan is not described but is merely stated in what the author must intend to be the ominous silence of condemnation. It is simply recorded that the people of Benjamin "did so" and then "returned to their inheritance and rebuilt the towns" Israel had destroyed in its war against Benjamin. The events of chapters 19–21 have come to their end, and the author notes that Israel disbands and returns home, "every man to his inheritance." This echoes the conclusion to Joshua: "So Joshua sent the people away, *every man to his inheritance*" (Josh. 24:28; cf. Judg. 2:6). But the assessment of Joshua's day is not what we find in Judges. At that time, "Israel served the Lord all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua and had known all the work that the Lord did for Israel" (Josh. 24:31). But in Judges Israel has served the gods of the land, forgetting the Lord and forsaking the covenant (Judg. 2:1–2, 11–20). It is the time in which everyone has done what is right in his own eyes.

<span id="page-673-8"></span><span id="page-673-3"></span><span id="page-673-2"></span><span id="page-673-1"></span>21:25 The book concludes with the fourth and final summary statement that shapes and controls the content and interpretation of the two conclusions to the book. For a discussion of the placement and significance of this statement cf. Overview of 17:1–21:25 and comment on 17:6.

#### <span id="page-673-4"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-673-0"></span>The first conclusion to Judges focused on Israel's idolatry. This second conclusion focuses on the *impact* of Israel's idolatry. Idolatry does not consist simply of worshiping other gods; it also takes the form of living like those people who worship other gods. Israel was warned of this danger when Moses declared, "You shall not worship the Lord your God in that way, for every abominable thing that the Lord hates they have done for their gods, for they even burn their sons and their daughters in the fire to their gods" (Deut. 12:31). Judges records the progressive corruption of Israel through idolatry from the time of Joshua to the advent of the monarchy in 1 Samuel. In these final chapters the corrupting power of idolatry is exemplified by the complete corruption of Benjamin. The Benjaminites have become sodomites, resulting in the horrific rape and murder of the Levite's wife in Gibeah of Benjamin. From this event flows all of the other events of this section.

<span id="page-674-0"></span>The sins of Sodom in Genesis 19 provoked God's judgment, the complete destruction of the city and its inhabitants as a type or intrusion of the eschatological judgment to come. In a similar manner God sanctions the complete destruction of Benjamin by Israel, putting them to the same ban as any other Canaanite tribe in the land of Israel's inheritance. However, just as Israel was unable fully to drive out the Canaanites, so are they unable to destroy completely the tribe of Benjamin. With their misplaced compassion, the Israelites spare the six hundred survivors of Benjamin and provide them with wives by slaughtering the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead and recommending the stealing of virgins from Shiloh. It is difficult to imagine living in this place at this time. These events would be horrifying to witness in a time of anarchy and terrifying violence. As with the remaining Canaanites, the preservation of the tribe of Benjamin will become a snare to the people of Israel in the establishment of the monarchy. Israel will reject the Lord as her King and ask for a king like all the other nations. The Lord will give them exactly what they ask for, a king from the tribe of Benjamin, a Canaanite tribe like all the other nations. Even Saul's name plays a role in this situation. It means "what was asked for." The people ask for a king like all the other nations, and God gives "what was asked for." This is one reason to be thankful that the Lord does not give us everything we ask. It is an act of love and mercy on his behalf not to do so.

<span id="page-674-3"></span><span id="page-674-2"></span><span id="page-674-1"></span>The corrupting power of idolatry is that it makes us become what we worship, in terms both of behavior and of judgment (Ps. 115:8). The Lord created us to be like this, to reflect what we worship. God created humanity to worship, and we cannot help but do it. The conclusions to Judges warn us about the corrupting power of misdirected or misguided worship. It blinds us from seeing the glory of the one true God (2 Cor. 4:4). But we have great hope because of the gospel. Those who have been ransomed from the darkness of idolatry are now being transformed into the image and likeness of Jesus, becoming more and more like him through worship. Even now "we all, with unveiled face, beholding the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image from one degree of glory to another. For this comes from the Lord who is the Spirit" (2 Cor. 3:18).
